If I am ever in the market to purchase more of these copper mugs or anything coated in beautiful coppers I will surely be back here to purchase more stuff! I highly recommend anyone to purchase this item.

I needed some sort of keyboard for my Ipad device since I get annoyed stabbing my screen to take any notes for my class lectures and I found this wireless keyboard suitable for any Apple device. I simply love this! Now I can take notes and type 100% faster now with this amazing device and I'm so proud that I purchased it!

This is truly a beautiful wine bag and I so glad that I decided to purchase it! I was thinking about sending a gift bottle of wine to my grandmother since she is a die hard wine taster and I wanted to add more to the gift then a simple bottle. So I discovered these wine bags and had to buy one to make my little gift stand out and I was excited that she loved the wine I sent and of course the wine bag with it! I will be purchasing this again for my future gifts!

I purchased this beautifully designed Bangle Bracelet for my niece since she is at the age where she has to have shiny jewelry to show off to her friends so I thought it would be nice to give her something that was in the high quality. She absolutely loves it! I never seen her face so bright when I gave her this! I would definitely tell my friends and family to purchase this for anyone special in there lives,truly beautiful designed bracelets.

As a business man that travels alot I need something that can charge my devices with the require watt power it needs so nothing happens on my tablet devices and I am glad to have found the Alibro Travel Plug Adapter! It simply amazing! To get the required amount of watts to power your device all you need to do is turn the switch on the device and enjoy safely charging your tablets,phones in other countries! I will be recommending this product top many of my friends and business associates,this is a must have item!

I've had joint pain in my knees and a more nagging pain in my legs for as long as I can remember. It has never made me completely immobile, but I've always had a little extra trouble doing simple tasks. Even standing for too long trying to the dishes would wear my legs out. It had also become difficult for me to stand up from a sitting position. I talked to my doctor about using a tennis ball for relief, and then I stumbled upon this gem in my search. Since using the Tennis Ball Self Massage system I have been able to move and walk and even jump with little or no ill effects to speak of. I feel as if it has revitalized the way I move and I've even been going on walks. Before reading this book, I could only walk around the block before the pain in my legs forced me to sit down. Just last week, I walked a full two miles with no joint or muscle pain!I've also rooted around Amazon for some other hidden gems, and I came up with Simple Natural Cures: Cheap & Effective Remedies for Everyday Common Ailments. It's a short, easy read and acts as my go-to guide for treating and curing several familiar illnesses or ailments. Headaches, insomnia, anxiety, and even eczema are on the list of conditions that the book goes over. It offers plenty of unique (and totally natural) treatments for all of these issues, and I have to say that I never knew how easy it was to treat basic problems. I wish I had learned about the Tennis Ball Self Massage and Simple Natural Cures a long time ago because they have helped me immensely.Before I get too far ahead of myself, the relative brevity and ease-of-reading provided by the Tennis Ball Self Massage book is outstanding. It's not a difficult concept to grasp and the author doesn't go on and on about useless details. They get right to the point and they cover all kinds of muscle and joint ailments and how to properly use the tennis ball to treat them. Anyway, if it hadn't been for these two books I'd probably be hobbling around and complaining of head pain, but not anymore!

If this necklace is an example of slightly blemished, I don't want to see heavily blemished.I will start with the tag.  It says "Made in China".  That strikes me as an odd place to get Tahitian pearls from.  Then the opposite side of the tag says "D".  That is the lowest rating for the worst pearls that are still marketable.  Any more blemished and the pearls are destroyed.I have added some pictures of the types of blemishes I found; and every single pearl in the string was similarly marked.  The first two are different views of a round pit in the nacre that went right down to the seed.  That small white circle in the pearl I am holding is not a reflection.  It is the white seed core the pearl is grown around.  The third and fourth are of other blemishes on other pearls, all of them quite deep.Obviously, it isn't practical to show more than a few examples and the luster of the pearls makes it hard to see still photographs of some of the dents and creases because of the reflective surface.  These are not slight blemishes that were concealed by creative drilling and knotting.  The pit that exposed the underlying seed should have been erased by a drill hole if that were the case. Instead, it was dead center on the middle of the pearl.  I can't see paying upwards of $800. for such heavily blemished pearls.On the plus side, the colors were very well matched and the sizing was quite nice.  None of the pearls on this string were oddly shaped like in the pictures that go with the official description.  They were all almost perfectly round and nicely graduated in size.The presentation box for the pearls was extremely well packaged in a tough, well-fitting outer box; but there was nothing inside to pad the pearls from being jostled during shipment.  I provided some bubble wrap for the trip back because I simply had to return them after seeing what a low grade they were.Interestingly enough, the description of the item says the pearls are "slightly blemished".  I am pretty much a pearl lover and have several other strings, none of which show blemishes as large or obvious as the ones here.  It's possible I got a bad string; but I have to call it based on what I received.  The pictures give an indication of that.  I probably should have tried to get a motion camera for a video.  That would have displayed the pearl surfaces better, but I do not have the equipment for stabilizing the camera while I handle the pearls.  Sorry.

Definitely not for older people.  There is a point early in the game where one must follow one of 7 identical cards as they shuffle and spin around one another.  While something like this was no problem for me when in my 20's, as a 60+ person the task is pretty much impossible.  However, without being able to do it, you can't proceed in the game.  So for anyone who is losing the visual acuity needed to follow extremely fast motion, the game is unplayable.  And trying to obtain a password for the "victim's" computer from a walkthrough doesn't work.Sorry; but I had to delete this after 5 minutes into the game.

Simpson masterfully tells a nail-biting, fast paced story that moves relentlessly from one player to another in a way that makes it hard to put the book down. This set consists of the first 4 books in the series so far and had me relentlessly turning page after page to see what would happen next. It starts with a war and a death, and then somehow undoes everything, and redoes it again.  He turns his universe topsy turvy and deals quite a few surprises, both happy and sad, as we learn more about the players we have already met and the ripples that have spread out to all corners of existence.

This is a very nice ring with a true color peridot mounted.However, there is a caveat.  Peridot is a relatively soft stone, 6.5 approximately on the hardness scale.  That is about equal to opal and the stone can be easily scratched if one is not careful.  Be very careful about the circumstances for wearing the ring and never, ever turn it backwards on your finger to hide the stone from potential thieves.  It just might be enough to damage the stone.Despite all that, I love the ring.

It took a little work to get this plugged into both my phone and recorder so that no base hum was apparent.  I had to set my digital PCM recorder to 120 Hertz low filter; but I got a clean recording from a voice mail on my phone.I had tried it earlier on my smart phone's recorder, but nothing transferred.  The single contact plug on the adapter probably interfered with the 3 contact input the phone was looking for.It lost one star for the need to filter out low band noise.

This flour keep seals really well and easily holds a 5 pound bag of flour.  It can either be left in the bag, or poured into the keeper.  The second choice is better as it makes the task of scooping and leveling a measuring cup very easy.  I have kept flour in it for severl months now with no discernable change in flavor or texture.

This is another great Timex watch.  It is a color that matches most of my work suits.  The purple bezel is not very intrusive and the grey strap is a nice neutral color.  The overall shape of the watch is lightweight and stylish.  It keeps very accurate time, too.The only down side is that the strap is not removable.  When it breaks, the entire watch must be discarded.  And it tends to break even before the battery runs down.  If there was a way to replace the strap, this watch would be unbeatable.

This is an inexpensive, extremely warm jacket.  It kept me toasty at 8 degrees.  The outer fabric is tough, but I am not as sure about the lining.  However, at this price, the lining can be easily patched, if necessary.  When I finally got a 31 degree day, this jacket kept me too warm.

Anker is rapidly becoming my goto brand for charging devices and cables.  These cables are long and well constructed.  What's best is that the micro plug has a narrow enough 'handle' to be able to fit inside my phone's protective case.

These are great boots for walking on cold days or in snow.  Ice can be problematic although I haven't slipped once with them yet.  Because I have plantar fascitis problems, I do use an extra soft arch support; and it works very well.  I know the item description says they provide extra exercise when walking; but I actually find them easier to walk in than any other boot I have.

This comes with its own moisture disc with lid storage for keeping brown sugar soft.  The disc has to be removed from the lid, soaked for 15 minutes, and wiped dry on the surface first; but when you put it in contact with the sugar after that, it will keep the sugar soft and lump free for several months, if necessary.I don't bake over the summer and any left over brown sugar has to weather those months.  The natural humidity in the air isn't enough and the apple slice trick gives only limited success.  I keep the damp disk against the sugar and evedrything stays loose.  I check once a month and redampen the disk if necessary.  This method has saved me from throwing out more sugar bricks than I cvare to remember over the years.  If the container is empty, or the sugar is sealed in its original bag, store the disc in the lid where it never gets lost.This also works with turbinado or demarara sugar, too; but not as well.
It's flat, and it does a great job removing citrus zest.  I found it easy to clean (hand wash) and it stores flat in a drawer.
I still can't figure out how this works.  It seems to be nothing more than a camera app.

These are heavy duty stainless stell with a convenient tab on the end to enable a slip-free fit on a wide range of cups.  The only drawback is the textured interior.  Any measured material, liquid or solid, clings to those grooves and won't come out of the cup.  I deducted one star for that as it is a real inconvenience to me.  If you don't mind having that happen, then you will love these measuring cups.  The variety of sizes sure is handy.

This unit has been able to remove hairs that at least 6 other epilators of various brands couldn't.  That makes it A-1 in my book.As with all epilators, individual tolerances will vary and your comfort level will probably not match mine.  However, this little unit has been able to remove hair shorter than any other brand I tried and did it quickly on the first pass.  That means less friction from the rotating heads and a cleaner profile for a longer time.

At last Genina's superlative sudoku app comes to Kindle.This app generates its own puzzles on the fly, so you never have to download packets of new puzzles.  They only come in classic sudoku form, though; but I am more than happy with that.The game play features a choice of selecting digit first or cell first.  The digit first option can really cut down on taps when you can see more than one cell at a time where the digit fits.  There is also a pencil switch that allows you to fill in guesses on the fly and then switch back to standard selection.  And all that is displayed on screen.There is also an eraser for removing digits you want to erase.  Sorry, but this puzzle does not erase an entered digit with a second tap (except for penciled in digits).  It does count up the number of times you use a digit and gray it out when all nine possibilites are on the board.  It also highlights all instances of the selected digit on the board to help you line-of-sight locations that can't be used and puts a red border on a cell when you try to enter an "impossible" digit.  If you fill in a digit, all penciled in instances of that digit will be removed.  (However, it won't prevent you from penciling in a digit where it shouldn't be.)Off screen, there are lots of options on the pop up menu, including Undo, Redo, an option to fill in possible digits for the entire puzzle at once, a validation function to point out mistakes when you get a conflict, and a way to get some hints.  Even deeper in the menu are options for Settings, solving the entire puzzle (if by some chance, you should ever want to give up), and a Reset command to erase all your selections and start over.The range of difficulty is also pretty wide.About the only thing not to like is that the Welcome Screen was never resized for Kindle tablets.  It is still the same size that fits on cell phone screens, which means it looks tiny on a Kindle Fire 8.9 inch screen.

The ring itself is beautiful and available in a wide variety of exact sizes to perfectly fit any finger.However, the stone is very disappointing.  For a created sapphire, it is surprisingly murky and non-reflective.  When the ring is on my finger, it can't even be seen.I'm afraid I will have to exchange this one for a different stone.

This ring looks way better than its picture.  Sizing is true to generous and the stones are set very slightly lower than the level of the metal surrounding them.  That should provide good protection for the stones.  This one is a keeper, and I even bought a companion in pink tourmaline.Just a quick note that these comfort fit rings, especially with stones set into them like this, are thicker than regular high setting rings.  That may be a consideration for people that don't like the extra thickness around the finger.

This ring looks way better than its picture.  Sizing is true to generous and the stones are set very slightly lower than the level of the metal surrounding them.  That should provide good protection as tourmaline is one of the softer gemstones.  This one is a keeper, and I even bought a companion in blue topaz.Just a quick note that these comfort fit rings, especially with stones set into them like this, are thicker than regular high setting rings.  That may be a consideration for people that don't like th extra thickness around the finger.

The ring, when it arrived was very pretty.  The stones are a light, but bright chartreuse color, not quite as dark looking as pictured.However, the sizing is quite tight.  I normally wear a size 7 ring of late and can sometimes fit into a 6.5, depending on ring design.  This ring was labeled 7, and the vendor was very nice and quickly responded to my email about it; because I couldn't get the ring on.  It was definitely too small.  Just to make sure my fingers hadn't swelled up, I tried on five of my other rings and they all fit as they normally do. So, I sadly had to return it.If you buy the ring, you won't be disappointed in the looks or color; but be sure to consider going half a size up, if possible.  If not, try a full size up; but be aware before buying that sizing should be a consideration.  The manufacturer's sizing guage runs a bit smaller than expected; but the ring itself is absolutely beautiful.

I know that tanzanite is a problematic stone.  It literally photographs a lot darker than it looks in person.  I know because I have tried it myself, and sure enough, the stone looks darker in the photo than it does on my hand.The basic color of tanzanite is a very pale lavendar.  The darker the stone, the more expensive it gets, and that should be considered when buying this ring.  I received a ring with a nice little solitaire stone that is definitely blue-lavendar, clear and quite pale in color.  The nice thing about it is that the blue tint is clearly visible when the stone is viewed straight on,  It's lovely.  However, every stone is different.  It isn't possible for each ring to be identical to the one pictured, but mine was very close and I consider the picture a good representation.The ring size is true and the ring itself would look better on smaller hands because it is a thin ring with a small stone (barely more than 1/4 carat) that will get lost on a larger or broader hand.  If I get a chance to photograph it, I will try to edit this review later.

The color is very impressive with a true kaleidescope of mostly turquoise shades,  The sizing is true, and perhaps a tad generous.There are a few things to note, though.  Comfort fit rings like this one all tend to be a bit thick bodied and this is no exception.  If you prefer a close fitting flat ring that can't be felt between the fingers, stick with a traditional setting. Also, there are future considerations, such as how will the ring age?  Opal is a delicate stone and it is set all around the ring.  I will keep an eye on the ring to see if the stone scratches with use, especially when I have to grab something (like a subway pole for balance).As it stands now, I take it off when I have to put my hands in water; but that should be another consideration and opportunity for abuse of the ring and stone.  The tungsten should be able to take it, but again, consideration should be given to care for the opal stones as water may eventually work its way underneath them and either loosen them or cause fading or cracking.If one is willing to treat the ring with care keeping all this in mind, it should be an attention grabber for a long time to come.I think I will be ordering another one sometime soon - as soon as I can decide on what color I want.

This is a rather bright cocktail type ring.  I wouldn't select it for everyday wear as it is rather flashy.  Tanzanites are stones with a wide range of shading.  I already have tanzanite that ranges from pale lavender with barely any color to as dark as a frosted blueberry.  The darker the stone, the more expensive it is; and true blueberry colored stones will cost $1,000 for a clear, flawless 1,2 carat specimen.The ring I received has a pale to medium lavendar stone with great clarity and sparkle.  Also, the ring sizes to a true 7 with maybe being just a tad on the generous side.  This is important because silver rings can't be easily sized like gold ones can.  The set stones on the sides of the ring stop just short of being in an annoying place, which is good news for comfort.  I daresay the pictured ring is the best one of the lot with the darkest stone; but expecting that color for the price of this ring is unrealistic.  The stone I got is true tanzanite color, lavender with some flashes of blue when viewed from the side.  Looking at it straight on won't display that additional color, I'm afraid.
It is very comfortable and soft.  It also washes well with no fading or shrinking.  Also, love the color.  I couldn't decide on which color.  So I bought several.

I had a lot of bubbles form when I applied this cover.  It took about 4 hours of work to get the ones that didn't have dust particles beneath them pushed out to the edges of the cover. The cover itself had a nice semi-matte surface and takes a lot of finger contact and cleaning with alcohol pads in stride.I have applied a lot of different screen covers over the past 16 years and this was by far the hardest to install.  Luckily, I have a situation where the bubbles don't matter much, but if I needed an absolutely clear screen I would have been disappointed.It gets lots of points for toughness and durability; but loses points for the difficult application.

Everything it is claimed to be, as far as being bubble-free goes.  However, it was not anti-glare.The unit I received was an ultra-clear cover, but it is shiny and almost as mirror-like as the Kindle it protects.  Also, I applied this to the newly released Kindle fire 8.9 with 3G connection capabilities.  There is a slight problem as this new model is ever so slightly smaller than the previous one released in November 2013.  The difference is only about a millimeter, but that is enough to have the edges of the cover flush with the outside edge of the Kindle (as opposed to the end of the screen area).Anyone ordering the new Kindle Fire 8.9 3G should be aware that you may have to wait for i-Blason to cut a new master for the smaller size of this model.That being said, this cover does not actually stick to the surface of the viewing area.  The black border of the cover contains a thick-ish backing that absorbs the bumps from any stray dust particles that may have escaped cleaning and does not form bubbles at all.  So far, so good.  The clear area does not cling to the screen.  That means it is immune to bubbles; but consequently can form rainbow interference patterns as it meets the glass beneath it.  Many people might find these patterns annoying; but they are an alternative to having bubbles and dust bumps on a cover that sticks to the glass with a tacky surface.I deducted one star for not having a truly matte surface because I can't give it half a star.  The mirror finish is ultra clear, which is a plus, and I can't fault a cover I bought for the older Fire 8.9 model for being a millimeter too large for my new Fire.  As long as the lens holes fit in the proper place, this cover will do the job well.I don't know how many times it can be removed and reapplied, or how it should be stored between applications; but I can vouch that I was able to lift and reset it several times before I got the alignment exactly right with no bubble or dust problems.This cover is extremely easy to apply in comparison with every other cover I have used, including the wet application ones.

Let me preface my review with a bit of background.  The story follows 4 teenage friends through their adventures in a self-contained fantasy world.  The four are the pair Talis and Mara, with Nikulo and Rikar making up the other two.  At this point in the story they have broken up into 3 groups with Talis and Mara staying together and the other two going their separate ways.  this is relevant to my review.I had serious issues with this book.  It seemed quite rushed and some passages were clearly wrong.  For example on Page 140 the characters Nikulo and Holoron are talking together.  Suddenly on Page 141, Holoron is talking to Talis, a character who in the story line is about 1,000 miles away at the time. Finally, on Page 143, it is Nikulo and Holoron who are back in the conversation again. It is errors like this, where character names and identities are not checked, that tell me the book was rushed to publication without a decent proof read.My second issue was with the ending, where one character miraculously shows up in the main story line with very little story time in the book before that, while another character who has been followed closely in the plot for nearly the entire book simply disappears from the story line.The book is clearly an interim installment, but the previous books had gone to the trouble of wrapping up the current plot before throwing in a hook for the next installment at the very end.  This book just drops the story in midstream with unresolved plot lines all over the place and no end in sight.  Tune in next week for the sequel.  The previous books did not do this and I am terribly disappointed that this installment did.  Luckily, I had the good sense to borrow it instead of buying it.  At least I can say I didn't throw my money away.
This is a series of "extra" Ranma episodes.  About 12 episodes are included on the two-disc set.  Some of them are quite funny and all are worth a watch.
The towels are convenient popup squarish 9 x 10 towels.  They are a bit rough and stiff, though, and that is the tradeoff for the convenience of having pop-up paper hand towels.
This replacement is even better than the original that came with the coffee pot.  The folded edge is crimped much firmer and the hub does not rotate in the mesh

Second favorite case, slim and light.This case adds practically no bulk or weight to the phone.  It is a relatively soft case with precise dimensions that reach the edge of the glass screen and no farther.  This means that it will not interfere with any stick-on screen protectors.  It has a smooth matte finish with cross work embossing on the back for both shock distribution and grip.  It pops right on the phone and is only slightly more difficult to remove.  The key is to start at the bottom corner opposite to the S-Pen slot.The bezels around the screen and the camera lens offer just enough lift to protect from scratches and drops and the edges of the phone have the tiniest bit of air space around them to offer good protection in a drop.  The openings for the ear phone plug and the charger have a tight enough tolerance that larger plugs will have trouble staying plugged in. I have an Amazon USB charging cable that is wide enough at the plug to keep popping out of the phone when I am trying to charge it in this case.  So that might be an issue for some.However, my biggest gripe is the flat button covers.  They make it tough to find the buttons, or avoid them.  So I find myself accidently pushing unwanted buttons all the time.  Other than that, though, it's a great case.My only other choice before this is the heavier Spigen Slim Armor case.

These are great cables for connecting any device that accepts micro USB input to a charger and have it accept the fastest charging rate it can.  The lack of data connections means my Galaxy Tab will charge from any outlet on my multi-charger.  I just wish they weren't so short.EDIT: I have to revise my review of these cables because they have started failing - big time.  Two of the five have already started to break.  They will connect and start charging; and immediately disconnect about 1 second later.  At this rate, all five will be worthless in less than a week.Can't recommend with a failure rate like this.

Love this case.It is a little more expensive than other Spigen cases; but well worth it for me.  I like the contrast between the central hard portion and the rubber interior and ends.  This particular case doesn't feel like it leaves any air space around the edges of the phone, unlike the ridged back; but the rubber itself fells pliable enough to absorb the shock of a reasonable fall with no trouble.The case does increase the weight and bulk of the phone a bit; but it feels so solid and sleek that it is forgiveable.  Unlike many others, I don't have headphones with thick plugs.  So that is not an issue with me.  However, I do have USB charging cables with thick plug grips and some of them are a bit snug fitting.  The outer ridge around the phone's screen ends precisely at the groove in the edge of the glass and allows the metal edge of the phone to be seen if viewed at a very shallow angle.  However, the precise cut means that any screen protector can be used with the case without interference as long as it is applied reasonably straight.The extremely smooth hard outer shell may become a problem if one tries to handle the phone with wet or greasy hands; and it tends to pick up smudges and fingerprints way too easily.  I think I will be cleaning it often.  On the other hand, it makes the phone feel almost like it has no case because of the sculpted edges, which are beveled on both sides making them nearly round.  Both the front ridge and the bevel around the camera lens guarantee that neither the screen nor the lens will get scratched on any flat surface.The buttons are raise slightly and easy to press.  That makes them easy to find even when not looking at the phone.  It also makes it easy to accidentally press them when the phone is in a purse or pocket.  Since the front button at the bottom of the screen will also wake the phone from standby and is easier to reach in an enclosed space, I don't consider that to be a negative.Putting the case on was very easy if I started from the bottom.  Taking it off was a little more difficult because of the stiffness of the outer shell; but it was still easier than a lot of cheaper cases to remove.  There is no sensation that a drop or bang will separate the case from the phone and that solidity is all that I ask for.My only real dilemma is whether to use this or the Spigen Bounce case which is all rubber and both slimmer and lighter than this one.  Decisions, decisions.  I will probably go with this since it is smoother and easier to slip into the side pocket of a purse.

Added this to my Galaxy Note 3 phone and it was just like I had expanded internal memory.  I could not notice any difference in speed between this card and the phone's native memory. It was recognized immediately and did not need formatting. Now I have a 64 GB phone.

I am ecstatic about this card reader.  I have an SDXC card which my current PC cannot read under any circumstances.  If I connected it to the PC directly, it "needed" to be formatted.  Then when I put it back in the camera, it had to be formatted again.  What a great way to keep losing data.  Finally, if I attached the camera to the PC via USB, I couldn't transfer the pictures because, once again, the PC does not recognize the card as formatted.  I had to put the card away and get a SDHC model instead.Then I got this reader.  I plugged the card into the reader and the reader into my USB port ---- and the PC was suddenly able to read the card!  At this point I'm not even concerned about transfer speed, which is fast.  I'm just so happy that I can now use that expensive 64GB SDXC card.

Pros:Easier than tacky back PET screen protectors to apply.  Follow the video directions percisely to get very good results.  Add the extra element of going to a bathroom and running the shower steaming hot for 5 minutes beforehand to clear the dust from the air and you can get great results.Extremely clear and virtually bubble free.  Almost totally bubble free after a few days and practically invisible, except when tilted at an angle to the light.Touch sensitivity did not seem to be affected.I have a light touch with pens. So I did not experience the marking issue with the S-pen that others have.Cons:The cover is soft.  It will easily pick up fingernail marks that stay and will develop ridges from the smoothing and squeegee application process.The soft surface will also offer more resistance to swiping/sliding with fingers and to the S-pen point.Extreme care must be taken during the application process to avoid getting the application solution inside the phone.  Wetness and electronics do not mix well.  Try to allow 20-24 hours for the phone to dry before turning it back on and, if possible keep it face down on a microfiber towel or lens cloth the entire time to wick away moisture.Due to its softness, it will probably be more likely to scratch during normal use.  The softness means it is self-healing; but that can only go so far.However, all things considered, this is a much better choice than the harder surfaced dry application protectors.  Both ArmorSuit and Skinomi make very good products and I will take their solution to the screen protection problem any day over the others.  The wet application process means less dust gets caught between the protector and the screen; and what little there may be will not create distorting bubbles like the dry application covers do.The cover loses one star for being so soft, but I wish there was a way to make it 1/2 star because the rest of it is so good.  The previous suggestion to apply with the phone case on has merit.  However, you will have to take into account that some of the liquid will get squeegeed under that cover.  It will be best to remove the case immediately after application to prevent liquid from getting into the phone because of it.

The movies are extensions of the popular TV show and are relatively short with thin plots.  Something Ranma does gets misinterpreted and things showball from there.  However, the transfer quality and sound were pretty good and laughs were to be had.  This isn't great enough to earn 5 stars but it was fairly entertaining.  Among some of the funnier aspects were the easy availability of both hot and cold water in remote locations on a moment's notice.

For starters, I ordered blue but got black.  Okay, that's a minor issue; but it goes downhill from there.  The case was nearly impossible to disassemble as I had to use my fingernails to spread the back cover sideways to release the front.  Then it was difficult to put on the phone properly since the sides had to be pushed back into place and of course that meant accidentally activating all the buttons on the sides of the phone in the process.Thankfully, I did not experience the sensor obstruction issue that so many others have complained of, but the clear screen produced some very annoying oil slick effects as it contacted the phones touch screen unevenly.  I cleaned both surfaces several times with microfiber lens cloths and could not stop it.  This also meant removing and reinserting the phone into the case several times, a real pain - literally.The case is stiff and the button covers flush with the rest of the edge.  This may be good to prevent accidental button depression; but that extends to all button use.  On top of that, the buttons are so stiff that I had difficulty pushing them even when not having to hold the phone to my face for a call.  I tried to adjust the volume when making one phone call with the case on and wound up taking 10 pictures of the sidewalk instead.  Bear in mind that others may not have the same issue with stiff buttons flush with the case edge.  At least that design prevents liquid from entering the phone via the button covers.Yes, the case is very inexpensive; but I'm getting something else.On the very plus side, PC Micro is very attentive to customer relations.  I called them and got a live person in under a minute.  We had a long conversation about the design aspects of the case and they made good on their promise of full satisfaction.  So, I give the case design 1 star and customer service 5 stars, for an average of 3 stars.

It gave me a few problems starting up, mostly with hulu plus.  Outside of that issue, it is pretty nice.My only complaint is that I can't adjust video quality and my data consumption has more than tripled since I got it.
Great all-purpose office supplies caddy

I could say this for all the One Piece collections, but this is a great series on a nice 23 episode DVD set for a reasonable price.  This particular season covers the escape from Skypeiea and the Davy Back Fight arcs ending in the arrival at Water Seven.

With the slight exception that the felt can be a bit rough and clingy, this case does the job very nicely.  I needed something to store a portable hotspot made by Samsung.  It is larger than other hotspots and square, which limits the types of cases I can find for it.  This case protects it to the nth degree and even allows me to carry a pair of earphones as well.

This version is only useful for transferring contacts stored on the SIM card.  For some reason, it passes up on the internally stored entries.  Since my SIM card entries don't store the street address, etc., for my contacts.  That limits the app's effectiveness.  However, what it does, it does well.  I can transfer between phone models and carriers with just a click or two.However, the internal entries had to go as vCards over Bluetooth.I don't know if the paid version would do better; but I didn't want to take a chance.

I think I wasted my money.  Not only are the buttons stiff and impossible to tell if they are pushed, but there is a big cut-out in the upper right corner of the case.  That means at least one spot is very vulnerable in a fall.  However, it seems logical to have it there as the only point where one can gain leverage to remove the case without damaging the phone.Yes, the color is very nice (gold in my case) and the case itself fits tightly, once I can get it on; but that is all.  The very process of putting on the case turned the phone on for me after I had been careful to shut it down and not just lock the screen.  The same goes for removing it. The right-side On/Off button is so stiff I can't tell if I have pressed it successfully and more often than not it triggers the "Shut down" dialog.  Since I am not about to purposely drop a $620 phone just to test a $17 case, I can't vouch for its protective abilities.Sorry, but this is a throwaway and I will be looking for a better case, maybe one of the Spigen models.

7:33 MinsThis case boasts almost all the protection of Otterbox at 1/4 the price. First, the case comes in a plain-vanilla cardboard box.  No frills here, just the company logo.However, there are no written instructions, just a youtube address to a video instruction.  Here it is: http://youtu.be/McReHvr_fDkThe video will demonstrate how to unpack and separate the case, insert the phone, use the port protectors, and finally remove the box.  However, it has two faults.  The demo is done on a Samsung Galaxy S5, not a Fire Phone, and the demo leaves out the small fact that there are two stick on protector films on the clear screen protector.  They have to be peeled off BEFORE inserting the phone in the case.  The rest should be self-explanatory in the video.The review itself is on the attached video file.  Sorry, but the camera's auto white balance reacted badly to the blue back of the case.

The case is gorgeous, light and very well made. However, it offers no protection at all. It snaps on in a second and is comfortable and lush feeling. But nothing projects beyond the phone and I don't see how it can absorb enough shock to protect the phone.  Sadly, this will have to go back.

This is a great looking ring with pale peach-pink morganite stones as a centerpiece.  The silver base of the ring reduces the cost a little while the pink gold plating makes it look more costly than it is.  Morganite is a relatively inexpensive stone with an unusual color that can really impress.  Plus this ring coordinates with a wide variety of outfits.This ring arrived in a large, beautiful double keepsake case.Diamonds step aside for the world of color.

This is the best compromise so far.  The unit is balanced between the "thin and light" pretty covers and covers that offer at least some protection.  This cover comes in two pieces: a case for the back of the phone and a shield for the phone's face.  Now for the details.As others have posted, there are absolutely NO instructions how to install this cover, not in the box or on the web site.  There are instructions for related items; but not this specific model.  However, I was able to muddle through based on previous experience with screen shields on other devices.  Matching up the back case was no problem; but finding a start point to peel off the packing adhesive was.  I finally got a fingernail under an edge and pulled with all my strength to get it off.  Succeeded without any scratches to the plastic.  Whew!  The second cover on the outside of the case wasn't as bad.  After that, the case just popped onto the phone when I matched the camera openings to the lens location on the phone back.The case for the phone has a clear polycarbonate back that shows off the Amazon logo and collects all the fingerprints that would have otherwise gone on the phone.  The button extensions are easy to use and the outer edge of the case is rubberized with a nice tactile feel and grip.  It is tapered slightly toward the back of the phone making the phone's profile less square and the edges more rounded.  This reduces fatigue gripping the phone, a plus.  The downside of the case is that even the slightest condensation on the back will be visible as an oil slick-like blemish under the clear cover.  The upside is that the slightest condensation between the case and the phone will be visible.  Since it wasn't difficult to remove the case, taking it off and wiping away the moisture is easy.It would be good to have an eyeglass cleaning cloth to wipe off all those fingerprints at the end of the day, though.Since the case pops over the front edge of the phone, it makes a nice, rubber bumper that lifts the phone face slightly off any surface you put it on.  This provides a surprising amount of protection for the glass.  It might even mean that the second part of the case set, the stick on shield, isn't really necessary.Now that I have reached the shield, I have to preface my review by saying I have learned to *hate* these things.  While it is possible to apply them with no bubbles, the effort required isn't worth the protection they offer.First, both the sticky side of the shield and the phone face should be perfectly clean.  This means dusting off the outside of the adhesive protector on the shield and cleaning the phone with a pad dampened with household rubbing alcohol.  Dry off the phone thoroughly, preferably with a microfiber eyeglass cloth.  Most shields come with such a cloth; but this time you will have to supply your own.Next, find a dust-free area of your home to do the actual application.  The bathroom or kitchen is best because you can either run the shower or boil some water that will condense around dust particles and "clean" out the air a bit.Thirdly, you will have to position the shield over the phone glass and find the starting point to pull away the backing on the shield.  The first place to adhere the shield is where the backing first pulls away.  Work down the face of the phone carefully, keeping the shield aligned the way you positioned it and peel away the protective adhesive out from under the shield very close to the glass, smoothing out most of the bubbles as you go.  If the glass was truly clean, there shouldn't be any dust caught in the middle and the bubbles with move sideways as you press down.Finally, get a credit card and pass the edge over the top of the shield to finish smoothing it down, pushing the bubbles toward its edge.  If there is no captured dust, all the bubbles should slide out in front of the card edge and the shield will be almost completely smooth and clear.  Any remaining minor bubbles should flatten out over the next day or two, unless they have dust specks underneath.Whatever you do, don't remove the shield to adjust it.  All that will happen is dust and lint will get caught under it and things will get worse.After doing all that, however, I had a spot in the upper left corner that refused to stick to the phone glass.  There was no dust or dirt under it.  It just refused to adhere for over two days.  Since the edge of the loose section went right over the center of one of the dynamic sensor lenses, I just removed the stupid shield and threw it away.  Somehow, I think the ridge around the edge of the glass will do more good than the shield anyway.Also, each corner of the cover has a curved ridge on the backside that forms a "foot" which keeps the clear cover raised off the surface the phone is resting on, a small but welcome feature.  The cutouts for the USB port and the headphones are extra large to accommodate some of the heavier plug bases.  This is important to me because I have had encounters with covers whose access cutouts were too small for the charger.On the whole, this case is a good compromise between the paper thin vanity covers and the extra thick rubber or silicone protective covers.  It is trim and stylish with an innovative display for the phone back and still offers cushioning protection around the vulnerable edge and glass face of the phone.  It isn't perfect, but I like it a lot.  AT $13, it is a very attractive alternative to the $30 plus cases.

If you want a pretty case with with a nice textured surface, this is it.But don't expect it to protect the phone.  It is tissue thin, and although hard, doesn't cover enough or provide enough of a "bumper" to offer any protection to the phone. As mentioned before, the front lip is so thin that the glass face of the phone will make full contact with every surface as though there was no cover on it at all.It snapped on the phone very easily and came off nearly as easily.  I had to expend very little effort to get a thumbnail under a corner and pop it off.Yes, it looks good, is a great color (gummetal gray for me), and adds little or no weight to the phone.  Yes, it has an easy grip velvety surface that reduces fatigue holding the phone and looks really streamlined.But that isn't why I buy a case for the phone.  Both the front and the back of the phone are supposedly made of gorilla glass 3 and either one can easily shatter in a fall.  That's what the case is meant to prevent.  The case itself barely covers the corners of the phone, but the top and bottom are wide open and that may be just enough to allow the case to pop off in a large enough fall on a hard enough surface.The most vulnerable part of the phone is the glass face. Simply having raised bumpers around the edge can be enough to stop it from contacting a damaging surface that will scratch or crack it.  This case is so thin it is nealy flush with the glass.  While it may look like a sleek design, it will do nothing to keep the glass safe and a broken glass face is a very expensive fix, if it doesn't "total" the phone altogether.I want more than a "feather" weight case for my phone.  So this is going back.

This measuring set is simply awesome.  It is made of extremely heavy gauge steel and the weighting on the bottom of the cups ensures that they will never tip over and spill your stuff.  They also look like they will last 100 years.  About my only complaint is that I would have loved to get one or two intermediate sizes like I have in my other measuring set.  The rounded corners make it easy to get every last bit of ingredient out of the cups and spoons with nothing left in the non-existent corners.Of course, I outsmarted my self because the tip-proof bottoms took away my ability to indulge in the habit of tipping the cup sideways in a larger vessel to have all of any liquid inside flow to one side and be poured out.  But that is a small price to pay for such great quality.

All I can say is the color of this pendant is beautiful and more pronounced than its picture implies.  The chain is a deent length and it is a great addition to my jewel box.The man-made sapphire is an intense blue and fairly clean and well cut.  My only reservation is the tendency of silver jewelry to tarnish over time and storing it with tarnish absorbing protective paper will be a must.

The real life color of this watch is even more striking and beautiful than the picture indicates.  So far, it is keeping very accurate time and the only drawback is the lack of contrast on the dial face.  However, the manufacturer took care of that by putting two highly reflective indicator tips on the hour and minute hands.  I have a couple of blue outfits that this watch complemets really well; and the best part is the complements my friends give this watch!I haven't noticed any signs of wear or fading on the bevel or band.  So this one is a keeper.

That being said I have a few issues with the case:The good:  It is fairly thick and well-ribbed, which makes it easy to grip and offers at least a little drop protection (and, no, I did not test that part). It also projects forward above the screen about 1/16-1/8 inch.  That's enough to keep the screen clear of a lot of surfaces and reduces scratch potential.  The stand in back is potentially useful; but only if you want to use the phone in horizontal mode for widescreen video.The bad:  I did not find it at all easy to remove; and in the process, the black outer portion separated from the colored inner portion at the corner.  The two portions do not snap together; so the only possible repair involves glue.  The operating buttons on the phone are covered with pushout buttons on the case.  While they do operate the buttons underneath them, I found the one covering the On/Lock button to be unusually stiff and difficult to operate.  On the other hand, the Camera/Firefly button is unusally soft and easy to press.  This may be due to the location of each on the phone; but the end result is a lot of time spent in battery-draining Firefly mode (since it can be engaged without unlocking the phone screen).  Finally, the openings on the bottom of the phone for the microphone, speaker, and USB port are cutouts with a downside of the USB opening being rather tight fitting for the USB plug.  I was wondering why the phone wasn't charging until I noticed that the thick case was resisting the charging plug and literally pushing it back out of the port.  I was using the Amazon ultra long charging cable with their standard charging adapter.  Even after I spread the opening in the case wider to allow the plug to seat properly, the slightest movement of the phone made the case squeeze the plug out until it stopped charging the phone.  I had to find a much smaller and shorter portable hard drive cable to fit into the case's cut out.The ugly:  I bought the orange case and the color that arrived didn't match the soft orange pictured in the item description at all.  It is more like Safety Neon Orange.  The up side is that I can spot the phone from 50 paces away.  Haha.To sum up, you get what you pay for.  The case has several really good features and a lot of issues; but considering the inexpensive price, the trade-off might be well worth it.

This boot is made of distressed cowhide, and a fairly good quality at that.  However, there are a few "gotcha"s that you should know about before buying.  It will save having to return the boots if you know in advance.First, only the toe cap and instep is fully lined, along with the lower part of the heel.  The entire calf and the upper part of the heel are unlined.  This is common in riding boots where thinner leather between the leg and the horse is a good thing; but if you want to do a lot of walking, the rough surface of the interior will prove uncomfortable.Then there is the strap across the ankle.  It makes the boot hard to put on and is difficult to loosen.  On the other hand, the strap across the top of the calf can help make that part fit better and only works because the calf rise is unlined, i.e., a single layer of leather, and very pliable.  Since I happen to have a boot chuck, taking them off was no problem.I wear size 10 and the length of the foot was adequate, to roomy.  However, even with a medium to narrow foot (B width), and virtually no instep to speak of, the boot was too narrow.  Anyone with a wide foot or high instep should take this into consideration before ordering.  It will save a lot of trouble in the long run.  Also, the half-lined heel would be comfortable astride a horse but will definitely rub against the foot during extended walking.I happen to own riding boots, or boots meant exclusively for riding, and they are fitted with canvas loops on the inside of the boot top.  With a pair of boot hooks, the difficult process of putting them on is relatively easy.  I would have loved to see those loops on these boots.  They probably would have slipped on quickly.  The construction of the boots is solid and they should last for several years under normal wear and tear.  The pull-on loops would have been a boon, though.  Also, the sole/heel combination is thick and heavy and should stand up well under use -- for any person with the right foot to fit the boot properly.In summary, if you have a narrow foot and wide calf, these boots should fit well and be comfortable.  Anybody else would be better off trying a different style of boot.  I gave it three stars because the fitting problem is a major issue to me.
It contains lots of definitions, but very little in the way of actual explanation of the syntax.  Not useful for newcomers.

This is another in the list of hidden object games from DifferenceGames with a new menu system, additional objects and, finally, settings that do not reset at the end of each game.Here are the good points:Objects are now partially obscured.  Some are overlaid on other objects, others run halfway off the screen or are partially behind permanent parts of the scene, and others are so transparent they can barely be seen.There is a new menu system with a Greek style font that is very inventive.Sound settings are persistent from game to game and do not need to be reset each time a new game starts.The transitional music riffs are quite nice.Found objects now disappear with a sparkle from the scene and the thumbnail also disappears from the selection bar, instead of being checked off.The scenes are now packed with overlapping objects, increasing the challenge.There is now an option at the end of every scene to return to the main menu instead of just clicking to continue to the next scene.It is possible to wrap around to the beginning or any intermediate scene by selecting the "Next scene" button after the 20th, and last, scene is completed.  Your score will continue to climb.  However, there is a Catch-22.  If your score climbs above some as yet unidentified cap, the game will revert to negative scores and ultimately crash.Now for the parts that mar the experience:In Scene 6 (particularly), the tambourine icon points to the toy drum object, although it can also point to the right object, namely the tanbourine.  Something similar happened with the handheld mirror and the wall mirror in one of the later scenes.The tap area for some of the objects is either too small, offset somehow, or obscured by the tap area of nearby objects.  Hence, tapping on the object will sometimes incorrectly generate a point deduction.One of the two spiderweb objects is invisible against the icon bar background.  I have reached the "end" of several scenes containing the spiderweb with an apparently empty bar and had to tap on the spiderweb to complete the scene even though the icon for it didn't show.Just once so far, an object was in the icon bar that did not seem to exist in the scene.  Even after hitting the Hint button, no part of the scene was highlighted.  I believe this was in one of the later scenes, 16 or 18.Also, since I installed the game, my Kindle Fire HDX (7") has behaved strangely, freezing even though I quit the game a while before.  I have had to restart the Kindle twice and was able to Force Stop the game a few other times to get things working again.Overall, this game breaks new ground for hidden object "puzzles".  However, it will have to work out a few bugs before earning 5 stars from me.
Once again we have a truly engaging story.  It was hard to put it down., even after it was over.

This book is not just aimed at creating "commercial" web sites.  It contains instructions that can be equally valuable to bloggers or anyone who just wants to have their own personal site.Everything has been worked out in a simple cookbook form with consideration for everything from choosing a domain name to protection to backups; and each step of the way he offers choice analyses of the available software and hosting solutions with the pros and cons for each selection in the simplest terms possible.  This is not a book that one needs a degree in HTML code and web design to understand.  A complete, insecure, newcomer can follow this book's instructions and have a website up in just a couple of hours.Most of the other books I have read are aimed at retailers but this book is for everybody.  As a matter of fact, there are some who might consider it too simple; but they probably shouldn't have bothered with it in the first place.

I have to say that the previous books in this series left quite an opening for future developments; and that this book surprises because it did not follow any of the obvious courses.Inhuman introduces at least one new villain (you will understand what this means when you read the book) and turns the tables on our previous conceptions of characters we have met in the past.  It goes to a new set of problems and ironically solves what could have been a problem based on the ending of the book 3.  With all the unknowns associated with the creation of the Trans-human, it has surprisingly become a non-issue concerning the potential problems it could have caused.  The focus instead has become the mystery surrounding reports of character appearances and on the newly revealed biggest threat to not only humanity's survival but the existence of the entire cosmos.The stage expands and events from way back in the first book come back into the plot in new, sinister ways.  Never a dull moment here.Simpson masterfully tells a nail-biting, fast paced story that moves relentlessly from one player to another in a way that makes it hard to put the book down.  It is the longest single book in the series so far and still had me relentlessly turning page after page to see what would happen next, and root for new friends that were once enemies and boo enemies that were once friends.  He has turned his universe topsy turvy and dealt quite a few surprises, both happy and sad, as we learn more about the players we have already met and the ripples that have spread out to all corners of existence.I doubt that anyone who reads this will be disappointed; but to get the full impact you should be sure to read the previous four books first.

The game is visually beautiful; but I have two issues with it.The first is the sound control.  There is none.  The only way to turn off the sound is to turn the volume of the device all the way down.  Then I have to remember to turn it back up after playing.  An in-game control for that from the menu would be nice for those of us who want to quietly catch a few minutes of play during a work or meal break; or who don't want to hear the sound track repeat..The second, which is minor, is the Hint system.  It keeps pointing to items I have already found.  I ask for a hint to find items I can't locate, not the ones already marked.The game loses a star for these two omissions.

Having had very good luck with the Way Basics (square) Storage Cubes that I bought 2 years ago for my daughter's nursery, I decided to buy a couple of these (rectangular) Storage Cube Plus cubes in early 2014 to store some of her toys in.  I chose the Expresso (dark brown) color, because it would blend in with the color scheme in our living room.  Unlike the square cubes, which have held up for over 2 years without so much as a lean, the adhesive strips in these rectangular Cube Plus cubes began to fail after only 3 months, causing the edges of the cubes to separate.  My 2 cubes were stacked on top of each other, so when the bottom cube gave way, both cubes ended up falling over.  The load in the cubes wasn't particularly heavy, either - mainly lightweight, toddler-sized toys.  I can't for the life of me figure out why the rectangular Way Basics Cube Plus cubes fell apart but the square Cubes have stayed intact, especially since the rectangular cubes came with a thick, cardboard "backboard," which you'd think would help to hold the Cube Plus together.  We store only cloth items (lightweight blankets, stuffed toys, etc.), in the square Cubes, so perhaps the moral of the story is that only very lightweight items can be stored in Way Basics cubes.  I definitely couldn't see these working for storing heavy, compact items like CDs/DVDs, vinyl records or books.  Fortunately, I was able to press the boards back together after the Cubes Plus fell apart, so they're not completely unusable.  However, we're only able to store soft, very lightweight toys in them now, so I have to find another storage solution for my daughter's plastic toys.  I gave this item 3 stars instead of 2 or 1 because it is an eco-friendly alternative to toxic engineered wood products, and a budget-friendly alternative to expensive, natural solid wood shelving.  But I wouldn't purchase Way Basics products again or recommend them to others unless they're going to be used to store fluffy items like lightweight sweaters or stuffed toys.Grade: C+UPDATE 9/2014: Shortly after writing this review, I was contacted by Way Basics Customer Service.  They were very attentive and eager to help me resolve my issues with this product.  I sent them some photos of my Storage Cube Plus cubes ... And, as it turns out, I had the cubes stacked the wrong way!  Apparently, for maximum product integrity, the Storage Cube Plus must be placed with the long edges vertical.  If the long edges of the cube are horizontal, that causes separation of the adhesive at the seams.  Unfortunately for me, I was using each of these cubes to store two small canvas storage baskets Whitmor 6241-1501-Kid's Canvas Collection Tote, Small, Blue (of kids' toys) side-by-side, and they won't fit with the cubes in vertical orientation.  So I had to make do with super-gluing the seams in place and putting the cubes back in horizontal orientation.  However, I still can't give this product 5 stars because nowhere on the product instructions does it state that these cubes must be used in vertical orientation only.  Something like this warrants a very clear warning on the package or in the manual/instructions, given that the cubes virtually fall apart if placed horizontally.  Had I known this up-front, I wouldn't have purchased the Storage Cube Plus in the first place.Customer Service: AUpdated Product Grade: B

My almost-3 year-old adores Disney's princess Jasmine, and would walk around our house with blankets on her head pretending they were "Jasmine's hair."  So I figured she might like this Jasmine Costume Wig.  To say she adores it would be putting it mildly!  She can now act out all her favorite scenes from the "Aladdin" story/movie, starring herself as Jasmine.  So why, then, did I give this item only 2 stars?  Firstly, this wig is really hard to put on and keep on.  Every couple of minutes, my little-one has to stop and ask me to fix the wig because it's slid off her head.  (My daughter has very curly hair that's not especially slippery at all).  What's more, the elastic band around your head that's supposed to keep the wig on is very small.  The product states that it's for kids 3+, but my daughter isn't quite 3 yet, and the elastic band feels too small (or the band is poorly constructed and can't hold the wig in place).  I can't see the wig elastic comfortably fitting a child over 4 years-old.  Secondly, this wig is very flimsy, especially since it's geared to (small) children.  Within minutes of my daughter first putting it on, "hair" was already coming loose from the jeweled headband, and she wasn't being especially hard on it.  This is definitely not an item that I expect to survive the rigors of preschooler play.Grade: C-

These sandals are very attractive and comfortable-looking.  The lilac color is a refreshing departure from the usual pink-for-girls, and the glittery bow detail at the front is adorable.  It also gives the sandals a dressier look, so they go equally well with play clothes or a party dress.  The foot-bed is cushioned and the sole is flexible, making the shoes comfy and appropriate for toddlers' and preschoolers' developing feet.Unfortunately, my 2 year-old girl didn't like these sandals.  Apparently, she prefers closed-toe sandals because she feels like her toes are more protected.  (I actually like them as well because stubbed toes are a common occurrence during preschool play!)  She tried these Meredith sandals on for about 30 seconds, and then took them off and asked me to "send them back."  So back they went.Grade: B

I usually try to steer clear of products that contain chemicals, so I should've gone with my first instincts and passed on the pottyPod when I read that it contains an "antimicrobial additive."  Although antimicrobial substances are usually added to products with the best of intentions (e.g., to kill germs and prevent odors), most of them are chemicals with very questionable toxicity and side-effects.  When I first researched the pottyPOD, I actually called the manufacturer's Customer Service line to ask what kind of plastic the soft seat is made of, and what type of antimicrobial agent is in it.  The rep was happy to inform me that the soft part of the potty seat is made of high-density polyurethane foam, but she was tight-lipped about the antimicrobial additive, stating that that info was "proprietary."  By that point, I'd already ordered the pottyPod, but I should've cancelled the order after my conversation with Prince Lionheart Customer Service.  Instead, I decided to wait and check out the actual item "in person" before deciding whether to keep it or not.As it turned out, that was not the wisest decision on my part!  As soon as I opened the box in which the pottyPOD was packed, my nose was immediately assaulted by a strong chemical smell.  It was coming from the soft part of the potty seat.  I couldn't tell whether the source of the fumes was the polyurethane foam itself, or the anti-microbial additive, but either way, I was past the point of caring.  Nothing that smelled that bad was ever getting near my preschooler's bare bum!  In addition, the so-called soft, comfortable seat is actually not that cushy.  It looks and feels almost like a gel seat made out of extremely compressed foam, which is only about 1/4-inch thick.  Honestly, I can't see it doing much to ease the discomfort if your little-one needs to sit on the potty for more than a couple of minutes.  The pottyPod is definitely being returned.  (The only reason this potty got 2 stars instead of 1 was that it's height-adjustable, which makes it good for taller/older toddlers and preschoolers).Grade: D

Although Nelson's brands itself as a maker of "all-natural" products, their sting gel is definitely not so.  The active ingredients are naturally-derived, but the inactive ingredients are certainly not.  The last time I checked, methylparaben (one of the inactive ingredients in this sting gel), was an artificial chemical of questionable toxicity.Unfortunately, by the time I needed to use the sting gel and read the list of ingredients, it was too late to return the product.  I just wanted to give a heads up to others.  If you're looking for a truly all-natural product without artificial ingredients, Nelson's Sting Gel is not for you.Grade: D

These Blueberry Training Pants are very well-made and comfortable.  My 2 year-old daughter likes wearing them, the plush cotton velour lining feels good against her skin, and the leg openings fit snugly against her thighs without being too tight.  (The material of the piping is soft so it doesn't dig into my little-ones thighs or waist).  In all, these underpants can be a decent potty training aid, if you're aware of their limitations.  Most importantly, these Blueberry Training Pants are NOT TOTALLY WATERPROOF!  (The product description from the manufacturer is very clear about this).  They contain a hidden polyester panel, which is water-resistant, but not waterproof.  So they will temporarily contain a small accident, and prevent a cascade of urine from running down your child's legs if they're standing up.  However, after a couple of minutes, the fluid will leak through the underpants and onto your child's clothing or whatever they happen to be sitting on.Therefore, Blueberry Training Pants are best suited to a child who is almost fully potty trained, and who only has occasional, small accidents.  However Blueberry Training Pants would probably not be a good fit for your child: (1) if your little-one has just started potty training (and still has frequent accidents or is a heavy wetter); (2) you're taking a long trip or are someplace where frequent bathroom access isn't possible; (3) if you're looking for leak-proof underwear for daytime naps or nighttime sleep.  If you need to prevent moisture from seeping through these training pants, I've found that a good work-around is to pair them with a waterproof diaper cover or shell.  We like the Waterproof Pull On Pants Potty Scotty/PottyPatty, Large.  They're made of waterproof nylon (rather than toxic PVC/vinyl), and they're very thin, so they add waterproofing to any training pants without adding bulk.  If you're looking for a one-stop potty training solution that's completely waterproof (without having to buy 2 separate products), then I would recommend Super Undies Pull-On Potty Training Pant (Medium, The Cupcake Queen), Best Bottom Potty Training Kit (XL/5T, Coconut), or Mumtaz Soakers Nighttime Fully Waterproof Training Pants (available on E T S Y).The main reason I deducted one star from my rating was not because Blueberry training pants aren't completely waterproof, but because they're expensive for non-leak-proof underpants.  They're only a couple of dollars cheaper than Super Undies and Best Bottom training undies, without the benefits of being fully waterproof.  Other than the fact that they're somewhat pricey, I would definitely recommend Blueberry Training Pants for parents who need only partially waterproof underwear for the occasional, small leak.Grade: B+

These Blueberry Training Pants are very well-made and comfortable.  My 2 year-old daughter likes wearing them, the plush cotton velour lining feels good against her skin, and the leg openings fit snugly against her thighs without being too tight.  (The material of the piping is soft so it doesn't dig into my little-ones thighs or waist).  In all, these underpants can be a decent potty training aid, if you're aware of their limitations.  Most importantly, these Blueberry Training Pants are NOT TOTALLY WATERPROOF!  (The product description from the manufacturer is very clear about this).  They contain a hidden polyester panel, which is water-resistant, but not waterproof.  So they will temporarily contain a small accident, and prevent a cascade of urine from running down your child's legs if they're standing up.  However, after a couple of minutes, the fluid will leak through the underpants and onto your child's clothing or whatever they happen to be sitting on.Therefore, Blueberry Training Pants are best suited to a child who is almost fully potty trained, and who only has occasional, small accidents.  However Blueberry Training Pants would probably not be a good fit for your child: (1) if your little-one has just started potty training (and still has frequent accidents or is a heavy wetter); (2) you're taking a long trip or are someplace where frequent bathroom access isn't possible; (3) if you're looking for leak-proof underwear for daytime naps or nighttime sleep.  If you need to prevent moisture from seeping through these training pants, I've found that a good work-around is to pair them with a waterproof diaper cover or shell.  We like the Waterproof Pull On Pants Potty Scotty/PottyPatty, Large.  They're made of waterproof nylon (rather than toxic PVC/vinyl), and they're very thin, so they add waterproofing to any training pants without adding bulk.  If you're looking for a one-stop potty training solution that's completely waterproof (without having to buy 2 separate products), then I would recommend Super Undies Pull-On Potty Training Pant (Medium, The Cupcake Queen), Best Bottom Potty Training Kit (XL/5T, Coconut), or Mumtaz Soakers Nighttime Fully Waterproof Training Pants (available on E T S Y).The main reason I deducted one star from my rating was not because Blueberry training pants aren't completely waterproof, but because they're expensive for non-leak-proof underpants.  They're only a couple of dollars cheaper than Super Undies and Best Bottom training undies, without the benefits of being fully waterproof.  Other than the fact that they're somewhat pricey, I would definitely recommend Blueberry Training Pants for parents who need only partially waterproof underwear for the occasional, small leak.Grade: B+

Contrary to what's stated on the content tag inside this backpack, it's NOT made of 100% polyester.  The front zipper pocket of the backpack has a rear panel that's clearly made of vinyl (PVC), and it gives off a strong chemical smell.  Not something I want around my preschooler, so it's being returned.

Ever since my now 2 year-old daughter was about 18 months old, she has been a heavy overnight wetter.  So much so that she would wake up with wet pajamas and crib sheets 4-5 times per week.  We tried going up a size in her Earth's Best diapers for nighttime, and we even tried the 7th Generation Overnight Diapers, but she would still wake up with wet clothes at least 3 times per week.  A friend of mine suggested I try diaper booster pads to absorb the excess overnight wetness.  At first I tried the Select Kids Booster Pads Diaper Doubler Pack/30, but because they didn't have an adhesive strip to hold them in place, they would slide around inside my daughter's diaper (especially with her wiggling around during diaper changes), and move away from where I needed them to be for maximum absorption.  Then I found these NorthShore Disposable Baby Diaper Doubler pads.  These booster pads have an adhesive strip along the length of the pad, so you can stick the pad firmly in your child's diaper and it won't slide out of place.  It looks sort of like an old-fashioned maxi pad, except that the booster pad allows excess wetness to flow through the pad and into your baby's diaper, whereas maxi pads have a plastic backing that prevents fluid from flowing through to underwear.  (FYI: I wouldn't recommend using a maxi pad as a diaper booster because the moisture-proof backing causes excess urine to spill out of the sides of your little-one's diaper instead of flowing through to the absorbent diaper beneath).  The NorthShore booster pads are fairly thin without sacrificing absorbency, so they don't bunch up between baby's legs even when wet.  And the fact that they're individually wrapped means that they're easy to toss into a diaper bag or suitcase for overnight trips away from home without getting crushed or misshapen.There are 2 caveats that prevent me from giving this product 4 or 5 stars:1.  Although this product is called a "Baby Diaper Doubler" here on Amazon, the actual product packing itself doesn't say anything at all about it being for babies.  It's simply called a "Booster Pad," and the "X-Small" size happens to be small enough to fit babies/toddlers.  Presumably, the larger sizes are designed to fit older children, adults and senior citizens who suffer from incontinence and need extra absorbency in their diapers.  I'm usually wary about using "non-baby" products on babies because products designed for babies tend to be milder and use fewer harsh chemicals.  However, at the time I bought these, I couldn't find any other comparable baby-friendly diaper booster pads on the market, so I decided to give these a try.2.  When my daughter has had an exceptionally wet night, the NorthShore booster pads leave little gel beads on her skin.  Manufacturers of conventional diapers and booster pads claim that these super-absorbent polymer gels are safe and non-toxic, but they still make me uneasy since they're synthetic/artificial materials with mysterious ingredients manufactured in a lab rather than by nature.  Therefore, when my current pack of these NorthShore booster pads is finished, I'm going to try the Flip Inserts: Disposable - 18 pack, which contain more natural materials.Grade: B-

I bought this cup so I could insert a picture of my 2 year-old daughter's favorite cartoon characters, in order to entice her to drink her milk from a straw cup instead of her soft-spout sippy-cup.  The first thing I did upon receiving this product was check the packaging to see whether the plastic cup was BPA-free.  There was no mention of this cup being BPA-free on the packaging, and I couldn't find a recycle code/number on the bottom of the cup.  (Recycle code "7" often identifies polycarbonate plastic, the worst culprit for containing BPA).  This cup was discontinued by Playtex a few years ago, before parents and the general public became fully aware of the dangers of exposing babies and young children to BPA.  Plus the product packaging seemed a bit dated, so I figured that there was a good chance this cup contained BPA.  It just wasn't worth the risk to me, so I returned the cup.  If this cup is in fact BPA-free, it should be clearly stated on the product packaging so parents can make an informed buying choice.Grade: C-

I had high hopes for these Britax EZ-Cling Sun Shades because my 2 year-old had started pulling off the conventional roller/suction-cup shades that we'd been using since she was born.  Unfortunately, however, the Britax EZ Cling shades were no match for the scorching temperatures (over 90-degrees Fahrenheit) or intense, direct sunlight of Southern California.  I parked in an outdoor parking lot around midday while my daughter and I went grocery shopping, and by the time we returned to the car 45 minutes later, the clear plastic film on the back of the shade had started peeling away from the car window glass.  Naturally, my daughter noticed this and proceeded to pull the shade the rest of the way off.The EZ-Cling Shades also had a very strong chemical odor when I removed them from the packaging.  Before buying this item, I actually emailed Britax Customer Service and asked whether the product contained any PVC, phthalates or lead.  I received a very delayed response (only after I called Britax's corporate office to complain) stating that all of Britax's products are free of phthalates and lead.  However, I have a hard time believing that this product is phthalate-free given its strong "plasticky" smell.  (Perhaps it was one of the many other scary chemicals in PVC).  Within 2 minutes of installing one of these window shades in my SUV, the whole car smelled like a chemical factory!  I probably would have ended up returning the product because of its odor even if it had stayed put on my car window, so I suppose it's just as well.Grade: D

Lately, my 2 year-old has started getting a kick out of trying to yank the suction-cup sun shade off the window next to her car seat.  (I had to use all 3 suction cups because the clips that came with the shade were too thick to allow the automatic car window to close).
