Very cool to watch and a brilliant piece of performance art.All in all, the Immersion box set of The Wall is exactly what you would expect: a very well-produced package that does indeed immerse you into the experience of Pink Floyd's The Wall.

After hearing the first single from this album, I was pretty excited about hearing the rest. Sadly, as with so many other artists, the single is the best cut from the album. On the other tracks, Paul's voice sounds rather ragged. With a few notable exceptions (Willie Nelson, to name perhaps the best example of a voice that seems unchanged from 30 years ago) this happens over time. But other artists of the same era have adapted their singing to better fit their changed vocal range. Not McCartney, unfortunately. When he is not singing in his worn normal range, he is switching to a falsetto that is just as worse for wear. It doesn't work, even with studio vocal overdubbing, and about halfway through the album I found myself getting very depressed.While nothing is as distressingly horrible as "Freedom", a few of the songs feel like they are filler. And I remember when McCartney's filler was considered outranking many musicians primary work. Not these toss-offs. Both musically and lyrically, they are just too slapdash for an artist of McCartney's stature. Don't even get me started on the production, I'll just say this: the mixes seem way off on more than one track. I have to agree with others who believe that there is no one around McCartney who has the guys to say "No" or "That really isn't working as well as it could, perhaps we might try this?"I love Paul McCartney, but not this album.

This is an attempt to copy the extremely addictive browser-based games Cookie Clicker. While the original Cookie Clicker is a masterpiece, this is just a shallow attempt to replicate a few features of it. Cookie Tapper is missing a lot of the features that make Cookie Clicker so much fun. Once Orteil (the creator of Cookie Clicker) finishes his Android port of Cookie Clicker, then the real fun will begin. I see a lot of worn-out Android device screens in the future.If you're looking for a fairly simple diversion until Orteil's version comes out, you could do worse than Cookie Tapper. But you could also do better.
Dark. Gritty. Abusive.  Cliffhanger ending.  I am not a fan of cliffhanger endings but I am thoroughly enjoying this three book trilogy.
Dark. Gritty. Abusive.  Cliffhanger ending.  I am not a fan of cliffhanger endings but I am thoroughly enjoying this three book trilogy.
Numerous grammatical errors.  This should've been proof read prior to publication.

This 17 page "Original Summary & Analysis" is written by Serial Publishing NOT E L James.  Grey: Fifty Shades of Grey as told by Christian, is the actual 559 page novel written by Author E L James.I picked this up as a freebie and rolled my eyes at the current marketing ploy to grab unassuming consumers; "Regularly priced at 7.99 Limited time Discount Only 2.99"$7.99 for 17 pages - Seriously?$2.99 for 17 pages - Really?Is it even possible to recap a 559 page novel in only 17 pages?  This recap was nowhere near long enough to serve as a summary and analysis.Buyer Beware

I enjoyed the story but at times it seemed a bit repetitive. This was more of a spanking tale with a little bdsm ("Yes, Sir(s)" and safe words).  The safe words were interesting; white, grey and black instead of the typical standard green, yellow and red. There were some typos that should've been caught prior to publication.2.5 stars
Sixty (60) page book summary. Chapter by chapter short summaries. There is no dialogue. It'skinda like reading cliff notes.

This cooler will hold 16 cans of soda or beer but there is not room for much more (like ice). The cooler is much smaller than one might think. It works well as my lunch box for my 12 hour work shift. I purchased the cooler in green. The color is a lot brighter than in the picture. It is not the softer, muted color as in the photo.
This short m/f/m story was quick paced and steamy.  I read its continuous one scene in about five (5) minutes.

This short story ends abruptly.  I wouldn't even call it a cliffhanger ending.  It just simply ends.  For "romantic erotica" it was not overly steamy.  The very first kiss happened past the 80% mark in this 12 page ongoing series.  The first two installments are currently available.1. Kidnapped By The Highland Prince: The Highlander's Captive Series Book One -  $2.99 / 12 pages2. The Highland Prince's Captive Lover: The Highlander's Captive Series Book Two - $2.99 / 12 pagesI will not be continuing on with this series.  The first two available "books" combined together are only 24 pages in length; $5.98 is way overpriced (IMO).

Twenty-eight (28) inches long?  I read it again, yep, 28 inches long.  It doesn't take a mathematician to do the math and realize that 28 inches is longer than two (2) rulers combined!  Was twenty-eight inches a typo, or a huge unbelievable embellishment?  Hopefully, the author also made the guy with 28 inches at least 8 feet tall, otherwise the head of his 28 inches might be peeking out from the bottom of one his pant legs!There are a lot of grammatical errors in this. I definitely do not recommend it, unless of course you want a good laugh.  Twenty-eight inches, I am still chuckling at that (and rolling my eyes)!
Lysol Cling Gel toilet bowl cleaner works great and smells fresh.  It's the only toilet bowl cleaner that I buy.
I use this lightly scented antibacterial soap in my guest bathroom.  It is pretty, matches my decor and works great.
This cheese shaker is a great addition to my Princess House Orchard Medley collection.  I keep seasoning salt in mine instead of cheese.
My 70-lb airedale loves Whimzees.  He usually devours one in about 15 minutes (once he gets done tossing it in the air).  I think they do a pretty good job in helping to keep his teeth clean.
Sage and Citrus is one of my favorite scents from Yankee Candle.  I love the strength of the scent and how many hours of fragrance the large jar provides.
Clean Cotton is one of my favorite scents from Yankee Candle.  I love the strength of the scent and how many hours of fragrance the large jar provides.
Very pretty, very classy.  I love the princess heritage design.  The glass is very delicate and somewhat thin compared to other iced tea goblets from Princess House.
Very pretty Fantasia poinsettia design.  This dinner plate is microwaveable and dishwasher safe.

Gorgeous moisturizer is made from organic ingredients and works well as a moisturizer. It's pricey but effective. I got mine directly from the manufacturer for less than ninety dollars plus six dollars shipping.

The book ends with three little words;TOBECONTINUED......Happy for now ending - but it you want another installment of the story be prepared to buy book 2 (currently available), books 3 and 4.I really enjoyed "Addict." The battery and charger are not included in this Factory Reconditioned Ryobi blower.  If you don't care about being able to use it cordless then perhaps a factory reconditioned blower is right for you.  I will say however that we found the air flow (blower) wasn't nearly as powerful as we wanted it to be when using our blower plugged in to an extension cord.------------------------*We purchased our Ryobi blower (P2107) brand new from a local home depot - battery and charger included.*We opted for this model because it is a hybrid. It can be used either cordless or corded. We wanted a cordless blower because no matter how careful "we" were, part of the extension cord would always end up in our swimming pool. Now, using this blower cordless it is no longer a problem.After we bought it my husband then decided to read reviews (not on Amazon). One review that he came upon said that the battery life only lasts eight minutes, so we decided to time the battery. Guess what? Eight minutes later the blower quits. It is out of battery. Back on the charger went the battery. It takes one hour for the battery to recharge.The air flow wasn't as strong as our previous blower either (even with it plugged in on our extension cord). My husband was a bit disappointed. We are going to keep this blower and invest in a more powerful corded one and then only use this one strictly for blowing off our pool deck or touching up our driveway.I like that the blower is lightweight and I don't have to struggle with wrapping up an extra long extension cord when I do our pool deck, patio or driveway.

There was no mention of the waiter returning with a booster seat.  That detail was dropped.  If this is a true script then it should've been included in the script.3. "Congratulations men! I was not a fan of the script format in this short 58 page novella.  Reading it as a script, I found myself wondering just who really talks the way it was written.  Reading it as a  book, there are numerous grammatical errors that should've been caught and fixed prior to publication.Here is one example:"Carlos(Looks at Jacob with disbelief) I ought of slap you over the head for thinking such nonsense.  We have been friends from since kids . You are a brother to me.JacobYea, I know."Here is another example:"JacobWhat sup?"And a third example:"PilotWelcome aboard lady and gentlemen.  Please buckle up your seat belts.  We will be parting shortly."Any pilot that says, "We will be parting shortly" is not a pilot that I would want to be flying with.  The correct word is "departing."  So, is this a grammatical error or an uneducated pilot?  I'm thinking grammatical error because with all of the education the FTA requires of pilots, I highly doubt one would find a licensed pilot who speaks as it was written in this novella.

The author has compiled a review of his own contributions to physics and cosmology.  These include a number of speculative thoughts, including his simple formula for the mass of a wide range of the elementary particles known as Hadrons (i.e. Mesons and Baryons).  This formula for mass=m(n+1/2)137 MeV, where m and n are integers (p.146), is successfully compared with the experimental values of particle masses on pp.148-156.  Apparently this formula has yet to have a large impact on the physics community, as the journal article in which it was introduced has only received 2 citations.  Other speculative theories addressed in this volume include the Feynman-Wheeler treatment of advanced and retarded fields (pp.6-7).It is not clear who is the intended audience for this book--and unlike most books there is no mention of such an audience in the preface.  At the very least the reader would need the equivalent of a B.S. in physics to benefit from this book at all.  Graduate level courses in quantum mechanics  would be necessary to understand many of the topics.  An understanding of quantum field theory would also help the reader in appreciate many of the author's observations.This almost 300-page book is filled with about 1000 equations (i.e. several per page)  and 455 references--but there are no figures--not one--not even a Feynman diagram!  It is almost like a stream of consciousness account of the author's thoughts--which are therefore difficult for the reader to follow.  Nevertheless, this book is appealing to some degree, from the discussion of dark matter (p.28; a topic to which the author seems to have made an important contribution) to an explanation of something as conventional as positively-charged carriers (i.e. holes) in a semiconductor (p.35).  There is an interesting discussion comparing the thoughts of the ancient Greeks on atomic theory and cosmology with that of Vedic India (p.1).  I was also amused by the author's observation that the range of the Yukawa potential for the photon (given the extremely small estimated mass of the photon) is approximately the radius of the universe (p.140).

This is a pretty easy introduction to Spanish that consists of a series of dialogues and vocabulary lists interspersed with brief treatments of grammar.  The dialogues cover many of the basic situations that you might encounter as a tourist, including registering at a hotel, ordering at a restaurant, buying plane and train tickets, and giving a taxi driver the address of your destination.  Visiting the doctor is also addressed by a dialogue.The CD that comes with the book is generally very helpful.  The parts of the book (chiefly dialogues) that are covered by the CD are marked by a CD symbol in the text.  In some cases, however, the dialogues marked as occurring in the CD are not, in fact, on the CD.  The largest oversight of this sort is found on pages 53-60; the six dialogues that appear on these pages would all seem to be on track 5.  Actually these six dialogues do not appear on the CD at all!  Fortunately, the dialogues that are missing are sufficiently simple that their absence is not really a problem.

Authors Akire and Rosen provide the reader with very satisfying insights into the origin and evolution of the romance languages.  This book opens with the reduction of the nine-vowel system to the seven-vowel system, using Italian, Spanish, and French as examples (pp.9-15).  With this discussion, the focus continues on these three particular romance languages through the first half of the book.A very interesting example of consonant weakening is seen to correspond to the initial f in Spanish taking on the value of a silent h.  In this way the Latin ferro (iron) transforms into hierro.  This change is explained in terms of the claim that h and f were considered allophones (i.e. variants of the same basic sound) by early Spanish speakers (p.51).French is given as an example of some the most surprising and far-ranging changes.  The palatalized labials via, vie, and bia that terminate Latin words are transformed into ge in French.  In this way serviente (assistant) becomes sergeant and rabia becomes rage (p.71).The authors also provide the solution to a puzzle that had commanded my attention when I first started learning Italian: that of the third person singular and plural endings brought on by the conditional tense.  It is shown that what began in Latin as cantare habebat (would sing) collapses into catarebbe in Italian (pp.171-172).The second half of the book discusses the evolution of Portuguese and Romanian as well as a brief narrative on the emergence of the romance vernaculars.  An index of linguistic terms is also provided.

Author Dieter Straub has penned this book with the intension of acquainting the reader with a different framework for addressing problems in engineering and physics, many of which deal with thermodynamics and kinetics.  Much of the work to which he alludes concerns an extension of the thermodynamics of J. Willard Gibbs by Gottfried Falk.  It should also be noted that Falk's work is principally in German, making Straub's treatment of Falk's ideas particularly valuable to the English-speaking world.He sees fit to compile these thoughts into nine chapters, which bear the names of the nine Valkyries:1) Gerhilde: Physics Today: Perspectives2) Ortlinde: Falkian Dynamics: An Introduction3) Waltraute: Motion and Matter4) Schwertleite: Systems and Symmetries5) Helmwige: Barriers and Balances6) Siegrune: Non-equilibrium Processes7) Grimgerde: General Equation of Motion and Its Approximations8) Rossweise: Paradigmata Are the Winners Dogmata9)  Bruenhilde: Gibbs-Falkian ElectromagnetismChapter 1 outlines how the treatment of non-equilibrium phenomena has evolved over time.  The discussion particularly highlights the work of Gibbs on thermodynamics and the claim that his treatment has been erroneously relegated to the realm of thermostatics (pp.19,21).In Chapter 2 the author introduces what Falk calls the Massieu-Gibbs (M-G) functions, in which the four quantities of internal energy (U), volume (V), entropy (S), and number of atoms in the system (n) are expressed in terms of one another (p.39).  A good illustration of Falk's approach is in resolving Gibb's paradox (pp.65-67).Chapter 3 introduces the Euler-Reech Equation, which adds to Gibbs equation for internal energy by including the flow velocity (p.73).  Here it is shown that while the flow velocity is independent of most other thermodynamic variables (e.g. pressure, volume, and entropy), it is not independent of the chemical potential (p.75).Chapter 4 reviews Noethers theorem and phase equilibrium.In Chapter 5 the balance in the title refers to the balance between forces represented by the Gibbs-Euler Functions (GEFs), while the barriers would seem to be those that must be surmounted by phase transformations.Chapter 6 introduces the Dissipation Theorem, which deals with the splitting of the energy flux density (j) into vectors representing the rate of heat transfer (q) and the rate of work (w) (p.173).Chapter 7 deals with models of fluid flow, including the Navier-Stokes equation (p.214).Chapter 8 (written with help from Michael Lauster) addresses more problems in fluid fluid, one of which include a treatment of Lorentz attractors from Chaos theory (p.232).  The authors note that Edward Norton Lorenz, "the father of chaos theory," was a meteorologist interested in climate forecasting.  Accordingly, the authors discuss Lorenz's model of convection between two free surfaces of different temperature, analogous to the situation encountered in modeling weather.Chapter 9 deals with Falks treatment of charge and current densities (p.280)The author also includes an appendix dedicated to a history of atomism that begins with Greek natural philosophy.  Its treatment of Renaissance science mentions a book by Galileo, Il Saggiatore, which introduces a kinetic theory of matter (p.327).  As was the case for some of his other intellectual ventures, Galileos version of kinetic theory attracted the unwanted attention of the Catholic Church.  Apparently many in the Church were concerned that Galileos theories interfered with prevailing notions regarding the substance of the Holy Eucharist.

This film chronicles the personal/sex lives of two college best friends and roommates from the late 1940s to the early 1970s. Art Garfunkel plays Sandy, the more shy and reserved of the two, while Jack Nicholson takes on the role of Jonathan, who begins his college years as a sort of lady's man in training.  Their social lives as college students consist of an interesting dynamic, with the two sharing thoughts regarding their romantic dreams, strategies, and conquests.  Jonathan, with his flat-out ambition to get laid at all costs, naturally scores well in advance of Sandy.  On the other hand, Sandy is the first to discover that women are often able to tell you thoughts that you never knew you hada curious milestone that maddeningly eludes Jonathans grasp.As the years go on, Sandy leads a conventional life married to his college sweetheart (Candace Bergen), who he later divorces.  Jonathan, however, seems unable to visualize a life beyond a series of conquestswhile growing increasingly intimidated  (to the point of impotence) by the sexual demands of a new generation of empowered women.  Even Jonathans discovery of a woman endowed with what he considers the ideal physical proportions (as embodied by actress Anne Margaret), ultimately leaves him frustrated and isolated.I am left wondering how Jonathans life would play out if this story were reimagined in todays world with the presence of Viagra and other ED drugs!  My guess is that he would still be frustratedwhile yearning for the invention of a Viagra of the Soul.

This book is of particular interest to me because part of my family were Quakers who founded Philadelphia under the leadership of William Penn.  About 50 years ago my maternal grandfather gave me a copy of a page he had typed that traced our family tree down to John Key, the first child born (in 1682) in William Penn's colony.  My grandfather's record indicated that our Quaker forefather "lived in cave near the Elm tree where Penn made the treaty with the Indians."  My grandfather's record also indicated that John Key was buried in Old Kenneth Cemetery.  In addition to reading the information passed onto me by my grandfather, I had read about my ancestor in other books as well as online.  I was interested to find a section in this book entitled "Cave-born John Key" in this book (p.40).  In addition, I was interested to see that the author had included an artist's rendering of these caves, which were actually holes dug into the bank of the Delaware River by the first settlers (p.42).  It is also reported by the author that some of these caves or "grottos" were abandoned by their original inhabitants as soon as they could build more proper wooden homes.  The caves were then occupied by the next waves of inhabitants who often used them as gambling dens or brothels.  The author indicates that the caves were exposed as veritable dens of iniquity as early as 1685 (p.41)!  Decades later, these caves became basements of stores and houses situated between Front and Water Streets.
I just used this cable for my Power Smart Snow Thrower.  The outside temperature was 25 F and the cable remained flexible.  The orange color helped me keep track of the cable in the snow.

I just used this for the first time to clear 6" of snow from my driveway.  I did the clearing of the driveway tonight, just a few hours after the snow in the Washington DC area had finished falling, before the snow could harden.  The snow blower did well when clearing this relatively dry, freshly fallen snow at a temperature of about 25 F.  It had trouble with compacted snow at the end of our driveway that was heaped up by the snowplow--which tended to clog the chute.  So this is a useful tool when used on snow that has not been compacted.
This olive oil has a wonderful taste that makes it easy to distinguish from other olive oils.  I think that I would describe it's taste as rich, smooth, and buttery.

Author Steven Brams considers the situations described in the Hebrew Bible (i.e. Old Testament) within the context of game theory.  In doing so, he addresses a number of important questions ranging from the nature of the God of the Hebrew Bible, to the nature of the faith of His worshipers.  The author arrives at a number of interesting conclusions as he unravels the strategies adopted by biblical characters.  One inescapable conclusion is that the Hebrew God, although possibly omnipresent, is not omnipotent--for it is the limited scope of His power that would seem to motivate his full participation in these game-like scenarios.  As for His adherents, the nature of their faith is seen to fall somewhat short of complete and monolithic--indeed it is their doubts that often seem to motivate God to modify his demands in order to better inspire their faith.  The author also goes so far as to consider faith more of a "dominant" strategy than a state of mind or quality of soul.  That is, "being faithful means that one's rational strategy is independent of the strategy of other players" (p.37).The doubts of the faithful include those of Eve regarding the death that would seem to immediately follow eating fruit from the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil, as well as the expectation that God would allow Abraham's sacrifice of Isaac to be consummated.  In addition, these doubts are seen to give rise to the counter-arguments that the faithful often direct towards God.  Adam points out that the forbidden fruit seemed less than completely suspect because it came from the hand of Eve--the very helpmate that God fashioned from his own flesh.  As for Cain and his slaying of brother Abel, Cain's somewhat insolent remark that he is not his "brother's keeper" is meant to show that the actual "keeper" is God, who set up this seminal sibling rivalry by his summary rejection of Cain's offering.

Davies' Ph.D thesis work and associated publications with the Wheeler-Feynman (WF) Theorem, which placed emitters of particles on equal footing with absorbers--an approach that was inspired by the existence of both retarded and advanced solutions to the wave equation in general and that of electromagnetic waves in particular.  It is of interested that the WF view has been taken yet another step further by the development of the Transactional Interpretation (TI) of quantum mechanics proposed by John Cramer in 1986 and then taken a bit further by Ruth Kastner in her fairly recent publications and even more recent book The Transactional Interpretation of Quantum Mechanics: The Reality of Possibility.In addition to the WF Theorem, Davies addresses time and reversibility in terms of thermodynamics, statistical mechanics, and special relativity.

As indicated by some of the other reviewers, this book would not be your best choice for beginning New Testament Greek.  The approach of Porter et al. is almost diametrically opposite to that of Dobson's Learn New Testament Greek--where the reader is introduced to NT readings of increasing difficultly, with more grammar added at each stage.  Instead, the approach of Porter et al. is that of discussing the grammar first and then using the understanding of grammar to parse individual sentences--the first parsing of which does not occur until page 42.  Over the course of its more than 400 pages, Porter never exposes the reader to more than one contiguous NT verse at a time.Nevertheless, I find Porter et al. to be useful as a reference, as well as a way to advance my understanding of NT Greek beyond that which I gleaned from Dobson.  I have used Porter et al. to look up a word in the index, locate the chapter in that word occurs, and find the table with the relevant conjugation or declension.

This 432 page book is divided into 40 chapters--each of which begins with a dialogue that provides one or more grammatical lessons.  For example, the dialogue in chapter 7 illustrates the present tense of "ere" verbs.  The verb charts, glossary, and index at the back of the book are also useful.  The glossary, though generally helpful, is somewhat inadequate in that it fails to list many of the words that occur in the dialogues and exercises.  The exercises themselves are very helpful and include solutions so that the reader can check his answers.

I originally bought the 12" pliers to use in removing the trap to my bathroom sink--and it worked well for that purpose.  Tonight I also used the 12" pliers to remove the hoses from my outdoor faucets so I could cover the faucets in advance of the cold weather overnight.  One of my hoses had a plastic coupling that was screwed onto the outdoor faucet very tightly, but with these pliers I was able to easily unscrew it.

I have been looking for short stories in Italian, but most of my searches turn up "dual language" books.  I, however, do not want a dual language book, where the original Italian page would be adjacent to page containing its English translation.  I find that there is too much of a temptation to glance over to the English page rather than carefully dissecting the Italian page.  This book contains 11 stories spanning a total of 118 pages, with the longest stories taking up twenty odd pages; the shortest taking up a mere 4-7 pages.  Stories of this length seem appropriate for those reading at a level equivalent to four semesters of college Italian.The stories that I particularly enjoyed are the following:"La Bandiera"--A public fracas ensues over the display of a monarchist Italian flag in the Fascist Italy of the 1930's."Marzo 1999: A 25 anni dalla partenza"--The account of an event or large party put on by "L'Idea", the author's magazine."Il Filosofo"--A brief sketch of a consummate professional and his unique work ethic."Welcome to the United States"--The arrival of Italian immigrants early 20th century New York, along with an account of the accompanying ocean voyage."Il Telefono Giallo"--A story first published in 1984 that seems to anticipate some aspects of the iPhone and its digital personality "Siri".

For anyone with some acquaintance with Hebrew and Akkadian, this book is truly wonderful!  As pointed out by the author in the introduction, much more is known about Akkadian than ancient Hebrew--due to the preservation of hundreds of thousand of  Akkadian cuneiform tablets.  It is great fun to peruse this book and look up the Hebrew words you encounter in your reading of biblical Hebrew--as well as to look up words that just pop into your head.  Also included is a lexicon of biblical Aramaic, an index of biblical names, and a list of Akkadian words and their Hebrew equivalents.The discussion of Hebrew in this book is greatly enriched by phrases illustrating Akkadian cognates.  One of the most illuminating and timeless is an Akkadian phrase cited in reference to the Hebrew word for testicle (ishku in Akkadian,p.39): "if a woman should crush a man's testicle during a quarrel."  The name for God "El Shaddai" is noted as related to the Akkadian word for mountain "shadu"--suggesting that the name is that of a mountain god.

This is an amazing movie.  The viewer feels the depth of the chasm that exists between a widowed Chinese man visiting his grown daughter in America--even though the dialogue is almost entirely in Chinese with English subtitles.  Both the father and the daughter have had difficult lives--the difficulties of which each keeps from the other.  How the two slowly comes to terms with each others lives and disappointments makes for an emotionally intense story.The film has a few light and subtly comic moments as well, including a visit by young Mormon missionaries that come by the apartment and attempt to explain to the old Chinese man (with limited English) what they regard as the universal truths espoused by their religion.I also enjoyed the conversions that the old man had on a park bench with an older Iranian woman who also has an Americanized grown child.  Despite the broken English that was their means of communication, it was striking how well these two older people understood one another.

I used this tool to clear my bathroom sink.  It worked successfully, but when I used it to try to make my tub drain better, the cable got tangled up inside the drum.  Fortunately, there are four screws you can undo to open the drum.  After opening the drum I was able to untangle the cable out in my back yard.  I then screwed the drum shut again and wound the cable back inside the drum.I found it hard to maintain enough pressure on the trigger to wind the cable in and out, so I tied an old sweat sock around the handle and trigger to help apply enough pressure.

I have a longstanding interest in Viking-era Norse society, language, and exploration.  I have even gone so far as to read accounts of Viking exploration in the original Old Norse excerpts found in Gordon's book An Introduction to Old Norse.  I was therefore particularly interested in the author's discussion of the Norse colonies In Iceland, Greenland, and North America.  These Norse colonies suffered three different fates.  Iceland proved to be sustainable and exists to this day.  The original Norse colony of Greenland existed from 986 to about 1500.  The North American colony of Vinland might have persisted for a decade in two around 1000 A.D.  It is well-known that Vinland settlers decamped back to Greenland because of hostilities involving the Native Americans they encountered.  The eventual collapse of Norse Greenland is generally traced to the so-called "Little Ice Age" that shortened the growing and a grazing seasons to level unable to sustain an agricultural society.  Iceland, of course, was able hang on.The author completes these stories with a number of less-known or rarely-considered observations and factors.  For the case of Greenland, the author points out the incredibly high overhead of maintaining the style of European society favored by its Norse inhabitants.  An enormous amount of resources were devoted to ecclesiastical dictates: from cathedral building way beyond that required for the small 5000 person colony, to tithes--including additional "tithes" for supporting the Crusades in the Middle East.  Clearly, Norse Greenland would have done much better to trade for utilitarian goods than for massive stained glass windows and liturgical vestments!  The author also points out that the ability of Iceland to sustain itself was greatly augmented by the recognition of the need to care for the poor soils of their volcanic island.

The movie makes me wonder how many drummers were left behind when their band leaps to stardom.  I was a young teen when the Beatles first came to the States and remember reading that Ringo had been preceded by Pete Best--an event which British fans greeted with the jeer "Pete forever, Ringo never!"  However, for Rain Wilson's character "Fish" no fan backlash marked the producer's push to replace him in the band "Vesuvius" with his nephew "Sticks"!  Even Fish's superhuman chase of his erstwhile bandmates is to no avail.  The poor guy is left to labor at a call center for 20 years before the next chance at fame comes a calling--in the unlikely guise of his own nephew's Matt (played by Josh Gad) garage ban: ADD!This film has a great cast, including Christina Applegate as the mom of ADD's brooding front man and song writer Curtis, played by actual musician and songwriter Teddy Geiger.  Emma Stone play's Amelia, the band's sullen bass guitar.  The members of Vesuvius: Lex, Kerr, Trash, and Sticks, are played by Will Arnett, Fred Armisen, Bradley Cooper, and Lonny Ross.  Jane Lynch takes the role of Fish's acerbic mother.  Jason Sudeikis is remarkably smarmy as ADD's ethically-challenged agent.Be on the look out for Fish's inspiration to push a song in an up tempo direction in their first recording session.

Over the years I have found Jackson to be more than an essential textbook, it is also a wonderful resource for research.  As a graduate student almost forty years ago, I found its treatment of plasma oscillations (pp.335-339) to be a good introduction to one of my research topics: solid state plasmons.  Over the past month I have found Jackson's discussion of boundary value problems in dielectrics (especially for  a point charge, pp.110-113) to provide a good background for the analogous treatment of the mechanical problem of a dislocation at a boundary of two materials with different elastic constants.I should also add that Jackson's mandatory graduate E&M course was well regarded by the graduate students in the physics department in the 1970's at University of Illinois.  I also had the opportunity to speak with Prof. Jackson about my Ph.D. research topic and found his comments very helpful.

The "dinner" is for the ants--the "show" for you!  Really, this product is worth the price for its entertainment value alone!The main thing that you need to watch for, however, is a factor that other reviewers have mentioned--namely the tendency for the liquid to thicken or harden after 8 hours or more, therefore making it harder for the ants to consume.  So, try not to put more than the ants can eat.  This is hard to judge, of course, since the ants mob the stuff when you first put it out.  Ants often seem to cluster around the hardened liquid--even when fresh liquid is near by, which is another aspect of the problem.  I noticed that one ambitious ant actually cut off a line of the hardened liquid and struggled to drag it back to the nest--a comic possibility that I would never have considered!When I bought this product, we had ants coming into our kitchen though two different doors leading outside.  After two weeks of using Terro, the ants were completely gone.This product is also available at Home Depot for less than four bucks!

I particularly identified with the aspect of this movie that portrayed the conflict between working scientists (like Jodie's Foster's character Ellie) and the suits (like Tom Skerritt's administrative flunky).  Skerritt's flunky cuts off the funding for Ellie's project to search for signals from alien civilizations using radio telescopes.  Ellie then secures a source of private funds. When Ellie finally detects a signal from an extraterrestrial civilization broadcasting from the vicinity of the star Vega, however, the flunky and his government cronies rush in to claim credit!

Rubbing this little gray stick on the rust stain on the rim of our toilet transformed it from something out of a gas-station rest room to what would be acceptable in a proper home acceptable for out-of-town guests!  It only takes a few minutes for the voids in the solid pumice to cut through the stain!

This 9"x11" 111-page book provides the reader with a detailed description of the development and operational capabilities of the famous Me 262 German WW2 jet aircraft.  This discussion of the aircraft is accompanied with a wealth of beautiful photographs and diagrams that really bring the Me 262 to life!Pages 1-13 provide an overview of the aircraft and its place in military aviation history.Pages 14-51 provide a diary of the development of the Me 262 from Messerschmidt "receiving the first information about turbo-jet propulsion" in 1937 to its use as a jet fighter in Autumn 1944 to Spring 1945. The initial prototypes are discussed on pp.14-25, beginning in Autumn 1938 and ending on July 18, 1942.  It is interesting to note that the development of the fuselage was completed before that of the wings and jet engines.  A propeller-driven version, the Me 262 V1, was first flight tested on April 18, 1942.  The first jet-propelled Me 262 V1 is tested on March 25, 1942, with the propeller-driven capability retained as a precautionary measure--a fortunate decision, as the BMW P 3302 engines failed immediately after takeoff (p.23)!  The first successful flight under jet power would have to wait until July 18, 1942 (p.25).  The testing of the proper jet-propelled Me 262 is seen to range from Summer 1942 to Summer 1944, with a number of "setbacks and advances" (pp.30-51).Pages 51-79 give operational details and a description of the range of armaments and special features available for various Me 262 models.  Of particular interest is a version with a 50 mm canon that projects at least 6 ft. from the nose of the aircraft (p.65)!Pages 80-96 consist mostly of large color photographs of the Me 262, inside and out.  In addition, pp.86-87 span the official colored drawling of the aircraft from the graphics department of Messerschmidt AG, Augsburg (1944).Pages 97-106 describe the production of the Me 262, including the implementation of decentralized production designed to cope with the damage done by Allied bombing.  A complete set of production figures are included (p.106).Pages 107-111 consists of an Appendix that includes the design layout and performance graphs.

While reading Ingrid Daubechies' Ten Lectures on Wavelets (CBMS-NSF Regional Conference Series in Applied Mathematics) I came upon a reference to Battle's treatment of quantum field theory (QTF), which led me to Battle's treatment of wavelets and renormalization.  Battle divides his book into five chapters.  Chapter 1 (pp.1-104) is a brief introduction to QTF, whereas Chapter 2 (pp.105-178) introduces wavelets.  Chapter 3 (pp.179-280) deals with topics found in solid state physics such as phase transformations, spin systems, and Landau mean field theory.  Chapter 4 (281-400) gets into the real meat of this book and discusses the renormalization group in terms of wavelets.  The final Chapter (Ch.5: pp.401-512) is devoted to Euclidean field theory.

One of the central attributes of a good reference book is its ability to direct the reader to the item for which he is searching.  Gehke's compact (~300 page) guide to Fortran 95 accomplishes this goal with short but complete descriptions of Fortran language and concepts, backed by an easily searchable 12-page index.

I once had a conversation with Gert Ehrlich regarding the genesis of his research work.  He joked that his career began with research on the tungsten filaments that supported the development of electronic vacuum tube technology at General Electric's flagship research lab in Schenectady NY.  He went on to observe that this research program collapsed into apocalyptic obsolescence with the advent of semiconductor electronics.  This tragic turn of events forced all those whose careers were supported by tungsten-based technology to find another line of work--and thus surface science was born--especially surface science of refractory metal surfaces!  As so Ehrlich and his colleagues streamed out of the sinking ship of Tungsten-bound electronics, manned with the modern techniques of ultra-high vacuum (UHV) learned at the feet of GE luminary Irving Langmuir!  For Ehrlich, his sanctuary was that of the isolated prairie enclave of the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana--where he assumed the position of full professor in 1968.  And so, 40-odd years later, we see what Gert Ehrlich and his colleague Grazyna Antczak have wrought!Although the field ion microscope (FIM) images of atomic configurations are seductively beautiful, the UHV environment necessary for such experiments is a harsh mistress!  Think of the generations of graduate students and post-docs laboring to bake and outgas their UHV FIM systems (a process taking about a week) only to burn out the filament on the first attempt at depositing adatoms on the FIM sample!  Think of the thousands upon thousands of FIM images recorded--and each one just to determine the position of a single diffusing adatom.  Think of all of the patient waiting while the adatom diffuses a few atomic steps while the tip is annealed!  It is intimidating to contemplate the degree of tedious observation, equipment repair, and troubleshooting required for these experiments!Nevertheless, and in spite of the tragedy of wasted youth laboring in Midwestern oblivion, this book is wonderfully beguiling!  The pioneering FIM surface diffusion measurements of Ehrlich and Hudda for the W(211) plane in 1966 were refined over the course of later investigations (p.211-212, ref.82), first by Graham and Ehrlich in 1975 (ref.84) and later by Flahive and Graham in 1980 (ref.85)--with the latter revealing a slight dependence of the activation energy on the width of the plane.  Senft and Ehrlich (pp.124-127, refs.169-171) were even able to show that diffusing adatoms were able to execute acrobatic jumps that actually soared over adjacent surface bonding sites!  John Wrigley (p.29, refs.28,29; p.90, ref.47) even used Rob Chamber's specially-designed atom probe (p.28, ref.27) to discover that diffusing adatoms could exchange with those (of different elemental composition) constituting the surface.The technique of scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) invented by Nobel laureates Rohr and Binnig in the the early 1980's were later joined with the FIM techniques developed by Erwin Muller in the mid 1950's to complete this magnum opus.  The authors review of atomic imaging techniques is very comprehensive--they even see fit to observe that an early version of STM was developed by Russ Young in 1972 (pp.31,60, ref.45), a fact that seems generally known to only Young's contemporary fellow scientists at the National Bureau of Standards (now NIST) in Gaithersburg MD.One final and ironic observation is that even the semiconductor world eventually looked to the work of Ehrlich and Schwoebel on metallic diffusion near a surface step in order to better understand the growth of electronic device layers.  I feel certain that this book, and the hundred and hundreds of works sited at the end each chapter, will be aggressively mined for the rest of this century and beyond!

As stated by the author in the first sentence of her redoubtable treatise (p.1), "The wavelet transform is a tool that cuts up data or functions or operators into different frequency components, and then studies each component with a resolution matched to its scale."  She goes on to trace the evolution of this mathematical tool, that is seen to rely (in the case of Meyer wavelets, p.119) on "quasi-miraculous cancellations."  Sigrid Daubechies' contribution was that of developing an algorithm for defining a wavelet function that did not suffer from the drawbacks of previously-defined analytical or digital functions.  Analytical functions, while usually sufficiently smooth, are not truncated in temporal or configuration space--nor are the associated temporal or spacial frequencies commonly accessed by Fourier transforms (p.4).  On the other hand, digital functions such as square waves or step functions (or the Haar wavelet, p.15) are often not sufficiently smooth.  As the author observes on the first line of Chapter 6 (p.167) "Except for the Haar basis, all examples of orthonormal wavelet bases in the previous chapter consisted of infinitely supported functions."  Daubechies, however, was able to unravel the Gordian knot by defining discrete/digital wavelets (pp.53-105) that are both sufficiently smooth and naturally truncated or "compact" (i.e. "compactly supported," pp.194-199).The author lucidly derives and proves the incredible properties of what have come to be called Daubechies wavelets--thereby convincing the reader that these amazing mathematical entities actually exist!  It is difficult, however, to digest every proof laid out by the author.  I would therefore suggest that the reader begin with the most interesting proofs, which are found in the first section (5.1, pp.127-137) of Chapter 5: "Orthonormal bases of wavelets and multiresolution analysis."  The reader should pay particular attention to p.132, which introduces the trigonometric polynomial m0(u), the properties of which are further detailed on pp.155, 168, and 216.For those of us who are not heavily involved in signal and image processing, however, Daubechies' book is a difficult place to begin one's study of wavelets.  A better starting place for the novice would be an introductory textbook such as that of Burrus et al.: Introduction to Wavelets and Wavelet Transforms: A Primer.  In reading Burrus along with Daubechies, however, the reader needs to keep in mind that the two books use different notations for expressing wavelets and scaling functions (Daubechies p.130; Burrus p.15), such that scaling parameter as used in one book's notation is the reciprocal of that defined by the other.A good overview of the field is also provided by Hubbard's The World According to Wavelets: The Story of a Mathematical Technique in the Making, Second Edition.  It is also necessary that the reader have an understanding of Fourier transforms at the level of Bracewell's The Fourier transform and its applications (McGraw-Hill electrical and electronic engineering series).I should also note that Daubechies' subject index spans only two pages--which is not nearly long enough!  The shortcomings of the index and the detailed nature of this monograph limit its usefulness as a reference book.  Therefore, the reader needs to buy his own copy of Daubechies and mark it up to his heart's content, including notes on the title page (and the pages immediately following it) that may supplement the subject index.

The authors of this 1994 monograph cite 583 references as they draw on a wide range of research beginning with the 17th century work of Bertolini and Huygens on elastic twinning of calcite (p.66).  The work on calcite interested many researchers in the 19th century, including Brewster (1816), Kelvin, and Voigt (1890).Soviet researcher (and co-author of this book) R. I. Garber was prominent among those advancing this study in the 20th century, especially as he was the first to observe reversible plasticity--using optical microscopy to discover reversible twinning in calcite and sodium nitrate published between 1938 and 1947 (p.68).  Garber also seemed to be the first to observe the petal-like shape of the twinned region (p.69), the profile of which drew the attention of Soviet theoreticians interested in its elastic properties and dislocation theory, including Lifshitz (1948) and this volume's coauthor V. S. Boyko in the 1960's and 70's (Ch.2: pp.23-65).The contributions of modern researchers in Western Europe and American are also covered, including that of Christian, Cottrell, and Frank in the U.K. in the 1950's and 60's.  Clarence "Marv" Wayman at the University of Illinois and Greg Olson at MIT used microanalytical techniques with great success in the study of martensitic transformations and the shape memory effect in the 1970's (Ch.5 pp.149-173).  Wayman even went so far to have his own transmission electron microscope for the exclusive use of his group at University of Illinois--an instrument that was never even seen by graduate student electron microscopists outside of his group.  I also recall Professor Wayman demonstrating a heat-engine involving a shape-memory wire moving through an array of pulleys that drew it through a liquid that I assume was held at a temperature different from that of the room.  Greg Olson spent the first part of his career at MIT, receiving his undergraduate degree from MIT in 1970, his Ph.D. in 1974, and then serving as a member of technical staff at MIT until he became a professor at Northwestern in 1988.  When I met Greg Olson in the early 1980's he told me about his use of field ion microscopy in the study of martensite.More recent work includes the study of high-Tc superconducting oxides and metals (a research of area of co-author A. M Kossevich), where the ability to reverse twin formation is expected to reduce the deleterious effect of these twins on superconductivity (pp.254-261).

The author provides the reader with a careful survey of the New Testament writings that have come to represent the life and teachings of Jesus.  In doing so, he asks us to imagine the world that was the source of these writings--one that existed well before modern printing, editing, and journalism.  He makes it clear that the various writers who composed the Gospels, Pauline letters, and so fourth were often unaware of each others writings; while at other times they borrowed from each others work.  The working of these many hands led to various issues becoming clouded.  For example, was the kingdom of God immediately at hand and about to arrive before the last of the disciples died, or was this event to occur in the distant future?  It also seemed that the Pauline letters were written without any knowledge of Jesus' supposed biography.  Such discrepancies are in keeping with the account of a life that is largely legendary--which is the central and well-argued point of the author.The discussion of the Gospel of Mark is of particular interest.  It is generally believed that Mark was written before the other four Gospels, and that the Gospels Matthew and Luke borrowed heavily from Mark.  Therefore, Mark is closer to the origin of the Jesus legend than the other Gospels.  The author views Mark as a literary work where drama is enhanced at the expense of realism.  For example, the disciples are shown as unable to understand Jesus' parables--which made them seem impossibly dull!  This dullness, however, served a dramatic purpose in that they were later able to understand after the Resurrection.  He also observes that some aspects of the Gospel of Mark may reflect the conflict between Christian and Jewish communities during the time that the book was written (70-100 AD?)--rather than the situation characteristic of 30 AD Palestine.  I would also make an additional observation, that the attempt of the gospels to present Christianity as an otherworldly religion that does not challenge Roman temporal power, was meant to aid Christians at the time of the Gospels' composition.

The author chooses a sort of winding scenic route through the world of research addressing the possibility of extending human life way past a mere hundred years or so--and appears to seriously consider a lifespan of 500 years or more.  Much of this quest seems to have been spent at the side of British scientist Aubrey de Grey, with almost as much attention spent on de Grey's love of beer and English pubs as anything else.  As the author hangs out with de Grey and other luminaries, he gathers their thoughts regarding what shortcomings of the human body might be corrected in order to greatly increase its lifespan.The author lays out two types of strategy for addressing these issues, with one camp labeled as "skin-out" (evolutionary, ecological, and field biologists) and the other as "skin-in" (cell and molecular biologists).  "Skin-out people look at the big picture and skin-in people tend to think about the panorama of history" (p.176).  Skin-in people look to Darwin for inspiration, while skin-out people look to Watson and Crick.Among the most interesting challenges to longevity mentioned in this book is that associated with the atrophy of mitochondria with age (p.150).  That is, many of the mitochondria in old cells (and old people) loose their ability to manufacture ATP--the main currency of energy in our bodies (pp.75-77).  This is a big problem because every day a person burns through his own body's weight in ATP (p.79).  Unfortunately our body is not always able to detect derelict mitochondria so that they can be disposed of--which only serve to contaminate the cell (p.81).Although the author tells an interesting story about the failure of our bodies with age, and how these failures might be prevented, in the end he does not supply enough detail to satisfy me.  There are no diagrams, for example--or figures of any kind.  The are no charts of the lifespans of animals or cellular entities as functions of various genetic or physiological attributes.  There are no diagrams of mitochondria and the sites that might be damaged by free radicals.  Really, too much time is spent on the personal habits of Aubrey de Grey and not enough on the science.  If you cut out all the fluff, this book could be condensed into a 20 page magazine article.

Updike paints a darkly comic portrait of the America that remains after a nuclear altercation.  His focus is on the life of a sixty-odd year old upper middle class man who is lucky enough to reside in New England--a section of the country largely unscathed by the exchange of nuclear missiles with the Chinese.  Although the central government is in tatters, life seems to pretty much go on for our protagonist and his neighbors.  In place of the government, a number of commercial entities emerge to maintain something resembling order--from local thugs to Fedex and UPS.  One of the most amusing vignettes involves our hero taking a few local teenage extortionists under his wing.  I loved the scene where he advises the boys to wear respectable blazers while canvasing the neighborhood for protection money--a strategy that meets with great success!

Reid includes many elements that are helpful to the materials scientist interested in plastic deformation.  I particularly like Chapter 3, which deals with elasticity theory.  Particular attention is paid to the stiffness and compliance tensors, and the role of material symmetry in simplifying these tensors for specific crystal systems.  The geometry of slip systems is also addressed in a complete and lucid manner.

The author considers the concept of entropy within a wide variety of contexts: from the aging and the eventual death of the human body, to the decay and demise of nation states and corporations.  The ideas of Ostwald Spengler, author of "The Decline of the West," are also mentioned, as is the statistical definition of entropy.  Claude Shannon's concept of informational entropy is touched on as well.  The author also includes a short story written from the point of view of a smallpox virus, which includes the cataclysmic demise of its host.The role of entropy in the universe is covered, but fails to include the role of black holes as entropy sinks.  See Roger Penrose's book The Road to Reality: A Complete Guide to the Laws of the Universe for a treatment of this topic.

Given the difficulty in defining the path of a particle in quantum physics, a fractal path would seem worth considering.  The fractal formulation is at variance with one alternate formulation of quantum mechanics--that of David Bohm where particles follow the smooth path dictated by Bohm's version of the Schrodinger equation.  On the other hand, a fractal path has much in common with the Feynman path integral of quantum field theory (pp.89-109).There is also a fractal quality to interactions that create electron-positron pairs.  This appearance of electron-hole pairs is consistent with the space-time path of an electron jerking alternately forward and backward in time (pp.106-109), such that the particle going forward in time is an electron, but traveling backward in time is a positron.  The author also points out that the proliferation of Feynman diagrams (and associated virtual particles) needed to describe an interaction suggests the fractal character of quantum electrodynamics (pp.164-171).

The author provides a mathematically sophisticated treatment of dislocation stress and strain fields near interfaces in terms of the concepts developed by Lekhnitshkii, Eshelby, and Stroh (LES theory) in the 1950's and 1960s.  The author goes way beyond the derivation and application of the very abstract complex variable based LES theory--he also provides an intuitive motivation for these concepts.  This intuitive treatment is especially valuable for understanding the forces acting on edge dislocations at interfaces (pp.255-273)--which are much more difficult to treat than screw dislocations.Despite my high regard for this book, it does have a few problems--one of which is that some of figures are confusing.  The author has chosen to represent every dislocation in these figures by the symbol that is normally reserved for an edge dislocation with the Burgers vector running from left to right (e.g Fig.3.3, p.78).  In the case where the Burgers vector of an edge dislocation is tilted, the symbol for edge dislocation should also tilt--but the author does not see fit to include the tilt of the symbol in his figures.  What is even more confusing, however, is that the edge dislocation symbol is also used to represent screw dislocations.  As a result, the reader is left wondering regarding the location of the screw dislocation mentioned in the figure caption when only edge dislocation symbols are present in the figure!  So let me just warn the reader that in this book all of the dislocations in the figures are represented by the edge dislocation symbol.As in all books that involve mathematically-intensive theories, there are sections where some of the details are left to references.  Allow me to point out a reference that the reader must go to in order to understand one of the major topics in this book--the configurations of image dislocations at an interface: Ting, J. Mech. Appl. Math. 45, 119 (1992).  Unfortunately, this article is not online and therefore requires the reader's access to the library of a university or research institute.  The author does, nevertheless, devote a great deal of attention to such half-space problems, including those involving the bilateral problem and the position of orientation of the attendant image dislocations (see especially Fig.8.6, p.272).Prof. Ting includes the best treatment of the Lekhnitskii formalism that I have read thus far, with Chapter 4 (pp.118-133) dedicated to this topic.  The derivation of the homogeneous 6-order differential equation (pp.122, Eq.4.3-13) is particularly clear.The author includes an in-depth discussion of Barnett-Lothe tensions and the role of positive-definite matrices in two-dimension deformations of anisotropic elastic bodies (p.192).  In fact an entire chapter (Ch.6: pp.164-200) of this 570-page book is dedicated to the structure and identities of such matrices.  There is also a chapter completely devoted to degenerate matrices (Ch.13: pp.486-496) and to a generalization of the Stroh formalism (Ch.14: pp.497-519).Professor Ting treats a number of the problems in anisotropic elasticity theory in addition to planar half spaces, including curved boundaries (p.353), elliptical boundaries (Ch.10: pp.365-408), cracks or rigid line inclusions (Ch.11: pp.409-439), as well as steady state motion and surface waves (Ch. pp.440-485).  The final chapter (Ch.15, pp.520-536) addresses three-dimensional deformations.  In addition to a useful subject index, the author includes an author index.The author also graciously provides a short biography honoring luminary Allen Neil Stroh (pp.159-161).  Stroh was born in Queenstown, South Africa on April 4, 1926--only two and a half weeks before the birth of Queen Elizabeth (April 21, 1926). He received his secondary education at Queens College (1934-42) and his undergraduate education at Rhodes University College (1943-1947).  He went on to receive his M.S. degree in physics from the University of South Africa.  He received his Ph.D. from University of Bristol in 1953, where he was supervised by the legendary J. D. Eshelby and Sir Neville Mott.  He was DSIR fellow at Cambridge's Cavendish Laboratory in 1953, and a lecturer at University of Sheffield from 1954-1958.  He went to MIT in 1958 as a Sloan fellow and became an associate professor of mechanical engineering in 1959.  He went on to accept a position at Boeing Research Labs in Seattle in 1962.  On his way to this post, however, on Friday December 21, 1962, his car skidded on a wet road and went over an embankment on a highway near Steamboat Springs, Colorado, resulting in his untimely death at the tender age of 36.For those who wish to delve even deeper into anisotropic elasticity theory, I wish to recommend the excellent book authored by T. C. T. Ting's former Ph.D. student, Chyanbin Hwu: Anisotropic Elastic Plates--a treatment that makes extensive use of analytic continuity in complex variables.

The authors have assembled a textbook that differs significantly from other books that fall under the title mathematical physics.  Rather than focusing on Bessel functions and spherical harmonics, the authors have penned a survey of classical and modern physics.  Topics covered include Hamiltonian mechanics, coupled oscillators, normal modes, vibrating strings, electromagnetic fields, fluid dynamics, thermodynamics, Heisenberg's equations of motion and uncertainty principle, the quantum harmonic oscillator, time-dependent perturbation theory, Fermi's Golden Rule, quantum angular momentum, electron spin, and superconductivity.  Interspersed between these topics are brief introductions to mathematical techniques such as matrices, differential operators, and complex variables.Given the wide range of topics addressed by this book, I have difficulty imagining the course that it might accompany.  Perhaps it might be of greatest value to advanced undergraduate physics majors who might want to look and back and check what they have learned against the contents of this book.I found the treatment of superconductivity the most interesting aspect of this book (pp.357-373).  This authors systematically lead up to their introduction to superconductivity by preceding it with chapters that address the quantum statistics of Cooper pairs (pp.345-355), second quantization (pp.335-343), magnetic susceptibility (pp.307-327), Bose-Einstein condensation (pp.297-305), the free electron gas (pp.283-296), and quantum statistics (pp.273-281).  The authors even briefly address high-temperature superconductors like YCBO.

I like the treatment of complex variables in this book, especially with respect to analytic continuation (pp.76-80).  The discussion of analytic continuation culminates in the discussion of the Schwarz Reflection Theorem (pp.80-82).  The Schwarz Reflection Theorem is proven using Morera's Theorem (p.43), that if the integral of a function is zero for a closed contour, then that function is analytic.  The authors' lucid proof of the reflection principle relies on imagining a contour that loops around a boundary with an analytic function defined within this contour.

Most people with a physics degree at least vaguely remember the 1927-1930 gedanken experiment discussed by Bohr and Einstein addressing the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle.  This book continues Bohr and Einstein's debate into the present day, or at least up to the publication date of 2007.  Einstein once characterized as "spooky" effects that would seem to suggest a transluminal connection between entangled entities, a view which culminated in his formulation of the Einstein, Podolski, and Rosen paradox in 1935 (and which was, in turn, countered by Bohr's own proposals).  Such spooky effects were put on a much firmer foundation by the experiments of Aspect and others in the 1980's, 1990's and early 2000's--to such a an extent that Bohr's views might be regarded as triumphant.  The authors, however, point out the difficulties in accepting Bohr's Copenhagen approach--as well as challenges by alternative views of quantum mechanics which have their root in Einstein's criticisms.The authors address a number of interesting points that I have not seen discussed in my previous readings.  In particular, I am interested in their discussion of quantum coherence issues (pp.303-305).  The authors challenge the view of Joos and Zeh regarding collisions of a wave packet with the bombarding particles and radiation that would seem to pervade any environment.  While Joos and Zeh propose that such collisions limit coherence and therefore wave packet spreading with time, the authors counter that such scattering is not strong enough to introduce significant decoherence.The authors devote a small amount of space (pp.221-246) to Bell's theorem, and even less space (p.231-236) to the actual experimental tests of this theorem.  Unlike other books covering experimental tests of Bell's theorem, there are no figures laying out the positions of the lasers, optical paths, beam splitters, and detectors used in these experiments.  Nevertheless, the compact overview provided by this book is still valuable as it divides the evolution of these empirical tests into a discernible eras.  For example, the need for high efficiency detectors (in successful Bell-type entanglement experiments) was first discussed by Clauser et al. in 1969, although it was not until 1987 that is was realized that this efficiency would need to be at least 84% (p.233).I was also interested in the authors' discussion of David Bohm's relationship with Einstein (pp.196-199).  While at Princeton in the early 1950's, Bohm laid out to Einstein his program for building on the approach of De Broglie and Schrodinger, which led to what is sometimes called "De Broglie-Bohm" theory.  Although Bohm seemed to have received some encouragement from Einstein to pursue this path in these conversations, Einstein did not actively promote or explicitly endorse Bohm's theory once he came out with it.  This lack of backing from Einstein was deeply disappointing to Bohm!  Nevertheless, the fact that Einstein did not endorse Bohmian mechanics might be seem as emblematic of Einstein's view of almost all aspects of quantum theory and its interpretation--that of an independent thinker who could never be satisfied with half-baked ideas.

This book spans a surprisingly wide range of topics, even given that it is a 818-page tome!  Interface geometry, crystallography, interfacial extended defects, thermodynamics, kinetics, and atomic bonding and potentials are all addressed at a level that provides a useful introduction for professional researchers and graduate students.  A wide range of materials are considered, including metals, semiconductors, and oxides.  Ample examples are given from research papers, which are listed in the extensive bibliography at the end of each chapter.  There are plenty of thoughtfully planned figures, as well as images recorded using transmission electronic microscopy (TEM) and electron beam induced current (EBIC) techniques.I was surprised to find the number of specialized topics addressed in this book.  The authors provide an introduction to Bob Pond's treatment of interfacial dislocations (pp.48-62).  An excellent introduction to density functional theory is also provided (pp.149-163).  Although much of this book is devoted the interfaces involving extended defects, such as grain boundaries (pp.253-345) and cracks (pp.768-798), ample room is set aside for semiconductor interfaces, heterojunctions, and band offsets (pp.657-684).

The authors describe the nature of collusion, where a number of individuals or corporations seek to increase profits by agreeing to cooperate rather than compete.  Much of this story is told as a series of vignettes, following the activities of the colluding entities as they secretly work together towards their common goal.One particularly easy to visualize example constructed by the authors is that of a bidding ring consisting of antique dealers who bid on high-end furniture, such as original Chippendale pieces, at estate sales and auctions.  One particularly interesting practice of this bidding ring is that in which only one dealer belonging to the ring places a serious bid at any given time.  That is, the members of the ring never bid against one another--which would drive up the price of the item.  For show, however, the members do bid against one another at early stages of the bidding, but only when the price under consideration is at a ridiculously low level!  Another reason that the members of the ring do not bid against one another is that a series of high ascending bids notifies less well informed auction attendees that the piece under bid is of great value, which provides free information to members outside of the bidding ring--resulting in others bidding higher and driving up the price!  As the dream of the members of the ring is to buy valuable pieces at prices characteristic of neighborhood garage sales, constraining the bidding process is necessary in order to insure large profits.The discussion of bidding rings also provides a good introduction to the concept of the "square off" where the members of the bidding ring divide the pieces purchased among themselves after the auction--a process that often consists of a mini-auction that is conducted among the ring members.  In corporate collusion there is also a square off process, though in this case it deals with the problem where one member of a cartel sells more units than has been agreed upon at the outset.  Essentially, the member who has exceeded his sales quota must pay a penalty to the other members of the cartel, or buy units from the other members at a specified price.The authors also address the problem faced by cartels and bidding rings in avoiding government scrutiny, as such collusion activity is illegal.  The members are seen to hammer out their agreements at trade association meetings, the minutes of which are recorded only by an employee (often a lawyer) of the trade association itself--while the cartel members themselves do their best to divorce themselves from the formal proceedings.  It is also interesting that the square off often takes the form of the members of the cartel suing one another--a form of monetary transfer that is more opaque than more direct transactions.  Collusive activities may also avoid government scrutiny by taking the form of constraining product quality rather than constraining price.  In the early 1990's incandescent light manufacturers put this strategy into effect by capping the operating lifetime of each light bulb!The one place where this book falls short is in the mathematical description of competition.  The authors devote a few tables and footnotes to a mathematical description of price competition, so that the derivation of the relevant equations remains almost completely opaque (pp.93-98), even for the simple linear model considered by the authors.  The authors briefly reference about a dozen papers on this topic, with that of Singh and Vives, 1984 (which can be found online as a pdf file) given more attention than the others.  To get some flavor for this class of models, the Wikipedia article on the Cournot pricing model is worth reading, especially as an example of Nash equilibrium.  The model described by Singh and Vives, and that of Cournot, however, only involve two competing entities (i.e the duoloply case).  I have yet to find a paper that treats an arbitrary number of competing entities to my satisfaction.  The case with an arbitrarily large number of players competing for a slice of a given market is central to the collusion process, as the greater the number of players, the more difficult it is maintain the high prices that are the objective of the colluding entities.

The authors, James Ward Brown and Ruel V. Churchill, introduce the reader to complex variables at a level that attempts to strike a balance between mathematical rigor and convenient brevity.  In the end, however, the reader with the uneasy feeling that he has not gained enough intuitive insights from the proofs assembled by the authors.The few physical applications addressed in this 386-page, 12 chapter book are contained in chapter 10 (pp.299-325).  This chapter, Applications of Conformal Mapping, addresses temperature profiles, the electrostatic potential (which consumes less than 3 pages), and fluid flow.It is worth noting that the authors include a derivation of the Schwarz Reflection Principle that is based on the Cauchy-Riemann equations (pp.57-59).  In other books, the SRP is proved using Morera's Theorem (Dennery and Krzywicki's Mathematics for Physicists (Dover Books on Physics)) or the Mean Value Theorem (Ullrich's Complex Made Simple (Graduate Studies in Mathematics)).

Kramers began his career in physics in as a graduate student at University of Leiden, but left Leiden in 1916 to do his Ph.D. thesis research with Bohr in Copenhagen.  Kramers went to to serve as Bohr's assistant, and later as the vice chairman of Bohr's famous institute for theoretical physics after it was founded in 1921.  Kramers eventually returned to his native Holland to continue his academic career, during which he wrote the original German edition of this book, which was first published in 1933.  In 1957, the English version of Kramer's QM text was published, translated by Kramers' old graduate student D. ted Haar.  As ter Haar's native language was Dutch, he found himself with "the hazardous task of translating from one foreign language to another."  Nevertheless, he deemed this to be a worthy undertaking because "I felt that that this book still represents the best available exposition of quantum theory."  Although such a bold statement as this might well be challenged, we should be grateful to ter Haar for undertaking this mission and allowing those of us in the English speaking world to get a view of quantum theory from one of Bohr's closest disciples.Kramers' book is admirable for its direct and unassuming explanation of quantum theory and its mathematical formalism, and written in such as way as not to overwhelm the reader.  As stated by Kramers in the preface to his 1933 edition: "The apparent lack of mathematical models which is contritely pointed out in the text is not exclusively due to the incompetence of the author.  Physical morals, even (or rather especially) in their purest form, that is, unencumbered by pedagogic afterthoughts, do not live happily together with their mathematical relations in the restricted mansion of the human mind--and neither in the restricted volume of a monograph."  Despite these modest qualifications penned by Kramers, his book manages to address the depth of concept and completeness of mathematic description common to graduate level textbooks on QM, including the derivation of the Dirac equation.  Like Landau and Lifshitz's QM book, however, Kramers book is still sufficiently unencumbered by abstract arguments that it is accessible to advanced undergraduates.  In particular (and also stated in his preface) Kramers avoided reference to group theory in order to make his introduction to QM more approachable.I should also note that Kramers assembled his book in such a way as to highlight the most important aspects of quantum mechanics--and without bothering to look back at earlier contributions that were considered somewhat dated by 1933.  It is particularly noteworthy and laudable that Kramers made no reference to his 1924 work with Bohr and Slater (BKS Theory) that pointed the way to Heisenberg's 1925 work with Born and Jordan on matrix mechanics.  Kramers also avoided any mention of his own independent version of the Dirac equation.

Max Dresden, a prominent Dutch-born American theoretical physicist, is the author of this wonderful book--which is a biography of his fellow countryman and theoretical physicist Hendrik Antonie Kramers--as well as a sparkling account of the revolution in early twentieth century physics that led to quantum mechanics.Born in the Dutch city of Rotterdam in 1894, Kramers assumed the nickname "Hans" as a boy.  He went on to study physics at the University of Leiden, followed by the unusual step of traveling to Copenhagen in 1916 to convince Denmark's newly-minted first professor of theoretical physics, Niels Bohr, to hire him as an assistant.  In doing so Kramers got in on the ultimate "ground floor" of physics, establishing himself as Bohr's first and only assistant--long before Bohr's famous institute was established in 1921.  Kramers continued as Bohr's second-in-command at the institute, or as Wolfgang Pauli later said, "Bohr is Allah and Kramers is his prophet."  In his work with Bohr, Kramers played a significant role in the development of quantum theory.  Of particular note is the 1924 paper that Kramers wrote with Bohr and Slater (BKS theory), and which laid much of the groundwork for Werner Heisenberg's 1925 paper that would establish matrix mechanics and the Heisenberg uncertainty principle.  In 1926 Kramers left Bohr's institute to assume the professorship at University of Utrecht, leaving Heisenberg to assume the position of Bohr's adjutant.I was also interested to learn that Kramers independently discovered what came to be known as the Dirac equation, the development of which was foreshadowed by Kramers discussion with Pauli regarding the possibility of a comprehensive theory that explained the origin of spin.  Sadly for Kramers, however, his version of the Dirac equation was completed only a couple weeks after Dirac's result was published in 1928.  Because he was scooped by Dirac, Kramers did not bother to publish his results, but waited almost another decade before including it as one of the final chapters of a textbook.  Kramers had also done significant work in the development of electron mass renormalization in quantum electrodynamics--results which were hardly noticed by the rest of the physics community until the discovery of the Lamb shift in 1947.  Kramers' efforts in mass renormalization did finally come to light during his participation in the Shelter Island Conference in 1947.  These near misses with respect to achieving a greater level of fame led to some of the great men of physics to describe Kramers' career with certain qualifications.  In discussions stimulated by Kramers' death in 1952, Bohr even went so far as to lament that Kramers was "without ambition."In addition to describing Kramers' career in physics, the author comments on the contributions of many other great men in physics.
