I was surprised to learn that it was Konrad Lorentz who first recognized the problem of wave packet dispersion when Schrodinger's famous 1926 paper appeared.  It is also interesting that Bohr strongly resisted claims that called for existence of photons.  The author also draws an interesting contrast between the three major research institutes that played the principal roles in the development of quantum mechanics: Copenhagen, Gottingen, and Munich (p.37).  Of course Copenhagen was led by Niels Bohr and was well-known for an informal atmosphere which fostered so many rich collaborations.  A completely different atmosphere was that of Gottingen, with Max Born taking the lead in theoretical physics.  The University of Gottingen was known for its formal and rigorous approach to mathematics as exemplified by David Hilbert, and which Wolfgang Pauli jokingly characterized as "Gottingen Learnedness."  Theoretical physics at the University of Munich revolved around Arnold Sommerfeld, who advised such brilliant students as Pauli, Heisenberg, Bethe, and Debye, as well as numerous accomplished post-docs.  Sommerfeld encouraged his students to address concrete problems using a mathematically sophisticated approach, leaving philosophical rumination to Bohr and his associates.The author also devotes ample space to Kramers' personal life as a thoroughly decent man in the most trying of times.  Kramers was one of the 53 professors (out of a total of 56) who resigned from the University of Leiden in March 1940 rather than accept the antisemitic dictates of the occupying Nazi forces (p.499).  While the university was closed Kramers continued to teach in secret, so as to provide for a generation of students who might otherwise be lost.I should also mention that the Max Dresden goes far beyond giving the biographical details of Kramers' life and career.  Ample space and attention are also devoted to a detailed and mathematically complete description of Kramers' contributions to theoretical physics--especially with respect to Bohr-Kramers-Slater Theory and Kramers' renormalization of the electron mass.

The author provides the reader with an intuitive introduction and overview of complex variables with a good selection of topics.  I was particularly pleased to find a treatment of the Schwarz Reflection Principle (pp.95-97).  Because the author does not provide even the most rudimentary proofs for the theorems treated in this volume, however, it is difficult for the reader to feel comfortable with some of the more difficult and counter-intuitive concepts within complex variables.  Without proofs to guide me, I often find it difficult to even understand mathematical notation.For a more complete and satisfying introduction to complex variables, especially for scientists and engineers, I would recommend David Ullrich's Complex Made Simple (Graduate Studies in Mathematics).

Kierkegaard advocates a faith of personal commitment where the objective of the adherent may seem outside the dictates of conventional society and logic.  As the exemplar of this faith, Kierkegaard chooses the biblical patriarch Abraham, with the near sacrifice of his beloved son Isaac as the seminal act of faith.  In addition to Abraham's ultimate act of faithful sacrifice, Kierkegaard also considers Luke 14:26, where Christ maintains that his followers must "hate their father and mother" in order to properly devote themselves to the mission he lays before them.  In each of these cases, the adherent of the Judeo/Christian faith finds himself in a position that is in many ways contradictory (i.e. to "hate" or "sacrifice" those who one clearly loves--and in regard to one's parents, those who the fifth of the Ten Commandments requires one to honor).  Kierkegaard also maintains that this version of faith is significantly different from that espoused by other religions.I should note that Islam, the other religious faith that traces itself back to Abraham, assumes an approach that seems to differ from the Judeo/Christian one--and that this different view serves to further illustrate Kierkegaard's thesis.  The Koran also details Abraham's sacrifice of his beloved son, in Surah 37, verses 99-107.  Though in the Koran, the name of the son offered for sacrifice is not explicitly stated.  Given that Isaac is mentioned immediately after the Koranic account of the sacrificial act, in verses 112-113 of Surah 37, it would also seem that it is Isaac who is the son designated for sacrifice.  Nevertheless, according to Islamic tradition, Ishmael, the son of Abraham through Sarah's handmaiden Hagar, is considered the object of the anticipated sacrifice.  Ishmael plays a much larger role in the Islamic faith than in Judeo/Christianity, especially as he is considered the ancestor of the Arab people.The difference between the Islamic view of Abraham's attempted sacrifice of his son, and that of Judeo/Christianity, does not consist merely in whether it was Isaac or Ishmael who was chosen.  In the Koranic version, the son is informed by Abraham of the plan of the divine sacrifice and explicitly agrees to comply.  In Genesis, the plan for sacrifice is strictly between Abraham and God, with Isaac neither informed of their intentions, nor playing any role in the decision making process.  Therefore, the burden of the decision in Genesis is born only by Abraham, which is completely in keeping with Kierkegaard's notion that Abraham's leap of faith is strictly an individual one.  In the Islamic version of this sacrifice, the burden of faith is born by the son as well as by Abraham--and thus is not a completely individual choice.  I should also observe that this sacrificial act is not an obscure event in Islam, but is commemorated by the feast "Eid al-Adha" which is one of only two religious holidays in the Islamic calendar (the other being "Eid al-Fitr" which marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan).

The authors provide a good introduction to the many important theorems, and the proofs for these theorems, many of which are not found in standard textbooks on complex variables.  I found it very helpful that the authors discussed and proved the Mean Value Principle at the very beginning to this book, on pp.4-7.  Another very useful result, the Schwarz Reflection Principle, is stated and proved on pp.66-70.  This book includes an index for special symbols and the page numbers on which they are defined.  There is also an appendix that provides the formula for a volume of any dimension, as well the proof for this formula.  This book is also very accessible, as it is available online in its entirety, as a pdf file.

I turned to this book for information on a very specific problem among the many facets of anisotropic elasticity theory addressed by the author: the interaction of a dislocation with a free surface, or with a planar boundary for a layer of different mechanical stiffness.  I had read about the treatment of this problem using Stroh's 2-dimensional dislocation model and analytical continuation in the complex plane in numerous journal articles.  Prior to reading Hwu's rigorous treatment of this problem, however, I did not understand how the authors of these articles used analytic continuation to extract the boundary conditions from the continuity of displacement and stress at the interface.Instead of presenting the boundary conditions as "obvious" or as the result of "standard analytic continuation arguments" (as indifferently observed by the authors of various journal articles), Hwu clearly explains how Liouville's Theorem (a concept found in all complex analysis books) is used to arrive at the result.  Liouville's Theorem states that a function which is analytic in a given region of the complex plane must also be constant in that region.  Therefore, if a function in a given region is analytic, that region would necessarily be free of singularities/dislocations.  By invoking Liouville's Theorem (p.102, Ch.4), Hwu makes it clear that each side of the interface (i.e. each half-space) may only be represented by a sum of functions that are devoid of singularities.  Thus, if the dislocation is contained in the lower half-space (i.e. half space#1, which is situated below the interface), half-space#1 cannot include the Green's function G(z) corresponding to the dislocation/singularity.  The sum of functions representing the upper half-space (i.e. half-space#2, the which is above the interface), however, may include the Green's function for the dislocation/singularity because the Green's function is finite within half-space#2.  Similarly, the sum of functions representing half-space#2 may not include the Green's function corresponding to the reflection of the singularity/dislocation (i.e (G(z*))*, according the Schwarz reflection principle for harmonic functions).  On the other hand, the sum of functions representing half-space#1 may include (G(z*))*, because (G(z*))* is finite within half-space#2.  For a good treatment of the Schwarz reflection principle see Dennery (pp.80-82) Mathematics for Physicists (Dover Books on Physics).Almost everything you need to know about calculating the strain field or Peach-Koehler force on a dislocation near an interface or surface is contained in Chapter 4 "Infinite Space, Half-Space, and Bimaterials" on pp.87-114.  What I have learned from reading this chapter in Hwu's book is vitally important in my research work.  Only the level of understanding achieved by reading a book of this caliber is sufficient for the dedicated research scientist or engineer to have confidence in his calculations.The brilliant treatment that I have described above, however, only takes the reader up to the first four chapters (pp.1-113) of this outstanding book!  In addition to the laying the groundwork for the treatment of half-spaces, the author addresses wedges and interface corners (Ch.5: pp.115-158); elliptical and polygonal holes/voids (Ch.6: pp.159-186);  interfacial cracks and delimitation (Ch.6: pp.187-23; inclusions and their interactions with dislocations (Ch.8: pp.239-275); surface indentation and the elastic theory of contact between two adjacent bodies (Ch.9: pp.277-332); thermoelastic effects on voids, cracks, and wedges (Ch.10, pp.333-367); piezoelectric materials (pp.369-410); and plate bending (Ch.12: 411-434).  Chapters 13-14 (pp.435-543 address stretching, voids, and inclusions in laminates: Chapter 15 (pp.545-588) is devoted to boundary element analysis.  The remaining pages of this book (pp.589-673) are devoted to its extensive appendices, tables, references, and indices.For those who find this book as fully informative and enjoyable as I have, I recommend the book authored by Professor Hwu's Ph.D. advisor, Professor Thomas Chi-Tsai (T. C. T.) Ting: Anisotropic Elasticity: Theory and Applications (Oxford Engineering Science Series).

I searched for a complex variables textbook that explained and proved the Schwarz Reflection Theorem for harmonic functions in a way that I could understand.  I found that Ullrich accomplished this goal in only two pages (pp.215-216).  This is an important result that allows you to calculate image forces/fields in electrostatics and dislocation theory.
Exceptional viewing for the whole family.  It is charming, sweet and delightful.
Oh my stars how wonderful!  The sets, costumes, acting, .... completely entertaining and I certainly hope this continues.  Christina Ricci grows more lovely with every year and truly owns this role.
Fun, sweet and good family fun!  Entertaining for all age groups.
and absolutely adorable.  May "change" and "growth" be a part of all of our lives. :)
which results in horrible quality cutting.  Do yourself a favor and get a quality rotary cutter.  OLFA 45mm Deluxe Handle Rotary Cutter

and it is evident in everything Olfa makes.  Quality products give you a quality result. Love that I can set it so the blade retracts every time yet lock it when not in use.  I purchased another retractable cutter from Amazon and, when in use, the blade wobbles as it rotates.  Quilting Bee 45mm Deluxe Rotary Cutter for Quilting, Crafts and Scrapbooking (RCDX45)Do yourself a favor and get a quality, Olfa rotary cutter.  Quality products are a joy to use.
But now, dirt doesn't come out.  I mean what's the point of having a laundry detergent which doesn't get ordinary dirt out?  I mean smudges of ground dirt. Nothing.  :(
Absolutely stellar.  There are a few things I disagree with. Overall, the movie is engaging, entertaining and thought provoking.Well done!!
and overall the socks were clearly not the same length of foot section as those I purchased in a brick and mortar store.  Returning.
While the description does not say this, this is a girl's, not women's, size sock.  Cute though.  I am returning it.
The thread pins were not what I was looking for... That said with the cone thread tray, this satchel works beautifully.
Love these and so great for keeping like cone thread together. I can separate by product number and make sure I don't purchase duplicates.  Very handy!
If I were shorter it would be longer. :)  At 5'10" it falls about 4" above my knees.  Very soft and comfortable.  I knocked off one star for the shortness of the t-shirt.
I'll forever see scenes from The Guardians of the Galaxy whlie listening to this. :)  Fun!

My cat loves this stuff.  I had switched to Wysong for several years but they "improved" their product and I'll let you see the heart breaking reviews on the Amazon site.  This, my cat eats like they are treats.  Good quality.
I had to use parts from my 8+ year old Pur filter to make this one work.
at a great price.  Can't beat it with a stick!  Fast shipping also.

I have been using a stainless steel straw in a stainless coffee mug so I don't have to tip my drink up in front of my face.  This straw is only 7 inches long (I missed that in the details) so I cannot use it for my purposes.  Perhaps, someday, I'll find the perfect use for it.VERY light which is nice.  Easy to clean with an appropriate straw brush.
Despite what other reviewers said, I think this is an adorable movie.  Predictable and enjoyable.
Oh my stars, this works SOOOO well!  I've yet to try the make-my-own jar lid setup so I'll review later.  Just wonderful.
W O N D E R F U L  movie!  Love it!  Fabulously written, wonderful humor and repartee resplendent. I can't wait for the sequel. :)
Wonderful book, entertaining, fun, sweet and insightful.  Lovely backstory to the TV show and blog.
More to the point, my cat loves it. :))  I'm careful about where I point it and he has a blast chasing it. :)

Works great!  I've only used it with the glass bowl http://smile.amazon.com/KitchenAid-K5GB-Tilt-Head-Measurement-Markings/dp/B002WUPWC2/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1419622840&sr=8-1&keywords=KitchenAid+K5GB+5-Qt.+Tilt-Head+Glass+Bowl+with+Measurement+Markings+%26+LidJust perfect!!
Wonderful!  I thought I already had this CD but it is better than the one I actually did have.  Wonderful
Awesome bowl!  GREAT for any type of mixing and I couldn't be happier.

Absolutely wonderful paint!  I love it.  Amazing this paint does NOT separate like other paints.  I do stir it though.. call it my paranoia. lol  It sticks to absolutely everything and this color is stunning.  I'll be back for more and look forward to more colors!!
Classic comedy I enjoyed.  Haven't seen it in ages.
Meh.... I skipped through a bunch... not funny... not scary...
I invite Mike Dooley to open up his mind.  Read The Stone Woman by A.S. Byatt with an open mind.... Read Seth the same way ... All that exists has consciousness.

I have several over-the-door racks from different companies.  I was a bit concerned about the plastic parts on this OXO rack, compared to the all metal construction of the others, but, so far, so good.The hooks are sturdy enough to hang up a terry cloth robe, plus some lighter garments. A big plus is that the plastic bars that go over the top of the door are invisible, so you don't see metal bars as you do with other racks. Additionally, those plastic bars snap on, so the rack stays put and doesn't slide from side to side.It's important to measure your door plus the gap between the door and the door jam. I have one door in my house, in a bathroom no less, that is so tightly fitted that it won't accommodate any over door rack. The product guidelines state that it fits "over thin and thick doors (1 3/8" - 1 3/4") - my door is a bit bigger than that, not quite two inches, and it fit - and a "standard 3/16" gap between the top of the door and its frame." This last measurement is important, too, so I advise taking the time to measure before you order.

Cute little space heater, surprisingly effective, too. If you need a small space to be warmer than it is, and want something that is cuter than your basic space heater. I use it to make a bedroom warmer, and with the door closed to trap the heat, it works well. I also have a small Vornado heater, and if you are looking for something with a "brain" that will pause when the room is a certain temperature, that would be a better choice than this, which just keeps throwing off heat at a particular setting. The flames don't look real, but it's nice to look at something that reminds you of a fireplace.

This is the second time an Ensure product has helped an elderly family member regain health and strength. My aunt is a healthy eater, and has avoided pre-made shakes like this. That is, until she was hospitalized with colitis, and could not tolerate mist foods for quite a while. Ensure probably helped save her life. Recently, she was hospitalized again for other issues, and the hospital gave her Ensure Compleat. Not only does she love the chocolate flavor, it provides her with the protein and minerals that are critical for her at this time. Fantastic, tasty product, and Amazon has the best price I've found.

I have very sensitive, reactive skin. I tried this on my sunburned and peeling skin.  It was mild and soothing, went on thick and greasy, but was absorbed pretty quickly.  It did not make most of my skin burn, but I did feel pain after application on one part that was peeling a lot.  In contrast, I have no sensitivity to Epionce or Creme de la Mer, both of which I would give five stars, so this gets four.  I still recommend this cream because it works and is significantly more affordable than the other two I listed.

Good tasting whole grain pasta.  Some whole grain pastas out there just taste weird, and fall apart completely when cooked.  This one does not - if you follow the cooking instructions, it holds together well; I have found it to be a bit sturdier than other brands.  It also has a "whole grain" taste to it - slightly nutty, and more flavorful than the plain white elbow pasta by Barilla.  Something to keep in mind is that this package is not a full 16 ounces, but is about 2.5 ounces short of that, which may matter in your recipe.

My favorite brand of grocery store pasta is De Cecco, but Barilla runs a close second, if not equal in some categories. Elbow macaroni is one of the types of pasta where I see no difference in taste or texture between the two brands. I have used this pasta in soups, pasta salads, and to make Mac and cheese, and as long as you do not overcook. It turns out great.  It tastes like pasta, not vegetables, but you are getting a bit extra nutrition, and the colors are nice. One thing to be aware of is that this is NOT a 16 oz box - it is 25% smaller. This is something that a lot of manufacturers have started doing, and it is irritating to be double checking weights and buying extra pasta so that you have enough for recipes that require the standard one pound box. Subtracting one star for that.

Excellent product. Yes, it has sugar in it, etc., but this product is flavorful and packs a lot of nutrition in it for those who need it. The elderly and children are prone to appetite fatigue, and after receiving this in the hospital, an elderly relative has started eating again and drinks 2-3 of these a day to get additional protein and vitamins.  This product is not cheap, but buying it directly from the manufacturer via Amazon is the most competitive price I've found, but for occasional sales.

I don't have very dark circles under my eyes - they are there, just not very dark.  The product promises results in a week, and I did not notice any lightening of the circles, but that could just be because mine are light to begin with.  What I did find is that it was a nice moisturizer for my dry winter skin around the eyes, and it did not interfere with makeup.  It's not greasy at all, and is quickly absorbed.  I'll keep using it and update this review if my circles do get lighter.

These nightlights cast a cold, weird blue light that does not seem to illumine as well as an old-fashioned lightbulb. I think this is OK if you don't want or need something brighter, bur if you do, this isn't very effective.

A refillable bait station that claims to be tamper resistant.  The plus is that this stuff really works, and beats those open D-Con boxes that spill bits of rodenticide all over the floor.  I put these out in the fall to deter mice from moving into my house.  As for the tamper-resistant feature, it will not stop a determined dog.  I have one dog that is entranced by the smell of these bait stations, and tries to figure out ways to get to them.  Therefore, I have to put them at higher elevations - high window ledges, shelving, etc., so he can't get to them.

UPDATE: this lotion was not causing the irritation on my skin at all, it was just the extremely dry air.  It does provide short term relief for dry skin, but I recommend using it with an additional cream or lotion after the shower if your skin is extremely dry.Interesting product.  I've never before used a lotion that you put on in the shower and then rinse off.  My skin felt soft after using it, but be warned, it leaves your shower floor very slick.  I also have very sensitive skin, and the combination of this lotion, which requires you to rinse off in a hot shower, is leaving the skin on my hands and forearms a bit irritated.  The cold, dry weather could also be a contributing factor, but if you have very sensitive skin, you might want to be careful.

This is not an all purpose towing strap - it is specifically designed for towing snowmobiles and ATVs, and it works very well for that person.  The most mechanically inept person, meaning me, can use this if they have any common sense.  The construction is very sturdy, and the strap should last a very long time if protected from the elements.

This is a FANTASTIC product - it has cut down significantly on the time it takes for us to light a fire. Basically, just crumple a bit of paper, place a couple pieces of fatwood on it, light, and once it ignites the wood (which happens quickly), you can carefully start to add more wood.  This has helped us completely skip the "add kindling and baby the fire for a while" step.  Highly recommended.

Dishwasher safe and safe to use - you can wash this on the top rack, and the design prevents you from grating a finger or a knuckle.  A plus is that a lever hold the item to be grated, so you don't have to be pressing anything closed, as with other graters, to get it to work. Because so little effort is needed to get this to work well, I think it would be a great gift for someone with arthritis or another illness that has caused loss of hand strength.

Great idea - the plastic is sturdy, safe, and does not smell.  There are two drawbacks that I've found: (1) it takes a while for the interiors to dry.  You have to make sure that they're propped open FULLY for a while. (2) They are not designed for thick sandwiches, so if you like to pack Dagwood-sized sandwiches, you're better off using plastic wrap.

I tried this with an open mind.  I love plain coconut water, I like a number of Pure Protein products, so this looked interesting, especially with the added protein.  This just tastes weird, and not a good weird.  It tastes like a mix of citrusy-sweet tasting chemicals.

I've been taking protein powders for over 20 years.  They usually range in taste from terrible to tolerable.  Rarely, if ever, do I find one that tastes "good," and when I do settle on one, it's always vanilla flavor.Imagine my surprise when I tried this one - it actually tastes good. No weird aftertaste or gritty texture. The berry flavor is a little fake tasting, but it is mild, and not overwhelming.  I get a decent hit of protein and not a lot of calories.  My smoothies are very simple, too: water, pineapple or blueberries, a spirulina powder, and this.  Vanilla Myoplex will continue to be my main protein drink, but I will throw this one in the rotation a couple times a week.

Pros: it works. I'm not a car expert by any means, and I have not used other products like this ever before, so I have nothing to compare this to. What I can say is that the scratched, hazy headlights on my 10-plus year old car look amazing. Five stars for effectiveness. This is not a quick and easy process, however. It takes a long time and you absolutely must read the instructions through completely, preferably a couple times, before you start, or you can really goof things up.  If you have kids or pets, I found it best to have them otherwise occupied while I was doing this.

The carpet washer came extremely well packed.  It was easy to put together, and that's coming from someone who is not very mechanical.  The directions are clear, and it was easy to use.  It comes with a cleaning solution that worked pretty well, too. On the negative side, the cleaner is heavy (but I don't mind because it actually cleans), and you MUST be careful not to oversoak the carpet or it will be really tough to get all the water out.  I recommend that you do a light cleaning, and if certain areas aren't as clean as you'd like, go over those areas again, instead of really soaking the whole carpet.

Update:  After using these for a while, I have to say they drive me nuts because they snap together and that makes it difficult to feather the spoons out in order to pick the right size. I prefer stainless steel spoons on a ring for ease of use.***OXO is one of my favorite brands.  Some of their products really make cooking easier, such as their salad spinner.  That being said, sometimes there are items that really don't need much engineering, and I think that measuring spoons are one of them.  I prefer metal spoons, but for some applications, such as dealing with lye, they are not a wise choice.  So, it's a good idea to have a set of plastic spoons on hand.  Metal spoons also won't melt if you leave them too close to the burner.  These plastic ones are sturdy, and clip together at the end of the handle.  I don't use the scraper at all, so it's useless to me.  If I had to get one set of spoons, I would get a sturdy stainless steel set (Williams-Sonoma spoons have served me well for 30 years), not plastic.

I thought this was a different product from what turned out to be exactly the same one, just a larger version.  This smells like NOTHING, which is exactly what I wanted.  It just smells clean.  Best of all, this Gentle version gets my clothes clean, even when I use the cool water setting.  I deducted one star because the pods themselves do not completely dissolve in every load, and I've found bits of plastic-like substance in the laundry.  I have to wonder if this will cause damage to the washing machine.

This smells like NOTHING, which is exactly what I wanted.  It just smells clean.  Best of all, this Gentle version gets my clothes clean, even when I use the cool water setting.  I deducted one star because the pods themselves do not completely dissolve in every load, and I've found bits of plastic-like substance in the laundry.  I have to wonder if this will cause damage to the washing machine.

At almost 40 pounds, this is not a lightweight tool.  I was really surprised by this, and like another reviewer, had a bit of a struggle bringing it into the house from off the porch.  I am not mechanically savvy at all, but I was able to attach this to a two-inch hitch at the back of the SUV without much trouble at all, which is really saying something.This thing is STURDY.  Made in China.  It has a powder coated finish; I am not sure how it will hold up in terms of rust if you leave it outside, but it is so easy to attach and detach that shouldn't be a problem. There are screws that you can use to keep it in place as you drive to different spots. This is a good tool to have if you have a larger piece of property, even a couple acres, and have a project far from the house - attach the vise, drive out to wear you're working, and you have this ready to use without having to run back and forth to your workshop.

A perfect book for a plane ride or a rainy day! I've never read any of Ms. Yu's books before, but this one has ensured that I will be reading many more.  Set in Singapore, Rosie Lee is a restaurant owner and amateur sleuth who, like Jessica Fletcher it seems, keeps walking into murders without much effort on her part.  In this case, someone appears to be poisoned by her food, and she resolves to find the real murderer and clear her name, and her culinary reputation. The Asian setting adds a lot of interest to the story.This was a fun read that didn't require a lot of focus and concentration, but at the same time, I didn't want to put it down.

The Remington curling iron claims to straighten, curl, and add volume.  The pros are the ceramic plates, it fits well in my hand, and you have, theoretically, one tool instead of three.In practice, I don't need a curling iron, but it worked fine.  I was interested in the straightening and volumizing abilities.  It didn't seem to straighten any better or worse than other irons I've used.  I noticed no difference at all with the volumizing.  None, and that was a disappointment because that's what I need the most.So, in the end, it's nothing special, but I've seen worse.

How do you publish a comprehensive guidebook on a country as large and diverse as the USA?  Well, you can't, at least not without it being multiple volumes, but this book does give a very good overview of the United States.  The paper is thin, the photos and font are small, and the details are sparse.  I think this book would be good to PLAN a trip from a macro level - do you want to hit the Pacific Northwest? New England? From there, narrow down areas of interest and get guide books for those locations to supplement the info in this one.

Pros:- 4 different colored inks plus a pencil all in one pen.- eraser in the back cap- blue and black inks write very smoothly with no skips or jumps- lead pencil is fine and glides across the paper- apparently, you can by ink refills separately which is great, however, where are the instructions?Cons:- red and green inks are poor.  Lots of skipping on the paper, leaving gaps in letters.- pen is a little on the thick side, so may be hard to handle for those with small hands- instructions would be very helpful explaining how to insert refills

I don't bake with stevia because we rarely eat sweets, so when I do bake, I use sugar.  Therefore, this review deals with the taste of the product in coffee or black tea, which I drink almost every day.I have found that most sweeteners, including white sugar, have a slightly bitter aftertaste when I use them to sweeten coffee or tea.  The two exceptions are agave nectar and sugar in the raw.  Stevia has a taste so weird that I can't use it at all, so I was curious to try this.  First, it has half the calories of regular sugar, because it is a combination of stevia and white sugar.  Second, the aftertaste is milder than either straight stevia or straight white sugar.  Bottom line:  there is an aftertaste,  but if you don't like agave or sugar in the raw, this might be worth trying because everyone's palate is a little different.

The texture of these gummies is wonderful - soft, chewy, what a gummy should be.I'm not as thrilled by most of the flavors, however, which are simply "fruity" or "tart," without being identifiable.  In other words, it tastes like fruit, but you can't tell if it's cherry, grape, peach, what?  The package also explains that there are endless flavor combinations, and if that's what you want, that's great, but if, for example, you like to pick out all the "cherry" gummies, as nondescript as they may be, then you're out of luck. There were some really unusual ones in the mix, however; they actually had a bit of jam or jelly type filling for a burst of flavor.  In those cases, I could really tell that something was strawberry or raspberry-flavored.To summarize, fantastic texture (the best I've come across), and decent flavor, but nothing spectacular.

Lots of pictures with sound-bit types of reviews, but not really in-depth. Good size for traveling and carrying around. One of the best features is the attached full-sized map of Rome.  I would recommend using this guide in conjunction with other guides if you are going to spend a lot of time in Rome or want a more comprehensive guide that covers the history, attractions, and travel problems, such as the pervasive and problematic pickpockets.

I've had over ten years of experience with this and another grab bar, the Avin AI 1001 Red Handybar 3-in-1 Vehicle Support Handle, because of an elderly relative with mobility issues.First, this works, and no installation is required.  You just hook it onto the latch hood on the body of the car when you open the door, and then it can be used to brace oneself to stand up.  This was all the help my aunt needed for many years, but then her joints deteriorated to a point where  this tool was not enough.  Specifically, if the assistance needed is PULLING UP instead of PUSHING DOWN, this (or any other grab bar) will NOT work. If you have the strength and mobility to swing your legs out and scoot your butt to the edge of the seat, and only need to use one hand to push yourself up from that position, this bar will work for you.  The problem for my aunt was that it was impossible for her to do any of that after a certain point, and she needed a strap (like Stander CarCaddie) on the car door window plus one on the window of the back door, as well, literally to pull herself out and then up.  Unfortunately, these straps also have their own issues, as you will see from reading the reviews.Another concern is that the plastic feels flimsier than that of the sturdy Avin AI 1001, which as lasted us for over 10 years, with no problems.Bottom line, yes, this works well for certain people, and can even be used in conjunction with a strap.  It may not work for everyone, and I hope that my description can help you figure out if it will work for you.

I have been using their guides for over 20 years, back from when they were the new kid on the travel guide block.  Their India guide is fantastic, and remains my favorite.  This guide to Italy is also excellent - it covers every region of Italy, and provides a lot of detail on food establishments, which is something most travelers are interested in.  There is a handy pull out map of Rome, and the usual information on hikes, museums, and other activities.  If you plan on spending more than a couple days in a particular area, I recommend getting an additional guide for that locale, which will provide more in-depth coverage.  This guide is great for short visits.

I have used this brand's organic pumpkin in the past, liked it, and had no issues with it.  This sweet potato, however, was horrible from the moment I opened the can.  First, I was hit with an overwhelming "tin can" smell that almost bowled me over, even though the cans are BHP free. Next, the taste:  it tasted like the smell, only sweet.  Finally, the texture was very, very runny.  Cannot recommend this product.

I've been searching for a long time for a lid to cover large 28 ounce cans, specifically, pumpkin.  I decided to give these a shot.  Big mistake.  They are incredibly flimsy, not food grade, and grossly overpriced for the quality.  Worst of all, there is no lid that fits a 28oz. can of pumpkin.  Don't bother with this product.

I am one of those people who has read some if not every book in the different series by Ms. Harris. She has a creative mind and an ability to engage readers.  Nevertheless, I was disappointed in the Sookie Stackhouse series, which started off wonderfully, and then took a decided turn for the worse around book 6.The product description for this book provides a good synopsis without giving too much away - small town, mystery, things are not as they seem.  I thought the book was interesting, moved a bit slow at times, but most promising is that the author is limiting this to a trilogy.  That is why I said "thankfully" in the title of this review: not because Harris is a poor writer, but because I think she gets bored, really bored, writing an open-ended series, and it shows.  Hopefully, she will stay enthusiastic and engaged through a brief trilogy.

I usually use EAS Myoplex, which agrees with my digestive tract and contains only whey, no soy protein.  I was curious to try this for occasional use - I still don't want a lot of soy in my diet, but a little bit from time to time is ok.  This powder is a little chalkier than the Myoplex, but once I added some banana and an ice cube or two, I didn't notice it.  The flavor is not as rich as the Myoplex.  A negative is that there is no disclaimer indicating that non-GMO soy was used, so if that is an issue for you, you may want to avoid this product.

Two stars, and that's being generous.First, it works, IF you follow the directions and fit it to your dog properly.  That's the good news.The bad?  There is a part that hangs under your dog's chin, and it has a clip that opens and snaps shut to adjust the tension on the nose strap.  That clip lasted exactly one week.  At first, when snapped shut, it would stay put; after a week, it just slides up and down the strap, causing the nose band to twist, irritating the dog, and losing the tension needed for the headcollar to be effective.  We are now trying to use a binder clip to hold this together.  A total waste of money.

I also taste tested a savory sampler, and I think I prefer that one to this one.  If, however, you have a big sweet tooth, this sampler might be an option for you.My ranking:Kettle Corn - a nice hint of sweetness that is not overpowering.  I like to combine this one with a savory seasoning, like the White Cheddar. 4 stars.Caramel - tastes like fake caramel, but it's not repulsive.  When I mix it with Kettle Corn, it's actually pretty tasty, but I don't really care for it on its own. 3 stars.Milk Chocolate Caramel - Blech.  Very fake and weak tasting.  I can see this appealing to little kids, but that's about it.  I would give this one star.

I love these.  I have also tried and reviewed the sweeter seasonings, but I think these win, hands-down.My ranking:White CheddarNacho CheddarGarlic ParmesanThe flavors taste like their names, but they are NOT overwhelming, just tasty.  They also don't leave me with a headache, as some seasoning powders have from time to time.  I find, however, that if I put any of these on a big bowl of popcorn, I end up eating the whole big bowl of popcorn, instead of nibbling.

Most bars of this type are nasty, in my opinion.  They have chemically tastes, or an odd texture, or a funny aftertaste, or all of the above.  This bar has none of those problems, is gluten free and has a decent protein and fiber content, as noted in the product description.  I liked them, and found myself reaching for one when I wanted a taste of something sweet.  There is a distinct raspberry flavor, but I wouldn't say it was overpowering.  The one negative is the lack of dark chocolate flavor - the bars are supposed to be dark chocolate, they look like it, but the flavor is even milder than a good milk chocolate.

I was a rock fanatic as a child, and I would have loved this book.  It is small and light, making it easy to carry.  It is not a comprehensive book, but it's not supposed to be, so if you have a rock hound in your family is intermediate to advanced, this is not the book for them.  The paper quality and some of the photos are not the best, either.

This is not a comprehensive guide, nor is it intended to be.  It includes a brief description of a flower, organized by region, with key words and a picture or two.  The photos are where I found I was really disappointed - they are not very good, the color is off, and the quality of the paper is poor.  That being said, I have seen worse books, and this might be suitable for a beginner who needs something lit and portable.

I am NOT a connoisseur of duct tapes, I just want stuff to work when I need it.  I've been very pleased with Gorilla tape - it has stuck to bricks, and is currently holding together an under-cabinet trash can contraption in my kitchen, which I can't repair properly because of overly large drill holes.  Regular duct tape would not keep everything held together in that dirty trash area, due to dust, sometimes bits of grease, etc., that would fall on the surface.  Gorilla tape did the trick.  I put this tape to the same test.  It is thicker than Gorilla tape, you have to cut it with scissors (not tear it like regular duct tape), and it does seem to be sturdy.  When I used this tape on my repair project, however, it took more tape and a lot of pressing to get it to stick, when the Gorilla tape required less effort.  It is holding up, and that trash bin gets a lot of daily use, so I'm pleased with its performance so far.**UPDATE** After a couple of months, this tape is losing its stickiness, while the Gorilla tape held my trash bin together for a year.  Still, in a pinch, not bad to have.

What do I mean by "approachable"?  I mean that it's doable - there are a lot of new Southern chef cookbooks on the market, like the wonderful John Tesh's, but they provide labor-intensive recipes that take more time than the average home cook can allot.The B.T.C. Old-Fashioned Grocery Cookbook is just what it claims to be - a compendium of delightful, old-fashioned, quintessentially Southern recipes that are comfort food, especially if you grew up eating them. Every once in a while, the authors will toss in something a little more modern.  For example, tucked into the breakfast chapter amongst the Skillet Biscuit and 4 different gravy recipes, you will find Honey Goat Cheese Frittata with Prosciutto and Arugula.  Not your typical Southern fare.  The casserole chapter has a recipe for Artichoke and Green Pea Gratin, and a few pages later, Chicken Spaghetti, which calls for hoop cheese, a can of Ro-Tel, and three different types of Campbells Cream soups.  98% of everything I make is fresh and from scratch, but I am not a snob, so I tried that Chicken Spaghetti recipe and my family asked me to put it on the "repeat" list.If the authors have a favorite product, they mention it by name, such as Tabasco sauce and Hellman's (Best Foods out west) mayonnaise, which I think is great.  One of the things that I wish they would have done is provide a bit more explanation about some of these regional or locally-named items, such as hoop cheese.  Other recipes I tried:  Pimento cheese (yum), Home Brined Corned Beef Brisket, the Marinara sauce in the lasagna recipe, and Buttermilk Ranch Dressing (delicious).  All were very good.A couple final notes.  Some of these recipes do take time, so take that into account.  The Chicken Spaghetti recipe is quick and easy IF you have the chicken on hand, like a rotisserie chicken.  If you want to get a better idea of what's in the book, go to the top of this Amazon page and click on the "Look Inside" option.

I'm a fan of Lindt truffles, but had not tried this flavor.  If you like Reeses, you will probably love these.  The chocolate and filling are smooth and creamy, with no graininess like Reeses.  The chocolate tastes like chocolate and not wax, and the filling tastes like peanuts, but it is on the mild side. I'd like these a bit better if they had a stronger peanut flavor, but don't get me wrong, these are good!

I love these and find myself using them all the time since I received them.The pros:- They take up little space and fit in small storage places- Comes with a finger guard- Affordable- Easy to cleanThe cons:- The slicers are not adjustable like a mandoline+Basically, I find myself just washing one of these after use, and leaving it in my dish drainer, to be used again.  I love my $300+ mandoline, and I will very occasionally use it to slice something extra thin or for a special shape.  The thing is, I so rarely used it that I found myself avoiding recipes that would require me to pull it out, set it up, then clean it and shove it back into its dark storage space.  With these little guys, I am slicing radishes, cucumbers and fennel to add to salads, which I wanted to do before but did not want to go through the rigamarole I described above.  I find that I also rarely pull out my box grater or microplanes for the same reason - I just leave the graters in the dish drainer and use them as needed.So, if you do not need an expensive mandoline with multiple settings, and are content with an inexpensive but practical set, give these a try.

I love Kettle Chips and order them from Amazon and buy them in local stores.  I was excited to try this flavor, because I really like Sriracha, too, and it sounded like a great combo.  Well, something was lost in the execution - it tastes hot (not too hot), has a hint of sweetness, but no flavor.  It doesn't taste like Sriracha or potato chips.  These are just kind of blah and lifeless, with a slightly bitter aftertaste.  I don't recommend these.

This book straddles the fence between new-agey type of approaches to life, along with some science.  I was prepared to find it irritating, but found myself liking it because I managed to keep in mind what it is and what it isn't:  it is an accessible self help book that encourages you to take small common sense steps to improve your life.  It is not a scientific treatise, or a philosophical dissertation.  For people who may think that they have to change their entire lives all at once, this approach is actually doable and a breath of fresh air.

Beautifully photographed and organized according to regions, this is a nice paperback book that falls in the category of a wish book, not an in-depth travel book.  By that I mean it's useful for getting an overall idea of an area that you wish to visit, or that it is good intro for wannabe world travelers, but it is not greatly detailed.  I'm also not very clear on how different places were chosen for inclusion in the book.  I see this as a nice gift for kids or someone who has not traveled a lot and would like to.

I was intrigued by this product, primarily because of the portability and ease of use.  You just add drops to a glass of water and that's it.  The good thing is that because it is a drop delivery system, you can easily make this as strong or as weak as you like, unlike powdered one-serving products, such as Crystal Light drinks.  You also don't have any empty packets to dispose of until you finish the bottle.  The reason that I give this three stars is that I prefer a stronger tea flavor with a hint of peach in the background.  This product tastes like the reverse to me: strong peach with a background tea flavor.  If you don't mind that, definitely give this product a try.  It was not too sweet, either, which is another plus in its favor.

I am on my third charger since December 2010.  Three hours ago, I brought the third one home, made sure all the magnetic connectors were clean, and plugged it in.  Like its two predecessors, this one is overheating.  It doesn't matter WHERE I plug these chargers in, at home a coffee shop, the airport, a friend's house - the same thing happens. Charger number two was actually smoking last week.  The Apple store folks cluck and tell me that's not supposed to happen, but refuse to do anything about it except sell me a new almost $80 charger because my laptop is no longer under warranty. I just bought the third charger at a Micro Center and bought a $10 warranty from them to go with it.

I've been to India, and I found that some books were light on info and geared more toward group tours, while others were encyclopedic with so much info that it was overwhelming, and so bulky that it would be a bother to lug it around all day.  This book strikes a good balance - good size, loaded with color photos, well organized, and plenty of information.  This is a book that I would cart around all day.  That being said, the more comprehensive treatises also have their place as a source of preliminary research.  India is one of those places where the more you study before you go, the smoother the trip and the better time you'll have.

I wanted a backup for those times that I run out of or forget to buy fresh parsley.  The color is a vibrant green and the flavor is pleasant.  Not as good as freh, but the best dried that I've been able to find.

I accidentally bought an 8 oz. jar of this to use in making an olive condiment for muffuletta, when actually I meant to buy olives stuffed with pimentos.  The taste and texture are pretty good:  firm, not mushy or mealy, with a strong hit of capers. If you like capers, that's a plus, but if you do not, be forewarned because you will taste them. For some reason, maybe the presence of pimentos in the jar, I thought they were pitted, but they are not, so keep that in mind in case you need pitted olives.

I have fine hair, but a lot of it, so I expected that something with macadamia oil would weigh it down like so many other products do.  Boy, was I surprised - it left my hair feeling silky but not weighed down, but I didn't go bonkers with the product, either.  The scent is not too strong straight out of the bottle, and I found that it dissipated quickly, but for a few hours after I washed my hair, I thought the scent was on the strong side once I actually used it. It also doesn't smell like macadamia and orchids, but like mild coconut.  If you are sensitive to smells, or are a perfume wearer who doesn't want scents to clash, keep that in mind.

The more soluble form of the coenzyme is available in this soy and GMO-free, but not vegetarian capsule.  There are other reviews that go into great detail comparing this product to others, and I recommend that you read them.  My whole family takes this product, including our dogs, and I am pleased with the results:  blood testing indicates that the product is being well absorbed which is what you need if you want to get the most health benefits from it, instead of wasting your money on an expensive supplement. The other CoQ10 that I use from time to time is Life Extension, which is also absorbed well but more expensive.

What I like best about this brush is the ergonomic handle - it is easy to hold and handle the brush.  Frankly, I was surprised by this, and find that I am brushing my teeth longer than I normally do.  I also like the large brush head.  I have not found that my teeth are any whiter, and even though it's a soft brush, it does feel a bit harsh on my gums, so I advise a light touch when brushing.

I honestly wasn't sure what to expect with this - if I didn't like it, it would have been too expensive to ship back because it's heavy.  At any rate, I was not disappointed - the stairs are very sturdy, attractive with a richly-colored wood, and easy to use.  No assembly required, a big plus for me.  After a bit of gentle coaxing with treats, my 13 year old pup LOVES them and uses them all the time.  One caveat:  measure the height of the furniture that your dog will need access to so that you order the correct size.

I was looking for a bucket that was stable and easy to carry, so when the opportunity came up to review this bucket for Amazon, it was perfect timing.The PROS:- sturdy, yet light weight.  When I pick a full bucket up by the handle, I don't get the wild swinging that I have with tall, round buckets.- the handle is easy to grip and hold.  Other buckets have handles that are too thin and twirl around, making it hard to keep a grip.- the markings on the side of the bucket are very helpful, and are marked in both metric and English standard measurements.- it took me a bit to figure it out, but there are also marking on the bottom of the bucket to help you measure liquid amounts without the use of another measuring cup.  At first I thought they were for dry ingredients, but they work for best for liquid ones, like bleach.The CONS:- the markings are a bit hard to see- the handle gets slippery when wetNeutral:Other reviewers have had mixed feelings about the mop clip, but I don't use it so it doesn't affect my review.None of the cons are significant enough for me to subtract any stars.  I love this bucket, and even use it to haul stuff around the house, not just for cleaning.

As you can see from other reviews, this is a fantastic product - for the right dog.We recently adopted a 13 year old dog with a number of health issues, and having used other products from this company, I purchased this as a vitamin supplement that I could use on all my dogs (with my vet's OK).  I started the dogs out on a half dose, and 2 of them ended up with diarrhea.  Again, NOT unusual when you make changes to a dog's diet, so I cut back to a quarter dose.  Still terrible diarrhea.  That's when I put on reading glasses and took a closer look at the label, and saw that the fourth ingredient on the label is Nutritional Yeast.  The 2 dogs that were reacting badly to the product are allergic to Nutritional Yeast.Unfortunately, neither the Amazon description nor the product page at the manufacturer's website at rxvitamins - dot - com (if I put in the link, Amazon will delete it, so just replace "dot" with a ".") provide any information on the actual ingredients in the product.  Here is information off the side of the bottle:Active Ingredients per scoop:L-Glutamine (2500 mg), Kelp Powder (760 mg), Lecithin Granules (760 mg), Nutritional Yeast (760 mg), Bio-Agaricus (600 mg),L-Arginine (500 mg), Green Tea Extract (500 mg), Spirulina (500 mg), Sodium Ascorbate (250 mg), Larch Arabinogalactin (250 mg), Silymarin (150 mg), Del-Immune V (25 mg), Zinc picolinate (15 mg), Vitamin A (500 IU), Vitamin E (200 IU), Vitamin D (75 IU), Selenium (25 mcg).Cautions:  Safe use in pregnant animals or animals intended for breeding has not been proven.Directions for use:  For each 50 lbs. (22.7 kg) of body weight, mix 1 scoop in your pet's food once daily or as prescribed by your veterinarian.  Higher does have been associated clinically with increased formula efficiency.Like I said above, the website does not give any of this information, so you may have to call or email the company directly.  Contact info is on their website.So, this is a terrific product IF your dog is not allergic to any of the ingredients; in the case of 2 of my dogs, that is nutritional yeast.  Had that information been available in the product description or on the manufacturer's website, I would have passed on this particular supplement.

In a nutshell, the people who will probably like this book are ATK fans, and those who like to experiment with a crock pot.  Those who may not like it likely view a slow cooker as the ultimate fix it and forget it kitchen tool, where you throw everything in the crock and come back at the end of the day to a meal.I like this book better than the first one because the recipes appeal to me more.  However, many of the recipes are not slow cooker only, but require the use of a microwave, the broiler, stove top, or boiling water.  I tried one of chicken wing recipes and it was good, but after basting and finishing it off under the broiler, it left me wondering just how much of a savings the crock pot was in terms of effort.  I would probably never make any of the desserts in the book, not because they look bad, but because I like to bake the traditional way.I really recommend that you click on the "Look Inside" option at the top of the product page, and take a look at some of the recipes, photos (a big plus- lots of color photos), and some of the recipes.  This book will either click for you or it won't, as you can tell from the tone of a lot of the reviews.  The recipes are good, so that's not the issue - it's whether you want to put more effort into them than is typical for slow cooker recipes.

I tested this with very, very low expectations.  There are some decent products on the market, but none have been able to tackle the stains left on old berber basement carpet that serves as the thoroughfare for three dogs from the back yard.  Earlier this year, the dogs added some pee stains and family members added BBQ chicken juice to the carpeting.  Had I been around when this occurred, I would have used Nature's Miracle, a fantastic product that works very well if used *promptly.*Almost a year later, I decided to try Krud Kutter on this conglomeration of stains.  While I was still spraying, THE WORST STAIN STARTED TO DISAPPEAR BEFORE MY EYES.  I was completely shocked.  I then went bonkers tackling spots, some of which were 6-8 inches long and very dark (the BBQ sauce had acted like a glue).  Those took a little rubbing with a damp cloth, per the instructions, but they, too, disappeared.  This is the best stain remover I have ever used.  I am tempted to try it on a couple of old t-shirts to see if it works on them.Note:  My basement carpet is a speckled berber that is on the pale side, so there was no discoloration from the cleaner.  The label states that you should test first for color-fastness, and if you have darker rugs, you should definitely do that.  This stuff is powerful!

The vacuum is heavy, but surprisingly easy to move. Good suction and a convenient retractable cord.  It worked well on my carpet covered stairs in my 3-very hair dog-house.  Quieter than my uprights, but it still makes noise like a vacuum cleaner, so don't expect it to whisper.  It is NOT bagless, so you will have to figure out when to change bags and the replacement bags are not cheap. Things I would change:  a way to store parts (they fall all over the closet floor when I store it), a longer hose, and some sort of gauge to let you know when the bag is full.

I have found that this helps shorten the length and reduce the severity of a cold IF you start taking it early - as soon as you feel the vaguest of cold symptoms. Follow the directions and do not take more than the recommended amount or you may end up with some temporary loss of the ability to taste, which I think may be due to some of the active ingredients.  This has happened to me but went away within a few days.  When I've used this in conjunction with Zicam spray, the combination really helped.  Again, follow the directions and don't overdo it.

I have been making fermented foods for many years, primarily krauts and sourdough breads.  I have Sandor Katz's wonderful book, The Art of Fermentation, too, so I wasn't really getting my hopes up with this book.  I was wrong.When it comes to the "Dummies" series, I don't expect anything in-depth, just a good, decent overview of a topic.  I was really surprised to find out how much the author's managed to pack into this book! From fermented vegetables, to nut cheeses, from dairy cheeses to breads to kombucha, the book is packed with recipes and clear guidance for anyone who wants to add these healthful foods to their diet.  If you want to see what's in the book, as well as to take a look at the table of contents, click "Look Inside" at the top of the page.  Highly recommend this book.

I've been cleaning up my diet over the past few months, but when I want to eat dessert, I don't mess around.  I eat the real stuff, and these recipes fall in that category.  Full of classic and new puddings and pudding-based desserts, this is a beautiful book with lovely photographs and easy to follow recipes.  I had a black and white preview copy, but if you click on the "Look Inside" option at the top of the product page, you can see for yourself how nice the color photos turned out.These are NOT low fat puddings.  They include heavy cream and egg yolks, and boy are they good.  I've made chocolate, vanilla, and butterscotch.  To be honest, the cream/egg yolk versions are a bit too heavy for me, so after making the chocolate, I switched to regular milk and the recipes still turned out great.  If you love pudding and want a few more recipes to make, plus pudding pops and cakes, this is a good book for your library.

I've read, bought, and checked out from the library about a dozen paleo cookbooks, and I'm usually left with a kind of "meh" attitude.  Nice, but not inspiring for me, although they may be for others.  This is not one of those books.  Beautifully photographed, clearly written with some recipes that have a long list of ingredients, but most that don't, I actually want to cook from this cookbook. I've made several main dishes and salads, with a favorite being the meat loaf muffins.  I don't really like the dessert chapter much, but honestly, when I allow myself to eat dessert, I go for it and don't try to make it healthy.  The recipes use a lot of coconut milk, which works find, but I've also subbed heavy cream (which is probably more "primal" than paleo eating), and it worked find.  Nice cookbook for everyday eating.

*UPDATE*- I ordered these again, and this time I would rate the jalapeno 1 star.  Why?  My personal preference is mildly spicy and mildly salty.  In the second batch, the jalapeno flavor was inedible for me - so spicy and so salty that I had to eat yogurt to cool the burn in my mouth and throat.  So, the heat and salt intensity were extremely inconsistent between the two batches.  If you love heat and salt, no problem, but if you don't, be careful.My family loves Kettle Chips, and once in a while we will get a big Costco-sized bag of rippled chips for special occasions.  Because you never know if another variety will taste good, and I didn't want to be left with a bag of chips that I hated, I had been reluctant to try other flavors.  This variety box did the trick, and I found 2 new flavors that I will be buying in the future.Sea Salt and Vinegar - 5 stars, my favorite flavor.  Perfectly salted, with a vinegar taste that does not overwhelm.Jalapeno  - 4.5 stars.  The bags say "HOT" but they're not, just mildly spicy, and this is coming from someone who does not like a lot of heat.Backyard BBQ - 4.5 stars - typical BBQ flavor, but it was not as salty as other brands of BBQ chips, which is a good thing.Salt and Pepper - 4.0 stars - very strong pepper taste, which I like, but which got old after a while.If you like strong flavored chips, this is the variety pack for you.  Really glad we tried it.

The recipes in this book are really good, for the most part - flavorful, very diverse, and interesting.  The photos are great.  I'd give the book 4 stars for those two things alone.The problem, however, is that this is supposed to be a book on techniques, i.e., a teaching book.  In this regard the book is weak.  While there are pictures of cutting up a chicken, for example, I don't think there are enough of them for a beginner.  Another example of sparse instructions can be found in the instructions for scrambling eggs - a side note explains that the addition of different liquids will change the results. . . and that's it.  It doesn't tell you what adding cream versus water versus milk will do.  You are left to wonder.  So, if you want some really good recipes and don't really care too much about very detailed technique, this is a great book to have.  If you are looking for a book that provides more detailed instructions, then I recommend looking for another book, such as Cooking, by James Peterson.

When I ate the first couple of crackers out of the box, I thought, "nah, nothing special."  There was a mild chipotle taste, and I am not really a fan of chipotle.  After I ate 2/3 of the box, which is about 1200 calories later, I changed my mind.  Delightfully salty and zesty, I like these a lot better than regular Cheez-its.  18 crackers add up to about 150 calories, and there are 12 servings for box.  These would be great to serve at a party where you have other people to help you eat them, so you don't eat all your calories for the day in one sitting!

As some of the other reviews noted there are no slick production values. It feels and looks like you are in a working dojo street sounds and all. Frankly that doesn't bother me as I work out in one. David Chang demonstrates the moves well and narrates as he goes along to help get the proper movement. For me the learning speed was just right, not too fast or too slow. It may take several run throughs to get it all right, but the beginner can accomplish learning basic Tai Chi from this DVD. There is an 8 minute stretch to begin then you have a 28 minute session where there is a choice between a regular and mirrored version. I appreciate there is a version for iPod as I like to use mine.I only have 2 small criticisms. The iPod version of the regular workout portion is split into 3 separate 9 minute clips instead of one flowing one. I also would have liked an un-narrated version where once the moves were learned we could just go with the flow of the stretches and routine. Of course you can always turn off the sound and put on some music and the only distracton would be ignoring the lip movements as Chang narrates. Other than these two small quibbles, I enjoyed this DVD and would recommend it to beginners. As I recall I also purchased this DVD new at a discounted price so for me it was also a good value.

As of the writing of this review, the book is availble free on the Internet (due to Amazon's policies I am not able to leave the URL here). Of course there are plugs for Dick Sutphen's products and workshops, but along the way he does manage to deliver some interesting info and I can't complain as I got the book for free. Plus, I have nothing against people making a living.To summarize some of the info, there are different qualities to the energy of the vortexes, yin and yang or postive and negative (negative does not mean bad or evil, but it's just a different quality like the positve and negative ends of a battery) and each vortex also emanates energy that is electric, magnetic, or electromagnetic (combo of both). Boynton Canyon is electromagnetic, Airport Vortex is electric. It is also possible to see "auras" around some of the vortexes. Many anecdotes from his workshop participants are included. The e-edition I found was copyrighted 2006 and was approximately 150 pages. I can't substantiate the info and to be truthful haven't done any research into vortexes so I can't say if his info is accurate, but it was an interesting read. There are a few suggested meditations and suggestions for things to try such as automatic writing while a vortex.I have visted Sedona and had some interesting experiences after coming off the votexes. I also saw one of the most breathtaking rainbows there and I can see why many feel it is a sacred place.

I found this book in PDF for free on the Internet (because of Amazon restrictions I cannot put the URL here). It was copyrighted in 2006 for the e-edition of the book and is about 150 pages. It has interesting information about vortexes and people's experiences, though I cannot confirm all of it is accurate. Of course part of the purpose is mentioning Dick Sutphen's products/tours, but it didn't bother me as I felt there was interesting info presented along the way and the man has a right to earn a living. Perhaps at this point in time much of this information is available for free off the Internet so that is why the book was made available for free. If the info is accurate there are different types of vortexes, yin and yang or positive and negative (not negative as in bad or evil, but more like a different quality such as the positive and negative ends of a battery), and each vortex also carries a different energy or combination of energies, electric, magnetic, and electromangnetic. According to Sutphen Boynton Canyon is a great place to visit as it has balanced electromagnetic energies. Another good place is Bell Rock as it's like an energy beacon and there have been many UFO sightings. Some also state they able to see energy "auras" around the vortexes. There isn't a whole lot of deep info and the book isn't very long, but still a nice collection of interesting info and anecdotes. There are a few suggestions for meditations and things to try such as automatic writing while at a vortex.I can say for myself I have been on a Sedona vortex tour and I had some interesting experiences after coming off the vortexes, perhaps the best words for it would be synchronicities. My experiences changed my mind about the spiritual. I was always busy running offices and people and never thought about the spiritual and after Sedona I took up energy work and now do volunteer energy work in local hospitals. This book is about Sedona vortexes, but it mentions Kauai as the other positive energy vortex (the entire island is apparently an energy vortex). I have also heard people mention Maui and Kona as energy places to visit. I offer this as additional info for those looking for these types of places to visit and I admit Hawaii is my home state so I am biased in favor of a visit there.Not everyone will experience something on vortexes and everyone will experience something different. A trip there can be expensive, but if you're able to go when the rates are lower or look for a B&B rather than staying at an expensive hotel you can do it for a reasonable cost. The beauty of the place is undeniable and if you enjoying hiking Arizona is a great place to do it in and there are many hikiing trails and clubs. There are touristy areas and given there are limitations to what kind of business activities one could do there what else do they have to support the area but tourism, health and wellness, weddings, etc.? You can go out from the area and experience other things. As with all things it is what you make of the experience and if you only want to focus on the touristy parts then that is what you draw in. I met some nice people there and found authentic Indian made jewelry for about the cheapest price I've seen so far so explore the area and make it a positive experience. I saw one of the breathtaking rainbows ever while there. I can see why many feel it is a sacred place.

I know it's nice to have the author or creator of the product speak on it, but in this case it was not helpful as unfortunately Ingerman's voice was distracting. This CD is what I would term guided meditations as journey's should not have too much guidance. Part of the point of the journey is to allow what is meant for you to receive. Ingerman should have provided some info, help set the intention for the journey then let the imagination of the journeyer take him/her on the journey to discover what is meant for him/her. A large part of the shamanic journey is allowing and using your own imagination and by trying to guide too much I felt Ingerman didn't allow the natural journey process to occur. Also since her voice was distracting I just could not keep my mind focused on the journey.

This book is aimed at the layman and is kept succinct, around 75 pages, so as not to overwhelm the reader. There is some great information and Rita explains a technique called The Remembrance. The Remembrance essentially relaxes you, puts you in touch with the sacredness/love that dwells within. The Remembrance instruction is about a page and a half and easy to do. It can be done prenatal to connect/bond with your baby. This would make a wonderful gift for any family expecting a baby or preparing for parenthood. Even if that baby has already been born, this book can help families understand and connect with that precious little one and with your own inner resources.

What I appreciated most about this book first published in 1919 is Arthur Avalon (Sir John Woodroffe) takes great pains to stay true to the sanskrit texts instead of reinventing them or overlaying them with his personal experiences, interpretations and thoughts. This book is a follow up/expansion on his previous book Shakti and Shakta and in retrospect I wish I had read it first, although it is not necessary as this book stands on its own. In the beginning of the book Avalon/Woodroffe takes to task some of the Westerners, most notably the Theosophical Society and Charles Leadbeater, which popularized their version/ideas about the 7 chakras in Western society. Avalon/Woodroffe felt they also popularized misconceptions or inaccuracies along with their ideas about the cakras/chakras. As the author prefers to let the texts speak for themselves most of the book is devoted to his translation of the texts and their description of the 6 cakras (chakras), their associations and powers. He also discusses kundalini and the rising of kundalini. Having said all this, the book is not an easy read. Avalon/Woodroffe uses many sanskrit terms and verses to keep to the actual text/meaning and while he does explain each and there are copius footnotes this will not be reading you can breeze through. I particularly enjoyed some of the verses.Verse 37He then also sees the Light which is in the form of a flaming lamp. It is lustrous like the clearly shining morning sun, and glows between the Sky and the Earth. It is here that the Bhagavan manifests Himself int he fullness of His might. He knows no decay, and witnesseth all, and is here as He is in the refion of Fire, Moon, and Sun.Perhaps not a book you might want to begin with, but for those interested in studying the cakras/chakras a must.

I was looking for something in the 15-30 minute range as I wanted to use the didgeridoo track(s) to journey or meditate to. These tracks fit the bill. I also purchased Didgeridoo Meditation: An Odyssey Through Consciousness. I didn't care for the water sounds for some reason so I only purchased the 3rd track off the album after listening to the samples. I feel the nature sounds really add to it and I like that it's just didgeridoo playing without a lot of new age/digital enhancements. Playing the track makes me feel relaxed and yet energized and like I'm camping out sleeping under the stars. Recommended.

I uploaded some card images and to help you decide if this desk if for here is some info from the book:The Karma Cards are designed to answer two types of questions:1. What will be the outcome...(of any situation)?2. What should I do (about, because of, with, to)...(any situation)?Two other ways to phrase questions for the Karma Cards are:1. What should I keep in mind when I...2. What kind of situation/mood/atmosphere can I expect to encounter or prepare for...?The questions you can ask of the Karma Cards are suitable to answer a wide range of issues. The cards are divided into Planets, Houses, and Signs. The cards have a red end for action and a blue end for the outcome. You will orient the cards by the red or blue ends depending on whether you want to receive an answer for action or outcome answer and card will be chosen from each of the 3 card divisions. Each card end also gives answers on 3 levels (spiritual, mental and physical). There are phrases written for each of the levels and the phrases on each level are strung together as an answer with one or more of the sentences. The meaning of the sentence is up to the recipient of the reading, in other words there is no set meaning and each person may interpret the same sentence differently. They were a fun alternative to tarot cards, but to be honest I prefer fully illustrated tarot decks as I am visually oriented and I'm not too familiar with or interested in astrology. What I liked about the Karma Cards is they are easy to use and anyone can do a reading for themselves. The sentences formed are in a positive and encouraging vein. It was fun turning the cards and playing with the sentence formed. I think I am going to give my set to a friend to do readings for herself and the set would make a nice gift for a special person.There appears to be another listing for this same card set Karma Cards. You can read more reviews about the card set. Blessings

The subject of reflexology is complex using many points throughout the body, but by keeping the subject to the hands and feet the author makes the subject accessible for beginners. The hands and feet are great places to start to learn reflexology. My own experience doing energy work has taught me that working the hands and feet, lightly massaging them to release stress, has been very helpful to patients so starting off learning reflexology with the hands and feet makes sense. The drawings for the reflexology massage were clear, but some of the other illustrations were a bit cartoonish and simplistic. The general information and written instructions were clear and easy to follow showing where specific locations are connected to organs, nerves, etc. and how to perform basic sessions. The back of the book has an Ailments Reference Chart of a few pages with ailments, symptoms and main areas to treat. The chart has a range of ailments that include cerebral palsy, cancer, bursitis, gout, angina, epilepsy, constipation, indigestion, hay fever, and migraines. Overall I liked the book and thought it was good starter book for those wanting to learn the basics before heading off into a more complex book. The book appears to be out of print at this time, or perhaps they are updating it.

I uploaded some card images and to help you decide if this deck is for you. Here is some info from the book:The Karma Cards are designed to answer two types of questions:1. What will be the outcome...(of any situation)?2. What should I do (about, because of, with, to)...(any situation)?Two other ways to phrase questions for the Karma Cards are:1. What should I keep in mind when I...2. What kind of situation/mood/atmosphere can I expect to encounter or prepare for...?The questions you can ask of the Karma Cards are suitable to cover a wide range of issues. The cards are divided into Planets, Houses, and Signs. The cards have a red end for action and a blue end for the outcome. You will orient the cards by the red or blue ends depending on whether you want to receive an answer for action or outcome answer and card will be chosen from each of the 3 card divisions. Each card end also gives answers on 3 levels (spiritual, mental and physical). There are phrases written for each of the levels and the phrases on each level are strung together as an answer with one or more of the sentences. The meaning of the sentence is up to the recipient of the reading, in other words there is no set meaning and each person may interpret the same sentence differently. They were a fun alternative to tarot cards, but to be honest I prefer fully illustrated tarot decks as I am visually oriented and I'm not too familiar with or interested in astrology. What I liked about the Karma Cards is they are easy to use and anyone can do a reading for themselves. The sentences formed are in a positive and encouraging vein. It was fun turning the cards and playing with the sentence formed. I think I am going to give my set to a friend to do readings for herself and the set would make a nice gift for a special person.
