If you want a true ghost story, reported by multiple credible witnesses and repeatedly documented by a  corporation over several years, look no further than this fascinating account of true supernatural sightings. After a plane goes down in the everglades due to the pilots preoccupation with a faulty landing gear light, many of the parts are salvaged for use on other planes.  On those other planes, members of the doomed flight crew appear to give cogent warnings as to electrical and hydraulic problems.  These fully formed individuals are seen and even spoken to by industry executives, flight crews, flight attendants, and passengers.  At first the industry reacts by sending employees to shrinks, and reissuing new log books for flights after every sighting. Then finally, they pull the parts out of every plane.Often true haunting stories are poorly written and poorly documented (too often seem to be written by people who want to publish a book, so decide they live in a haunted house, based on little more than dreams, feelings and noisy pipes).  But this is a well written and well documented account.  Worth the price and fascinating, not just for the credibility of the sightings themselves, but for the accounts of how truly "real" and interactive these manifestations were.  You may start reading as a skeptic, but given the multiplicity of the sightings and credibility of the witnesses, on multiple planes over long periods, this phenomena passes the credibility test.

After starting off well, with a naive but interesting heroine and situation.  But then the story looses focus and strength when it moves to the spirit world.  I became impatient with her often purposeless meandering there and  eventually skipped to the end.

The other review seems to be describing a completely different book.  Me, Cassie, is the funny and  irreverent narrator of this coming of age story.  It's set in the mid 60s, in a suburb outside of NYC,  but actually Cassie's journey is essentially timeless.  The chief attraction for this novel, outside of the narrator's voice is the cast of characters, which starts out with Cassie, her suburban club attending cause conscious mother, businessman father and odd teenage brother Eddie.  She also has an eccentric actress grandmother who lives in the East Village.  Cassie is very pretty, but becomes attracted to a short, nerdish new boy, and they go out without actually going out. Meanwhile, upheavals occur in her family, a whole group of orphaned relatives move in, and in the confusion, her mother forgets she's invited an African exchange student, who actually turns out to be two.  Cassie describes the resulting tumult  very amusingly. Meanwhile, through her Grandmother, she begins to get modeling, print ad, and tv commerical jobs, eventually becoming a minor teen celebrity.  Her boyfriend goes off to Harvard, assorted relatives and exchange student friends go off to their colleges, while she stays home and becomes increasingly famous without, she believes, any merit behind it - the kind of empty fame from exposure rather than skill.  By the end of the year, she's come to a conclusion about that sort of work and something of her future is settled.The real merit of this book is not in the actually storyline, but in the characterization and dialogue and in the zany happenings.  I am surprised there are no other reviews for this book, and so I have to put in a plug for it. I read it as a teen and periodically reread it every few years, because it is always good for a bit of a laugh

The daughter of a famous radio personality who will soon be graduating from college visits the U.N. while her mother is making a research trip for her father's book.  Undecided about a future career, but not wanting it to be in radio, she becomes enamored of the U.N. guides after taking a tour.  A year later she arrives in New York to train and serve as a guide.I purchased this as a Scholastic book title when I was eleven or so, some ten years after it was published in 56.  Coming across it, have just reread it, noting that it was written by the later bestselling gothic author Phyllis A. Whitney.  Even early in her career, due to her competence,  the story moves smoothly.  Three storylines intertwine -- the story of a young woman moving away from home to her first job in a big city in search of her life's work, a love story, and a tribute to the U.N.  According to the author's notes, she was asked to write a book involving the U.N., and it becomes almost the main character in the book, particularly the UNICEF children's fund, which children often collected change for during Halloween in specially marked milk cartons.More than 60 years after it was first published, the story holds up pretty well.  The heroine's search for her own identity and her plight of not wanting to be a clone of her famous father is universal regardless of century.  While the heroine, her apartment mate, and their suitors  read as very young, compared to a similarly aged young adults  today, it's more likely this is because the story was written with young teenage girls in mind, rather than that young people of that age were that nave.  It's interesting and amusing, to see NYC through Whitney's eyes in 1956.  What is most anachronistic is to compare the hopes for the U.N. as expressed ten years after WWII, to what the world has become now.

I read very carefully the description of this item, and while it says it strips undercoat and removes dead hairs, it doesn't say it cuts hair. I also bought the model recommended for a German Shepherd (GSD)  I started at my dogs head and ran it along her body in long sweeping strokes.  It brought out some undercoat, but mixed with guard hairs. I will say the removed fur was not so flyaway as it is on regular shedding rakes, but as I looked at it, I realized that was because it contained as much guard hair as undercoat.  Still I thought it was removing 'old dead' guardhairs, as the description claims.  I will say that my dog, who sometimes objects to a pin or rake style shedding rake, apparently didn't mind the feel of this on her.But on conclusion, my dog appears to be of a different color in places where her long black tipped guard hairs were cut off before they turned black.  Her guard hairs are not standing out as much from her coat.  And her tail, which I didn't think I had gone over very much, appeared more like a rat's tail than a fat GSD plume.  I've never had a shedder rake do this.I went back and read the description again, and all the reviews.  The description of the item, and the reviews just don't indicate this kind of result. While there was one lone review warning it cuts hair, the rest say it doesn't cut hair, but removes undercoat and thins out dead hair.  Pulling out dead hair is very different than cutting off long guard hairs.  True, most of those reviews  are for owners using it on newfs, terriers and goldens, breeds who may not have the long guard hairs of a GSD, particularly a long haired/long coated GSD.  But some were for long coated dogs.Anyway, in terms of comfort for the dog, she minded it less than a pin style rake.  As far as raking hair, I don't know how effective it is at thinning or removing dead undercoat.  Being September, her last years undercoat was already largely blown.  It brought out some additional undercoat, but that appeared to be mixed with half guard hairs, which I suspect were not all "dead" guard hairs being removed, but live ones sheared off.

This book lacked a beginning and an ending, and useful details.  I wasn't looking for excitement or drama.  But  the author does little setup and to me doesn't quite deliver on the title.  If you're familiar with the geography of the area, you can soon tell he's intending to climb Everest from the north.  But the author doesn't say that at the start, nor is he very explicit in the beginning as to what expedition he's climbing with, details as to his choice of this group, etc.  OTOH, seldom is a beer drunk, (and there are a lot of beers drunk) without him noting the brand.  I would have liked a little more on climbing.

Commercial guided expeditions for risky endeavors are more common than ever.  So it is interesting and useful to have a rational account presented of the decision making of this survivor, and so far as he can relay it, by Rob Hall, as to why this expedition went so wrong.  If you ever join an expedition with similar life threatening risks, it might be useful to you.Some of what might have been motivating Hall is information I had not read before. What motivated the author was love, responsibility, and a desire to return alive and whole to family  -- when he could clearly see this expedition was taking the level of risk to an unimaginable level.But why was it raised to that level?  I've never understood why Hall continued to guide his group so late, when he knew if they went to summit they were going to run out of oxygen before they returned to the oxygen cache. Apart from the issues of daylight, weather, relative strength, etc, the logistics of oxygen, for those using it, were incompatible with success with that timetable.  Hall had to know it, particularly for Hansen - who'd had a problem crashing in the previous year.  Hearing Mr. Kasischke relate his problems with his oxygen system,  added to complaints from others,  made me wonder if that gear was flawed. A bad oxygen system would  contribute to the poor decision making.Kasischke relates his own psychology of why he climbs, why he chose the Hall group, his disappointment when Hall made decisions counter to the reasoning he chose him in the first place, and when and why he broke with Hall's leadership when he determined it was fatally flawed. I think all these are useful for anyone who might need to make similar decisions in the future. Even if survival is not part of the end result - we all have to choose who to follow, why, when to follow, and when to leave.In terms of content, this narrative is heavy on philosophy and less heavy on daily details of the expedition, personalities and color. That doesn't mean it isn't there, because it is. But that's only half the tale, the rest is philosophy.  And Mr. Kasischke is discreet.  Having been rudely surprised himself when Krakauer's ratings of his teammates appeared in an Outside Online web interview - something the members of the team didn't expect to  have discussed or reported on -- Kasischke is careful to respect his teammate's privacy.  As a reader, I respect that too, but I confess I had less of an immediate feel of the places and people at times, due to that.  Still, the last chapter, where he goes into some of what he suspects was Hall's reasoning for the summit attempt was fascinating and something I had never read elsewhere.This book also gave a great sense of the truly frigid experiences of high camp after the summit attempt, how pinned down everyone was by the storm and how difficult survival was even for those who made it back to camp.  I can completely understand why, having survived this, the author chose to hang up his crapons after this expedition.  I am glad, though, that he didn't hang up his pen, and that we have this account.All in all, if you are interested in Himalaya expeditions, Everest, or just this particular expedition, this is a book that you have to purchase.

I read this bio decades ago, and liked it for her insider's view of the SF and NYC Ballet companies, as well as her later 'comeback' attempt in the U.K and Europe.  True, those looking for the fantasy of standing ovations and roses may be disenchanted by the hard work, sore muscles and injuries, jealousies and intrigues and so on that the author relates.  But this is a backstage view of the 'making' and 'unmaking' then 'remaking' of a dancer.  I think the author speaks very believably.  Glad to see it is out in kindle form.

According to the description, there were 8000 applicants for the 19 positions in this reality series on recreating an authentic Edwardian manor house environment.  To me it seems the selection was based more on who would provide the most 21st century angst than who were most suited to the positions, and how much historical reality was involved in setting up the house or was that contrived for drama, rather than the historic re-enactment.The participants are repeatedly described as volunteers. I wonder if that means they were entirely unpaid for their labor in the house, because certain of them were required to labor -- apart from the filming --  while others had leisure.  The life of a scullery maid, of course, was the most hellish, rising well before dawn,  basically tied to a sink or a scrub brush for 18 hours a day.  Using caustic soda would rapidly turn hands red and raw, and they fell into bed exhausted at night. The girls who took these jobs  were generally from the workhouse, or extremely poor, all of whom had little choice but to go out at work at 14, or not eat.  Their families often had to scrimp and save for 2 years just to buy them the uniform -- dresses and aprons -- necessary to start life in service. And their families were often depending upon the wages the girls earned, that they often sent home so their siblings could eat.  They generally were getting the best food of their lives in service.  Even as bad as it often was, at least food was available and the alternative was back to the workhouse.I have to wonder what 21st century girl would volunteer to spend 18 hours a day chained to a sink or scrub brush for three months for free?  There is no great drama in washing dishes, scrubbing floors or peeling root vegetables.  After a day or two, when it sunk in that there was no drama, and the 3 months would be mere drudgery, I'm not surprised two scullery maids left.  All I can say is I hoped the ones who stayed got paid because that was drudgery.As far as historical accuracy, I thought the house was understaffed even for daily life --  based upon the size and the usual staffing levels of such houses then.  And it was also usual that for special events, extra help was brought in.Most servants in 1900 had a half day off every week or two,  so that initially the servants were given no time off at all, seemed contrived to make them revolt.The older son Jonathan would have been at school, and even the younger son would probably have been away, so that seemed odd to me.  What they should have had were a family with daughters -- daughters stayed at home with governesses.I thought the butler was tiresome in his search to be loved by both upstairs and down. A butler was the head of  a house.  The butler here kept having 21st century staff meetings, trying to work things out democratically.  And expecting his employer to be fond of him. He came to realize his employer regarded him as just a servant responsible for his comfort.  But still to the end of the show, the butler seemed to whine more than the underservants.  Striving to be liked seemed equal or more important to him than doing his job.'Sir John' was probably the best and worst chosen, best because he quickly fell into the mindset of thinking that because ultimate power suited him, everyone else was fine -- smiling maids are happy maids.  Worst because he quickly seemed deluded as to what was going on around him, quite content  so long as he wasn't forced to do anything he didn't want to do.  His unwillingness to eat the traditional cuisine being an example.  His peevishness toward his cook, butler, etc, for delivering that food to him was where he lost the distinction between being in a reality show, where he was expected to be inconvenienced by the period, and being "Sir John", where everyone was supposed to cater to his desires.This is where the premise broke down. It seems the butler was expected to keep reminding everyone of their roles. But the butler couldn't dictate to the family, and even the butler was often inappropriate. And no one was keeping him or the family on the rules. So the only people required to really follow the rules were the underservants.  So were their complaints because of the inequities of Edwardian life, which were many, or equally because of the inequities in the reality show setup?  Who was  keeping the upstairs players and upper servants on track?I expected in the end, to see some discussion from upstairs and downstairs as to this at the end, but the producers didn't. Perhaps because it would have pointed out where their setup failed. And of course having the double dissatisfaction in the under-servants suited the drama more.I thought it was interesting how "Sir John' and his wife, and even the sister, who professed that she was strait-jacketed at first, cried when the 3 months came to an end. The servants did not cry (apart from the butler, who seemed perpetually moved over his role).  I think the family had been infanticized -- reduced to the status of children, shielded from reality, cared for and protected  - because of course 'Sir John' had no real worries - he didn't have to worry about his son's succeeding in society or gambling his estate away, his estate paying, or his real status in society. It was all one big picnic.  In real life, that would not have been as much the case. The servants on the other hand, had mountains of work to get through.  So even that minor 'reality' in making their roles comparable was not real.  I think perhaps another family might have pulled this off better.  At least have been more likable. I can't say I grew to know, or like, any of the upstairs family or believed that any of what they were doing had any real reflection of what their roles would have been in Edwardian society.As for the downstairs, I grew really tired of the butler, and would have preferred to see more of the housekeeper. The lower servants were okay.  The lady's maid was very believable. The tutor was annoying and seemed there to beat the viewer over the head with the wrongs of English colonialism.  This was not the venue for a serious treatment of that theme, and having the tutor say 'do you think it was right for England' to do this or that,  to a child who was his student, is a simplistic question for both the child and the audience. And also not part of the reality of the time.  But the servants roles, the ones who actually did the cooking, cleaning, etc, were believable.2 1/2 stars seems more suited to this drama than three. I watched all of it, but I just didn't think it was as good as it could have been.  A more thoughtfully chosen cast, with someone keeping all sides historically accurate, rather than letting certain groups get off scot free, and a more realistic upstairs life would have improved it enormously.

According to the description, there were 8000 applicants for the 19 positions in this reality series on recreating an authentic Edwardian manor house environment.  To me it seems the selection was based more on who would provide the most 21st century angst than who were most suited to the positions, and how much historical reality was involved in setting up the house or was that contrived for drama, rather than the historic re-enactment.The participants are repeatedly described as volunteers. I wonder if that means they were entirely unpaid for their labor in the house, because certain of them were required to labor -- apart from the filming --  while others had leisure.  The live of a scullery maid, of course, was the most hellish, rising well before dawn,  basically tied to a sink or a scrub brush for 18 hours a day.  Using caustic soda would rapidly turn hands red and raw, and they fell into bed exhausted at night. The girls who took these jobs  were generally from the workhouse, or extremely poor, all of whom had little choice but to go out at work at 14, or not eat.  Their families often had to scrimp and save for 2 years just to buy them the uniform -- dresses and aprons -- necessary to start life in service. And their families were often depending upon the wages the girls earned, that they often sent home so their siblings could eat.  They generally were getting the best food of their lives in service.  Even as bad as it often was, at least food was available and the alternative was back to the workhouse.I have to wonder what 21st century girl would volunteer to spend 18 hours a day chained to a sink or scrub brush for three months for free?  There is no great drama in washing dishes, scrubbing floors or peeling root vegetables.  After a day or two, when it sunk in that there was no drama, and the 3 months would be mere drudgery, I'm not surprised two scullery maids left.  All I can say is I hoped the ones who stayed got paid because that was drudgery.As far as historical accuracy, I thought the house was understaffed even for daily life --  based upon the size and the usual staffing levels of such houses then.  And it was also usual that for special events, extra help was brought in.Most servants in 1900 had a half day off every week or two,  so that initially the servants were given no time off at all, seemed contrived to make them revolt.The older son Jonathan would have been at school, and even the younger son would probably have been away, so that seemed odd to me.  What they should have had were a family with daughters -- daughters stayed at home with governesses.I thought the butler was tiresome in his search to be loved by both upstairs and down. A butler was the head of  a house.  The butler here kept having 21st century staff meetings, trying to work things out democratically.  And expecting his employer to be fond of him. He came to realize his employer regarded him as just a servant responsible for his comfort.  But still to the end of the show, the butler seemed to whine more than the underservants.  Striving to be liked seemed equal or more important to him than doing his job.'Sir John' was probably the best and worst chosen, best because he quickly fell into the mindset of thinking that because ultimate power suited him, everyone else was fine -- smiling maids are happy maids.  Worst because he quickly seemed deluded as to what was going on around him, quite content  so long as he wasn't forced to do anything he didn't want to do.  His unwillingness to eat the traditional cuisine being an example.  His peevishness toward his cook, butler, etc, for delivering that food to him was where he lost the distinction between being in a reality show, where he was expected to be inconvenienced by the period, and being "Sir John", where everyone was supposed to cater to his desires.This is where the premise broke down. It seems the butler was expected to keep reminding everyone of their roles. But the butler couldn't dictate to the family, and even the butler was often inappropriate. And no one was keeping him or the family on the rules. So the only people required to really follow the rules were the underservants.  So were their complaints because of the inequities of Edwardian life, which were many, or equally because of the inequities in the reality show setup?  Who was  keeping the upstairs players and upper servants on track?I expected in the end, to see some discussion from upstairs and downstairs as to this at the end, but the producers didn't. Perhaps because it would have pointed out where their setup failed. And of course having the double dissatisfaction in the under-servants suited the drama more.I thought it was interesting how "Sir John' and his wife, and even the sister, who professed that she was strait-jacketed at first, cried when the 3 months came to an end. The servants did not cry (apart from the butler, who seemed perpetually moved over his role).  I think the family had been infanticized -- reduced to the status of children, shielded from reality, cared for and protected  - because of course 'Sir John' had no real worries - he didn't have to worry about his son's succeeding in society or gambling his estate away, his estate paying, or his real status in society. It was all one big picnic.  In real life, that would not have been as much the case. The servants on the other hand, had mountains of work to get through.  So even that minor 'reality' in making their roles comparable was not real.  I think perhaps another family might have pulled this off better.  At least have been more likable. I can't say I grew to know, or like, any of the upstairs family or believed that any of what they were doing had any real reflection of what their roles would have been in Edwardian society.As for the downstairs, I grew really tired of the butler, and would have preferred to see more of the housekeeper. The lower servants were okay.  The lady's maid was very believable. The tutor was annoying and seemed there to beat the viewer over the head with the wrongs of English colonialism.  This was not the venue for a serious treatment of that theme, and having the tutor say 'do you think it was right for England' to do this or that to a child, is a simplistic question for both the child and the audience. And also not part of the reality of the time.  But the servants roles, the ones who actually did the cooking, cleaning, etc, were believable.2 1/2 stars seems more suited to this drama than three. I watched all of it, but I just didn't think it was as good as it could have been.  A more thoughtfully chosen cast, with someone keeping all sides historically accurate, rather than letting certain groups get off scot free, and a more realistic upstairs life would have improved it enormously.
I found this most recent story to be very interesting even though I had never seen the comic books behind it.  Worth a look.
A haunting and beautiful song that I could listen to over and over.  All of this album is inspiring.  Highly recommended.
One of the best and most moving songs to come along in a long time.  This group sets a new standard when it comes to inspirational songs.  Recommended.
An absolute pleasure to both the senses and the spirit, this is a fine illustration of the spirit of the human race and out need to explore.  Fantastic 3D images, great story.  Highly recommended.
An outstanding look at the life of a man who has really made a difference.
Excellent merchandise.  I would deal with this seller any time.
Excellent documentary.  It was great to learn more about the man behind the faces!

Absolutely outstanding piece of technology.  I purchased my Chromebook about 6 months ago and I am just as pleased with it today and the first day I opened the box.  Several things that are stellar about this machine tha should be highlighted:Weight: At only 3 pounds it is easy to take anywhere and I actually ended up saving myself about 8 pounds.Cost: With a price tag that is lower than most tablets, why not have a real keyboard and a 13 inch screen?Ease of setup:  I was up and running on this machine is less than 30 minutes (a new world record).Lack of MS software:  Not an issue.  I use a remote desktop app to access any MS software remotely if I need it.Battery life:  At least 9 hours has been like having a long distance cord.  Never an issue!Lack of a hard drive:  Honestly, who cares.  The cloud is my hard drive now and it is much more convenient.Software availability:  They're right when they say "there's an app for that" because there very nearly is every time.Overall the best technology money I have spent in years.  I highly recommend a Chromebook (you pick your favorite manufacturer) and I am sure you will be pleased.

Outstanding solution to my need to charge multiple deices on the go.  This is the third product I have bought from Anker and these folks really know technology and how to make it work for the consumer.  Highly recommended!
One of the best team-ups of Thompson and Branaugh.  A real film noir thriller.  Recommended
Excellent substitute for OEM cartridges a 25% of the OEM cost.  Recommended!
Excellent substitute for OEM cartridges a 25% of the OEM cost.  Recommended!
Great resource for an aviation buff.  Highly Recommended!
Great resource for an aviation buff.  Highly Recommended!

The definition of the word practitioner is "a person actively engaged in an art, discipline, or profession".  If you are actively engaged in the art, discipline or profession of project management, then you just found the only book you will need to be successful at it.Lynda has done a wonderful job of distilling down the techniques involved in all the stages of the project management lifecycle and making them available in a concise guide that is easy to understand and implement.  Her combination of actual project management experience and extensive teaching experience provides a perfect mix of real world experience as well as an insightful method of teaching these techniques to others.The illustrations add just the right touch to make the techniques come alive for those of us who learn better "visually" as opposed to "textually".  As a life-long project management "practitioner", I am sure I will come back to this book again and again as a reference and invaluable project management resource.  Highly recommended!

I already have the smaller version of the Anker external battery and love it.  This is just another example of a perfect solution to a need for me.  This is light enough to keep with you at all times, works great and delivers a smart solution to my cell phone battery needs.  Highly recommended!
The music from the the sequel isn't quite up to par with the original Rio (no Taio Cruz, for example), but this song stands on its own very well.  Recommended.

At a very reasonable price and very good quality these bulbs were exactly what I needed as replacements for my outside flood lights.  Highly recommended.

With the cost of Dell OEM cartridges being so high, I thought I would give these a try.  I couldn't be more pleased.  for about 1/3 the cost these work perfectly and I've saved a bunch of money.  Highly recommended.
At the high cost of OEM tomer cartridges, this is a great find.  It works perfectly and is less than a  third the cost of OEM.  Highly recommended.

I fervently wish that Marvel would do more shows like this instead of continuing to bring out the Marvel Knights motion comics that just doesn't measure up.  This is a little know gem of a series that is as good as anything else Marvel has produced.  Highly recommended.

I have always thought that this spin-off of CSI was really better in many ways.  For one thing, there was never anyone else at the helm except Mac Taylor who is masterfully portrayed by one of my all-time favorite actors (Gary Sinise).  I highly recommend that you get all nine seasons of this show, start at the beginning and hold on for a great ride.
I think the chemistry between Dean Cain and Christina Cox works well in this movie.  It's a good story and one that you should watch with someone you care about.  recommended.
This is a must have for any Red Green fan because if you are like me you can never get enough of Red and the guys at Possum Lodge.  A great addition to your RG collection.  Recommended.
This is a must have for any Red Green fan because if you are like me you can never get enough of Red and the guys at Possum Lodge.  A great addition to your RG collection.  Recommended.

This is a must have for any Red Green fan because if you are like me you can never get enough of Red and the guys at Possum Lodge.  A great collection of specials to add to your RG collection.  Recommended.
With a literal who's who of video game history as a cast for this cartoon how can you go wrong.  It's a good story and is great for kids even if they didn't grow up playing Atari.  Recommended.
I never get tired of watching Hugh Jackman as he brings the character of Wolverine to life.  This is a must for any Marvel/Wolverine fan.  Recommended.

I don't know how the folks at Disney/Pixar continue to turn out high quality great stories that are a feast for the eyes and heart at the same time, but they do.  If you like Cars or any other Pixar offering, you will not be disappointed with this one.  Highly recommended.

This movie is well crafted and well cast.  And, if you pay a little attention you might even learn something about a part of the American pastime that you never knew.  But, either way you will enjoy this story.  Highly recommended.

Even though I am not a huge Star Wars fan I have enjoyed all of the seasons of the show and S% is not exception.  I really like that the writing and the production of this show has gotten better with each season.  If you're a Star Wars fan, get it (it's a no brainer).  If you're on the fence start with S1 and I'm betting you'll get hooked.  Recemmended.
Max has always been one of my favorites and the upgrade of this to Bluray is certainly worth the price.  A little sparse on extras, but it's great to have all of these movies in HD.  Recommended.

I like David McCallum very much.  I like Joanna Lumley very much.  I thought I would certainly like this series with both of them as stars.  They do work well together, but I'm afraid the problem is at the source.  The material that they are given to act is just not htat good.  I'll cut this series a little slack because it is from 1979, but if you want to watch McCallum and Lumley buy the Invisible Man and Absolutely Fabulous instead.

What's not to like?  I like Iron Man.  I like the Hulk.  I like the fact that they team up and learn to cooperate and fight together in this movie.  And after all, it is a CARTOON, folks.  Watch it with your kids.  Recommended.

I fondly remember growing up watching these guys bumble their way from movie to movie and always enjoyed the good clean fun and approach of these stories.  Take a trip down memory lane and let's hope that Warner keeps these coming so we can enjoy them all.

This is a good documentary of how we love to hate out super villains and why they are as necessary in society as super heroes.  Don't worry though this is far from all academic.  It has great action in it as well.  Recommended.
This is a great addition to the first three seasons and continues to deliver excellent comedy and fun.  Highly recommended.
I got this as a replacement for a similar dehumidifier several months ago and it seems to be performing quite well.  Recommended.
Great acting and an interesting look at the making of one of Hitchcock's best films.  Hopkins and Mirren are worth watching no matter what they do.
This is a film that is a surprisingly good animated take on the Shakespeare classic.  I love the scene with the statue in the park.  Recommended.
This is a very well done, cute and endearing film for the whole family.  Fun story and fun to watch.  Recommended.

I have always liked this movie because of the star quality of the actors.  My only disappointment was the way the film was presented on DVD.  The Blu-ray version is much better and well worth the cost.  Highly recommended.

I needed something to replace my previous cargo pants that had worn out and frankly I didn't think I would find anything I would like because the old ones were so good.  I was pleasantly surprised that these are even better than the old ones.  Great quality, great fit and great functionality.
Another season of one of the best dramatic series on television.  The great stories just keep on coming and they never get old.
A mediocre story is the first of the problems with this latest offering to come out of the Marvel factory.  Could have been better.
Finally the final season of Super Friends to complete my collection.  I have waited a long time for this and it was worth the wait.

As an adult it's easy to overlook how relaxing coloring is. This book reminded me of that. The intricate designs are beautiful and so fun to watch them "come to life." I like that their is quite a selection of designs in this book.What didn't I like? The pages are not spiral bound or perforated, that would have made coloring near the edges and taking them out to color much easier.  I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I love cooking with coconut oil. Using this I've cut out all the unhealthy oils.  This cold pressed oil is labeled USDA organic, non GMO verified. This oil does not require refrigeration, tho I do keep mine there in the summer.  You get alot in this container, which is plastic.When cold it does solidify and can be chipped at or warmed to room temperature to use.  There is no flavor difference in any of my baked goods if I use this or vegetable oil and the consistency is good too. I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

1:54 Mins My son loves trains and train sets, but we don't always have alot of room to set one up.  This train set is great because you can set it up in any size and format you want.  The pieces are incredibly flexible in location, watch the video to see a bit more about that.  We really like how portable it is, because most of the pieces are squares they are easily stack-able and can go anywhere with you.  Other than to change batteries, you will not need any tools with this set.My son is 3 and he loves this, he can decorate the scenery around the tracks however he wants.  Most of the time he asks me to help him set it up and then plays with this without a break for over an hour.  He asks for this first thing in the morning and plays with it for no less than half an hour at least 5x a day.  We also like that the tracks are different colors to help him practice his colors.  This is well made and looks like it will last us years.  Some other vehicles my son has fit in the tracks like the matchbox cars, but not his other train sets.  I do not have any other sets like this to plug and play tracks and roads, but it comes with quite a bit of track and I don't feel we need more. I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

This set has great colors and they look beautiful.  It's been years since I used color pencils and they are more fun than I remembered.  There are so many shades in this pack of each color that I didn't have to cross use 2 of them to make many.  These colored smoothly, no scratching or colors that just didn't want to appear on paper.  The names of the colors are not on the pencils, none are metallic or neon.  They appear to be a wooden pencil and sharpen easily enough.The case is nice for storing them when your not using them, however it can be difficult when your using the colors and changing them frequently. The snap closure is nice, but inside are tabs like on baked goods and while they are sturdy enough the first one goes through the middle for opening.  I took mine and put them in a pencil box and am quite happy.  I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

This pack folds into itself and then becomes a bag to carry it in making it great for a day at the flea market.  We put a medium Carheart jacket into it and it could easily fit more (see photo of it being worn.)  The bag is sturdy and well made.  Their is a pouch inside the bag (see photo). The top part of the bag can be pulled down to keep rain and leaves out of the bag.  The top otherwise is a drawstring.The sternum strap has an orange clip - it's a whistle which is very loud.Their are loops on the bottom you can hang things off of, my 3 year old son is holding it in the photo.I chose the blue because it has different tones to it making it very pretty.  Closed up upon itself it can easily be worn on a belt, thrown into another bag, or tucked into a car.  I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

The directions say: Adults take 1-2 capsules between meals 30-45 minutes after workout.This supplement speeds muscle recovery, supports muscle growth, increases endurance and metabolism, aids in healing digestive system, and helps stabilize mood. It also increases energy, stamina, and focus.I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

2:12 MinsThe pictures in this planner are beautiful.  The entire planner is smaller than you might expect as an English writer I was not able to fit much in the spaces. The holidays are written in Japanese only.  I was able to fit 2-3 words in each box on the monthly page if I wrote small. The notes pages are perfectly sized for writing.  The book is small enough to easily fit in most purses.  The maps are for metro in Tokyo, JapanI think this is best for: someone who is using it for appointments or special events only.  Wants to learn a new word each day.This is not a good planner for most students, anyone who writes in each day of the month, or if your not able to write small. I love baking and attempting to be artistic.  These pans help me with the artistic bit.  I used them to make brownies, nothing special but incredibly yummy.  I took photos to show you how much was left on them, what they looked like done and tried to show you the depth using a nickel for comparison.  One brownie mix made 2 butterflies.These are incredibly cute and with a steady hand you could trace parts of the butterfly with icing for a really nice look.  They are easy to clean, and stack together for storage.  I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

0:54 Mins Until recently I had never used a hot water bottle.  I really thought they were rounder and less comfortable to put your feet on.  Like many my toes are often referred to as toecicles.  My husband is loving that now I warm them up on this instead of him.The bottle is a good size and after filling it with my hotpot keeps warm for 3-4 hours on average.  The texture is nice as it keeps it from sliding out of my hands.  It also keeps you from having to wrap it in a towel so as to not burn yourself. The stopper is easy to grab and work.  I even enjoy this sitting warm on my lap on a colder day.  I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

This is another first rate album from the Cash Box Kings, one of the best current Chicago blues bands on the scene.This band has had some distribution problems with their CDs in the past; it took a year to get one of their previous CDs I ordered through Amazon because of problems with the distributors. Now that the band is on Blind Pig Records with this CD, the distribution problems appear to have been solved, for this CD at least.If you're already familiar with the Cash Box Kings, you'll like this album. If you're a blues fan and you haven't heard this band, you should check them out; this CD would be a good introduction to the band.

Sonny Landreth was a musician I had heard of but never actually heard, so I bought this album to check out his music.It turned out to be a really good album. It's a mix of blues standards (like Dust My Broom, Walkin' Blues, It Hurts Me Too, Key To The Highway) with some Sonny Landreth compositions.Sonny Landreth is a very accomplished slide player. After hearing this one, I'll be checking out some of his other albums.Overall, a very good album. For those unfamiliar with Sonny Landreth, this album would be a very good introduction.

This is a very good new John Mayall album, released in 2015.It features John Mayall with the same band that has been playing behind him since the Tough album (2009?). The album is 12 tracks of new recordings, clocking in at just under 47 minutes total playing time.It's all first rate music; there aren't many octogenarians making music of this quality. Mayall is in his 80s now but his voice is holding up well and his creative capacities are still going strong.Overall, a very good new John Mayall album. If you're a Mayall fan, you'll like this one.

This is an excellent history of Winston Churchill's  Cabinet and War Cabinet during the years 1940-45. It's well researched, well written and full of interesting information.Anyone interested in Winston Churchill, WW2 history or British politics in general should find this book a worthwhile read.I have the audio book version of this title. It's well done; the author's writing style adapts well to narration and the narrator does a good job with the material.I have a 40 minute commute to and from work and I typically spend the commute time listening to audio books. This is one of the better audio books I have heard recently. Highly recommended.

This is a really good book on the history of Christian theological battles (in many cases literally, battles) in the 5th and 6th centuries between Christian Popes and Patriarchs over issues like the nature of Christ, i.e. was Christ of One Nature (Divine) or was Christ of Two Natures (Divine and Human) and how these theological issues spilled over into politics in the Eastern and Western Roman Empires.It's a really interesting history, although it is not well known outside specialist academic circles. This author does a very good job explaining the various theological debates, the personalities involved and the political issues resulting from these doctrinal debates between theologians and Churches. He also shows how these debates still surface in modern theology.Overall, a very interesting book.

Bessie Smith is one of the great female vocalists in 20th century music history and this 4 CD set from JSP Records is an excellent way of getting her complete recorded work from 1926 until her death in Clarksdale, Mississippi in the 1930s.JSP has also released a second set (Volume 1 of this series) with Bessie Smith's complete recordings up to 1926.If you're a blues fan or you're interested in music history, Bessie Smith is a singer whose work should be in your music collection. This set and Volume 1 of this series are a very cost effective way of getting Bessie Smith's complete recordings. The re-mastered sound is very good for recordings from this time period; the liner notes are decent and the price is reasonable.Overall, a very worthwhile 4CD set of Bessie Smith recordings.

Bessie Smith is one of the great female vocalists in 20th century music history and this 4 CD set from JSP Records is an excellent way of getting her recorded work up to 1926. JSP has released a second set (Volume 2 of this series) with Bessie Smith's complete recordings from 1926 until her death in Clarksdale, Mississippi.If you're a blues fan or you're interested in music history, Bessie Smith is a singer whose work should be in your music collection. This set and Volume 2 of this series are a very cost effective way of getting Bessie Smith's complete recordings. The re-mastered sound is very good for recordings from this time period; the liner notes are decent and the price is reasonable.Overall, a very worthwhile 4CD set of Bessie Smith recordings.

This is an excellent book about the development of Masonic ritual from the early 18th through the mid 19th centuries.It's written primarily for Freemasons but anyone interested in the origins of modern Masonic ritual should find this book informative.It also includes a chapter with suggestions on how modern communications technology and social media can be incorporated into Freemasonry without compromising its historical traditions or the historic ritual.Overall, an excellent book that is well worth the attention of all Freemasons, particularly those in leadership roles in lodges or in Grand Lodges.

This is a very well researched and well written book about the events and politics behind the Balfour Declaration in 1917, in which the British government professed its support of a Jewish homeland in what was then the Ottoman province of Palestine.If you're interested in the historical background of events in the modern Middle East, this book should be of interest to you.

This is a very informative book on ISIS (aka ISIL, Islamic State).Robert Spencer details the history of this organization, its goals and objectives, the threat it poses to the Middle East and to Western countries, the Islamic theological basis for its actions (contrary to many Western leaders' statements that ISIS is not Islamic, Robert Spencer shows that ISIS actions are firmly rooted in Islamic theology) and what, in Spencer's view, Western countries should be doing about this threat.There are many who consider Robert Spencer an Islamophobe, a racist, a bigot, a hate-monger or worse. He is none of those things. This a very reasonable, well researched, well written and well argued book about an organization which poses a major threat to Western nations.Well worth reading. No problems recommending this one.November 2015 Update to Original Post: with the attack ISIS just carried out in Paris, there is all the more reason to read this book in the interests of "know your enemy."

This is a very worthwhile live recording of John Mayall's Bluesbreakers in 1967.The band line up is John Mayall, Peter Green on guitar, John McVie on bass and Mick Fleetwood on drums. Peter Green's guitar playing is superb; too bad that Green's health problems in the early 1970s derailed what should have been a very productive career. Green is at the top of his game on these recordings.The CD clocks in at just over 76 minutes total playing time so the full storage capacity has been used.Although these are live performances, the audience noise is minimal. The sound quality is good but not up to studio standards. I've deducted one star for the sound quality.But the performances are first rate. If you're a Mayall fan, this one is well worth adding to your collection. It's also worth having for Peter Green's performances. Peter Green only recorded one studio album with John Mayall (A Hard Road - I've given it a 5 star rating on Amazon) before leaving Mayall's band with John McVie and Mick Fleetwood to form the first incarnation of Fleetwood Mac. Since Peter Green largely disappeared from the music scene in the early 1970s due to his health problems, this CD is well worth having as an example of Peter Green's playing in his heyday, before his health issues set in.Overall, a very worthwhile John Mayall CD.

This is a 3 CD set containing 80 tracks of classic Howlin' Wolf, from his first recordings with Sam Phillips at Sun Studio in Memphis in 1951 to his well known work with Chess Records in Chicago during the 1950s and early 1960s.Many of these tracks are very well known, are very influential and have been covered extensively by other artists including the Rolling Stones, Eric Clapton and others of that caliber.If you're a blues fan, you need to have these Howlin' Wolf recordings in your collection. This 3CD set is a worthwhile way of getting them. It's well done and is reasonably priced. The sound is good, the liner notes are decent and the recordings themselves are among the most influential blues recordings ever made.

This is an excellent history of the American independent record labels of the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s which played a major role in the development of rock and R&B. It's well written and well researched, with many first hand interviews with the people actually involved with these independent labels.It covers everything from the major independents like Atlantic and Chess to small, little known independent labels in regional markets. It also goes into interesting detail on the business side of the music business, which often gets glossed over in many music histories.Overall, a very worthwhile book for anyone interested in the history of the music business and the development of rock and roll and R&B.

This is the second great collection (2 volumes so far) of Leadbelly recordings from JSP Records.The recordings run from Leadbelly's first recordings - the 1934 John and Alan Lomax recordings of Leadbelly at Angola Penitentiary in Louisiana - to Leadbelly's last recordings in 1948. The sound is good, the liner notes are decent and the price is reasonable.Leadbelly was one of the major figures in blues and folk history; this is a very worthwhile collection of Leadbelly recordings.

Bourinot's Rules of Order are the standard rules followed in Canadian government, business and private meetings. The better known Roberts Rules of Order are not as widey used in Canada as Bourinot's. If you attend Canadian meetings and/or are eligible to participate in those meetings, a knowledge of Bourinot's Rules of Order is very useful.This short book provides a very useful explanation of Bourinot's Rules of Order. If you attend Canadian civic meetings or are a member of any Canadian group that has meetings, this book would be useful to you.A note to fellow union members: most Canadian unions use Bourinot's Rules of Order, not Roberts', in conducting their membership meetings. If you're a union member and you want to make sure your local or national executive is following proper procedures, this book is very useful.

This is a CD/DVD combo of a Richard Thompson performance on Austin City Limits in 2001. The performance is 16 tracks on DVD, 15 on the CD.Thompson is backed by a drummer and a bass player and performs material from various albums he has released over the years. The sound is very good and the performance is excellent. On the DVD the camera work and editing are very good. The video looks good.Overall, an excellent performance and the CD/DVD combo is very good value for money.Any who likes Richard Thompson should like this one. If you're not familiar with Richard Thompson, this would be a great introduction.

This release from UK based Jasmine Records is an excellent CD of early 1960s British blues.Alexis Korner was one of the most influential figures in the late 1950s and early 1960s British blues scene and this CD is a great example of his early 1960s work. It features the material released on the 1963 album R&B From The Marquee as well as other first rate Alexis Korner material from the period.For those unfamiliar with the name Alexis Korner, note that people like Mick Jagger, Charlie Watts and Long John Baldry came out of Alexis Korner's bands.The recorded sound is very good and the music easily stands the test of time. If you're interested in early 1960s British blues, this is an album you should check out.

The Cash Box Kings are one of the best Chicago blues bands currently on the scene and this album is a very good example of their work.The album is 15 tracks with a total of about 70 minutes playing time. It's all first rate material. The sound recording is very good and the playing is excellent.One major issue though. I ordered this CD from Amazon in mid December 2013 and I finally got it in early March 2015. This is not Amazon's fault; it's the fault of the record label and/or distributor. The price on Amazon was $18 when I ordered it and Amazon delivered it at the original quoted price, despite the 15 month delay . In between my initial order and the final delivery, the price for this CD fluctuated between $30 - $160 from various Amazon affiliates. For much of that time it was unavailable.To the Cash Box King's record label and/or distributor - you've got a great band here that deserves commercial recognition and success but you're really screwing it up with your terrible distribution and lousy availability of their product. There's no excuse in this day and age for a 15 month delivery time on a CD; that's just blatant incompetence on someone's part.To the Cash Box Kings and their management - you really need to sort out the distribution and availability issues on many of the band's releases. The band is great but the availability and distribution of their CDs is pathetic. Sort out your record label and/or distributors.

As the title says, this 4 CD set contains all the Muddy Waters' singles released on the Aristocrat and Chess labels between 1947 and 1962. For novice blues fans, bear in mind that these labels typically released Muddy Waters tracks as singles during this time period so you're basically getting all the classic Muddy Waters material on this set.The sound is good. Liner notes are fairly basic but they contain all the essential information like recording dates for each track, musicians playing on each track etc. The price (currently about $20) is reasonable.These are very influential recordings. The Rolling Stones took their name from one of these songs. Led Zeppelin took another as the basis for the Led Zeppelin II track "Whole Lotta Love" and got sued successfully by songwriter Willie Dixon. Bands that have covered many of these songs are far too numerous to include here.If you're a blues fan, or you like bands like the Rolling Stones and Led Zeppelin, these are essential recordings for your collection. This set is a good way to get them.

I was a bit leery of this one when I first saw it on Amazon. It was on a reissue label that I'd never heard of, but I took a chance on it and ordered it anyway.It turned out to be a really good sampler of Duke Records releases from 1952-62. There are some familiar names like Bobby "Blue" Bland, Little Junior Parker and Rosco Gordon along with some names I wasn't familiar with. One little gem is Texas Flood by Larry Davis, which was covered by Stevie Ray Vaughan on his Texas Flood album. I wasn't aware of the Larry Davis original before I heard it on this album.Overall, a very good set. It's 3 CDs, the price is reasonable, the sound is good and although it's definitely not the full Duke Records Story, it's a very good Duke Records sampler.

I've never had a laminator before, so I wasn't sure what to expect. I always have to take projects to be laminated to a copy center.  I was leery about owning my own for reasons of space and price of laminating sheets.Overall, I'm very happy with this. I've found inexpensive laminate pouches here on Amazon, so I don't think that will be a problem. Especially as it seems I don't HAVE to use a specific brand for this machine.Pros:Heats up quicklyControl Panel easy to understand and useNo bubblesClear lamination--not milkyAuto adjusts to thickness of projectCons:No tray for loose items I wish to laminate

I've been quite pleased with these headsets.Pros:Easily PairedEasy to chargeHolds charge for several hours of continual playSound quality pretty good--not outstanding, but very clear and good qualityStays put during active workoutsCalls were easy to make/receiveCall quality on both ends (caller/receiver) were clearCarry case which turns into armband a nice touchCons:Hurts my ears after too long--which is to be understandable if you leave them in too long

This is an acceptable apron. It's not my favorite, but it isn't too terribly bad either.Pros:The fabric is easy to clean and light to wear.Nice big pocket in frontAdjustable neck strapCons:The top part of apron doesn't really stay in place. The adjustable strap loosens easily so I had to constantly readjust it.

Three single ladies move in to the McCauley's childhood home and rent it from their parents. Of course, one brother lives next door. And of course, trouble ensues when Flynn McCauley finally meets the fiery redhead, Maddie.Maddie has had it with men and swears off all men. She is middle of her tirade about how awful all men are when Flynn shows up to fix the sink. Flynn's not into relationships either, so why not arrange a friends with benefits arrangement. Only, Maddie isn't falling for Flynn's charm and Flynn has to pull out all the stops and even get help from his 5 year-old nephew to win Maddie over.Overall, this was a fun story. Yes, it was a bit predictable, but it was still fun. I really liked the brother's relationship and their banter. Even his 5 year-old nephew was a hoot--and real!Normally I'm not a fan of the friends with benefits storyline, but somehow it worked here for me. I think it worked for me because of how honest they were with each other about things. There was a bit of the back and forth thing as they try to sort out their feelings for the other, but it didn't drag on endlessly.The McCauley BrothersThe Troublemaker Next DoorHow to Handle a Heartbreaker (The McCauley Brothers)Ruining Mr. Perfect (The McCauley Brothers)What to Do with a Bad Boy

I am a fan of Zoe Archer. I haven't read everything she's written, but always enjoy her stories when I do pick them up. I haven't read the previous book in this series, so everything was all new to me. Despite the fact this is a continuation of a story line for the hero and heroine, I didn't feel like I was completely lost.A Nemesis agent and former client, Michael and Ada respectively, both go under cover as servants at a country estate to expose corruption. Michael and Ada had a romantic past, but that all fizzled when Michael left and didn't ever try to contact Ada. She's vowed to forget Michael and do her duty for Nemesis. Michael knows his in Ada's bad graces since he disappeared on her, but he has a very good reason...only if he can get her to listen.I enjoyed this story. It was actually quite fun to read about a country house party from the perspective of the hired help. Normally, all the historical romance stories are of wealthy debutantes and titled lords. Neither Michael nor Ada are grasping for the polite society and are happy with their stations. It was a nice change.The mystery they must solve was more of a background filler and easy to follow along. The focus seemed more on the repair of Michael and Ada's relationship and how they learn to trust each other once again.I always enjoyed Ms. Archer's writing. The storyline is smooth as she weaves a fun mystery to solve and watch two lovers reunite. I look forward to reading this series.Nemesis UnlimitedSweet Revenge: Nemesis, Unlimited Book 1Winter's Heat (Novella)Dangerous Seduction: A Nemesis Unlimited NovelWicked Temptation (Nemesis Unlimited)

The beautiful Miss Amelia Snow has been a nasty thorn in the side of many debutantes. So when her family falls on hard times and she is forced into employment as a companion to a wealthy cit's daughter, not many in the haute ton pity her. Humbled, Amelia is ready to change. She has been used to being the beauty everywhere she goes, but now needs to downplay her beauty so as to not outshine her employer. In the midst of her new reduced standing returns her childhood friend, Lord Quentin Fortescue. She snubbed his proposal years ago. Now they are thrown together again. Is she still the haughty beauty who stomped all over his heart? Can either of them risk their heart again?Having read a few of the previous books, I was surprised to see the villainess get her own book. It was actually fun to see what Amelia's fate was after she got her comeuppance. We were finally allowed to see behind the nastiness and faade Amelia used to parade behind. I didn't want to like her, but I slowly did.I liked the theme of second chances. Amelia worked hard to redeem herself and to find her true self. Who was she if she didn't have all her money? Who are her true friends? And just what is so special about her now? I liked how Quentin didn't just fall all over himself to "rescue" Amelia, but they both had to work to trust one another again.Overall, this was a fun short story to wrap up the Ugly Ducklings series. No, it isn't about one of the Ugly Ducklings, but it was a great way to show what happened "Happily Ever After."The Ugly DucklingsHow to Dance With a Duke (Ugly Ducklings Trilogy)How to Romance a Rake (Ugly Ducklings Trilogy)How to Entice an Earl (Ugly Ducklings Trilogy)Perks of Being a Beauty

I almost let this gem pass me by. I picked this up a while ago, yet it sat in my TBR pile. Im so glad I dusted this off and gave it a try.Hannah Cohens perfect life is starting to crash around her. She always knew it was a faade perpetrated by her family because appearance must always be maintained.  All her life she has followed a strict set of rules to maintain the image of perfection. But now, the rules arent helping her. While her dad is hiding in rehab, her mother runs off to Paris to pretend everything is ok. Done with all the pretending, Hannah opts to stay the summer with her aunt. She is dertermined to do things she never dared before. There, Hannah meets Jude Westmore. Together, Hannah and Jude set about making their own rules for how to live their lives and come to grips with their new realities.On the surface Hannah has it all, but the rules her parents have taught her over the years fail her as she tries to cope with life. On the surface she is polished, but on the inside she is a mess. The hero was tortured, having forgotten his own dreams, ambition, and way after a family tragedy. They had a way with each other that was sweet to watch.I could totally relate to Hannah and her trials. I never went through when she did, but her desire to start over and find out who she truly is was heartfeltand I remember feeling exactly like that at 17. I was completely engrossed in the story as it all felt so real. The secondary characters felt real instead as if they were just backdrop.I really enjoyed this YA story and wish I could read about their continuing story.

When I saw the reference to "Beauty and the Beast" theme I thought this book would be perfect for me. Overall, it was a good read with only a few minor annoyances at the end.Lord Jason Lockwood is notorious for his scarred face he hides from Polite Society as well as his Sin Parties. He is lonely but content, or he thinks he is. The reemergence of a half-brother stirs Jason to action to find out what the no-good bastard is up to and brings him into contact with Lady Lydia Prewitt. Under the tutelage of her aunt, Lydia has become the most feared gossip, besides her aunt that is. Lydia wants to change her reputation and sees helping Jason regain his social standing as a way to redeem herself from all the harm she has inflicted in the past.Both Jason and Lydia feel trapped by their circumstances. Jason feels like his half-brother ruined his life and is to blame for all the misery in his life. Lydia feels trapped by her aunt who is THE gossip monger and threatens Lydia daily with banishment if Lydia doesn't gather gossip for her.Lydia was an interesting character to get to know. She isn't all that likeable in the beginning. She has been gathering gossip for her aunt to wield as weapons against others and to elevate her own standing. She does want to change, but she is weak willed and unsure of how. She slowly takes steps to distance herself from Aunt and grows into a strong willed and determined woman who is sure of herself.There is a LOT going on in the story and a lot of backstory to discover to understand all the whys and the whats and the hows. The author does a great job at slowly peeling back each layer to discover more and more and still keep the storyline moving forward.I did love most of the book. I did have a problem with how Jason reacts at the end and how Lydia deals with it.Secrets & Scandals SeriesHer Wicked Ways (Secrets & Scandals Book 1)His Wicked Heart (Secrets & Scandals Book 2)To Seduce a Scoundrel (Secrets & Scandals Book 3)To Love a Thief (Secrets & Scandals Book 4)Never Love a ScoundrelScoundrel Ever After (Secrets and Scandals Book 6)Scoundrel Ever After

Two shattered and broken souls collide in this love story. Socialite Rebecca Clare is a tabloid staple, and her hard partying ways do nothing to stop it.  Her latest trouble is of course being documented by the ever present paparazzi--she gets into a brawl at a club. The only one to step in and help is Jake Montgomery--her sister's step-son.  Jake isn't usually one to help out like that, but he figures she is family...in a way. When the photo from the brawl goes viral, Jake steps in again to save Becca and family from scandal by claiming they are engaged. Becca agrees to play along for a while.Becca is a shell of a girl when we meet her. She recently lost her best friend and isn't coping very well. She can't sleep with the lights out, she needs to get drunk to even get a little sleep, and she is lonely in the crowd around her. She is also completely honest and never pretends to be anything she is not. Jake was a heartless, emotionless tin-man when we first meet him. He is currently on the outs with his family and needs a place to crash...which leads him to Becca. Where Becca has no ulterior motives, Jake is conniving and manipulative.We think we know them in the beginning of the story based off their tabloid exploits, but this story takes us behind the headlines and into their lives. I love how honest and upfront these two are with each other. The world seems to be getting crazy around them, but they gravitate toward each other and find their true selves in the process.Overall, I really enjoyed this story and would highly recommend this if you are looking for another new-adult read. I haven't read the first in this series, but it didn't seem necessary.

Whos Mr. Darcy? he asked, his frown deepening. And why does he get to go by his last name, while youve been calling me Gray since the moment you met me?****Sophie Dalton is perfectly happy with her aimless life and being everyones favorite party girl. Shes always the one to lighten the mood, even if its at her own expense. Her happy-go-lucky outlook seriously nosedives when she is mistaken for a prostitute by an uptight businessman while partying in Vegas at a Bachelorette party. She slinks home determined to truly reevaluate her life and make changes. However, its kinda hard to do when her sister brings home her new boyfriend to meet the familyand he just happens the same uptight businessman! Grayson Wyatt is cajoled by his date to give Sophie a job as his assistant and is now working with the woman!This was a fun opposites attract office romance story that I rather enjoyed. Gray and Sophie couldnt be more different. I couldnt see how these two could possible become a couple, yet the author did a fantastic job in letting these two characters grow and change to the point where they truly complimented each other.I really enjoyed getting to know both Sophie and Gray and to learn all that is hidden behind the social butterfly faade and the steely uptight demeanor.  I enjoyed the snark and the witty conversations they engaged in as well as their interactions. I felt like I got to SEE so much instead of being told what was going on.Overall, I was pretty happy with this story. It left me with a smile on my face.

At age of 17, Lady Alexandra was wedded and bedded to settle a gambling debt. After the deed was done, she fled and hid herself away under the assumed name of Lizzie Allbright. For eight years, Lizzie has been content and happy to live the life of the local pastor's adopted daughter. But her peaceful life is upturned when her husband shows up to reclaim her. He doesn't try to reclaim her with words of love and devotion, rather with the insistence that it is time she fulfill her wifely duty and give him an heir. Time is of the essence for Xavier, Lord Steyne who fears there is a plot to eliminate him.THE WICKEDEST LORD ALIVE was an overall good read. It was a little heartbreaking to read about a 17 year old virgin and the young 21 year old son forced into this awkward situation neither of their making.Lizzie was an ok heroine. She was resourceful, smart, and a natural caretaker. She enjoyed caring for those around her. She really cares nothing for wealth and title--she lived under the brutal hand of her titled father for 17 years.Xavier was made of ice. He kept himself detached from everyone and everything around him. He doesn't believe in love and is a cynic.As enjoyable as the storyline was, I had a hard time with believing the love.First, Lizzie barely knows him, had only seen him a few times before their forced wedding, once when he bedded her (and he wasn't very nice about it), and when he came to fetch her, yet she knew that she was already half in love with him. It couldn't have been his sparkling personality as he himself said "How the hell had she come to think herself in love with him? Hadn't he been autocratic, cold at times sarcastic to the point of brutality? What could she possibly have found in him to like, much less love?"Second, Lizzie thinks that she can save him. Her foster father even says to her "You might well be his salvation." It was just so clichd that to have this rude, cynical libertine who just needs the love of a good woman to save him.Apparently, this is part of a series. Maybe I would have been more invested in the story had I read the books before it. As it stands, I don't feel like I ever really new Xavier's wicked reputation as it wasn't ever really seen. Too much was just told instead of shown and experienced.Westruthers SeriesLondon's Last True ScoundrelThe Greatest Lover EverThe Wickedest Lord Alive

2-1/2 starsFor years, Celia and Marcus have been at odds. They cant be near each other without sniping and cutting remarks. Unfortunately, they are forced to play nice for a few minutes at the wedding of Celias brother who happens to be Marcus best friend. Well, those few minutes are enough to cut through the animosity and straight to the lust and wanting.This was a quick read that I couldnt really get into all that much. It was too introspective, not a whole lot of dialogue. Most the book was their thoughts where were are told everything, we dont see it. They both were really insecure and I found it grating. It was frustrating to see them both hide so muchnothing moves forward with both of them holding back so much!Overall, this was just an okay read that was easy to put down.

First off, I am a huge Ilona Andrews fan girl. Ive read just about all they have published.  Second, Ive followed the progress of this book on their website and read the snippets and have been eagerly awaiting this book. I had pre-ordered this book, so I jumped at the chance to get it early.Nevada Baylor is a small time PI strong-armed into solving a case she normally wouldnt touch with a 10 foot pole. She is tasked with bringing in a fire mage who is accused of killing a cop. In a paranormal world just like ours, magic and family are power. Nevada has family, but is short on the magic. She does have the ability to know if someone is truthful or not. But when she is going up against a fire mage who can melt the skin off her bones, it doesnt help her much. Her investigation draws the eye of another powerful man, Mad Rogen, who wants the fire mage for his own reasons and joins forces with Nevada.What I liked:1. NevadaWeird name, but awesome girl. It amazes me how unique and different she is than any other heroine Ilona Andrews has written before. She has common sense, is pretty intelligent, is incredibly loyal, and well rounded.2. The World Buildingeverything about this world made sense and was easily understood. As a bonus, there was no huge info dump trying to explain it nor was left vague and open with little clues to figure out on my own.3. FamilyNevadas family is hilarious, but they also felt so real! Their conversations and actions felt like real life. (You can tell the authors have a house full of teenagers.)4. Mad Rogenwhat a conundrum. I loved trying to figure out Mad. He is incredibly powerful and used to things his way. The fact he cant seem to crack Nevada has him scratching his head. (For Ilona Fan Girls: hes almost like Kate and Curran mixed togetheryeah, that awesome.)5. Storylinethe storyline was engaging and very interesting. It was easy to follow and clear. I felt like I was along the ride as Nevada and Mad worked through the investigation and was solving the clues along with them.6. Realistic RomanceEven though this is being billed as a romance, this wasnt the typical romance where we hear from the girl and then we hear from the boy and the main point of the story is their romance and everything else is secondary. Nevada and Mad Rogan meeting and actually getting to know each other is secondary to the investigationand I liked it that way.7. Development of powersI loved watching the different powers people had and how they used them. Nevada may think she is small time, but oh! I really dont think so.What I didnt like:Couldnt find anything.Recommendation: Read it!If you are new to Ilona Andrews, this is a great book to start. The action and mystery are nicely balanced with the romance making it an engaging read.

I was surprised at how compact  the Samsung Wireless Printer was. I'm not really on the cutting edge of tech, but this was easy to use and set-up (something I was dreading). The quality of printing surprised me--and it is so easy to use with the cloud function. Like others have mentioned, the cost of the toner is a little high.

Overall, I'm okay with this dresser. It came in one long box and took about 3 hours to assemble. The quality is ok to good--you do get what you pay for. I got this for my 5 year-old daughter, and It is holding up to young kids. The laminate is easy to clean (which is a must with young kids) and is nice looking.

Me? I don't get Minecraft, but my kids LOVE it.They have Minecraft on their iPods, but love to play this version as they can do so much more. There are more tools and things to choose from to build new and fun exciting things.

Ive tried lots of detergents over the years trying to find a deal, but I keep coming back to TIDE.I like the scent and the clothes come out clean--even the stinky soccer clothes hidden in duffle bags for days and even the dirty, dusty, sweaty baseball clothes. They come out clean the first time.

I have been really happy with these headphones. I can work on the computer and listen to my music or listen to an audio book on my android phone while I work without any discomfort.Pros:Great Sound QualityFits on the ears instead of over the ears muff style allows for your ears to breatheComfortable fitAdjust easilyFolds up nicelySturdy case to store headphones in when not in useCons:n/a -- I haven't had any in the 1-1/2 months I've been using these.

My kids LOVE water parties, water balloon fights, water gun fights, etc. We have invested in a lot of water guns over the years. We have learned Nerf Water Guns are always a good buy. They last a long time, are good quality, and are loads fun.Pros:Shoots WellAims easilyQuick RefillShoots 3 streams of waterCan retract the side bars and shoot 1 steam of water at a greater distanceSmaller water reservoir means lighter weight for younger kidsCons:Smaller reservoir of waterholds 40 oz. of waterwhich means you need to refill often

Friday Night is movie night in our family. We love to rent a move and pop popcorn and enjoy a night in. Overall, these have been a fun addition to our movie night popcorn. I like the variety pack as everyone has different tastes and can flavor their own popcorn accordingly.Pros:Good flavors. My favorite was the white cheddar.Nice variety pack for differing tastes--some sweet, some savory.Cons:Dry powder wouldnt adhere to the popcorn. It would just all fall to the bottom. It needs something to make it stick to the popcorn.Lots and lots of chemicalskinda make me leery.Overall, its a fun idea just needs a little tweaking. I actually tried it on salads and on potatoes and really loved it there.

Smash is a highly entertaining and deeply moving journey that will take you by storm and never let go. The paranormal aspect drew me in like a moth to the flame, but it was the amazing and bold characters and the intriguing storyline that held me utterly captive. There is a beautifully raw and absolutely mesmerizing talent that will leave you both wanting more and completely satisfied.David has lived a full and relatively satisfying life until a deep craving begins to make itself known. This craving comes naturally to those like himself. He desires above all to find and claim his mate. He is ready to lay aside his empty, carefree life and bask in the deeper meaning and fulfillment that comes with the cherished bond of ones mate.
