My heart broke for Romeo since he was left completely in the dark without an excuse or any word from Evie for 5 years. I admire him for not hating her when she came back, but instead he was fiercely determined to prove to Evie that he still loved her and she had always been in his heart even she shut him out of her life. He was relentless in loving her and proving to her that she deserved to be loved so completely and perfectly even after she broke his heart. They belonged together, and he did everything he could to show her that she needed to choose him this time.Rachelle Ayala has created this beautifully dysfunctional Sanchez family who you love and yet want to smack them from time to time. They are a fun yet realistic family who in the end loves each other in spite of their faults and mistakes. While they might not go about things the right way, in the end they find the love, forgiveness, and courage they need to make the right decisions. We all get frustrated with those in our family, but deep in our heart, we love each other unconditionally. This is what I love to see each time I come back to this incredible group of people who have touched my heart one person at a time. I very much look forward to seeing more from them in the future.

This feels like the perfect storm in how it wildly and surprisingly brought Andie and Cade together and now all we see is its cruel and persistent attempts to pull these two apart. Thankfully, there is more than just a pretty face to this couple otherwise they would have thrown in the towel long before now. They recognize that there is something undeniable and irresistible that they found in the other that they havent been able to find in anyone else. Rather than give in and run away from their problems, they continue to weather this out of control hurricane and in the process they are forced to strengthen their defense and strike back just as viciously with their offense. The victors that are still standing after this disaster ends will win the ultimate prize which is unconditional and unquestionable love with an incredible future that is brighter than they ever dared to imagine.With a new and exciting job that pays well enough to help her parents out and getting a fresh start with Cade, Andie would love to sit back and just enjoy all of this good fortune, but fate is not without a bitter sense of humor. She finds her past has returned with a vengeance and a vendetta to destroy everything she holds most dear.  Knowing the messy and painful results of lying out of fear, she works up the courage to tell Cade the harsh truth of the life-altering shock that is tearing down her dreams one breath at a time. Cades life is finally settling down as he anticipates the birth of his son. He has Andie back in his life, and he couldnt be happier. Knowing that she intends to help and love his son, and seeing how well he is performing at training, he is walking in the clouds. Just as he gets comfortable, he is also blindsided with a surprise that tilts his world on its axis. Can Andie and Cade find the courage and strength they need to get through this together, or will one or both of them fold under the pressure and be forced to leave the game prematurely?I cant say how much I have enjoyed watching Andie and Cade grow as individuals and as a couple. They have a lot to work on and figure out, but they find out that the amount of time, patience, and love they invest in themselves and each other will be returned back to them ten time times greater making it so worth it in the end. Nothing seems to be easy for them, but truthfully nothing that is worth anything in life is ever easy to earn or work towards. That just makes the reward that much sweeter when they finally find it and keep it. I know for me its been so hard to watch these two wonderful characters struggle so much, and I know their troubles arent over yet. In fact, they are just heating up to a fast boil. Now, we will see if what they have already invested in each is going to pay off by standing with each other to the end no matter what or if they will instead choose to give up and walk away. I really hope they choose to be strong and hold each other up because this story ending with them together will be so very sweet and utterly fulfilling after this horrendous ride they have been forced to endure.While it may sound like I keep repeating myself when I sing my praises for Rachelle Ayalas masterpieces, but its only because it is the pure and honest truth. I continue to be astounded by the depth of creativity and heart that she pours into each of her stories. There is no pretense, it is just her offering up a piece of herself to all of us, and I am eager to accept it, savor it, and treasure it forever. The fresh and original approach to each of her stories just blows my mind. Nothing is stale with her storylines or her characters. They both jump off the pages and forever embed themselves into my heart. I will never get tired of the soul and honesty that I see hidden inside each book. It deeply touches me like nothing else can. Whatever you do, you have to read at least one of Rachelles beautifully captivating and thoroughly entertaining stories! You will never look at stories the same ever again.

Incredibly heartfelt, amazingly optimistic, and fiercely passionate are just a few of the ways that I would describe The Mistake by Elle Kennedy. It is definitely unique in its view of life and the people who are a part of that life. Rather than dishing out harsh rebuke for mistakes, Kennedy wants us to focus on the motivation behind those mistakes. Dealing with and resolving the root cause rather than just making the problem worse. Bad decisions are owned and instead of despairing over them, her unbelievable characters choose to rise above them and make amends as much as possible. Everyone from family to friends has a hand in helping those who need to right a wrong. After all, we dont live our lives in isolation, so why should we not offer a helping hand when we know we can truly help someone?!John has no future. At least that is what he has convinced himself over the years. His family situation continues to fall apart fast, and this only adds more chains of depression and hopelessly that wrap around his heart cutting off the happiness and joy that he desperately clings to. His only solution is to plunge himself into every pleasure that he can find which include a never-ending supply of girls and parties. Grace started college with a resolve to become more then what she had settled for in high school. She wants to spread her wings and find out who she is and what she is capable of doing. Along the way, she inadvertently crosses paths with John, and what starts out as a mistake blossoms into something that is too beautiful for words. When John carelessly pushes Grace aside under the guise of protecting her, her heart is broken and he realizes too late the needless damage he has done. What he doesnt realize in time is that his heart is steering him towards something that is longer lasting and more deeply fulfilling than what he has settled for. Will he listen to his heart before its too late, or will he lose his one chance at a love so pure and ravishing that he will find himself in an even worse place then he can imagine? One thing is for sure  John has his work cut out for him because he isnt winning Grace back without hard work, determination, and imagination.I wasnt sure what to expect going into this story, but I can tell you that I was rocked to my core at finding the immense love, powerful encouragement, and out of this world determination to hold onto the precious gifts and surprises that fate throws into our path. Each problem and conflict is dealt with such grace and love that I almost cried a few times at how much it really touched me. This story is nothing short of a stunning success! John and Grace were fiercely independent and not the usual weepy, touchy-feely teenagers that you might see in NA stories which made me love them that much more. Their journey felt so incredibly real and their struggles tore at my heart as I watched them stumble and fall a few times, but my spirit soared with them as they both learned to trust, depend, and love each other in a positive and uplifting way. These two had me falling for them before I realized what was happening which tells me that this author knows how to sincerely touch the heart of her readers in a way that will leave them forever changed.Elle Kennedy surprised me, shocked me, and secured my loyalty as a reader. I am over the moon in love with John and Grace and their extraordinary story! Everyone should read, experience, and enjoy their story as well. It will leave you rethinking your approach to life, friends, family, and strangers. I dont know about you, but I love being challenged by books that are written with the heart and soul of a person who longs to show others that love and hope can change the world one person at a time. Now, its up to you to decide what to do with the challenge that Kennedy has placed before you.
It's hard to find this style of bit with the round shaft; typically they are hex, These are worth the price at $10 a pair. getting them 2/3 off is a steal

the two-gang model needs more support than the two swing-out grabbers; i had to add glue to at least one that I used. I'm not aware of any models 'done right' that have more so I would still buy this model If i had to but wish it was better made.
I've been doing AV wiring for decades. used a dozen ways to wire AV equipment and this is the only way I use anymore.

This is not magic, it will work amazingly well for the small set of people who are quite overweight and need fiber but other methods aren't working. I tried plenty of other fiber rich foods nothing worked. Lost 1# per week for more than half a year with this product. hence the 5 stars.. now the 'cons'; this brand is VERY over priced. I was happy to pay the 4x premium because they were the ones that brought it to my attention with their pricy national advts. but now I use generic konjac root for 10/g vs 44/gram this costs.I have to keep taking but in my case only about 1-2g/day average helps me maintain 160# vs 185# and that is five-stars worthy. The pills don't work at all for my wife; she apparently gets enough fiber.

Awesome value,  useless tweezers,  sadly missing the 100g weight that would make the kit complete. I bought a 100g weight hoping i could modify the box to fit it into the space that seemingly was made to fit it so that i could have a complete set that I could use to calibrate my new 200g scales. (both of which need 200g but one of which needs both 100g and 200g)I used a razor knife to separate the inner frame from the box, pulled out the inner frame from the box, then i used a forstner bit size 7/8 to drill the bottom out of the 100g spot. The foam in the lid was too tight for the box lit to close w/o distorting it so i used a 5/8 fortner bit turned backwards by hand on the foam to cut a nice circle, using the same trick i cut a circle in a piece of smooth cardboard and pressed down on the foam so the cut circle would 'pop up' through the cardboard and used an extendable razor knife to slice off about 80% of the thickness of the foam; now i  have a complete set including 100g individual weight and enough other weights i can easily calibrate my two 200g scales.I managed to 'tiddly wink' one of the 20mg weights across the room and lost it and am pretty sure the kit came with a 5mg weight that went missing on first use; so word to the wise be very careful opening the ziplock bag with the micro weights!My new scales have 0.01g precision and all the weights appear to be well within 0.01g tolerance as i've been getting exactly repeatable measurements.the mg weights could be made better and with consistency (e.g. all stainless steel so they won't disappear in the presence of a magnet) and it would be *really nice* considering the size of them and the negligible cost, that there might be some spares! That said it would be a solid 5 stars if it had the mystery 100g spot filled with a 100g weight and if the tweezer included wasn't pointlessly useless (wouldn't open enough to pick up the 5g weight and broke when trying to stretch it open big enough to do so, also wouldn't grab the mg weights so really literally useless). Super happy on the purchase and would most definitely buy again. (and modify again and through out the useless tweezer again)

Great little scale,  stunning price, hard to pick between this one and it's brother, the ACP-200. After studying the reviews I bought both so I could review and either send back the least favored or keep them both (i'm keeping both).How do they compare?The size; chrome is smaller, 2 1/2 x 4 9/16 x 3/4 inches vs 2 3/4 x 4 7/8 x 3/4 (2 7/8 bumps for the hinges)volume: 8.55 cu. inches vs 10.05 cu. inches (the chrome is 15% smaller).The chrome is nearly identical in width and height to an iphone 4 in a case, and 1/4 in. thicker, the other is 1/4 inch bigger in all all 3 dimensions.The chrome weighs 116g vs the other is 143 w/o the pouch and 152g with. (means the chrome is 25% lighter). for comparison my iphone 5 with  the case is almost identical to the acp-200 (not the chrome) at 142g.Displays:Hands down winner is the non-chrome. The chrome is reverse LCD and you can almost always see the ghost of the non-lit segments, you can see the illumination point on  the side, it's not evenly lit but the saving grace is it's still always absolutely legible. The height of the numbers is 3/8 on the non-chrome vs 1/2 inch on the chrome.  The non-chrome's display is perfect. absolutely perfect EL blue illumination corner to corner. It shows the battery level it shows grams value always and the secondary unit choice also always in 1/4" tall numbers in the  bottom right. In addition it shows a zero mark when it's not reading any weight which is nice to remind you if you've tare'd or not.Functions:They are functionally nearly identical with these differences:1) the chrome has avoirdupois oz, troy oz, pennyweight, carat, grain as well as gram but ONLY shows the chosen unit,2) the non-chrome has pennyweight, grain, carat as well as gram and shows the secondary unit simultaneously.This clearly puts the chrome ahead if you want for measuring gold or jewelry or need to have your results in oz right away w/o needing to do math.The LID/cover as a tray:The chrome model, the lid comes off completely in normal use, and works a little better as a tray, It also includes a cheat-sheet of operation which is really helpful for reminding you how to calibrate the scale but is missing a critical item: how to use for piece counting! (something you are very likely to forget how to do by the next time you want to use it).There is a curious quirk with the lid on the chrome model: if you put on upside-down, it takes literally 12x the force to remove (i just measured 50g force to open when installed correctly and over 600g force to remove when upside down). this is after wearing it in; when brand new it wsa likely twice that or 'nearly impossible'. The fix; pull open from the top not the bottom. Testing just now the lid pulled off at 700g from the bottom and 100g from the top when on upside down. You can grip from the sides and slowly pull at the top edge; if your fingers are too slippery use a piece of tape, then pay attention in the future and put on correctly you'll never have a problem again.The non-chrome model,The lid is attached with a hinge. I didn't notice in the manual if it said how to remove to use as a tray but it's quite simple; open the lid 90and pull the lid away directly sideways either at the top or the bottom 'peeling' the lid away from the base.The performance 'as a tray' goes hands-down however to the chrome. The lids are both a little bit convex so when placed on the scale platform they get skittish and will want to wander around a bit; the chrome model it's not noticeable but on the non-chrome it's super-duper noticeable; it feels like you've invented magnetic levitation. I just spun my lid and it twirled over a dozen full rotations. Fortunately in practice it rarely causes any problem, it's more of a nuisance than any actual problem.Calibration:The chrome model is easier to calibrate requiring only a 200g reference where the non-chrome requires both 100g and 200g weights.Do not attempt to use some makeshift solution you will need to get some actual reference weights to calibrate your scale. My chrome scale came completely miscalibrated; off maybe 6g at 100g when I got it; the non-chrome was spot-on and within 0.02g from the factory. My 100g calibration kit came with the scales but my additional 100g weight hadn't arrived yet but I was able to make one pretty easy in this way: I put my 100g reference on the working scale, and hit the tare button giving me a zero reference. I put a small measuring cup that would hold maybe 150ml of water and filled it until the scale read almost exactly zero. Then i took a small wad of paper towel and soaked it in water. taking that piece of paper towel either squeezed out drips or soaked up a bit of water until I got the scale to register 0.00 g.Then I took off the makeshift water weight, zero'd the scale and put the reference weight back on. noting the reading (100.04 for example) and put the water weight on.. it was slightly different probably due to evaporation so tinkered a bit until it matched the reference exactly and I could swap the two and get the same reading within 0.01g. At that point I could use the real reference and the water copy to achieve the 200g needed to calibrate both scales with perfect success.. A little while later I measured the 'water weight reference' and sure enough  it was a few 00ths of a gram lighter due to evaporation.With a little bit of luck on your side and a pile of coins you could likely achieve the same success if you have 100g reference but need 200g. You will want to have a permanent actual 100g and 200g reference.accuracy:absolutely amazing on both scales! I have taken over a dozen pictures with the scales showing 0.00g error or 0.01g error at all levels from 0.50g to 200.00g and even with the scales stacked; putting the chrome on the non-chrome, hitting tare on both and putting a weight on the top scale. I could put on 52.12g of reference weight and get 52.12 reading (0.00g error) on both scales where the bottom scale is of course measuring with  116g offset yet still achieving near perfect and repeatable accuracy.just now put a 5g reference on each scale and got a 5.00 reading on each. added 50g and chrome reading 54.99 and non-chrome also 54.99.added 10mg and non-chrome came right up to 55.00. repeated on the chrome and it likewise came up to 55.00. The fact that the scale will actually register a change of .01g after it's already settled in is astounding.Auto-off function.As you will see from other reviewers; the scales will shut off after some amount of non-use. The non-chrome seems to do a MUCH better job at re-setting the count-down timer when you change the weight; bump the scale, add or subtract weight within a minute and it does not shut off. The chrome model shuts on me plenty, the non-chrome if i bump it once in a while (within a minute) it stays on continously and i never have a problem with it. The chrome model on the other hand is annoyingly quick to shut off. fThey clearly have the same basic timer; doing this review i've  seen them both shut off within 1 sec of each other half a dozen times but during the same time Ive seen the chrome off while the non-chrome still on at least a half dozen times.Accuracy:They both are crazy accurate and high or low weights.If you need to measure crazy low weights like 2-20 mg, you want a different scale but in a pinch these guys will measure values in the 100mg range with repeatable accuracy. I have noticed the non-chrome does have some better software and hits repeatable values better. example; putting on a 100mg reference, I'm more likely to see 0.09 on the chrome than the non-chrome. Or when adding on 10mg, more likely to NOT see the up-tick on the chrome. In BOTH cases, lightly tapping the platform (talking about a 1-2g tap with tweezer), i've found that the re-weigh will be far more likely to match the  reference especially if you've just added on 10-20mg.That being said, using 100+10mg  references, I could repeatedly get 0.10 and 0.11 readings from the non-chrome as well as get readings  as low as 30mg that matched the reference weight where that just won't happen on the chrome. below .1g I wouldn't trust the chrome at all, while i've gotten repeateable accuracy of 30, 50, 80, 110, 130, 150mg on the non-chrome. it may take 10+ sec. for the final reading to come in but sure enough.. I saw 0.05g reading after I added 20mg to 50mg (it didn't show the addition of the 20mg).. i looked away for a few seconds and sure enough 0.08 was showing! at the same time i put 100mg on the chrome and it settled in on at coincidentally 0.08. off by 20mg.another test just now: 5g = 5.00, add 100mg; 5.10, add 50mg;  5.15, add 10mg; 5.16, then add 20mg and it reads 5.18. that is absolutely insane for a $16 device!now the same test on the chrome: 5g= 5.00, add 100mg; 5.09, add 50mg; 5.14, add 10mg; 5.16, then add 20mg; 5.18. also insane.I tapped the platform any time i add weight to "tell"  the scale to re-evaluate. oh the scale just changed to 5.17; also something that happens more often on the chrome; wondering results. never a big difference but more likely than the non-chrome to do so.astounding; both scales auto-off'd on me, I turned 'em on, let them warm up a few seconds and put the 5.18 back on.. the non-chrome hit 5.18 the first shot. the chrome: 5.16, then with a tap, 5.17, weights off; tare, weights on; 5.17, weights off, re-tare, weights on; 5.17, tap; 5.18.took som coaxing but did work. non-chrome auto off'd; power on, weights back  on; hit5.18 first shot.So in my first 5 days with the scales, this is what ive been experiencing; the non-chrome ACP-200 has been hitting repeatable #s within 0.01g, and while the chrome model will hit within 0.02 per it's claim, it is a much bigger fractional error on small weights so the non-chrome kicks its butt when weights are less than a gram and even when below 10g, the error starts to become significant (.4% at 5g where at 100g that error is 0.02%).last test; 1g weight freshly turned on; the non-chrome hit 1.00 within a second, the chrome registered 1.01 for a couple seconds then was 1.00 then 0.99 then back to 1.00; adding 50mg they both hit 1.05 within a couple seconds. absolutely stunning. Adding 50mg to chrome and 51.04, tap and 51.05 appears. non-chrome: 51.04 and stays. adding 50g and the -.01g offset stays 101.04g. the chrome started with101.04 but settled in at 101.05 exactly matching the reference values. re-weigh after power-cycle and with 100g reference hit 100.00g (i took a pic) then put on the 1g + 50mg and it hit 101.05g for almost a minute; it wandered up to 101.06 (0.01% error). just before powering off. I think i've discovered the key too the short power-off cycle; it shuts off before it will start to wander too far off course.The summary. If I had paid $50 each for the two scales I would be THRILLED with the results, The fact they were $16 each is just amazing. I'm thrilled beyond words.I'm happier with the performance of the non-chrome, and that will be my go-to standard I will keep in my kitchen for use 'most of the time'. The chrome being more portable, and having more useful units, will be the one I have in my coat pocket ready to use anywhere anytime.ps; just for fun put 30mg on the non-chrome and sure enough after a good 10 sec., 0.03 magically appears!

crazy awesome value. wish i'd have known about the spork case a decade ago! I bought 3 of them; gave one to a brother with 2 sporks inside, put one in the glovebox with 3 plastic sporks inside and used the 3rd with my two titanium sporks inside that i often will have in my coat pocket for going to picnics etc.

The non-chrome seems to do a MUCH better job at re-setting the count-down timer when you change the weight; bump the scale, add or subtract weight within a minute and it does not shut off. The chrome model shuts on me plenty, the non-chrome if i bump it once in a while (within a minute) it stays on continously and i never have a problem with it. The chrome model on the other hand is annoyingly quick to shut off. fThey clearly have the same basic timer; doing this review i've  seen them both shut off within 1 sec of each other half a dozen times but during the same time Ive seen the chrome off while the non-chrome still on at least a half dozen times.Accuracy:They both are crazy accurate and high or low weights.If you need to measure crazy low weights like 2-20 mg, you want a different scale but in a pinch these guys will measure values in the 100mg range with repeatable accuracy. I have noticed the non-chrome does have some better software and hits repeatable values better. example; putting on a 100mg reference, I'm more likely to see 0.09 on the chrome than the non-chrome. Or when adding on 10mg, more likely to NOT see the up-tick on the chrome. In BOTH cases, lightly tapping the platform (talking about a 1-2g tap with tweezer), i've found that the re-weigh will be far more likely to match the  reference especially if you've just added on 10-20mg.That being said, using 100+10mg  references, I could repeatedly get 0.10 and 0.11 readings from the non-chrome as well as get readings  as low as 30mg that matched the reference weight where that just won't happen on the chrome. below .1g I wouldn't trust the chrome at all, while i've gotten repeateable accuracy of 30, 50, 80, 110, 130, 150mg on the non-chrome. it may take 10+ sec. for the final reading to come in but sure enough.. I saw 0.05g reading after I added 20mg to 50mg (it didn't show the addition of the 20mg).. i looked away for a few seconds and sure enough 0.08 was showing! at the same time i put 100mg on the chrome and it settled in on at coincidentally 0.08. off by 20mg.another test just now: 5g = 5.00, add 100mg; 5.10, add 50mg;  5.15, add 10mg; 5.16, then add 20mg and it reads 5.18. that is absolutely insane for a $16 device!now the same test on the chrome: 5g= 5.00, add 100mg; 5.09, add 50mg; 5.14, add 10mg; 5.16, then add 20mg; 5.18. also insane.I tapped the platform any time i add weight to "tell"  the scale to re-evaluate. oh the scale just changed to 5.17; also something that happens more often on the chrome; wondering results. never a big difference but more likely than the non-chrome to do so.astounding; both scales auto-off'd on me, I turned 'em on, let them warm up a few seconds and put the 5.18 back on.. the non-chrome hit 5.18 the first shot. the chrome: 5.16, then with a tap, 5.17, weights off; tare, weights on; 5.17, weights off, re-tare, weights on; 5.17, tap; 5.18.took som coaxing but did work. non-chrome auto off'd; power on, weights back  on; hit5.18 first shot.So in my first 5 days with the scales, this is what ive been experiencing; the non-chrome ACP-200 has been hitting repeatable #s within 0.01g, and while the chrome model will hit within 0.02 per it's claim, it is a much bigger fractional error on small weights so the non-chrome kicks its butt when weights are less than a gram and even when below 10g, the error starts to become significant (.4% at 5g where at 100g that error is 0.02%).last test; 1g weight freshly turned on; the non-chrome hit 1.00 within a second, the chrome registered 1.01 for a couple seconds then was 1.00 then 0.99 then back to 1.00; adding 50mg they both hit 1.05 within a couple seconds. absolutely stunning. Adding 50mg to chrome and 51.04, tap and 51.05 appears. non-chrome: 51.04 and stays. adding 50g and the -.01g offset stays 101.04g. the chrome started with101.04 but settled in at 101.05 exactly matching the reference values. re-weigh after power-cycle and with 100g reference hit 100.00g (i took a pic) then put on the 1g + 50mg and it hit 101.05g for almost a minute; it wandered up to 101.06 (0.01% error). just before powering off. I think i've discovered the key too the short power-off cycle; it shuts off before it will start to wander too far off course.The summary. If I had paid $50 each for the two scales I would be THRILLED with the results, The fact they were $16 each is just amazing. I'm thrilled beyond words.I'm happier with the performance of the non-chrome, and that will be my go-to standard I will keep in my kitchen for use 'most of the time'. The chrome being more portable, and having more useful units, will be the one I have in my coat pocket ready to use anywhere anytime.ps; just for fun put 30mg on the non-chrome and sure enough after a good 10 sec., 0.03 magically appears!

Fantastic design, so happy I found them, what a bargain. The glasses will still fold up when attached. Not sure if they willl work on my new glasses that are coming but work perfectly fine on  half-frame fairly compact glasses. it took a bit to figure out  how they assemble; the key is the o-ring looking rubber band only goes around the temple ONCE on the side closest the lenses; the other side of the o-ring is pulled tight OUTSIDE the shield and is hooked onto a hook on the edge farthest from the lenses.

Really nice rack; some things to be aware of however;1) the kit includes a mount you attach to the wall and then hook baskets onto.2) the baskets are not necessarily 'square' with the pegs on the mount3) the pegs on the mount are not prefectly square with the mount.I mounted the mount on the wall perfectly plumb only to discover that the baskets 1) were not level and 2) were not the same amount of crooked.I found two of the three baskets that were the  same amount  of crooked, put my magnetic level in the bottom of the baskets and re-leveled the bracket crooked so that the baskets are perfectly level.The baskets are too close together reducing the capacity by 40% on the bottom two so i'm using 2 on the bracket that came with and will mount the  3rd elseware by itself.Since  the bracket is not wide enough to  reach between studs, I drilled holes into the  bracket in the center so i could mount onto a stud (totally not needed but I'm a member of overbuilder's anonymous). I would defintely buy again.

Impossible to beat thermos. two ice cubes and over night there will still be some solid ice in the morning. I make sure to measure the temp of coffee before putting in because it cools so slowly you won't be able to drink for HOURs if it's piping hot to start. 130-140 F is the temp I put my coffee in and it will be perfect drinking temp for 2-3 hours. You need to remove the blue seals periodically to clean them or your water will smell like cofee; I use some pure alcohol; everclear is good vs rubbing since it's food safe. I used to have the  plain stainless but love my new upgraded. It says it's 18oz but it only holds about 17.8. I just went through and posted a comment on a majority of the ignorant 1-star reviews that complained about leaking; the leaking is almost always caused from operator error; usually from over-tightening the lid; it takes about 1/12 of a turn of the lid to completely tighten this lid; more will damage the seal and either destroy it or make it fall out.

Can't imagine a  better value! I haven't used them yet but based on other people's reviews of Tekton honoring their warranty and some key aspects of this tool set:  bits stay in place,  combining sae and metric in one row; not two sets,  price is out of this world (i returned a 13 piece set that was $80 to get this one!) and  the case is  super compact and very wel designed.I picked up a 3-pack of 'wobble' extensions to mate with this set from harbor frt. and and thrilled with the combo.

Nice unit however one of two self-destructed on initial use. Obviously an mfg. defect and amazon replaced immediately. I would still buy the same unit as they do work as designed once they survived the initial power on.

I received the item much faster than anticipated but it was only packaged in a plastic mailing envelope. It was damaged in that the lead adjustment weight was knocked loose and it was about 2.5g short of 100g when I got it. Fortunately I had additional referenece weight so I was able to super-glue the piece of lead back in which got me to within 0.25g and then i rolled up some alum. foil and got the new weight to match my other 100g reference within 0.01g. Now I can calibrate my scale. I was able to fix the weight and had it been properly shipped I'd have given 5 stars as it matches my other weights perfectly and filled the missing hole of my American Weigh Calibration set.

I bought all three of these tools the 'minute' they came out. At least a year or two before available in america; bought via ebay-germany. They do exactly what they say. They do NOT do what they don't say.FAR more comfortable for most typical operations.  You CAN in-fact feel the tool twist under high torque situations since the plastic handle is a completely separate part from the tool unlike typical tools that are a solid steel design with just a plastic dip coating.I felt a need to balance out the nonsense review of 1-star based on 'It won't do the job it's not designed to do that a tool twice the size can'. This is a 4-5 star tool. There are some minor quibbles that make it not perfect but I won't leave home without it.

The tolerances of cutting from the side vs the top are 50x as tight, so it's not too surprising the failure rate is higher than the top-cut style (which cut 50x deeper than the side-cut; of course they are more reliable).At a price of $20-25 i would rather replace a side-cutter annually than ever have a dirty lid with sharp corners fall into my food, or have old food from months ago get poked through the bacteria on the lid of the new can into the new sterile environment inside the can.

Keeps a can of beer or soda cold for 3 hours no kidding. I've had one that works with bottles for about a decade but recently bought a handful of these to give to family as well has having a couple on-hand for 12oz cans. Several types of water bottles or small soda bottles fit in as well (like 12 oz plastic 'shorty' soda bottles). I won't go to any party or picnic without one or two of these

like the previous review mentioned, the viscosity of this material makes it likely to break the tabs if you use an inferior applicator that doesn't hold the nozzle due to the tremendous pressure built up when the epoxy starts to set up.Get the proper applicator: automix heavy duty 2oz. (all metal, holds the nozzle with a steel strap).-awr

I used to repair a couple shoes and WOW it worked incredibly well; the viscosity is low so very easy to squirt with the proper tool: 3M 2-Ounce Heavy Duty Epoxy Applicator Gun (don't use the plastic tool that costs like $2 less; get the STEEL one that holds onto the nozzle so it won't break off!.I used the DP100 to glue some magnets to some tin boxes and after about 10-15 minutes, i was able to knock off the magnet with a light pressure from my thumbnail! We took off all 30 magnets and with little effort were able to peel off all 30 little epoxy 'wafers' that were created between the magnet and tin.I switched to the gray 3M Scotch-Weld Epoxy Adhesive Duo-Pak, Gray, 1.69-Ounce and holy cow that stuff stuck. It 'stuck like epoxy!'Do not use DP100 on metal; i didn't see anywhere that it doesn't work on metal but trust me, metal is a perfect 'mold form' should you like to make a shape out of epoxy use metal 'cause it will release without an agent!I would like to have a clear epoxy that sticks to metal so anybody that knows the answer let me know!-awr

Ok i'd give it a 4 or 5 star review because the qualiy is excellent and the system for application is excellent, however i only bought this particular tube because it said 2 oz. size and i also bought the gun that says it works with 2 oz automix 3M epoxies.Turns out the tube delivered was 1.6oz, a clear 20% difference from the advertised amount, and that amounted to being short-changed by $3.19 on this order.So as it turns out, 3M/amzon use the various values interchangeably; 1.6oz, 1.7oz, 47ml, 50ml... basically if it looks like a duo-pak it is duo-pak. The DP epoxies in any of those sizes will work in any of the similar guns as far as i know.i bought the 3M 2-Ounce Heavy Duty Epoxy Applicator Gun, but there is a much cheaper option here: COX M25 25 ml. x 25 ml. Manual Epoxy Applicator for applying these duo-pak epoxies.
best portable drive made. 2TB and over 100MB/sec xfer when new.. typically more like 70-80 once half full but it's 2-3x the speed of firewire, and 'plaid' speed compared to normal usb-2

Absolutely fantastic; retail price over $230, they sell for $150 elsewhere and the PLASTIC VERSION was actually 50 more last time i looked.I couldn't find any review that would confirm that this tool worked with the scotch-weld dual-syringe 50ml tubes and this one says 2-oz but the so-called 2-ounce tube i bought with this gun actually said 1.6oz on it!So with amazon's policy of return, i 'took a bullet' for the team and bought some of each of 1.7oz (50ml) and so-called '2 oz' 'automix' epoxy and this gun to compare them and see which worked..The results:  1.6oz, 1.7oz, 50ml, 47ml, are synonymous and all work in in this metal version and presumably the plastic EPX applicator gun as well. The 'pro' with the metal one is it's WAY stronger, but the only 'con' is that it only works with 1:1 mix epoxy tubes, where the plastic one has interchangeable plungers allowing for 1:1, 2:1 and 10:1 mixes.It looks possible to modify this heavy duty gun to work with 2:1 mixes and i may buy one tube to verify if that is indeed possible. I will certainly post an update if that's the case.Also, the picture is very confusing so i posted a set of pics showing exactly how the gun works.-awr

I use for hovering a laptop over my bed. I added an extra arm to extend the reach and of course the laptop adapter.Fantastic! It reduces the stress and strain on my body by a factor of 500-800%I left the tilt function unlocked and that makes it even better! I rotate counter clockwise so my left wrist is not twisted and in a month I've healed from a serious RSI (carpal tunnel) injury.I will never go back to any other way to hold a laptop. I will be another set for living room to float the computer over a recliner.It will wobble if you type without the laptop resting a little bit on your leg or a pillow or such but it's an easy fix.Worth twice the price.-awr

We have the 21 and the 25" of this suitcase. They are fantastic. I bought the 21" one first then wanted the matching larger one. If you travel by air and not first class you don't want the 28" model it will be 2/3 full at most when it hits 50#.There is a model that has the same shape but NOT the same color as this model. If you want 'the one' that has the bright colored side panels so you can literally see from 100' away at the airport, you want THIS model and only this model.Soft sided luggage is much more survivable than hard sided, but these have a bonus; they are PADDED. might add a pound to the weight but they are very light weight, and it's well worth it to make the CONTENTS survivable when going through the gauntlet of airport luggage handling!Found out an added bonus the other day: the 21" exactly fits inside the 25"; it can't be by accident it's an exact fit; well that sure makes storing easier and extra handy for a trip where you will be bringing more back than bringing with.The photos online are terrible; these things are BRIGHT orange, like hunter's use for deer hunting, the yellow i hope is similarly bright.If you like a little splash of color in your life, get the bright yellow or orange models and you will LOVE how easy they are to spot coming out of baggage. (of course, unless too many people read my review).-awr

I thought there were magnets to hold the blade but it uses rubber pads. I HATE going to cook at friends or family only to find they have worthless knives so I bring my favorite with. Until now I used tape or cardboard for transport. This thing is 22nd century cardboard!Bumping off a star because loading is a little tricky when knife is at the max size (8" knife in 8" holder): it won't close unless you put in the "correct" side first and using all folding plastic for the hinges and latches means they will fail 10x as fast as if they used an actual hinge or clasp. It's literally 10 of plastic with 5000% markup due to the I.P.  nice deign but could be sold at $3 for a profit.-awr
You can trim to fit nice in the corner of glasses and make them flex better to fit some pretty radical curves. They are over priced and could be made a little more flexible or id rate five stars.

Update: bumped up to 4 Starr's from 3: the easy fix stayed for 15  months before I sold my pan to a buddy and bought a new one. The new 12" had the hump (about 1/16 inch tall). I put a star back because in practice very few items have a problem with cooking on the hump and though every indication is t-fal is backpeddling on trying to say it's on purpose that is obviously not true if it's not always. "We purposely make SOME of them domed". My 10" is perfectly flat.As promised and only 4mo. after getting my new 12" I developed a new way to flatten the pan: one step and worked like a charm.How'd I do it? Drove over it with my SUV. NOT KIDDING check out the photos.I was trying to figure out a fool proof method somebody could copy using on-hand items.Items: sawdust or kitty litter etc sheet of plywood about 18" square several "drive over boards" (3/4 plywood about the width of your car tire good) some bricks or 2x limber cut to size small pieces of plywood cut to size as neededAs the last photos show, clips from my movie, I put sawdust down in a circle under the pan, slightly concave in the middleI put the 18" square of 1/2 plywood over the sawdustI put the pan on that sheetI assembled a ramp from bricks and plywood to get car tire over the lip of pan.I put a square of 2x4 on top of a 4" square of 1/2" thick plywood to do the pressing.I drove over using front wheel for more weight.I stopped for a second or two centered on pan and drove off.My dome dropped 58/1000 on one pass and the flat c-channel I used for flat reference shows nearly perfectly flat after and a test with some soapy water shows absolutely zero "moat" effect. 100% solved!For whatever reason my 10" model was perfectly flat out he gate so no fix needed.For naysayers that drank the t-fal koolaid: in addition to the problems of food like crepes and eggs being hard to cook: flat top stoves lose about 80% of their conductive heat transfer when only touching on the outer edges so it makes for uneven cooking which is my primary motivation for fixing my ONE AND ONLY EVER domed pan.Original review:As many have noted: the pan may actually be the holy grail of non stick but the ego stamped on the bottom makes for a mini mountain in the centre of the pan.Wheat happens is that you will get a "moat" of oil around the center island of dry in the center of the pan. Nice if you want to make donut shaped crpes I suppose. Not super nice for anything else.QC so "out of whack" for a top tier vendor like t-fal is inexcusable. Somebody should be fired literally.Is it too much to ask that the flat bottom of a pan is flat without having to fix it yourself? Yeesh!The good news: easy to fix. I've used the trick of standing in a pan on carpet to un-mound a dozen pans in then past, and a similar trick worked on this pan.Then trick: the thick aluminum bottom was more robust than the pans I've fixed in the past so i used a slightly different method:I formed a donut shape with a rolled up towel and set the pan on it, then I stepped inside and while standing on the ball of my foot I lunged up and down "hopping but keping foot On the ground".I checked for flatness with a ruler both outside and inside until I was satisfied. In the end, two teaspoons of water with a tiny bit of dish soap to "wet" the surface spread edge to edge, no island. Also 1 1/2 tbsp. of oil once heated filled the bottom of the pan perfectly. (When cold it puddled in the center and stayed).So, "A" for non stick, "D" for putting a hill in the center of every pan by stamping a logo in without the proper compensation in the blank or the very least a follow up stamp to make the pan flat and some friggin' quality control!Ok, so after 1-2 minutes of hopping up and down, the hump in the middle went from nearly 1mm tall (about 1/4 the thickness of the metal to put that into perspective) down to about a 0.2mm dent in the bottom and darn near perfectly flat inside. (There are a couple areas maybe 0.1mm shallow inside, enough to take maybe 0.1 tsp of liquid but inconsequential. The fact the bottom still has a shallow when the top is flat means the stamping process (for the logo) is making the metal thinner in the center in addition to making the little hill.Love the pan and can't wait to get some cooking done and a follow-up if the fix is relatively permanent.I'll post pics when I get a chance.-awrupdate: so i got to try it out, and freakeshly non-stick; was so easy to cook crepes in this pan! especially with the thermo-dot. It turns color just a little too hot for perfect crepes but they were amazing and tasty; and just slid out of the pan!I ended up having to re-level my stove before i could really test the flattened out fixed copy, but with only 2 tsp of oil to lightly oil the pan (probably not even remotely needed for these crepes), there were just random spots of oil; it doesn't want to adhere to the pan enough to make a coating.I have a neat picture of 2 tsp of oil just sitting in a puddle in the dead-center of the pan while heating. I also was able to make an 'oil moat' just about 3/8" wide around the entire pan at one point, so there is still a little bit of a 'low spot' or perhaps just the fact there is a bend in the pan gives the oil something to grab onto.Now if i can only get my wife to stop using metal instruments and get the pan to last a while.considering it was 1/3 to 1/4 the price of a decent tri-ply pan the same size, this pan in spite of its hiccups is a home-run.-awr

As others have mentioned the refills are 5-20x the price of a large bottle of soft soap on sale. There is an easy fix to that.CMT 529.095.31 Tenon and Plug Cutter 3/8-InchA plug cutter makes a perfect round hole that you can use to refil for pennies not dollars. You do need a drill press to use one. The fist modification I did I used regular drill bits and 3-4 steps in size up to half inch. That hole was nowhere near as perfect or easy as the plug cutter solution. note: the 3/8 size makes a 1/2" hole. The 3/8 dimension is the inside.Then to plug the hole I use an expanding plug like a boat uses to drain when pulled out of the water. I didn't know if the unit relies on vacuum to keep from leaking so I made a tight seal.I already had the plug cutter and the expanding plug cost about the same as ONE refil so will pay for itself quickly.I will just use a rubber test tube stopper on my next conversion.

I've been borrowing my dad's C7 for 35 years, finally bought my own. His looks exactly the same after 40 and more years of use and nothing cuts like it. I would wait a week to do a project if dad was out of town to use the C7 rather than try another tool.

Perfection achieved. They can stop trying to improve on the classic design. The rubber base on both the catch container and bottom of the keeps it from moving. The lid didn't fit perfect but did seal and stay on after some brute force (the measuring cup also has a lid to seal your fresh cheese in the fridge).

It works just fine. It the mechanism is a little sloppy. I would have hoped for a little more precision. Example: because the sweeper blade doesn't fit precisely on the inside of the bowl, the contents do not exit in one piece. (I bought for specifically one job: sizing cookies). I have to follow-up and re-shape all the cookie balls because they don't exit cleanly.They do end up all the same size which was the main point. Haven't seen something that would do a better job though I may try a 1cup plunger type measuring cup.-awr

The power switch (they call a 'selector switch' is a terrible and inexpensive design destined to fail. It is a non-snap-acting leaf switch related to the 'knife' switch we used when we were in 4th grade but less reliable. The design is inherently bad, and destined to fail. This is because every time the unit is turned off it wil absolutely ARC which will cause a little bit of a 'burn' on the contact making it less conductive the next time. The switch is not different from the type of switch used in the 1800s for a telegraph machine; two contacts held apart on a springy coper strip that is pressed on until the contacts slowly touch (guaranteeing and arc every single time).(if you ever notice a flash of light emitting from the bottom center of the unit (reflecting off your counter top), that is from the ARC going across the switch with one more 'simon says' step toward certain doom)In my case, the switch self-destructed on the SECOND use. the contact for the main element overheated due to the carbon from the arc and melted the plastic lobe designed to SLOWLY PUSH the contacts closed, so the contact didn't close and it would no longer turn on.the ones that stay working are just lucky. the design is terrible. (of the switch). It (the switch) carries 12 AMPs and NEEDS to be a snap-acting switch. i'm very shocked this unit passed any type of product testing (e.g. UL labs).In any event, rather than waste 45% of the price i paid for mine just to send it in and get another useless switch, i re-engineered mine to utilize the other half of the leaf spring switch to carry the high-current of the unit and by KNOWING how tragically bad the inherent design is, i can switch the switch as fast as possible or better yet, turn the 'selector' switch to the position i want FIRST and *THEN* plug in the unit. the arc will then happen in the plug in the wall 1. something that gets cleaned each insertion and 2. costs $1.50 for a replacement.If my repair job fails i will 'jumper' out the switch permanently so that i will HAVE to plug/unplug to supply power to the unit and the 'selector' switch actually will be just that and no longer attempt to be a power switch.If I really feel like it i may replace the piss poor power switch with a proper one then won't have to un-plug to power down. a proper snap-acting switch even if just a light switch will do the job properly.I will post pictures of my failed switch and some descriptions that will help somebody with electrical skills to repair their own unit for free (and permanently).almost certainly if your unit started to turn itself off, and then would turn on only if the switch was partly turned toward either grill or griddle but would turn back off when all the way to either, your switch self-destructed by over-heating and can easily be fixed permanently.if you get one or have one, if you want it to continue working you should NEVER turn the unit OFF while plugged in! it will also last longer for SURE if you plug in AFTER selecting the mode you want. The switch literally is not designed to handle being turned on or off with power applied, it's a terrible terrible switch design for high-power.now for the good.1. man it makes a mean panini. absolutely perfect toasting of the bread, it self-levels and does exactly what it's supposed to do2. replaces my $20 griddle. probably not really better but eliminates an appliance and does fit eight pieces of french toast at once! I probably will never use for bacon unless i use it outside camping! just way too much grease splatter (though i'm considering trying it CLOSED). the new enclosed grease tray should harvest the splatters well.3. i bought the waffle plates. see my review there; they are great, not fantastic, however they are perfectly acceptable and there goes one more machine i don't need anymore.4. the 'new' model doesn't match the descriptions in many of the '1 star' and '2 star' reviews. Clearly they made a 'revision b' model with the same name (dumb dumb dumb). The new model 1. uses flip-over vs separate plates for grill/griddle, 2. uses identical plates for top and bottom, 3. has an integrated drip tray, 4. has a METAL hinge! 5. has some really tough plastic clips to hold the hot plates on.I'm very happy with mine, now that i've fixed the switch and know not to flip the power off while on. (oh. an easier way to turn off w/o pulling the plug would be to turn down the temperature until the 'heated up' indicator goes out, at that point the main switch would have no current and would not arc. That doesn't really help for turning the unit ON. I recommend having the selector switch set to your choice BEFORE plugging in the unit, then as just mentioned, turn down the temperature before turning the unit off. If you follow that protocol, the unit will last a WHOLE lot LONGER.I recommend the unit for anybody interested in the utility. I recommend that unless you are an electrical DIY genius you get one NEW so you have the full warranty. I recommend you follow the previous paragraph to the letter if you wish it to last.look for my pictures of the ridiculously cheap and inadequate switch, the fix and the 'plan b' fix for if and when the stop-gap fix fails.update: i annotated the picture of the switch to show how somebody can DIY repair a defective power switch.-awr

I wish they worked a little better but using the cooks illustrated buttermilk waffles with the seltzer water achives the best tasting waffles i've ever had.that said, they cost more than half the price of my griddler so they should be bundled even if at a higher price of course.the size of waffle is perfect. they are under 200 cal each (before condiments of course), and the recipe i use makes exactly three batches or 12 waffles.the waffles tend to come out perfect on one side not quite perfect on the other.I only spray with 'pam' before the first waffle (and only if i've cleaned the plates since the previous batch). they are perfectly non-stick!I LOVE the overflow area. at first i was annoyed they wouldn't use the entire space for bigger waffles, but clearly they needed to get the heating to work out best they could with the squggly heating wire and non-contact heating.my waffle recipe has a lot of 'lift' and actually pushes the top plate up unless i hold it down.it's very helpful that you can adjust the temperature for waffles. my first batch i used 400 but they weren't tosted properly by the time the indicator said 'done'. at 425, they came out much better without over-running the cooking time, and also the frozen ones are re-heating better without turning HARD.the plates should cost $20. but i only paid $70 for my griddler so i'm not complaning overall.. $100 total including both sets of plates and i gave away my old waffle iron.Oh ps: These waffles are a bit of a mutant in between belgian waffle and regular waffle. I'm loving the results with my machine even if not perfect. If they were priced appropriately OR they were perfectly even waffles OR if they toasted to a full  brown (especially both sides), i'd give 'em 5 stars. My official rating would be 3 1/2 stars but i put 4 because i'm very satisified overall even with the few hits.-awr

The overall look is fantastic; tubes of stainless is gorgeous for sure! An added bonus is they pretty much can't get dirty, all dust and dirt and water fall right through the rods!now for the limitations:1. the counter-sink holes for the screws are not uniform so the screw heads don't seat flush. minor but it's not as clean as it should be.2. The tubes are made of very thin metal. I have the 48" long version which exaggerates the issue but even the 31" version will have considerable 'wobble' and 'flex' to the tubes when placing items. even a 2-3 pound load will make the tubes bend and flex. It's most noticeable if you put on a small item that only touches 2-3 rods but has some heft to it; it makes other items rock back and forth that share the same rods.3. egregious oversight: the width does NOT match the standard spacing of STUDS in the wall, so there is virtually no way to mount this item solidly. wall anchors? please. On mine I was able to put the brackets on with the bracket to the OUTSIDE of the bars which spread the spacing between mounting holes to just about 48  inches so i could get the screws into the STUDS so it's solid.I added some support brackets under the rods at each 16" and now the shelf is 'as it should be'. I could probably put 200# of items on EACH shelf without a problem. My added brackets don't reach to the very first rod so it's super obvious how wobbly the rods are without the added support. I tried to take a picture but didn't have enough hands.

I want to point out something many are unaware of. typical to this type of rack system; when designed for mobility the shelves are designed 'upside down' that is; the sides go UP from the shelf level so there is a 1" LIP on all sides (to keep say some onions or cans or boxes) from falling off while being moved. I was planning to use the self as stationary shelves and that was going to be a problem.Then i re-engineered the design to be much more useful for my purpose.I set four of the rods aside, put the three shelves very close together (for storing the likes of pyrex 13x9x2 baking pan), i installed the bottom rods in the unit upside down and bought some -20 eye bolts and put them in the now TOP of each corner.Then i found some studs in the wall, screwed in some lag type eye-bolts and used some nice heavy stainless chain to each of the four corners to each of the four eye-bolts in the wall using some cut-out links from the same chain (vs s-hooks; looks much cleaner).so now rather than spending $90 for a purpose-built pot rack that is nearly identical, mine cost $30 and i have THREE levels. I will upload a picture or two to showcase the solution.update: i did in-fact upload and NOTE very detailed photos for anybody wishing to copy me. I will be making a second copy of the pot rack for my mother soon. Also, since i ended up with four spare rods, i found the perfect use for them. legs for my son's built-in bed. drilling holes into the edge of some 5/4th decking board and it made a perfect support beam.UPDATE:  21 may 15I recently had to relocate my pot rack when i bought a new fridge. I re-oriented it wide vs narrow and wow it's a big improvement I actually ca to 'take off a star' because so many people mentioned distain about the top shelf not being flat and a microwave won't work on the microwave rack but this rack it NOT SOLD AS A MICROWAVE RACK and there is no claim to the contrary other than the photos indicating that the shelving is 'upside down' of a normal stationary rack.. the five stars remain. Best pot-rack EVER.If i could find the wheels i never used and confirmed they suck as bad as other reviewers mentioned i'd take off a star but i can't find them so i can't comment accurately about them. I just added a new photo with the rack in it's new home; take note of the way i put on the frypans; with the larger in the middle; it works WAY better that way than all the same way small-to-large.-awr

The design of this has a fatal design flaw. each lid will rest against the one next to it. ONLY the two on the ends have something to rest against.I was able to modify mine to be useful and will upload a picture. only every other slot holds a cover, but now they are completely independent and the rack works as you would hope it would.once modified, it's quite useful. i only had to use my hands (with gloves; it takes a LOT of force) to make the modification.

About 2-3 weeks into first use and I'm amazed how perfect the butter is. In 68F room, the butter is pretty firm, not mush like if left on the traditional stick plate with glass dome. Butter tasted today just like the day I out it in.It's very important to keep the water fresh because there is natural bacteria that will get in there.There is a common misconception about these butter crocks. Many people think that the water fits up into the butter, but just like a cup held upside down in water, the air in the inverted dome just holds the water out. (when completely full of course the butter will touch the water but water and butter don't mix and it.s actually kept even fresher because there is zero air).Lost one star because the build quality is not the best: there are some rough edges on the ceramic that would have me rate it worth more like half the price they sell.-awr

Tired of the wife melting the inferior models. Guided to purchase by cooks illustrated. I accidentally bought the spoon version first, but kept it and bought this be too. The spoon is a monster and I was worried about getting the 13 inch model but wanted the long handle to keep hand out of splattering stir fry oil. I chose wisely. The 13 isn't too big for normal use.The 13" spoon on the other hand is a lot bigger than this 13" scraper and definitely feels institutional sized.-awr

Finally tracked these guys down so I could replace them. I bought my first pair about 6-7 years ago and even with three fingers worn through at the tips they are still my favorite gloves to work with.The key is comfort: nothing competes with deerskin and the supple nature means you can still feel through the gloves like a second skin.Fair warning: the trade off is that deerskin is not nearly as tough as cowhide but cowhide is horrible for gloves if you desire any control over what you are working on.-awr

I had reservations about buying sight unseen because it's a lot more pricy than the basics.Il bought the six inch to save a few bucks.Turns out I wish they made a seven inch. The eight is kinda big the six is slightly small :-(That said, the build and the amazingly fine mesh (almost could strain coffee wo a filter!) make it worth every penny. IIf you want to save some $ get the 8 inch else you'll end up like me and buying BOTH.-awr

Four for the price of one. Buy them now! I was really surprised to see "Germany" stamped on these fine blades. I was not happy that they weren't stocked by amazon so shipping was over priced otherwise they are worth double the price!update: there is a very confusing nearly identical set: J.A Henckels International 4-Piece Paring Set, Multicolor you do not want that set you want this one. I accidentally ordered the low-grade version before catching the mistake.After more than 2 years these knifes are the 'go-to' knives stuck with magnets to the side of my range-hood, the color makes them indexed by type you know which you are grabbing instantly, very smart. The flat knife perfect for cutting small blocks of cheese. Very happy to have the set and just bought another copy for my brother.

Finally tracked these guys down so I could replace them. I bought my first pair about 6-7 years ago and even with three fingers worn through at the tips they are still my favorite gloves to work with.The key is comfort: nothing competes with deerskin and the supple nature means you can still feel through the gloves like a second skin.Mine have been soaked many times and never got stiff and never had a problem with dye bleeding.-awr

I've had the Robotoolz > portercable 5-point laser that this tool is based on for 8 years or so. It finally died after 7-8 years of abuse.The model/s this is based on used to 'lock' the laser once it was done auto-leveling. This new mini-me model does not. This shouldn't be a huge problem but i'm taking off a star because of it simply because with my old unit, it would NOT wobble around when walking near it and this one is in constant pendulum mode so will wobble/wiggle with any microscopic vibration.FYI: there is no 'magic' to the 'auto leveling' it doesn't use servo motors etc; it's simply a pendulum :-D on the higher-end models where you can hear a pulse like a motor doing adjustments, it's simply a mechanism that releases then grabs then releases then grabs the pendulum so when it's done the pendulum is locked in place and you don't get a wobbling laser dot.There are some good points brought up in one of the low-star reviews that are valid and stooped on bosch's part for having some gross errors in the manual:1. it would seem that there is no longer a 'mode' for calibration; it is *always* in calibration mode. I owned the older model that this device is based on; it had a pendulum 'grabber' that would 'tick tick tick' while it was bobbing around and when it was happy that it was done, it would hold the laser beams solid so you wouldn't get the bobbing and wobbling as you walked around on the floor near the device. IGNORE the step how to get into and out of calibration mode and i'm quite sure it will work as described in the manual.2. the ' tripod mount is built into the multi-purpose attachment. this is the same as the older brother to this device as well.3. it's true that because the laser goes through a few prisms in the path out of the device (it's a very smart design because it make sure that the five beams will always be perfectly normal to each other), the dot will a) have diffraction interference dots and b) will get larger the farther away you are.with respect to 3, the center dot will get pretty big at distance, but it will a) have a CENTER and b) have smaller and smaller dots going away from the center; example the center dot might be  inch diameter but the 6th interference dot left or right of center will be only ' " diameter. You can get a very decent level from the horizontal offset dots and you can get a very decent plum from the vertical offset dots. it's not perfect but it works perfectly well.i've used the older brother to this device for 8 years (finally died after using it literally in a puddle of cement), and i will miss the locking feature that the 'calibration' function was made for, also since the 'overthrow' function of the power button (you would push PAST on), to engage calibration mode, was also used to defeat the auto power down function, i'm not sure if that's possible on this model and that will suck.It would be FAIR to rate a THREE based on the sloppiness in the manual not 'getting' that there is no longer a calibration mode but that you CAN in-fact still CALIBRATE the friggin' thing, you just need to get past the bug in the manual, but i think dropping the fancy wobble grabber will likely make this model more reliable long-term.You can also defeat the auto-off (20 min) function by turning the unit on then off then back on immediately.. it will blink fast for 2 seconds to confirm the auto-off was 'disabled' (quotes because it will shut off after 8 hours!).From a 'construction' standpoint I would be dead-in-the-water; i pretty much literally use the 5-point laser for every single thing i build; it's fantastic for putting in garage doors (4-5 i've done), entry doors (about half a dozen), kitchen cabinets (dozens in several kitchens), tile floors; many; the square function is priceless.you can use the strap to strap onto a 2x4 and with this new model, it has 2 holes in the removable base to SCREW to a wall, then project a dot onto the NEXT stud and use as a reference to drill a hole; you can get a PERFECTLY horizontal set of holes for beautiful results when putting in wiring, or you can use a pitch offset (drill each hole ' inch lower than the previous and get a perfect " per foot slope!)There is NO other way to make sure counter top (cabinets below) are at the same height than using this type of tool. It's also priceless for getting doors perfectly plumb; you can get things to 1/32" over 8' really easy, that's not so easy with even a 4' level.in a word: INDISPENSABLE-awr

I abused mine like nobody's biz; i've had plaster walls fall on it during demolition, i plunked it down in cement, knocked over countless times. I definitely got the *charmed* copy of this tool.I replaced it with the bosch PL-5 which looks identical but ' this size (and blue vs yellow and gray).it's a crying shame so many people had theirs fail. I'm glad to see a 3 yr warranty on the bosch though!maybe mine worked so long because i used it so frequently? other than the very last time i used it where it went more than a year between attempts, it never went more than a couple months in storage; also spent most of the time stored vertically not sure if that's the way it was 'supposed to be' stored.I built so many things with this thing, once i discovered it died, i sought out to immediately replace it which i finally did with the smaller brother that looks and works exactly the same.the one bummer about the smaller model; no 'arch' on the bottom to index the bottom laser on the ground for plumb (it does have a mark but you have to extend lines from the floor dot rather than just move the laser directly on top of the dot.-awr

the primary point of the taper is to improve accuracy. In the case of mine, notsomuch. constantly off by about a tablespoon. I will upload some pictures.The ink is very hard; it sticks out off the glass; feels like the glass is etched at first (now that would be much better).The combination of the thick glass, the taper makes for a serious parallax read error; easy to be off 1/4oz It's actually easier to read precisely by looking THROUGH the liquid if it's clear enough to do so.I'd sure be a whole lot happier if the thing measured the amount according to the LINES on it!Oh. FYI for future buyers; it's EXACTLY a classic regular glass 'pint' glass like you'd use for beer, but with markings. As others have stated it's a PINT glass but the markings go to 1  cup not 2 cup. I bought mine to replace a 1c measuring cup that i melted with goo-gone trying to remove the idiotic sticker; man i tell you about the morons that pick what stickers to use!somehow i thought it was going to be RED and it was BLACKas far as the accuracy goes; if you always use just this measuring device, of course then you will just make slightly bigger recipes.It was mailed in a padded envelope! whoa i guess if they do it always and they make it; kudos for saving material but i was pretty shocked to see glass sent in a bag!-awr

This knife came as sharp as any knife gets. I haven't had it long enough to show any sign of wear but wanted to mention that it can only be bested by knives costing 4-6x the price so that says a lot. Not too many knives that can fillet a sheet of paper! This knife is freaky sharp!The sides are absolutely mirror finish which will by laws of physics generate a vacuum and hold smooth wet items. They make models with the granton scallops in the blade to reduce the wet cling issue so it's good to have one of those handy.Since the blade is a stamped blade it will handle countless re-sharpening if done properly so is poised to outlive me.-awr

I've tried and looked at a dozen variations of this type of soap handle scrub brush. The is the only one i've seen that has all these attributes:1. removable brush2. easy fill3. squirts (most open a valve and dribble).4. seals with a valve.there is a rubber button half way down the handle. when pressed it pressurizes the inside, pushing the valve open and squirting out some dish detergent.nothing short of perfection; it even has a little plastic scraper for tough items on the back side.-awrps: be CAREFUL selecting; oxo makes an nearly identical one that doesn't squirt i wouldn't GIVE that one away.UPDATE: Mine finally failed after 2 3/4 years. That is a very fair lifespan. I would recommend if you are getting over 2 years to buy a spare; don't bother buying the brush the button will fail before the brush wears out. Keep out of the sun, and don't subject to harsh chemicals or press harder than you need to. I suspect a lot of premature failures come from people pressing too hard on the button because there is a bit of a design flaw that it doesn't squirt well when less than 1/2 full. When it gets below half full re-fill it does not squirt well when less than half full (can't circumvent the laws of physics; when the airspace above the liquid doubles it takes double the pressing to get the same liquid out; when the airspace is 90% bigger it takes 10x the pressing of the button to get the same liquid out. So with this item the rule is; fill it often; it only works well when more than 50% full.Also, i hang mine over the sink facing brush side away from me; then i can squirt some directly into the sink or onto my hands for cleaning my hands, super convenient.  Off to order a new one to replace the broken one. I also ordered a couple of the palm models; i have a different similar one but it only dribbles out by gravity when you press the action button; the oxo palm model squirts just like this one.

KitchenAid 700-Watt 12-Cup Food ProcessorsThis FP has over 500 reviews. go see it at the link above. I don't know why there are two listings for this identical device.update: because the top does not seal so dry material sprays out (unless you fix it which i did), i've updated my rating to 3 stars.

Oh my no. If there's one aspect of book blogging that I dread, it's having to write a review for a children's book I didn't enjoy. Since I receive a lot of review copies from publishers with the understanding that I will post an honest review, I don't feel like I can just skip reviewing it altogether.I also can't sugarcoat it. If I didn't like a book, I have to be honest or else my favourable reviews of books that I DID like will be less meaningful. How would anybody believe I was being honest if I can't be honest about what I don't like, as well as what I do?Anyway, I didn't like this book. At all. If it had been a book for adults, it probably wouldn't have been so hard for me to be blunt, but for some reason I worry about hurting the feelings of children's book authors and illustrators more than other authors. But I need to get over that because this book was terrible.The illustrations are so crudely done that I was shocked it was a professional artist who created them. They didn't seem intentionally crude, either. They weren't like Garth Williams' delightfully "messy" pencil drawings, full of charm and intention. No, these seem like they weren't done with love at all.The concept of the book might have had potential, but the text felt woefully unfinished and under-edited. The idea of a little man who lives under a tree watering the roots is introduced out of nowhere, and the book ends just as abruptly. What was the point? Does he have adventures? What are we meant to take from this? It really could have been so much more than it was, but instead it was a story stub with forced rhymes and undeveloped characters.This is usually the part where I try to think of one nice thing to say about the book because I feel bad for hating it so much (maybe it's because I'm Canadian? or a preschool teacher?). Let's see...it was...um...short.

My daughter and I learned a lot from this book. I was vaguely aware of the role of animals in the First World War because I had seen A Bear Named Winnie, the biopic of the "real" Winnie-the-Pooh. I knew that there were horses and veterinarians sent over to help the war effort, but I didn't realize that Canada had sent so many police horses over to Europe, many of which were killed in action, and the rest of which were adopted out to European farmers at the end of the war.This book tells the story of one such horse, nicknamed "Bunny" because of its slightly long ears.Bunny was ridden by two different Canadian soldiers who were brothers. One brother was killed in action while the second brother--and Bunny--survived. The book showcases the bravery of Bunny and the other horses, as well as the soldiers themselves, without being overwhelming for young readers. I'd definitely recommend it for children, particularly Canadian children. It would make a good read for Remembrance Day or other times when children are thinking about soldiers and war.

Julia, Child is not strictly about the life of the famous chef, Julia Child...but it sort of is. It's a story very much inspired by the spirit of Julia Child, in the form of a little girl named--you guessed it--Julia who falls in love with food and wants to share her passion with everyone. She and her best friend, Simca (the real nickname of French cookbook author Simone Beck, a contemporary and friend of Julia Child), set out to share their buttery treats with all of the adults around them and to remind them of the joys of childhood and the joys of food.The illustrations compliment perfectly the delicate whimsy of the story and the spirit of its inspiration. Julia Child was an English chef who introduced the world to French food. She was a formidable woman who managed to put the most reticent aspiring cook at ease. She was funny and passionate and joyful. The pictures in this book (by the very talented Julie Morstad) are all of these things. There's something delightfully English-but-also-French about the scenes she creates; they're sophisticated yet rustic, joyful yet refined. I adore absolutely everything about them![This review first appeared on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on a digital review copy I received through NetGalley.]

In real life, I'm not sure that moles are particularly cute, but there sure are a lot of cute and curious moles in children's picture books. Why is that? I'm not sure, but my daughter Magda sure loves them!In this book by Ellen Tarlow, the little mole in question wants to explore the outside world, particularly in the daytime. She falls so in love with the sunny blue sky that she wants to catch it and bring it back to her home underground. This proves to be impractical for a number of reasons, but with the help of some of her animal friends, she manages something almost as good.Although I prefer animal books in which the animals all have names (rather than just 'Mole' and 'Rabbit,' etc.), I do like the fact that Ellen Tarlow made some of her characters male and some female. I'm always shocked by how many authors choose to make all animal characters male by default. Has anyone else noticed that? What is that about? Even female authors do that! I find myself changing the pronouns back and forth between "he" and "she" just to even it up. I was happy that I didn't have to do that with Mole Catches the Sky.As soon as Magda and I finished reading the digital review copy of this book (thanks NetGalley!), she immediately asked if she could read the "real" book. I completely agree with Magda that print books are more satisfying to read, particularly when it comes to children's picture books. I'm grateful for the chance to read books on my computer or ebook reader that I wouldn't otherwise have access to, but I'll always prefer to hold a book in my hands, smell the paper and turn the pages with my thumbs. Unfortunately, our local library doesn't have this book in their collection, so Magda and I have already put in an official request/recommendation that they buy it immediately!Magda's Take:"I know that a mole wouldn't really want a skylight in her home, but it was still very sweet of the other animals to try to give her some sunshine. It was just a book so the sunlight didn't hurt her eyes."[This review was originally posted on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on a digital review copy I received through NetGalley.]

Staying home all day with a busy toddler can be exhausting. Well, I say it can be, but I should say it is. It IS exhausting.
