At the end of the day you can feel like you haven't gotten anything done but you're completely wiped out.It's nice that this book not only shows what that kind of day can be like, but also shows it from the point of view of a stay-at-home dad. He makes breakfast, sees Mommy off to work, takes the dog and the child to the playground, reads books, and even gives the child a bath and gets him ready for bed. That IS a busy day![This review first appeared on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on a digital review copy I received through NetGalley.]

Mark Frauenfelder has true gadget geek cred. As the founding editor of MAKE magazine, former editor of Wired, and creator of BoingBoing, he's got everybody beat in the category of "guy most likely to write a book about cool DIY projects to try at home." But as a father of two girls he also brings the added element of "guy who understands how great it can be when dads share these cool projects with their daughters. It's not that any of the projects in this book are limited to dads only, or to daughters only, it's just that it's great to see that dynamic actively encouraged.As the parent of a little girl myself, I sometimes feel like I'm manoeuvring through a mine field of unhelpful--and usually harmful--gender messages along the lines of "construction toys are for boys" and "arts and crafts are for girls" (I saw almost that exact sign at a toy store just this week...ugh). A lot of times the message is subtle: pictures in magazines, books, catalogues and flyers that show boys and men using tools, blocks and trucks, but girls using paints, beads and dolls. This gender divide is reinforced literally everywhere. So I very much appreciated seeing so many photos of girls using band saws throughout this book (most of the pictures are of Frauenfelder's own daughters).I'll admit, some of the projects in this book are a little intimidating at first glance. In the introduction the author says that most of them can be accomplished with "tools you probably already have at home" then he lists a full page of equipment that includes things like jigsaws, soldering irons and blowtorches (wait, was there a blowtorch? I might be remembering that wrong). So it seemed scary. But in reality, a great many of the projects don't involve anything scary at all--just some cutting, gluing, painting, sculpting or hammering--and look like they could produce fantastic results. Even the lounge chair that he and his girls made looks pretty straight forward.The projects are not arranged in order of easiest to most complicated, so don't let a difficult looking project discourage you from reading further. "I wasn't always an eager maker of things," Frauenfelder assures us. Even he had to be coaxed into trying new things. But if he can make it all look easy--or at least doable--then maybe it's not so hard after all. And with several projects that involve delicious looking edible treats (YAY!), I'd say it's worth a try.This review was first posted on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on a digital review copy I received through NetGalley.

I agree with other reviewers who said that this book is a good reference for art students, or for artists who want to look something up quickly, or explain a concept to a non-artist.It's a brief overview of the second half of the 20th century (or at least it is now, thanks to the updated version) in terms of art movements and the major social and political events of their respective times.It is not necessarily a book that I would enjoy browsing through just to look at lovely art. It's definitely not a coffee table book...well, especially not my copy, since I was reading the digital version!The digital version does have the added benefit of being hyperlinked with cross references so you can look up definitions as you read.This review was originally posted on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on a digital review copy I received through NetGalley.

I'm sure I'm not the only one who has a preschooler at home who is obsessed with babies and pregnancy (tell me I'm not the only one?) but it's hard to imagine anyone being MORE obsessed than Magda. She unself-consciously tells people that pregnancy is "her hobby" (what the heck?). So I can't imagine anyone enjoying this book nearly as much as she did. It's a lovely book, but you haven't really experienced it until you've heard my four-year-old cooing and squealing excitedly at every picture. Every. Single. One. I tried to record her reactions so I could play an audio track with this review, but it came out is an unintelligible collection of "oohs" and "ahhs" and high-pitched giggles.Magda's Take:She can't talk right now. She's still staring admiringly at the pictures of the pregnant ballet dancer and the twins who look like truffula trees.This review was originally posted (sadly without an audio track) on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on a digital review copy I received through NetGalley.

The Sagebrush Singers is an interpretation of the classic "incredible journey" type stories in which a ragtag group of animals travels together to form an unlikely musical band. Apparently it's from a Brothers Grimm fairy tale, which you can read on the book's website (part of the publisher's site).The thing is, the original German tale is way better than this book. Way, way better. The 'twist' of The Sagebrush Singers is that it takes place in the desert (in the Wild West?) and has a burro, a coyote, a skunk and a crow gathering together for...some reason. It's not all that clear. They do manage to scare away a bunch of cattle rustlers so that's...something.The crude drawings, overly wordy text, Spanish words peppered in on every page (but apparently you have to go to the website to find the glossary), and nonsensical plot make for a mediocre book at best. Even Magda (the world's most generous book reviewer) gave it a "so-so". Harsh words, coming from her.Here's what my daughter, aged 4, had to say:Magda's Take:"It was...eh...so-so. I mean it was good, sort of. The pictures were a little...I don't know. Were they sexist, do you think? Because every single character was a boy--all the people and all the animals--no girls at all. It would have been nice if at least one of the animals was female. I don't know. It was okay, I guess."Mom's Note:Magda and I do talk about things like gender stereotypes and sexism from time to time, particularly when it comes to things like toy marketing and stories aimed at children. I do notice that WAY too many children's book authors (both male and female authors) decide to make every single animal character male by default. This annoys me. Not only is it irritating and lazy, it's also never the other way around. There are never animal books in which every single animal character is female by default, so it's not just a coincidence that could go either way. It's either evenly distributed between male and female, or else it's all male. Argggh.Anyway, this is one of those male-only animal books. I think Magda is noticing it more now that she's reading on her own, because she notices if I try to switch the pronouns back and forth between "he" and "she."To be honest, the all-male characters didn't necessarily bother me in this book (as it has in other books), but that might be because I thought the book had so many other problems going on already.This review was first posted on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on a digital review copy I received through NetGalley.

I adore Robert Munsch. I think he's a masterful storyteller and his long-time collaboration with illustrator Michael Marchenko has produced some amazing children's classics.Sometimes, however, when his books are condensed to board book form, they lose some of their oomph. The best parts are edited out, or they're oversimplified, or the magic is somehow not there.Pigs, however, retains all of its "Pigness" even in the shorter format. My only problem with it is that I'm not sure this particular story *needed* to be made into a board book.The board book format is presumably so it's easier for little hands to handle, so that younger children can access the story. I'm not sure Pigs is best suited for younger kids. It's one of the Robert Munsch stories that has characters being a bit rude to each other, with the constant refrain of "Hey you dumb pigs!". This may be fine for school-age children, but a lot of parents and teachers don't like reading that kind of impolite phrase to very young children.This review was first posted on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on a digital review copy of the board book edition that I received through NetGalley.

Ouch. This was a painful read. I alternated back and forth between reading the book and listening to the audiobook, so it was doubly painful. Sigh. I'll try to start with the good points.1. First, I loved the first book in this series, The Yard. At least I think I did. After reading and hating The Black Country and The Devil's Workshop, I'm starting to question if I ever loved the first book as much as I thought I did. Maybe I only liked it because it reminded me of the far superior Inspector Ben Ross and Lizzie Martin series by Ann Granger (THAT'S A HELL OF A SERIES, BTW). Anyway, at this point I'm ready to give up on Alex Grecian altogether. As a writer he is clearly more interested in a gothic thriller style than a classic Victorian detective novel. It's just not my cup of tea.2. Secondly, I should point out that the narration by John Curless is quite good. He doesn't overdo the voices or the accents, though sometimes it might be a wee bit hard to tell one character from another. Sure, it's excruciatingly melodramatic most of the time, but that's hardly Curless' fault. I'm convinced he read the book exactly as it was meant to be read. It's not his fault it was so poorly written.I think that's the end of my good points. I found the book, as I said, excruciating. Here are just a few things that annoyed me:1. Alex Grecian turned Jack the Ripper into some ridiculous caricature of a "devilish" baddy that is slightly less menacing than Sideshow Bob and twice as cartoonish. Plus all of his passages are italicized, which is a lot less fun to read than Alex Grecian seems to think it is.2. Inspector Day's perpetually pregnant wife Claire is, as it turns out, a total idiot. She finally goes into labour (hasn't she been pregnant FOR THE ENTIRE SERIES?) and reacts by writing horrible poetry and simpering like a child. I mean I know childbirth is hard (TWENTY-EIGHT HOURS OF LABOUR, PEOPLE!) and lord knows I'm probably the least brave person on the planet when it comes to physical discomfort, but even I wanted to scream at her to buck up a bit. Honestly. I'm amazed this woman has the brain cells to operate anything as complicated as a button.3. The entire premise of the book MAKES NO SENSE. A group of vigilantes have been busting prisoners out of jail so they can...what? Punish them MORE? But it's not like convicted murderers in Victorian England were sitting around on death row for decades before execution. These prisoners were definitely going to be executed, and quickly. So what then? Do they mean to torture them? I guess so, but again, Victorian English prisons WERE NO PICNIC. They were already being 'tortured' in a lot of ways, and the treatment they received at the hands of this secret group of vigilantes didn't seem any worse than descriptions I've read of actual prison conditions at the time. So are we supposed to believe that the torture was worse, but Alex Grecian just chose not to describe it? It's not like he's shy, because he certainly gets mighty descriptive about grotesque violence later in the book. My guess is he just didn't think it through all the way. So irritating.In the end, I think my favourite thing about this book is that it reminded me of another series which I do love, the Inspector Ben Ross and Lizzie Martin series by Ann Granger (seriously, it's sooo good), and it prompted me to check to see if there's a new one coming out. And there is! Hooray! So I have that to look forward to at least.

Callaloo: A Jazz Folktale is an "almost" book. I can see where the author and illustrator were going with it, but it didn't quite get there.The basic story is that a boy named Winston is eating callaloo, his favourite Caribbean dish, while sitting in his apartment in New York City, when he is suddenly transported to the island of Tobago. And that's when the book gets a little scary. Winston encounters a series of frightening demons and monsters before finally returning home to his kitchen. Upon his return he apparently has learned the value of eating in moderation. Was that what he was supposed to be learning? I guess so. It wasn't all that clear.I think the idea behind this story (which is based on a play) is that readers are supposed to feel they are transported to another land along with Winston (sort of like Where the Wild Things Are), or that a regular kitchen can have the power of transformation (like Jonathan Cleaned Up and Then He Heard a Sound), but also that we're supposed to learn a lot about the Caribbean islands (like The Drummer Boy of John John). The problem is that the drawings are simple and unsophisticated enough to suggest the book is for very young children, but then the monsters are pretty scary. So the overall message seems to be, "If you eat Caribbean food you may end up in Tobago, which is the scariest place on the planet." I can't help but feel the author intended the book to have the OPPOSITE message.Magda's Take:Magda didn't actually finish this one. We started to read it after she'd had a big lunch and just before she was supposed to take a nap. When she saw that it was about a boy eating a lot of food she declared that she was too full and too sleepy to read this right now. I finished it on my own while she was napping and I'm glad I did because those monster drawings would have definitely scared the crap out of her.This review (including my four-year-old's limited input) first appeared on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on a digital review copy I received from NetGalley.

Clara loves her curly hair but oh, how she wishes she could have MORE of it. Thanks to some conveniently placed hair growth formula found in her parents' bathroom, she gets her wish and more. Before long she has hair that reaches the sky and all the inconvenience that comes with it.She's like a cross between a Robert Munsch character and one from Dr. Seuss (remember Gertrude McFuzz?). How she managed to get her hair to stay upright as it grew past the ceiling I'll never know.Magda and I enjoyed this book, though I think Magda found the premise of wanting MORE hair a bit perplexing. She had been growing her own hair out so she could donate it to Locks of Love when she eventually had it cut. After months of dealing with tangles, braids, extra brushing and endless blow drying, the day she got it all chopped off was the happiest of her young life!Overall, the book is good, but didn't make it to the "read it again...and again...and again" list in our house.

What an absolutely charming, laugh-out-loud funny book! I know my four-year-old can be pretty easy to please when it comes to children's books, especially if they have dinosaurs in them, but I wholeheartedly agree with her glowing review of this one. Here's what Magda had to say:Magda's Take:"I loved it! I loved the part where it says 'If you happen to have a dinosaur in your living room' because it's so funny! You can't have a dinosaur in your living room! They died out before humans were around! But I liked where they got all the dinosaurs to give them rides and deliver the mail. I even liked the part where it said that some dinosaurs would make good kites even though those weren't really dinosaurs. It was still funny though. Can we read it again tomorrow?"This review (including my daughter's input) first appeared on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on a digital review copy I received from NetGalley.

My four-year-old daughter helps me review children's books on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and the Rose Lagercrantz books are among her very favourites in early chapter books. Here's our review (as it appeared on my blog):Magda and I were so excited to see this followup to Rose Lagercrantz's My Happy Life that we almost couldn't read it fast enough! First we had to re-read the first book (at Magda's insistence) which we borrowed from the library, then we devoured the second one in a single sitting. I know as soon as it is published Magda will want a "real book" copy of it as well.If you're not familiar with My Happy Life, I recommend reading it first. The characters are introduced so well in the first book that the second one makes more sense if you already know and love them, but I'm sure it's not strictly necessary. Both stories follow a little girl named Daniella--Dani for short--who describes herself as being "always happy" despite the fact that she actually has quite a lot of unhappiness to deal with. She prefers to focus on her happiest memories though, which she tries to think of often.In My Heart is Laughing, Dani is still trying to deal with the fact that her best friend, Ella, has moved to another town. She has other friends, but it's not the same. She tries to think back to her last visit with Ella to get her through the tough times.My favourite thing about these illustrated picture books for young readers (perfect for reading aloud) is that the character of Dani is complex and realistic, despite the fact the books are quite simple. At first glance, I thought that the stories would be saccharine and shallow, that the little girl would be happy all the time and everything would be perfect. While that may or may not have made a good book, it's not very true to life. I couldn't have been more wrong in my assumption, however. Dani's life is anything but perfect. Her mother died when she was young and her father is trying his best to give her a good childhood. She frequently has conflicts at school that she finds difficult to handle. She sometimes behaves in ways that she regrets. She is sad sometimes. But the book's delicate optimism hits just the right balance between sweetness and poignancy. Dani is a child to root for and relate to.My four-year-old, herself a happy child who has her fair share of anxiety, conflict and regrettable behaviour at times, adores these books. I asked her to tell me what she thought of My Heart is Laughing and she talked for about fifteen minutes! Here are just a few of the things she had to say:Magda's Take"I love this book. I think this book and My Happy Life are my new favourite chapter books. I can't decide which one I like better, but I guess it depends on my behaviour at the time. I know that sounds odd, but it's because in My Heart is Laughing, Dani has all kinds of behaviour that isn't very good--like when she squirts the sauce and runs away from school and kicks her shoes and breaks the vase--and she has to deal with all of that. Dani's the star of the books, but then when she hides under the table and runs away from school it's like she doesn't want to be the star anymore."My favourite scene is when Vicky and Mickey are pinching Dani. I like that scene because I like news. I mean, that scene was sort of like the news, because I learned a lot about the characters when they were pinching. For instance, I thought that Vicky and Mickey were sort of like stars of the book too, but then when they were pinching Dani so hard it was actually hurting, I thought that they're not stars at all. They were like her worst friends, the bottom two. But I liked that scene a lot because I learned about them by what they did. Even though it wasn't a non-fiction book, I felt like I learned a lot from this book. I think you can learn even from fiction books."I received an advanced digital review copy of My Heart is Laughing from NetGalley in exchange for an honest review. I was not otherwise compensated for my review. All opinions expressed are strictly my own...and, in this case, those of my daughter, who will want to get a hardcover copy of this book (or "real book copy") as soon as we possibly can.

I love cozy mysteries. Like most avid readers, I read a lot of different kinds of books, but I have a guilty-pleasure favourite genre. I adore a good paperback murder that has an amateur sleuth snooping around her small town looking for clues and handing out recipes. Ooh how I love them! And because I love the genre so much, I'll usually put up with a lot of the mediocrity that comes with genre fiction (by that I mean that even though there are many, many great examples of the genre, there are inevitably also many less successful ones...and I love most of them just the same).With Barbara Ross' Maine Clambake series, however, no forgiveness is required. Her writing is stellar, right out of the gate. In fact, if someone who had never read a cozy mystery before asked me to recommend a book to introduce them to the genre, I might choose this one.Barbara Ross understands everything that I love about fiction in general and mysteries in particular. First, her setting is a real place. I don't just mean that she set the book in a place that exists in real life (I don't care about that...fictional places are just fine), but that she describes it in a way that is so deliciously realistic that I feel I could walk down any street in her book and I would know exactly what it would look and smell like. She spends time on her secondary characters, giving them things to do other than just provide clues to the murder investigation (which is wonderful because some of them are hilarious).I had actually started reading the second book in this series, Boiled Over, first but then was enjoying it so much that I decided to stop and read this one first. Because of that, I think it was a little easier for me to figure out "whodunnit" in this one. I'd recommend just reading them in order if you can. They're both heaven.

Oh this is a lovely book! It tells the story of Feivel, a Jewish immigrant who comes to America in the 19th-century, leaving his family behind in Europe, so he can make a better life for them in the new world and hopefully earn enough money for them to come over and join them. A gifted artist, he makes a living carving elaborate and beautiful carousel horses, each dedicated to a member of his family. Finally, he earns enough for his wife and children to join him in New York, where they can finally see his amazing "horses."Because it's based on real events, the book is of particular interest to children of Jewish families, European immigrants, or those who live in New York, but it is certainly not limited to that audience. The theme of longing and determination expressed through art is a universally relatable one, I think, and I found it very touching. Mostly though, the illustrations are so rich and lovely that it made me want to go on a carousel. What a wonderful book to read in the summertime, when there are merry-go-rounds to ride on at fairs and exhibitions (though perhaps not as amazing and special as the ones in the book)!This review first appeared on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal.

I'll admit I picked up this cozy for the title. It's a hell of a title. Like many cozy mystery titles, it's pun-based, and after binge watching all three seasons of Rosemary and Thyme (an absolutely delightful British mystery series that has nothing to do with this book), it was a pun I was particularly susceptible to. Plus, I had a vague recollection of reading a review and/or giveaway for this book on another book blog some time ago, though I couldn't remember if the review had been positive. No matter. I figured I'd pick it up and decide for myself.I wouldn't say I was over the moon for this book or its characters. There was something unconvincing about the whole thing right from the beginning.The premise is that our heroine--not that I found myself rooting for her much--runs a spice shop in a small town in Georgia. A spice shop. As in, one that only sells spices. I'm not sure how she'll manage to stay in business! Granted, I'm sure these shops do exist, but the author has the spice shop owner doing such "radical things" as putting curry in mayonnaise (shocking, I know!), only to have the people in the town revolt over such exotic spiciness. Yeahhh...that's not a town that can support a spice shop.But I decided to ignore it. After all, Gail Oust is hardly the first author to create an amateur detective who runs a shop that couldn't possibly make enough money to stay afloat (*ahem* Joan Hess).Beyond the premise, though, it's the little things that kept taking me out of the story. Our "heroine," Piper, discovers the body (of course) and panics (okay) and thinks to herself that she should contact the authorities to "report the crime" (good). But then when the police arrive and spend most of their time being excessively rude and snappish (why?) and tell her they have a murder to investigate, she freaks the hell out. Murder! She never considered it might be murder! She's beyond shocked! Except that no, she can't be, because she just called it a crime scene two pages ago!It's just those kinds of little things that annoyed me throughout this book. I believe the technical term is "bad writing."Even if I had been willing to overlook the flaws in the storyline, it's not like I was enjoying following the characters around or being immersed in the setting. The town is dull and unpleasant, all of the characters are irritating, and Piper Prescott the spice shop lady only has two settings: shock and rage. She goes from being shocked to outraged and back again so frequently throughout the book that her resting face must be a deep scowl. If she used Twitter her favourite hashtag would be #whyinever. In short, she's unpleasant.I can't say I'd recommend this book. I would, however, recommend a lot of OTHER books with similar themes that have better writing and more likeable characters.This review (and some of my recommendations for better books) first appeared on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on a hardcover edition I borrowed from my local library.

The Ellery Queen Mysteries is a TV show about a regular forty-something single guy in New York who writes mystery novels and lives alone with his also single father, a police inspector who brings his son along literally every time there's a murder to solve the crime for him. That's normal right? Nothing strange about any of that at all.I've been curious about The Ellery Queen Mysteries ever since I read creator Peter S. Fischer's book Me and Murder, She Wrote (which is SUCH a great book btw). In it, he talks about several series he created or worked on, including Murder, She Wrote, Columbo, and a few you probably don't remember (like The Law and Harry McGraw or Blacke's Magic). There's a special place in his heart, though, for The Ellery Queen Mysteries, which Fischer recalls fondly throughout the book while expressing continued confusion as to why the show wasn't more popular. After watching the series on DVD, I think I know why.It's not that the show is terrible--it has a lot of great elements which make it fun and watchable--but it definitely has some problems. The premise--that writer Ellery Queen solves murder cases better than his police inspector father can--might be straight from the books, but the TV series makes it seem like his father is the world's absolute worst detective. It's not that he's portrayed as bumbling (quite the opposite--David Wayne is very gruff and direct) so much as that he has no idea what he's doing. Whenever there's a murder he literally panics until someone goes to get his son. His son the writer, not the police officer. It stretches the very limits of belief.I'm also not a fan of the fourth-wall-breaking moments when Jim Hutton as Ellery Queen speaks directly to the camera saying, "I've figured it out. Have you?" That almost never works out as well as TV and movie creators want it to. Suddenly I feel like I'm watching a children's detective show with the host saying, "Hey kids, did you figure it out?"The series was only based on the Ellery Queen stories in the most basic ways (only one or two episodes even credit Queen, the rest being original scripts using the same characters) so you're not likely to find your favourite books or short stories depicted. It does stay true to the "fair play mystery" aspect of Ellery Queen stories, in that all the clues you need to solve the mystery at home are given and shown. Of course, they rather hit you over the head with that point. And the answer to almost every single one is that the murderer left before the victim was really dead, giving the victim a few seconds to leave a "dying clue," some cryptic indication of who the killer is (no one ever uses those last seconds to call for help or try to stop their own bleeding).Still, there's something inviting about the show. It takes place in the 1940's but was made in the 1970's, which means that it feels very 70's. What was it about the 1970's that compelled people to make period dramas in which everybody wore polyester and shiny blue eyeshadow? And the odd relationship between father and son is sort of like a detective duo version of Sanford and Son. Plus there's the added mystery of how 5'7 David Wayne managed to have a son as tall as 6'5 Jim Hutton. How tall was the mom supposed to have been??But the chess-themed opening sequence and instrumental music draws you in. Get it? Because his name is Queen, like a chess queen? And he solves difficult puzzles, sort of like playing chess. Yeah, the show doesn't go much for subtlety. But I'm glad I watched them. I could almost hear Peter S. Fischer in the background saying, "I love this show! Why isn't anyone watching it?"This review first appeared on my blog, Murder She Watched, a mystery-themed offshoot of Cozy Little Book Journal, and is based on the Ellery Queen Mysteries DVD set that I borrowed from my local library.

I've been meaning to publish a review of this book for some time but I've been procrastinating just a little. Unlike the overwhelming majority of books I review, this was written by someone I know in real life. Sort of. I met author Eva O'Regan at a my local library where she was doing a book launch event for this book (which is when I agreed to review it on my blog) and it turns out she works in my dentist's office.I'm not one to sugar coat reviews, and I would never give a dishonest review of a book just because I'd met the author (or for any reason really), but, well...if I didn't absolutely love the book then a lukewarm review could be...awkward. I'd probably have preferred to just not review this book at all, but I already said I would, so here goes. (I assure you it's my honest opinion, but I definitely wanted to give everyone a heads up about any connection I have to the author, in case that changes how you assess my review.)My daughter and I read this book together and it's, um, okay. The idea is an interesting one: A little girl writes backwards and astounds her friends at school. The entire book is written in mirror letters (THE ENTIRE BOOK) so it comes with a sort of shiny reflective mirror paper thing in the back that you're supposed to use to read the words. The idea is that you put the shiny mirror paper against each page and read the reverse image.First of all, the shiny mirror thing doesn't work that well. It's awkward to read the book under the best of circumstances. I can only imagine how hard it would be once the reflective paper gets scratched, creased, smudged, or worse--lost. And because the book is paperback it's difficult to keep the reflective page at the exact right angle to read the words. Nice idea, but not the most practical execution.Also, when I say the entire book is written in mirror letters, I mean the ENTIRE BOOK, not just the parts where Rosie is writing. Personally I think it would have been more successful if the main story were written normally, but maybe the character of Rosie could write things in reverse that readers would have to "decode." That's just my opinion.As for the story itself, I do like the fact that Rosie's backwards writing is treated as a special talent instead of cause for concern. On the other hand, it probably would have been good if there had been a little bit of conflict for the main character to overcome. Did the kids at school think she was weird? Did her parents worry that she had a learning disability? Was her teacher annoyed that she wasn't writing properly? Although Rosie briefly worries about these things, the reaction from everyone is universally supportive. While that's lovely, it doesn't necessarily make for the most interesting storytelling.Here's what my daughter had to say:Magda's Take:Will I have to know how to write backwards when I start school? I know how to write most of my letters, but I don't know how to write them backwards! Is my teacher going to ask me that? Also, why does the teacher in the book look exactly like the mom in the book? Do you think the illustrator was just drawing herself? The grownups all look the same. That's strange..Mom's Note:Magda is right about the adults in the book looking a lot alike. I hadn't noticed that!As for her fears that she'll "have to" write backwards when she starts school, I've assured her she won't! But it seems like a bit of a missed opportunity to me that the author didn't include a parent resource page at the end about reverse writing, dyslexia, etc. Even a brief note on her website would have been great. Again, just my opinion.This review originally appeared on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, and was based on a print copy of the book that my daughter and I received from the author. All opinions expressed--for better or worse--are solely those of my daughter and myself.

Kathy Stinson's (Red is Best) book, Big or Little? is about an experience that every parent of a toddler or preschooler can relate to: your child feels (and behaves) like a big kid some of the time, but also feels (and is treated) like a little kid other times. Helping in the garden makes him feel big. Being able to reach the elevator button makes her feel big. But then she has to go to bed when she's not even tired, or he tries putting on a shirt and the sleeves end up in all the wrong places, and it's back to feeling small. It's the constant struggle of being a toddler.I say that parents will relate to it, but I can't guarantee that kids will admit to it (even though these are things they go through ALL THE TIME). When I read it to Magda I asked what things made her feel big or little. She said, "I'm four, Mommy. I'm BIG. FOUR IS BIG, Mommy." She probably just didn't want to admit to anything, in case it was a trick question to get her to take a nap when she wasn't tired.My daughter and I read a digital copy of the board book edition with illustrations by Jennifer A. Bell. You can see more about this book, along with other reviews, on my blog--Cozy Little Book Journal.

It's like Kinky Friedman and Christopher Moore got together and had a misanthropic baby. A baby with an ill-tempered monkey.I only wish I had read this book sooner. I've had it on my e-reader for about a million years (or whenever the advanced review copies were released) but it took me this long to get around to it. On the plus side, that also allowed me to enjoy the audiobook read by Arte Johnson, which is FAN-TAS-TIC.Another reviewer pointed out that Carl Hiaasen must not like women very much, since all of his female characters are broadly painted caricatures of awful personality types. And it's true. I mean, I think the "Dragon Queen" character isn't even given a real name. Of course, another reviewer responded by pointing out that his male characters are pretty awful and unlikable as well. Also true. So he's a misanthrope. But something about the kvetchy reading by Arte Johnson makes the misanthropic craziness of the book seem, well, almost irresistible.And the monkey IS very ill-tempered, so that's fun. But it's not really his fault. He is surrounded by awful people. What's a Capuchin to do?Still, it's not exactly an enjoyable read all the way through. There's racist language--which didn't seem to me to add anything other than, well, racism--a lot of sexist language, and some situations that are more than a little icky. I'm not sure if I would have enjoyed it at all if it weren't for the great narration.

I got this book from the library when I was about three and it was love at first sight. It was the first book I ever learned to "read" all the way through, meaning that I memorized all the words and when to turn the pages. When it was time to return it, my mom didn't have the heart to tell me I couldn't have my favourite book anymore so she marched me into the children's section of the Colchester Regional Library in Truro, Nova Scotia, and told me to 'read' the book for the librarian. She figured--correctly--that the librarian wouldn't have the heart to make a three-year-old part with her new favourite book either. The librarian was sufficiently charmed and stamped the book "DISCARD" right then and there so my mom could buy it for me.I still have this book today and now my own child counts it as one of her favourites. My mom is a freaking rock star.I wish I could buy this book for every child in my life but it's pretty hard to come by these days. I'm just glad I still have my copy!(You can see pictures of my copy, along with other reviews, on my blog--Cozy Little Book Journal.)

I've never read an M.C. Beaton mystery that didn't star either Hamish Macbeth or Agatha Raisin, so I'm glad I tracked down this stand-alone novel. It's charming, and written in a style that reminded me of Michael Palin's novel, Hemingway's Chair (which I read years ago and absolutely loved).The story revolves around two people trying to solve a years old train robbery rather than a murder, though a few people are killed--or nearly killed--along the way. I liked Fellworth and Maggie as the sleuthing couple and almost wish Beaton had given them their own series. They could have been a folksy Tommy and Tuppence (Agatha Christie), or a shabby Nick and Nora Charles (Dashiell Hammett).The only thing that surprised me, familiar as I am with Beaton's other work, was that there wasn't a literal skeleton in the closet. The title is use in the traditional sense of the phrase to mean "a hidden family secret," which is established early on as the main intrigue (so it's not a spoiler). Still, with M.C. Beaton, I was a little disappointed no bones came tumbling out of the pantry!This review originally appeared on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal.

Fantastic! I thought it'd be silly or at least, well, quirky (considering it's published by Quirk Books, who you probably know from their Worst Case Scenario guides and amalgams of classic literature with zombies, sea creatures, and the like) but this was full of solid advice like:--How to do laundry;--How to cook in a microwave (I'm totally stealing that personal sized chocolate chip cookie recipe);--How to ask your parents for money (do it in person and corner one parent rather than both);--How to email a professor (no emoticons!).I also like the small size. It's perfect for sending in a care package! (And graduation present season is just around the corner...)Also, it's fun that their legal disclaimer (just copyright information basically) is called, "Stuff Every Lawyer Should Know."This review originally appeared on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal.

Poetry collections are among the most difficult books to review. Poetry, even more than most other kinds of writing, is so subjective and also so personal. If you don't like a poem, it's easy for the poet to argue that you "just didn't get it."Having said that, I didn't like these poems.I was excited for this collection because I've always had a great admiration for Marilyn Monroe, like so many other people who were born long after she died. She's fascinating, even in death (my mother insists that Marilyn's fame after death is greater by far than any she enjoyed in life). Plus, I like poetry. I just don't like reviewing it.But this collection of free verse left me disappointed. The style and content are repetitive, to the point that I wondered why the author even needed to write more than one or two poems on the subject at all. Every piece has essentially the same point of view: Marilyn was beautiful and alluring but ultimately a victim. She didn't want to be sexy; she was forced into virtually everything in her life; and she was tragically and chronically misunderstood. It's a story that's been told many times before, and by writers far more compelling than Lyn Lifshin.This collection was originally published 20 years ago and I'm not sure what, if anything, has been updated. As much as I love Marilyn Monroe, I didn't find anything in these poems that hadn't already been better said by Elton John four decades ago.This review first appeared on my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal. I received a digital copy of the book through a giveaway on LibraryThing but was not required to write a favourable review (obviously).

There are some things I really like about this neck pillow, and other things I'm not so keen on.First of all, as other reviewers have noted, it is soft and feels lovely against the skin. I also quite like the colour, which is exactly as it appears in the picture (but that's a pretty small detail, and wouldn't have been a deal breaker either way). And the stuffing of the pillow is the kind that molds to the neck nicely, so it's very comfortable that way.So just as a neck pillow--forgetting the vibration for a moment--it would be very comfortable. Well, except that it's small. Very small. I didn't have any problem getting it around my neck, but once I had it on I didn't feel like it provided very much cushioning as a travel neck pillow, compared to others I've had. On the other hand, sometimes when you're travelling you have limited space, so maybe some people would prefer the smaller size.As for the vibration, I'm not sold on it. The vibration pack is located at the back of the pillow (it also has a battery pack that takes 2 AA batteries, not included) so it's very intense on the back of your neck, but nowhere else. And I found it loud! The sound of the vibration started to hurt my ears after a very short time (which is all I could use it for anyway, considering the instructions recommend not having it vibrating for any longer than 10 minutes). And even the lowest setting seemed fairly intense. Maybe I just have a sensitive neck, but I was hoping with 6 settings that at least one of them would be gentler.Also--and this might be something I wouldn't do as much once I got used to it--I found myself accidentally turning on the vibration buttons when I was taking the pillow off, putting it on, or adjusting it. Maybe it was just because I wasn't used to it yet (or that I'm a total klutz) but I had visions of taking a nap with it and waking up to a sudden surprise vibration as my face hit the 'ON' button.So overall it's okay, but not perfect. But it's not bad for the price. And I liked that it had an easy to understand instruction manual and a 3-year warranty (not that I use product warranties much, if I'm honest). It just wasn't the perfect pillow for me.Full disclosure: I was sent this pillow from the manufacturer at no cost in exchange for an honest review. I wasn't otherwise compensated and I never agreed to give a favourable review just because they sent me the product. What I wrote is exactly what I think.

Eeee! I loved this book so much! It was the most fun book I've read all month (I read a lot of books, so that's definitely a compliment).I love detective fiction set in Victorian England ('VicLit,' I like to call it) but lately I seem to have found all the worst examples of the genre. I was starting to despair. I'm so glad I found this book. It was like a palate cleanser after a bad meal, or in this case, after bad writing.Not only is The Revenant of Thraxton Hall well written, it's SO MUCH FUN. It's like a Scooby Doo episode for nerdy adults. Vaughn Entwistle has Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and Oscar Wilde investigating a murder in a haunted castle. There are secret passageways, spooky portraits, levitating psychics, blind butlers, ghosts, guests wearing masks, and--oh my god!--a family crypt with coffins! Not to mention a mirror maze, a monkey running amok, a woman allergic to sunlight... Oh it's just so much fun I can't stand it!It may seem strange that I loved this book so much when I criticized other books in the genre for having too many plot points, for being historically inaccurate, for having an ill-conceived ghost story, or unrealistic characters. So what makes The Revenant of Thraxton Hall different? Simple. IT'S WELL WRITTEN.If a story is well written it could take place in a unicorn colony on the moon and I'd find it believable. If a story is poorly written it could be an autobiography and I'd question its veracity.My only complaint is that J.M. Barrie didn't factor into the story as much as I'd have liked. He was with Conan Doyle and Wilde in the beginning, and I think it would have been fun if he'd been with them at the haunted castle. They could be a supernatural crime fighting trio, with Sherlock Holmes showing up as the secret advisor only Arthur Conan Doyle can see.I'm already fantasy casting the voice actors for a cartoon version of this book (can anyone say Stephen Frye and Hugh Laurie?).Visit my blog, Cozy Little Book Journal, for more about this book and a truly ridiculous number of similar book recommendations (turns out I read this genre A LOT)...

Such a great idea for a book! It's no secret that I'm a sucker for these types of books of weird facts aimed at ten-year-olds, and have been since I was a ten-year-old myself. This one is particularly great because the authors enlisted the help of actual kids (from schools across England, mostly 9-11 year olds) to submit questions they most wanted answered, then they approached various celebrity experts to answer them. The experts range from chef Heston Blumenthal to illustrator Quentin Blake, with a lot of TV doctors and hosts of science shows thrown in.And the answer to the titular question (which was not, I was disappointed to learn, the first in the book but instead buried mid-way)? Does your goldfish know who you are? Well sort of. It probably has a longer memory than the oft-quoted three seconds, and evne small fish can remember when and where they get their food, but it likely can't recognize your face.My favourite question in the book? "Why are Quentin Blake's drawings so messy?" To which Quentin Blake replies, "They are not messy! It takes ages to get the lines exactly as I want them!"

I thought I knew a little bit about Stephen Hawking but after reading his brief autobiography (it really is brief, he's not just saying that as a play on his most famous book, A Brief History of Time) I realized I hadn't known anything about him. First of all, I thought he had cerebral palsy and had been wheelchair bound since childhood. Not so. He has ALS, a degenerative disorder that didn't present symptoms until he was in his early twenties. He was on the rowing team in university! (Though he was the person who does the shouting and no actual rowing. What's that called? I literally just read it. Oh I forget.)I also learned that Stephen Hawking is twice divorced (the first divorce was particularly complicated and sad) and that he has written a series of science books for children with the help of his daughter, Lucy. I also learned that A Brief History of Time was meant to be a populist book to explain astrophysics to the everyday person. After four failed attempts at reading it, I question whether or not I qualify as an everyday person. But at least now I can say I finished a book by Stephen Hawking!

I don't profess to be a music expert, but here goes.  I like this recording a great deal - the soloists are very good and of course the music is sublime.  What I object to - and the reason this doesn't get a five-star rating - is that Maestro von Karajan treats this rather more like the Verdi Requiem than the more intimate piece I'd prefer it to be.Still, a very good recording.

I first saw and hear Bryan Hymel on a broadcast of the Met production of Les Troyens.  I was extremely impressed and a bit surprised - how could I not have heard of a great new tenor?  Apparently, I was not alone, as Mr. Hymel has become something of an overnight sensation - though of course an opera career rarely happens overnight.Simply stated, Mr. Hymel has a glorious and quite beautiful heroic tenor.  I don't know how he'd do in the more traditional heroic tenor roles (i.e., Wagner's), but he's really wonderful in French opera - and he gives us a taste of his Italian abilities with two arias from "Les Vpres Sicilianes" (better known as Verdi's "I Vespri Siciliani").  He has it all - elegant phrasing, phenomenal breath control, high and low notes galore.  In short, I think he's bound for operatic glory.So why only a four-star rating?  I will likely get bashed for this, but the program is repetitive and therefore dull.  I'd have loved to hear his treatment of some softer, arias - perhaps (assuming he wants to stick to French opera) something from Faust or Samson et Dalila.  Of course, he's loyal to the title of the recording, and thus sticks to heroes, heroes and more heroes.  But that makes it all rather stentorian and a bit dull.I'm very much looking forward to hearing more of and from Mr. Hymel.  As I said, he's a comer.

I've never read any of Oliver Sacks's books, so I'm not sure why I decided to read this one.  Perhaps it was that the reviews conveyed his sense of wonder, his humanity, his idiosyncratic nature, or all of the above.In any case, I am so glad that I was tempted.  "On the Move" is a profoundly generous, moving diary of a life spent in eternal inquiry and wonder of all that we see around us.  Sacks isn't moved merely by the disturbed patients that he's seen (and helped) over the many years of his life; he is also moved by some kinds of trees; by swimming, bike-riding and other physical activities (including his obsession with weight-lifting); by the brilliance of some of his fellow scientists and humanists; and by the humble joys of family (though his family is far from humble - his relatives included Al Capp and Abba Eban), reading and writing letters.  He's also not a perfect person, and he readily admits this; his problems with drugs; his inordinate sensitivity to what people say about him; and the fact that for much of his life he observed the world from an emotional distance - without love (and sex), among other things, are as much a part of his life as his insatiable curiosity and quest for knowledge of all things around him.Sacks discusses some very weighty topics, indeed, many of which are apparently the stuff of which his books have been made - and I've already ordered one of them in a kind of backwards pilgrimage from this one.  Yet he rarely loses sight of the reader (in fact, the only time he does this is in a rather lengthy and tedious discussion of the theories of Gerald Edelman toward the very end of the book), and as a result the book is eminently readable and enjoyable.It's rare for me to wish that a book could be longer; after all, there are so many more books I want to read.  However, this is a wonderful exception.  I wish the book could go on longer much as I wish that this incredible man could go on living.  Alas, he is dealing with terminal cancer and will likely not be with us much longer.  Having read this brilliant memoir, I can at least appreciate the sadness of his imminent death and of his absence from a world that he made a better place.

I don't usually read thrillers, but I was traveling and hated the book I was reading, so when I came upon this, having read Janet Maslin's review in the NY Times, I decided that some "light reading" was in order.I wasn't exactly right about the "light" part, but it was a great book to read while traveling; in fact, I read nearly all of the book on flights from Seattle to Jacksonville.  I certainly understand the comparisons to "Gone Girl."  It's a narrative told from the perspective of two people on opposite sides of the same facts, and neither of the main characters is appealing; in fact, they range from off-putting to totally creepy.  And of course, things turn out not to be as they seem.The writing isn't great; Ms. Knight isn't a great stylist, and her characterizations and dialogue aren't riveting.  However, she's apparently done lots of writing for TV, and it shows in that she knows how to write a good yarn.  It's really quite hard to put the book down, and while an argument can be made that she takes too long to get to the point, it's worth waiting for.  And even after the "major" facts come out, she throws in a few extra surprises for good measure.All in all, a good read for its kind.

I dont usually like political memoirs; too often they are boring (and then I did) and full of self-justifying/aggrandizing platitudes.  However, I decided to read this one because Im attending a conference at which David Axelrod will be speaking, and I thought it might be interesting to get his take on things before I listen to him in person.I must say that I was pleasantly surprised.  While Im sure Axelrod has at least a normal amount of ego (and maybe much more), he nonetheless comes across as a decent man who, like all of us, makes mistakes from time to time and has insecurities and worries.  He doesnt shy away from criticizing others views, policies and actions, but his criticisms are not nasty or gratuitous.  He also refrains from the insufferable self-righteousness of, for example, Hillary Rodham Clintons Hard Choices (surely among the worst political memoirs in recorded history).Axelrod also appears to be committed to his principles and to acting in accordance with those principles  for example, by opting not to work on campaigns of people with whose principles he disagrees.  Most interesting, however  and the reason we even know who Axelrod is and the reason he wrote this book  is his commitment to Barack Obama.  He believes in Obamas principles and in Obama the man.  Regardless of what anyone thinks of President Obama  and I know Im likely to get dozens if not hundreds of comments on this review  its refreshing to see someone who is loyal (though not unquestioning) to the end vs. so many memoirs that betray confidences and principles.Its also important to note that the title of the book doesnt just refer to Axelrods belief in Obama; it refers to his belief in our political system in general. Im not sure I can agree, given how big money has destroyed any remaining element of integrity in our political process and system, but hes a believer and I think we need some people like that.The book has some weak points, particularly Axelrods failure/refusal/inability to justify Obamas lead from behind approach, which even many liberal Democrats find frustrating to the max.  He seems to say that thats not Obamas way, but if thats true then Axelrod, as chief message-maker for POTUS, seems to have failed in doing his job.That said, this is one of the best of its kind, at least of those Ive read.

I need to accept that I just don't love mysteries.  The problem is that once in a while I read one that I really like, and then I find myself more susceptible when the next one comes along.  That's what happened with this one.The mystery in this book is OK, and the atmosphere - Berlin in 1936 - is intriguing, to put it mildly.  However, I found the hero, Private Investigator Bernie Gunther to be a bit too much of a wisecracker than seems appropriate for that time and place, and his constant wisecracks become tiring.  Also, the other characters are really caricatures - the beautiful movie star, the corrupt industrialist, and so on.OK, but not my cup of tea.

This book received good reviews when it was published, but for the life of me I can't figure out why.  First, it's touted as a book about Mr. Berg's brother's murder.  It's about that, but only partially - and secondarily.  Mostly, it's a memoir of the author.  That might not be a drawback, but the murder is really the most interesting thing about the author and his life, and by focusing on himself rather than the murder and the overarching tragedy of his family, he makes the book boring and stuffy.  And that's compounded by the fact that the author is very full of himself.  I have no doubt that the prosecutor who went after his brother's murderer did a bad job, but instead of expressing anguish or anger, the author goes into a long riff about how he would/could have done better; if that's the case, why didn't he more actively assist the prosecutor?  It just smacks of a big (Texas big) ego rather than a poignant tale about a family tragedy.

For many years, I thought that Norma was a tedious opera.  I can't explain why I felt that way, but I recently had occasion to listen to this recording, and it changed my views.  I don't think Norma will ever be my favorite opera, but in many ways it's grand opera at its best, and this recording is the best of this piece.  I know there are those who think that each of Sutherland and/or Callas was Norma incarnate, but for me they don't compare; I find that I can no longer bear listening to Dame Joan (may she rest in peace); the horrid diction, the scooping into notes, the lack of phrasing, and the sheer size of her voice always make me think of a Wagnerian hero in drag.  And I may be committing sacrilege to some, but for all of Maria Callas's acting ability (and she was a great actress if not a great singing one), her voice is, well, let's just say unattractive.But Caballe has it all - the diction, the precision of her singing, the phrasing and the sheer beauty of her voice - with no lack of power - are all there.  Fiorenza Cossotto is equally as good and the two of them together are greater than the sum of their not inconsiderable parts.  Domingo's role may be something of a cipher, but he's in his prime here, and that was glorious.The melodies, the duets, the arias, and so on are also great.  In fact, it's just a gorgeous opera to sit back and listen to and taken in the glory of the art and those incredible voices.  Take a listen.

An admission - I'm not a mystery reader.  I read them occasionally, and very occasionally I love them, as in the Stieg Larsson series.  However, as much as Mr. Sansom places this mystery in an interesting time, at bottom it's still, well, just a mystery.  I'd like to say that if you love mysteries this is a great book, but since i don't love mysteries I can't say that.

Clicking on a rating that translates into "I love it" is a bit weird with this book.  While I believe it earns five stars, saying "I love it" seems inappropriate for a book that is so disturbing.  Ms. Kim pains a very painful but very vivid picture of North Korea; it seems a truly barren country in all senses of the word - so much so that at times it's like reading a non-fiction version of 1984, with speakers blaring at you all the time and everyone spying on everyone.I note that some of the critical reviews questioned the inclusion of so much about Ms. Kim in this book, but it is subtitled "A Memoir," and to have written about the school in the Pyongyang "suburbs" without including something about herself would have been to extend the severity and sterility of the country to include herself; frankly, I found it refreshing - or, rather, humanizing - to include something of herself.  I also noted reviews that chastised her for possibly harming the other teachers at the school because they will be "found out".  I suppose there's some validity to that criticism, but how else could anyone write about a society as closed as that of North Korea?  Anyway, it makes the book a bit more interesting.A very chilling book but very important for that very reason.

To my knowledge, Leontyne Price never performed this role on stage, and I remember reading that it took every ounce of his estimable persuasiveness for von Karajan to persuade her to take on the role in this recording.  Thank goodness!  Aside from a somewhat bland Habanera (perhaps it's so hackneyed a piece that it's hard for it to be otherwise), she owns this role.  She is a sassy, angry spitfire who sings magnificently and who alone is worth the price.  The other performers are also at top levels; Freni brings her usual sympathetic persona and sings beautifully, and Robert Merrill is his customary virile self.  Many have carped about Franco Corelli - I'm among them - but I'm willing to forgive his excessive melodrama because despite that he really does sing his heart out.  (Note that I once saw him sing Don Jose in Philadelphia, where he sang the Flower Song in Italian; many booed, but given the overwhelmingly Italian make-up of the audience, most cheered.)  The conducting is von Karajan at his bombastic best as well.Oh, I know people will say this is an inauthentic Carmen, and of course that's true, but this recording is just too full of pleasures.  My favorite Carmen on disc is that of Regine Crespin, who is uniquely French and really knows how to seduce with her voice, but this recording is simply enjoyable to the max.

While I'm not a big fan of recital discs, one must settle for them these days given the paucity of complete recordings.  And this one had quite a buzz for a while.  However, the reality is somewhat disappointing.The good news is that Ms. Borsi has a lovely voice - not great, but lovely - and she has a way of caressing the words that is nice.  The other good news is that some of the pieces are intriguing, such as the Respighi aria that another reviewer has noted.Everything else is not so good news.  As some of the other reviewers have noted, she has what I'd call a "wide vibrato" - not a wobble (or at least not yet).  It's acceptable if noticeable most of the time, but she comes perilously close to the "w" word and given her relative youth I don't see this getting better.Second, despite her ability to caress words, everything sounds the same (with a couple of exceptions) - it's all lovely, bland and largely devoid of passion.  I call this the "Leona Mitchell Syndrome," except that Ms. Mitchell's voice really was exquisite, while this is merely lovely with a portent of ugly in that incipient wobble.Also, is it my imagination or are these pieces played way too slowly?  I thought my CD player was on strike or something - so much so that Ms. Borsi couldn't carry the full word "ascolta" in the aria from Turandot.  Shame!I give it three stars because it is, well, lovely and it's not going to the thrift store (yet), but a great recording it's not.

This is a "nice" recording.  It's hard to refer to Wagner as "easy listening," but this is about as close to it as you can get.  Jordan and the Paris Opera Orchestra have a nice command of the music and manage to infuse it with enough beauty and drama to make it pleasing to anyone who likes Wagner.  So put it in the CD player in your car and drive, or read a newspaper; you won't be riveted to it, but it will be nice to know it's there.Nina Stemme's rendition of Brunnhilde's immolation scene is a bit disappointing.  I couldn't tell if acoustics were the problem; at time it seemed as though she wasn't being miked very well.  However, like the rest of the recording it was pleasant to listen too without getting your pulse going.

As some others have noted, this is the perfect repertoire for Donna Anna - not that she's bad in many others (her poor showing in the Strauss Four Last Songs notwithstanding).  Her diction is perfect (it is, after all, her native language), and she just has a feel for the pieces.  She may be a bit too mature for Tatiana in Eugene Onegin, but others have sung it when they were older, and she could surely pull it off.  However, my favorite piece is the excerpt from Prokofiev's War and Peace, which I'm not familiar with but need to be; it's absolutely gorgeous and she sings is magnificently.

Every once in a while, a recording (book, play, whatever) lives up to the hype it's gotten.  That's the case with this recording, which has won awards and generally been cited as "the" modern recording of these terrific pieces.  Bavouzet, Noseda and the BBC Philharmonic all do a great job, and even the acoustics are terrific.  The Bronfman/Mehta recordings are very good, but these are superb.

This is a mixed bag, IMHO. I wasn't whelmed by the first concerto - it's competent, of course, but nothing riveting.  Concerto No. 2 was much better - particularly the final movement - but all in all the recording doesn't compare with the brilliant recent Matsuev/Gergiev recording, among others.  So while it's better then mediocre, it's not worth four stars, and I'll dispose of it to provide more room on my very crowded shelves.

I must agree with the other three-star review.  I've become a fan of Ms. Stoyanova, having loved her Desdemona on the recent Muti recording as well as her recital disk of Verdi arias.  She starts out a bit wobbly on this recording, though she does warm up and give a lovely performance. The other soloists are a mixed bag. The tenor, Saimir Pirgu, is unknown to me, and I'm not sure I'd like to know him better.  He's OK in spots, good in others, but really not good at all in others, bleating his way through some of the lovelier passages in this work.  The mezzo/contralto is Marina Prudenskaya, who's quite good, as is the bass, Orlin Anastassov.Which leaves us with the conducting, which is just plain odd.  There are passages that are so slow that I thought there was something wrong with the recording or my CD player, while others were up to speed and quite dramatic.  Normally, the conductor's approach to this work is consistent within itself; in other words, some conductors treat it like a dramatic opera - say, Otello - while others treat it like a choral work and de-emphasize the dramatics, but each conductor's approach is consistent throughout his work.  Jansons's approach is not; there seem to be passages where he's definitively decided that it's a religious choral work and others where it's high drama.  If he can't make up his mind, neither can I.All in all, not the worst recording of this work, but not the best either, and when you've got as many great recordings of it as I seem to find on my shelf, I don't regard this one as a keeper.

If you're thinking about buying this recording to hear and hold Anna Netrebko's version of the Strauss Four Last Songs, save your money.  I continue to think that she is a wonderful dramatic singer - I've seen and heard her in enough roles (most recently in Macbeth at the Met) to demonstrate that beyond a reasonable doubt.  However, lieder - even these most operatic of lieder - require nuance, subtlety and in a number of cases soft singing rather than scenery-chewing, and for that purpose Ms. Netrebko just doesn't have it.  At least not yet.  As some other reviews have indicated, the last song is a bit better than the others, but for the most part it sounds like she's channeling Lady Macbeth.  That may be a bit too harsh, but it gets the point across.The accompanying piece, Strauss's Ein Heldenleiben, is well done in my opinion, but it's an afterthought - it's not even mentioned on the cover of the  jewel box.  Instead, the cover features a photo of Donna Anna in a dramatic red gown; it may well be that she's running into the woods to hide from the reviews of her performance here.

Mr. (Ambassador?) Muoz is a distinguished diplomat and I have absolutely no doubt that he is intelligent and sincere.  However, this book is all over the place and sheds virtually no light on the assassination of Benazir Bhutto.  He starts out by giving a quick summary of the assassination itself and its immediate aftermath; then he goes backwards in time and gives a brief history of the Pakistani political scene; he then goes back and gives a more robust history of Pakistan, including the assassinations of Bhutto's father and several others; then he dissects his UN-sponsored investigation of the assassination - noting several times that his mission was not to find the culprit.  The last section of the book is an essay on the strange (and strained) relationship between the US and Pakistan.While these sections are more or less interesting, the early ones are repetitive and the last one has nothing to do with what I thought the book would be about.  Moreover, in most cases, the sections are too detailed to serve as the general overview he seems to seek to achieve, but not nearly detailed enough to give the full story.  And the weakest section of the book is the one that discusses the investigation of the assassination, because it told me nothing that I didn't know before (aside from details that I'm not sure I needed to know).  As a result, the book is choppy and inconclusive, and it's really not clear why he wrote it - or why he wrote it in this manner.So, despite his intelligence and sincerity, the book is not what it's supposed to be about and not very good at what it is about, and not worth reading.

Rosenkavalier used to be my favorite opera.  I still love it, and it's still one of my favorites, but each time I listen to it I feel more and more as though I'm listening to a recording of a three-ring circus.  Of course, this is in some ways what this opera is all about, and Solti is a splendid ringmaster.  This recording perfectly mirrors the lushness (is that a word?) of the era and the score, as well as the slapstick comedy, and both are made to order for Solti's style of conducting and his showmanship.As I've noted in other reviews, I believe that Regine Crespin was among the greatest sopranos of the 20th century. Her voice was huge but gorgeous, and she was capable of singing quietly without losing any of her quality.  She was also a singing actress in the sense that she acts most effectively with her voice.  All of these pulled together make her a Marschallin for the ages. The other cast members are equally perfect for their roles, and that includes the Baron Ochs of Manfred Jungwirth, who's a great singer as well as a great buffoon in this role.  Heck, even the tiny part of the Italian Singer is sung by none other than Luciano Pavarotti.I'm devastated that this recording seems to be out of print, but perhaps it's available for download somewhere.  It's well worth it.  Listen to it with a cup of coffee with whipped cream, and you'll feel right at home.

So coolI was honestly getting this as a gift for my mother in law, but i fell in love with it and i dont think i will be giving it away, i am just going to have to get another one because this one is mine.I love the size of it and how realistic it looks, my kids never even realized it was a cup I should have kept it that way because then maybe my son would not be drinking all my drink.I really like the included lens lid, and the top is see through, it screws on tight and I have not had any issues with it leaking.Its a great size and its perfect at keeping things hot or cold if you wanted.Easy to clean with just some warm soapy water.Overall a great product and I am happy I got it for review. *sample provided*

Very niceI really dont know what feature I like more about this mouse, its the perfect gaming mouse and back in the day when I would constantly play wow this would have been an amazing thing to have , it would have made my gaming so much easier. It is very easy to control and it works flawlessly. Very smooth, and does not stick. Works good with my gel armrest mouse pad. I am more used to cordless mice these days but even so i dont mind that this one is corded because the cord is nice, i really like that its braided cable and it does not get tangled as a standard one does, I have also noticed that it stays in place more instead of sliding all over the place.I love that it changes colors, its light a nice light display right at my computer. I also really like the skull on it, I love skulls so thats a big plus for me. Dpi works well and its nice to have , especially if your using it as a gaming mouse or you edit alot with it because your able to control it better then your average mouse.I have been using this along with the light changing keyboard, and I just love the light display.Even if you are not a gamer the side buttons that let you go forwards and backwards in your browser are a huge selling point.Overall  its a great product and I am happy I got it for review. *sample provided*

Love itI got something similar to this for my son and knew that my kids would fight over it , my oldest daughter has diffuser in her room that changes colors so I got this for my youngest daughter who is 8 and I know she will love it. I am keeping it for her for christmas but i tested it out and its amazing. I have always wanted to see the Northern lights and sadly this is the closest I and my family will probably get but its absolutely beautiful so i will take it.It displays a beautiful light display close to like what you would see with the Northen Lights. Then the best part the top can be removed and it projects a mini lazer light show, its so cool. It is very easy to control and switch between settings.It has a 1 hour auto shut off, love this feature my daughter will be able to enjoy it till she falls asleep and then it will shut off in the middle of the night on its own.Its not just a light projector but it also has a built in speaker very easy to connect to a phone , tablet and will be perfect for my daughter to use it with her mp3 player. Comes with all cables that are needed. The speaker is nice and loud and it is very clear, if this is taken care of it should last a long time.**Check out included video to see just how pretty the lights are**Overall its a great product and I am happy I got it for review. *sample provided*

My favoritesThe perfect set, cant get over how much I like these.I really like the ones with different compartments they provide just the perfect amount of space for different portioned foods, if you are someone who freezes meals for later these are amazing and just like having a tv dinner only with better food lol.
