While there are some gory details shared about the murders, the author gets into your head and touches on those deep, dark places that scare you.The story is excellent and keeps you on the edge of your seat with each turn of the page. Once I got about 3% into the book, I couldn't put it down and even stayed up much later than I should have to finish it! As I said, the author gets into your head, touches on those things that we fear and holds you captive with each page. I've no idea if the third book will pick up where this book ended, or if books one and two will be tied in together; but we were given a warning at the end of this book, "Protect the boy".  Does that mean they have to find the missing child in order to stop this?  There is one other avenue the warning could lead us down; Martin had a friend and even though we were never given intimate details about their relationship, is it possible that she is carrying his child and that's what was being referenced? I guess we'll find out in book three.If you love Gothic horror you won't be disappointed with Earthed.  Just don't read it in the dark....Please find this complete review and many others at bookie-monster [dot] com[If this review helped, please press YES. Thanks!]

This was a very well written book, plot and character development moved seamlessly. There were connections between the reader and characters with each page. Once  you begin reading this book, you will not be able to put it down.A beautiful family preparing to celebrate Easter and their lives together find themselves caught up in the end of the world - blinding lights, explosions, chaos and mayhem are their world now. Gone are the days of laughter and the luxury of simply being together. Their lives become one of struggle and fear. What was to be their trip to Devil's Dyke for fun becomes their destination for a safe haven and a chance to be reunited as a family.Robert McEwan is patiently watching the clock: "Thirty more minutes to wait before he could head home to his wife and son, and relax, knowing that the Easter weekend was upon them."  The connection with Robert begins early on - how many of us have watched our clocks waiting for Friday at 5 PM to come around?The beginning of the end becomes apparent as Robert sees the pandemonium below from his office window. He is  unable to reach his wife and struggles to exit the building to find his way home from downtown London. Upon reaching his mother-in-laws house, Robert learns that his mother-in-law sent his wife and child packing, so she could embrace the end.  Robert also discovers that he has become the target of a 6-foot tall creature who hunts him down every step of the way until one of them takes their last breath. Fox, a dog that joins Robert, seems to have the ability to sense creatures and protect those around him.His wife and child, Emma and Steven, decide to meet Robert at Devil's Dyke - their common get away place - far from downtown London, the chaos, and most importantly from the creatures.  Their travels by foot take them to a number of locations where they meet up with folks who have not yet lost their humanity.  Their journey to the Devil's Dyke is filled with fear and desperation. Kyle, a young man with his own demons makes Emma and Steven his mission.  He vows to protect them. Problem is, he has never been successful at protecting anyone ... until now.At the end of the book, Robert meets the tall, vengeance-seeking creature, and squares off in a battle one can only surmise that Robert will lose. He's exhausted and knows that his wife and son are just up the hill, but will the Euthonal in his pocket help him? Marik's borrowing from Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet is well done!  I caught my self saying out loud, "No!"What one may assume is a zombie book at times, there is no doubt that these are not mindless zombies but actively thinking creatures driven with animal rage attacking and eating everything in sight.  The creatures are vicious, eating and ripping flesh, strong beyond a doubt, and able to toss bodies as if they are rag dolls. One is left to ponder their existence - are they humans possessed by aliens? Smart zombies? Or ...?Often I found myself visualizing these creatures as the Aliens found in the Sigourney Weaver Alien series only to be jerked back to remembering these were once humans who have changed.This book will stay with you for days; it is not for the faint of heart.Please find this complete review and many others at bookie-monster [dot] com[If this review helped, please press YES. Thanks!]

I love this case. The matte finish gives it some grip and it doesn't slide off my clothes, which is a huge issue with most cases I've used.The outer shell fits snug around the soft layer and chevron grooves in the soft shell are accessible through cut outs in the outer shell, providing an additional grip.The cool thing about this case is something I've never seen before. Each corner has a bumper, and when impacting with a solid surface, they create a soft cushion to protect my phone.The volume and power buttons are easily accessible and the shell allows for accessories to plugin without any size issues.The case was easy to install.

Beyond the Dark, the final installment in Patrick D'Orazio's The Dark Trilogy, hits the nail directly on the head, so long as that nail was inserted directly into either your lower intestine, or possibly an ear.  The story starts a little past where we left our intrepid band of survivors, stacked like cordwood in a retiree's RV, on their way to a road trip along the highway to hell.  You're welcome for the earworm.  This installment centers on the survivors, our buddies, Jeff, Megan, George and Jason, and their new pals, a cut-throat business executive with delusions of grandeur and a new found S&M thing, his daddy-didn't-buy-me-a-pony-so-f-you-world girlfriend, a redneck, some teenagers, a wise ol' grandma, a giant with a heart of gold and some sure to need a sh*tload of therapy kids, and their escape from their former sanctuary, now deathtrap.The survivors flight is as tense as can be written.  As Jeff and some others risk themselves to try and keep the group safe, one can only pucker as something as simple as rounding a corner becomes cringe-worthy.  As the book goes on, the group is whittled down, both by human and zombie.  Some of these final confrontations are heart-wrenchingly, soul-crushingly, painful.  One was just so clich that I could not have cared less.  D'Orazio's description of a couple of particular deaths were so gut-wrenching that I damned near put the book down, cried and then damned near vomited on my shoes.  That was just about my "say when" moment.  Alas, I had to know what happened to everyone, so see where their travels took them.Needless to say, I continued on and finished the journey.  Now, I almost wished that I had put it down.  Our story ends with the future uncertain for most of our crew, without any real iota of hope.  Okay, maybe one, in that some people aren't dead yet.  Or should I say, YET!  Remember, our survivors have been together only a few days by t his point, how much can one take? .  Yes, I like my books to end with at least the chance of a happy ending.  D'Orazio seems to have eaten at the Martin/King table, which is in a restaurant that does not have an umbrella stand at the door, instead it has a trash barrel for your humanity.  And then you hit the epilogue.  You root for the good guys, and then they smile and get eaten.  With that in mind, the fact that I had such a reaction to the ending shows that I engaged with the characters, at least some of them, quite well and thoroughly.One of my biggest complaints throughout the series is that the characters seemed a bit thin and the books a bit short.  I did not like the coda style character stories after the fact.  I felt and still feel, that some of their ideas should have been incorporated into the main body of the story itself, that way you gave a hoot as to what was happening to the characters as it happened, rather than looking back and saying, "Oh, now I get it."Overall, I found Beyond the Dark, and the entire Dark Trilogy, quick, afternoon reads that were entertaining and engaging.  I would like to see something a bit more concrete and feel that maybe another few volumes are in order, since we still don't know WTF is screaming!  God I hate unanswered questions.Please find this complete review and many others at bookie-monster [dot] com[If this review helped, please press YES. Thanks!]

Red Tides, the second book in Mikhail Lerma's Z Plan Series, picks up right where the first book left off.We find our main character, Cale, being "rescued" (if you wanna call it that) by what's left of the Egyptian Navy.  Cale is taken aboard their submarine rather than left for dead in the middle of the sea, and he soon becomes sort of "enlisted" with them....which basically means that he's forced into making scavenger runs for them because his captors are too afraid to do it themselves.  Bound by chains to a fellow captor by the name of Naeem, the beginning of Red Tides follows these two in their troubles as they fight the dead on their forced scavenging trips and manage to escape at the last moment when things take a turn for the worst.I found that Lerma's decision to pair our main character with someone that spoke absolutely no English was very interesting.  Cale and his companion Naeem have no trouble communicating using everything but words.  In the apocalypse, survival is a universal language and Lerma does this well, never over-complicating the communication between the American and the African.After the two part ways, Cale continues his journey, through France this time, on a quest to return to America and make it home to his wife, Lauren, and their daughter, Marie.  A huge part of Cale's driving force is not only getting home to Lauren and Marie, but the constant reminder that his best friend Zach is dead, and Cale still blames himself for it.  It also doesn't help Cale out that Zach has now become sort of a "ghost" and appears from time to time to keep Cale company or give him some sh*t.  Zach's appearance is more of a manifestation from Cale's ever increasing mental instability than a ghost, but I like to pretend that Cale isn't crazy.What Lerma does with the second book that I really enjoyed was switching perspectives between Cale and his wife.  We jump from time to time from Cale's adventures across the world to Lauren's experiences State Side.  Lauren has managed to survive, holding on, day by day and pushing forward; unwilling to let go of her husband and somewhere deep inside, she knows he's coming back to her.  She's with a whole "colony" and together they all work together to make it in the apocalypse.  There are dangers lurking for Lauren, and I'm not just talking about the undead.  Without giving away any important plot points, let's just say I was extremely satisfied when those dangers were laid to rest...All in all, Red Tides was a fantastic follow up to the first novel, which I absolutely loved!  I'm always nervous when I read follow up novels to books that I adored because they've really gotta prove themselves to me, but Lerma has done it again with Red Tides; a non-stop zombie adventure that any horror fan will enjoy.Please find this complete review and many others at bookie-monster [dot] com[If this review helped, please press YES. Thanks!]

Adrian's back, and he's pissed! Hell hath no fury like a trinity scorned.The Trinity is the seventh book in Chris Philbrook's Adrian's Undead Diary series. With this being the second to last installment in the saga, Philbrook takes some time to slow down and let readers smell the roses...or is it the decay?Like with any sequel, there may be spoilers from the previous books, so if you haven't read them, you may consider stopping here.This one's a bit different than the others. A traumatic injury puts Adrian out of commission for a good chunk of the book and the spitfire, Abby, picks up his journaling slack. I like Abby; she's one of my favorite characters in the series. Though, at times, she may be written a bit mature for her age in both thought process and the manner in which she speaks. But since I'm completely invested in the AUD series, it's a small incongruous tidbit I can easily overlook.One of the reasons I hold this series is such high esteem is its realistic writing style. When Adrian writes in Mr. Journal, I believe him. There's no question, at least in this reviewers opinion, that every line from Adrian rings true. (See what I did there?)Evaluating the complete saga to date, The Trinity is my least favorite. But that should really be put into context...I still enjoyed the read, but some others have resonated more with me. If I had to analyze why, I think it would be a culmination of things. Not enough Adrian-let's face it, he steals the spotlight. And the action was minimal. The Trinity was more reflective, almost setting the tone for the grand finale. Which we really do need, but my personal tastes steer more toward the chaotic frenzy of undead.That said, The Trinity has left me dying to get to the end. And I just know once I get there, I'll go into withdrawal.

What do you get when you mix a couple hackers, a baby, a zombie overlord with no bowel control, a cheese-sandwich loving dog, and an autistic giant of man with a thing for boobies? Zombie Slaver...the fourth book in the Zombie Botnet series.The tone of this series continues to be following the trend of the third book. Less humor, but when added, it makes a big splash. Alfred, the new mayor of zombie-ville, reminds me of a functioning alcoholic. He's maintained a semblance of humanity but has some slip-ups. And I'm not just talking the inability to hold his bodily functions in...let's just say he has to change his pants quite often. Do zombies do laundry? Something to think about...Zombie Slaver introduces the 'hive mind' of the hordes, and Alfred is the one pulling the strings. We're only two weeks into the epidemic. Ven has really let herself go but manages to pulls herself together.The group finds a fairgrounds where the food and drink is still flowing, the rides are still operating, and the carnies are still swindling visitors. Al finds himself a buxom love interest, which could have gone terribly wrong, but instead provided the comedic relief in this installment. Watching Al become a lovesick puppy and swoon at some cleavage was more than entertaining.I love where the series is going with baby Tomas and can't wait to see how it continues! Keep em coming!

I bought Keep Your Crowbar Handy nearly a year ago, when it was a self-published title and before it was picked up by Permuted Press.Back then, I gave the book four stars, but I've got to hand it to Durnin and Permuted, they worked through the small issues I had with the book and the editing quality really improved.Keep Your Crowbar Handy is unique. It's zombies, for sure, but the characters are intriguing and unique. Do-good journalist, Jake is standing in line at the pharmacy with his elderly neighbor when a woman starts berating the employee attempting to help her. Jake steps in and gives the woman a verbal tongue-lashing in defense of the blue-haired Asian girl behind the counter. Kat sets him up with her roommate, Laurel, the Irish redhead, and it's love at first sight. Don't worry about Kat, though, the sexy vixen hooks up with Jake's daredevil best friend, Allen.Lucky for Jake, his ex-military landlord George is prepared for everything, including the zombie apocalypse! Durnin does a great job starting out with action right off the bat. The tension builds parallel to character development until the two meet in a clash.I also enjoyed the fact that there is no pussyfooting around. The character's first reaction to the chaos is 'zombies'. They don't question what is going on, or try to come up with any cockamamie excuses. So there is no time spent in denial.The first thing I did upon completing Keep Your Crowbar Handy was ask the author how long I had to wait until the next book. That, in my opinion, is the true testament to a good book. It engaged me enough to keep reading straight to the end and left me wanting to know what happens next. The characters are solid, the plot is well-structured and merely pushes at the boundaries of realism, making it just believable enough that the zompoc could really go down that way. Oh, and the zombies are plentiful.If you enjoy fun zombie fiction with just a hint of a military feel, and want an easy read, Keep Your Crowbar Handy is the book for you. 4.5 Stars from The Bookie Monster.Please find this complete review and many others at bookie-monster dot com[If this review helped, please press YES. Thanks!]

I bought these on a whim at the airport while waiting for my flight. A $150 purchase for earbuds was not a decision I came to lightly, but these are well worth the cost in my opinion.The Good:The sound quality is amazing. Truly. I sat in the store just plugging things into my phone and giving some heavy metal a good listen. These earbuds were hands down the best of the bunch.The packaging is great. Much more than I'd expect from such a small item. And in the package is a bunch of great accessories. (case, extender, buds, etc).Once these babies are in, there is no chance they're falling off.The Not So Good:I find it rather difficult to get them around and in my ears. It requires a bit of fancy fingerwork once I've got the lip over my ear to get the bud in my ear...I think this is because the bud is at an angle to fit into the ear canal.The only area I feel is not on par with the overall quality is the microphone/volume buttons on the cord. It is plastic and feels a bit chintzy. I use it sparingly for fear of breaking it with even the slightest touch.

I absolutely loved this peeler. It worked as expected and was easy to use. That it had both the julienne side and a regular peeler was a bonus and I had a blast making some great looking veggies. The peeler was easy to clean and great quality making it easy to give it a 5 stars rating.Though, it should be noted that the instructions and packaging were not in English. However, the product as easy enough to use without them.

The product was excellent. My cupcakes baked great, and with a bit of spray, the cupcake fell right out. The mold cooled down very fast and the molds were wonderfully easy clean up.My only issue was in the product packaging. I had to Google how to bake with silicone cupcake molds in order to discover that I was supposed to spray the molds before baking. Instructions should be included to clearly outline how to cook with, and clean up after, the molds
I picked this up before a flight, and it sucked me right in. Fredsti has come up with something inventive, fun, and unique.

Be careful of deals made with The Gentleman, as the terms are steep and binding.To say that James Greene is having a bad day, or let's clarify that to a bad year, is a bit of an understatement. A deal made with The Gentleman continues to haunt him. Literally. No matter where he tries to hide, it never seems far enough. What can a person do when everything that is attempted fails?This book drops you right in the middle of the main character trying to flee. Ever had those nightmares as a child where something is after you and your feet feel as if they're stuck in mud, and no matter how hard you try you can't get them to move fast enough? Welcome to The Gentleman. Where those nightmares are now real and the dawn of a new day is no longer your escape.You learn of James' past through snippets and memories. It's a mix of past and present that allows you to learn just enough of the character to understand some of his trauma, yet still leaves you wanting to turn the page to learn more. The writing is very good, the pace excellent and the attention to detail is evident.This was an excellent read and one that should be added to everyone's collection who enjoys a good bit of horror with their evening cup of tea.Review by Mona Markham for bookie-monster (dot) com

Atmosphere: 3 out of 5. There's not really much to say but it is there at times, usually amid brands and cigarette smoke.Characters: 3 out of 5. The characters are well-constructed. Where they do not necessarily have hidden depths of personality, their histories have layers enough to make up for it.Plot: 3 out of 5. The characters and story are well-integrated. No complaints on that account. The pacing is also good. The Phineas Priests and BFA are, however, hardly compelling villains. The story leaves things open for sequels without making the book feel incomplete.Writing Style: 3 out of 5. Some technical errors. Sometimes the paragraphs seem to be put together weirdly, usually when they're describing characters. Infodumps are usually handled well.Worldbuilding: Not applicable.Details, details: [here there be spoilers]The BFA want to improve their image so they insult people and call them sheep?As I mentioned above, the villains leave a lot to be desired. They're... "safe" villains, I suppose, the kind that hold together every bad thing that you can be sure will get a jeer from your readers. They're just the regular baddies, here to say mean things and do bad things.They don't necessarily do this badly, so to speak, but I feel that the author is capable of handling villains of greater complexity, even villains that could make us wonder, if only for a few minutes, just how wrong they actually are, and so I feel a great loss on account of what-could-have-been.Perhaps in the sequels.I would buy the ebook, perhaps, but not the hardcopy.

The action and adventure continues in Stephen A.  North's Dead Tide Rising, the follow up to the first book in the Dead Tide series.  The book begins at the beginning of the zom-pocalypse with the addition of yet another character, Dead Eye Johnny, and we are then hurled head first back into the continuing saga of the first book as the undead rip through the Tampa Bay area.Again, as with the first novel, it's definitely a fun read.  I love the blood and guts, the storytelling is adventurous and risky, and there is plenty of zombie action and death scenes to go 'round.  But just like the first novel, the follow up was just as confusing.  In addition to the already overwhelming number of character view points, North has added the president of The United States, Dead Eye Johnny the cart pusher, the president's wife, and so on and so forth.  I can only say so on and so forth, because after now reading two of North's books in the same series (nearly back to back) I can barely recall all of the characters' names and I couldn't begin to tell you anything other than their occupation.My favorite kind of story is one in which I can identify or relate with at least one of the characters.  I truly enjoy and have the ability to immerse myself into a book  in which I genuinely care about someone in it.  Unfortunately that is not the case in Dead Tide Rising.  For however much I enjoyed the content of the book, I never truly found myself ever caring about the characters and I found that if any one of them were killed off and the third book in the series has an entirely new cast of characters, I would be fine with it.  I never truly got to the point in which I wanted to see any of these peoples' stories played out, and again, as with the first book, I never found that "hook, line, and sinker" protagonist that made me root for them in any way.I'm not bashing North's books by any means, if that were the case I wouldn't have finished them.  In fact, I still have the desire to read the next book in the series.  I just wish there weren't as many characters, or that at least the characters were defined by something more than their name.Another quick thing to point out if you're planning on reading this zombie adventure, is that there is quite a bit of sexual tension between everyone all of the time, and rape tends to gets brought up quite a bit.  Something that just didn't seem to fit well with the story was the fact that during the end of the world, everyone seems to want to have sex with everyone that they meet, at all times.All in all, Dead Tide Rising entertains.  It's not a book that bores you and it's definitely a book you'll be able to finish and enjoy.  Again, North creates dialogue that is believable and genuine, something that matters a great deal to me when reading a book in any genre.  I think this is another great addition to any zombie lovers collection.  Just don't expect to remember the differences between different people unless you're really good with names.

This isn't your typical tale of a "psychic detective".  George is the real deal.  He isn't in it to solve the crime, but to help the spirit that is trapped in a plane of existence and needs to move forward.  Erin is his partner.  It seems that most of the time she ends up running interference for him because he's gone into a meditative state and if someone were to try to rouse him from that state too quickly he could suffer severe physical and mental repercussions.For the most part I liked this book.  The story was solid, the characters pretty well fleshed out.  There were a few references of either George or Erin's past that sort of left me scratching my head because were weren't really given any information on that.  Erin says at one point that she has "abandonment issues"... well, did her father leave her as a young child... is it just bad experiences with boyfriends... the reader doesn't really know.  I felt the characters could have been made a little more three-dimensional. at parts they really did fall flat.  But, as I said, the story was solid.  There's a mystery surrounding a murder.  It seems that no one is really interested in solving the murder and bringing the murderer to justice, because they all felt the victim deserved it.  He was a monster; a drug dealer, a child molester, and an all around nasty guy if you got on his wrong side.  And the victim's mother has the town wrapped around her fingers, so just about everything he's ever done has been brushed under the rug and forgotten (legally anyway... his victim is never forgotten).George deals with the local police, but his goal is to help this soul move on to where he is supposed to be, not solve the crime and catch the killer.  There are a lot of secrets in this town.  This murder has the capability of bringing a lot of people to ruin if all those secrets were to get out.  So obviously, the police aren't really pursuing it as they should.Near the end of the book there is a conversation between George and a police detective working the case involving what it is that George really does and how it all works.  While I do find it interesting, it felt more like a school lesson than a story that I was reading for enjoyment.  Thankfully that was near the end and it was only one chapter, so I pushed on through to the end.  Aside from that, my only issue was the amount of drug use... ok, so they smoked some hash, some weed, some things that were unknown to me and at one point Erin did snort some pure ecstasy.  But it seems like everyone within their circle did it (not the ecstasy, but the smoking).  Now, trust me, I don't judge... personally it's not for me and I've never really enjoyed books where the drug use was tolerated.  But those are the only things I can point out that I didn't enjoy about the story.Overall, this was an interesting book with a solid story and likeable characters.  I did actually learn a few things and didn't even realize it until I was done and telling my husband about it!  That's always a good thing when the author can educate a reader about a subject but not have it feel like it's just been a lesson (except for that one chapter).  It's a relatively quick read, the story is not really heavy--great if you have a few hours to fill with reading. 3.5

If you are a Stephen King Constant Reader, sit back and enjoy or, if you are new to the King phenomenon, this is a great volume with which to get acquainted.  "The Bazaar Of Bad Dreams" is a compelling compendium of 18 short stories and two poems , some old and revised, some new,  ranging from 10 pages to 50 pages each.Some have a supernatural influence while most portray horrors associated with real life rather than ghosts, aliens, and monsters.  This seems to bother some of the reviewers but in reality, King has broadened his genre considerably over the past two decades.  The offerings are somewhat connected by King's comments on when or why he wrote each story and by related themes of death, afterlife, guilt, and remorse.King never shrinks from utilizing the English language as attested by some of his monumental tomes and continuing series.  Yet he is equally renowned for his ability to write shorter concise and gripping stories as seen in his various collections of short stories and novellas over the years, many of which became screenplays.Caveat:  if you read and absorb everything King as I do, you will encounter tales in this collection that you have encountered before in one form or another--such is the nature of collected short story volumes.  But each has been revised and updated where appropriate.  Having enjoyed King's tales of haunted cars, such as "Christine" and "From A Buick 8", I especially enjoyed  "Mile 81" which should make any driver rethink stopping at a rest stop along any public roadway.  "Afterlife" presents a thought provoking choice that newly departed spirits must make.  And "Obits" is a fascinating tale of horror that while not new, is imminently re-readable.If you have read King's works over the past decades and matured in life as his legacy continued to grow, you should enjoy and appreciate this new collection; indeed, the new material makes the volume worthwhile to me regardless of whether I have previously read some of the stories.  I am only rating it with four stars as I selfishly would have liked to see a few more original offerings.

The "HP Officejet 3830 Wireless Color Photo Printer with Scanner and Copier" competently fulfills the two needs that motivated me to acquire it;  It prints wirelessly and, it prints from both my iPad and iPhone (as well as my laptops).  My desktop is linked to a high end Canon printer so I wanted this "HP" for quick and convenient printing to my mobile devices.  This all-in-one unit (fax, print, scan, copy) has impressed me with its ability to meet these simple expectations.  I would recommend it for a college student, home, or low volume use office. HP only recommends it to produce 100 to 250 copies monthly.The "HP Officejet 3830 Wireless Color Photo Printer with Scanner and Copier" is an all-in-one ink jet printer and I quickly state that I was surprised with how much more efficient and efficacious ink jet printers are now compared to pre-laser color printer days.  I find it much better for document reproductions than photo or intricate color copies.  It comes with one black and one color cartridge and pesters you to join its ink subscription service that "monitors" your ink usage and sends you replacement cartridges as needed.  It does not come with a USB cable for direct connection so you would have to provide your own if you want to go that route. It does come with a quick start guide but a detailed user's manual has to obtained from the HP website.  The software for the scanner is available for download at "iTunes".The unit was easy to set up and easily linked with my home wifi system.  A walk-you-through-it CD is provided for easy set up, although each mobile unit needs to be individually installed.  The 2.2 touch display is clear and responsive.  HP suggests that printing time is "up to 8.5 ppm for black and 6 ppm for color", so again, this unit is intended for light home or dorm room or office use.  Colors are close reproductions but not exact and the paper tray is a low capacity 30 pages.  As with everything we buy, know your needs, set your expectations, and buy this unit with confidence if it meshes with what you are looking for.

In his new novel, "Orphan X", Gregg Hurwitz introduces a character that rivals Jack Reacher and other well trained individualists and vigilantes who remain off the grid while helping others who seek relief or justice.  The Nowhere Man as he is called uses the name Evan Smoak and his skills bring to mind Jack Reacher,Jason Bourne, and Liam Neeson in the "Taken" series.  He was recruited as a 12 year old orphan by a handler named Jack Johns to become a future black ops government assassin after years of training in martial arts, weapons, surveillance, and avoiding detection; indeed, he grows up to become a deadly assassin who lives off the grid, having no backstory and no entangling relationships.Sadly, this means he also has no one to turn to when his handler is eliminated and he decides to disappear from the Orphan Project and begin righting wrongs of his own choice.  His protocol is to help someone in desperate need for his services and then admonishing that person to give his number to only ONE person someday who may also be in desperate need.  Consequently, Evan is rocked when less than a week after helping Morena escape the clutches of a despicable police officer, he receives calls from TWO people claiming to be in desperate need of his help and claiming Morena as their reference.  Which one is telling the truth, or are both telling the truth, or both lying--and, more importantly, why?"Orphan X" starts strongly and becomes a gripping can't-put-down book by the end of Chapter one.  It is well plotted, suspenseful, and filled with intrigue and violence as someone as shadowy as the Nowhere Man begins a cat and mouse pursuit that will culminate in a heart stopping page turner ending filled with tension and surprises.  Clearly, Hurwitz has created a character with a popular future should he continue the series.Hurwitz capably builds Evan's character as he matures from bewildered orphan into deadly assassin and I found Evan's personal growth as a man to be as compelling as his growth toward assassin.  As "Orphan X" unfolds, we see Evan balancing his loneliness and training with an inner need to belong, to have an emotional anchor with others, to feel love and a sense of belonging.  Hurwitz employs a mix of neighbors, some old and nosy, some attractive and supportive, a hero worshiping child, etc. to reveal Evan's emotional growth through interpersonal interactions.I am a great fan of the loner-who helps-those in-need sug genre of action/suspense thrillers and I enjoyed this novel immensely and do hope it becomes Hurwitz's signature recurring series.  I unequivocally recommend it to those who equally enjoy this genre of escapist literature.

John Connolly is one of the elite story tellers and thriller writers in literature today. His work with the Charlie Parker novels reflects great plotting, deep intense characterizations, flawed heroes, psychological entanglements and moral complexities, and often, a tasting of the paranormal, if not, supernatural. Connolly is much more than a pulp writer hurrying to produce several novels every year. Instead, he is a master wordsmith, an intelligent manipulator of prose and language designed to affect the reader's sensitivities both in context and in presentation; indeed, I often find myself rereading a paragraph or a description of a place or person that is so lyrical as to demand a second reading. Connolly is a master at creating a sense of forboding or a palpable feel of evil with only a few well chosen words. He is a master at creating forbidding locations and evil incarnate. His dialogue is usually spot-on and often times humorous, especially when Charlie Parker, Angel, and Louis are interacting and one-upping. Connolly's plots within the Charlie Parker series are tightly woven and filled with enough characters and red herrings to keep most diehard readers guessing until the end.In "A Song Of Shadows", Connolly develops a plot contrasting a battle between good and evil that has its roots in the Nazi concentration camps of WWII.  Parker is slowly recovering from his near fatal wounds from "The Wolf In Winter" in the small town of Boreas, Maine when he meets an enigmatic woman named Ruth Winter and her young daughter, Amanda.  Soon he is consulting on a case of a body that has washed up on a nearby beach and is equally intrigued by a family massacre, and a missing suspected killer--all of which may be interrelated and which leads inevitably into a morass of evil that began with a hideous plot of murder and thievery in a specialized Nazi concentration camp called Lubsko.Who among the inhabitants of small town Boreas is actually somehow related to the horrors of Nazi concentration camps and who protects them?  What other evils from Parker's past are active in Boreas?  Can the veteran Nazi hunters truly be trusted?  Parker, with the help of Angel, Louis, and other old allies including, surprisingly, his young daughter, Sam, begin linking recent events to past atrocities leading to an attempt to assassinate Parker.  Now in a race against the clock, with his life in jeopardy and confronting the ire of local police, Parker methodically seeks the answers that will lead to the closure of all the loose ends surrounding the deaths in Boreas.It is to Connolly's credit that the Charlie Parker tales, while often tinged with touches of the supernatural, are still enjoyable for the character development, suspense and thrills, and ultimately, for the ongoing struggle of good versus evil.  I unequivocally recommend this entire series to anyone who enjoys suspense thrillers with a touch of the paranormal/supernatural.

Although I have collected watches most of my life, the "Invicta Men's 21480 Pro Diver Analog Display Swiss Quartz Grey Watch" was my first experience with an Invicta product outside of their seemingly endless televised sales promos.  I have been pleasantly impressed by the workmanship, quality, and appearance of this timepiece.As stated in the title, this watch is a pro diver model purported to be water resistant up to 330 feet.  It is a stainless steel Swiss Quartz analog presented in gunmetal grey with silver tones and white hands and hour markers.  About 30 % of the bezel is in a light green tone that compliments the basic grey tones.  The band is a stylish grey made of calfskin and seems very adaptable to any wrist size.This wristwatch has 3 sub dials including 24 hour, day-of-the-week, and date, and noticeably, they blend in nicely without looking overly garish or crowded.  This Invicta also contains a tachymeter tool for measuring speed in MPH as extrapolated from elapsed time.  It includes a one year warranty.Be aware that as is the case with most Invicta watches, the "Invicta Men's 21480 Pro Diver Analog Display" is a very large timepiece.  The case is 48mm in diameter which will completely fill the wrists of many men.  Additionally, it is 13 mm thick and weighs nearly 13.6 ounces.  Although a large watch, it is not unusually so for a pro diver watch or compared to many of today's larger timepieces.  I am enjoying this Invicta as a casual everyday watch and so far I am pleased with both its quality and time keeping ability.

"The Killing Season" is a debut action/thriller novel from Mason Cross featuring a new series character, Carter Blake, a loner who specializes in finding people who don't want to be found.  Some are comparing Carter Blake to Jack Reacher and while there are similarities, there are also clear differences; indeed, suffice it to say that fans of Lee Child's Jack Reacher series should welcome Carter Blake to the same genre.Carter has little backstory to this point as he is called upon to join an FBI task force searching for Caleb Wardell, "the Chicago Sniper", who has escaped jail and is planning to continue his deadly serial killing.  Of course, being an outsider without law enforcement credentials makes him an unwelcome addition except for Elaine Banner, an ambitious Special Agent, more willing to trust Blake as things unfold than just following "the book".Carter employs "tricks of the trade", an insightful intuition, and just focused people skills to track and/or predict where Wardell may strike next as he hopscotches around the country.  For his part, Wardell, despite being a depraved serial killer without a conscience, is intelligent enough to engage in a cat and mouse pursuit with Blake and Banner as he begins executing his evil plan.  But who is the behind-the-scenes accomplice of this stone-cold killer and what is his/her motive?  Soon Blake is not sure who to trust as he and Banner are ordered off the chase.  And who is Wardell's ultimate target and why?  These questions are all answered in a pulse pounding conclusion that will have readers stopping to catch their breath."The Killing Season" is well written and executed for a debut novel and the Carter Blake character has great promise to develop a wide following of fans of the action/thriller suspense genre.  And similar to the Jack Reacher series, a conflict inevitably arises spotlighting the bureaucratic "by the book" form of justice and the "no holds barred" form of street justice--often highlighting how modern rules of engagement and judicial restraints leave some criminals "untouchable" until a loner who doesn't play by all the rules appears to exact justice of a different kind.  I greatly enjoyed this debut novel and I can recommend it and the planned series to fans of action thrillers.

"The Promise" is Robert Crais's latest Elvis Cole/Joe Pike thriller and Crais surprises the reader by bringing in their black ops mercenary friend, Jon Stone and LAPD K-9 officer, Scott James and his dog, Maggie (see "Suspect" by Crais).  With all his signature characters in one novel--it better be a good one.  And it is!  It a little slow getting off the ground, due in part to introduce so many characters, and then it takes off on a wild white knuckle ride to an intense but satisfying conclusion."The Promise" is generally about the strengths of promises, loyalties, and commitments to justice and to one another.  Elvis is hired by an aggressive woman who wants him to find a grieving mother, Amy Breslyn, whose son was killed by terrorists in Nigeria.  Amy may or may not have embezzled a large sum of money from her firm and may or may not now be trying to sell explosives to Al Qaeda.  If so, what is her goal, and why?  Before Elvis can even really get rolling, he is peripherally involved in a search for an escaped killer that somehow makes him a subject or suspect of intense interest by the LAPD and Homeland Security.  Also, it brings him, Scott, and Maggie into the same case.Soon, Elvis, Joe Pike, and Jon Stone realize they are in a case filled with lies and liars.  Few of the players are really who they seem to be--and what are their true motivations.  Who can really be trusted outside of Elvis and his friends?  And why has Scott and his dog, Maggie, been subject to assassination attempts?  Elvis and his pals team up with a reluctant Scott James as they discover the attempts to kill Scott emanate from the crossover of the cases they have been individually working.  Remember this--no one should ever try to kill an LAPD officer NOR his dog, especially a rehabilitated ex-marine dog who is instantly accepted by war vets, Elvis, Joe, and Jon.As usual, Crais has written a tight but complicated plot which makes this as much of a mystery novel as it is a thriller.  The dialogue is terse and credible but first time readers may be at a bit of a loss regarding the main characters'  back story since Crais moves rather quickly in this one at the expense of characterization, instead, relying on the reader's familiarity with Cole, Pike, and the others to facilitate and move the plot along.  I never miss a Cole and Pike novel and once you get into the series, I doubt you will either.

The "BLACK+DECKER PureOptics Summit Zoom Magnifier 5.5W Flicker-Free Natural Daylight LED Desk Lamp" is a great resource for hobbyists and professionals who work with tiny or detailed items such as stamp and coin collectors, fishing fly makers, jewelers, model makers, crafters, etc.  The unit utilizes LED lights to simulate soft natural daylight to lessen eye strain and is advertised as glare free and shadow free.It features an "Easy One Touch Control" that opens the lamp to the same brightness level it was on before shutting off; subsequently, users can then hold down the power button to scroll through all 5 brightness levels.  This magnifying desk lamp/task light sports a 5" 5 X optical grade glass magnifier to allow very close work with a wide magnified field.  It also features a USB power/charging port in the base that works whether the light is turned on or not.My only significant caveat to the casual buyer is the utter size of the unit and its lack of flexibility.  It is almost 3 feet tall when fully extended as it has two 16" sections connected by hinges to each other and to the lamp/magnifier.  Its footprint is large for an office desk at 6.5" by 9" and it weighs 12 pounds which certainly provides stability but limits maneuverability.  Once assembled, this magnifier desk lamp is really flexible in only one up/down direction unless the base is physically moved or swiveled into a new direction since it cannot be rotated from left to right.  Due to its size, I speculate it would be optimally useful in a dedicated work desk area or in a workshop.  But anyone requiring a lighted magnifier for close up work would be happy with this unit as long as its restrictions were not a deal killer.

The "Bose SoundTouch 20 Series III Wireless Music System" is a classy looking and audio pleasing addition to the Bose Audio product line.  I am in no way an audiophile--just a consumer who enjoys crisp clear sound without a lot of setup or matching systems etc.  I have owned a Bose Wave machine for years, have enjoyed it immensely, and find this new sound streamer to be a very compatible product in sound quality and ease of use.Simply put, the "Bose SoundTouch 20 Series III Wireless Music System" is a music streamer designed to link or access most modern music playing devices--computers, tablets, smart phones,internet services, etc.  It is featured as a wireless system that can link to your WiFi home system or bluetooth; indeed, it also sports an aux input which allows for plugging in devices directly.  Normally, it is tethered only by a power cord and at 7 pounds, it can easily be moved around a home or office.  Its dimensions reflect its small footprint--17" wide, 9.5" tall, and 7.25" deep. It comes with a power cord, a USB cable, and a remote.  Regrettably, it does not support earphone usage nor does it have an AM/FM tuner or an equalizer.The unit works in concert with the SmartTouch app designed for smartphones and tablets.  Set up is relatively easy as you link your phone or tablet to the device and then, with the SmartTouch app operating, complete the electronic link between the device, the app, and your smartphone (tablet) by synching with your local WiFi signal.  Now you can link or synch to any bluetooth sound device.On a front panel, a OLED displays the artist, track, album information, if known.  The remote is typically Bose in that it is simple, uncomplicated, and, while effective, you wish it did more.  Significantly, there are 6 presets that can be linked to music services (Pandora, iTunes, etc,), internet radio, or your personal music library on a computer or storage device.  This gives users one touch access to the source but maneuverability within the source is left to the app on your device or to the remote.As mentioned earlier, the sound quality is crisp and clear for me and can easily fill a large room with satisfying sound.  Initially the bass was a little too heavy for my liking but the app does offer a "tuner" for bass control in absence of a legitimate equalizer.  I am enjoying my Bose music streaming system and recommend it to non-audiophiles who don't mind speakers contained within a unit rather than strategically placed several feet apart.

Fans of the Nathan McBride adventure series by Andrew Peterson should be excited and pleased with "Contract To Kill", the fifth in the series.  It is perhaps not the best place for new readers to get on board as too many former characters with little back story are presented in this fast paced white knuckler,Toby Haynes, a friend of Nathan's, witnesses what appear to be cold blooded murders by his boss, Tanner Mason, head of security for a large Private Military Contractor (PMC) organization dedicated to eliminating drug and gun trafficking along the Mexican border and seriously destroying the deadly Mexican Cartels.  Toby shares his experience with Nathan McBride and his partner, Harvey Fontana, who are veteran CIA special operatives now running their own security company.  Soon, Nathan and Harv find themselves neck deep in a world wide conspiracy that includes North and South Korea, the U.S., and Mexico.Teaming up with a former series character, FBI agent, Mary Grangeland, Nathan and Harv must thwart a potentially devastating smuggling conspiracy involving the Koreas and Mexico but also must contend with perhaps the most deadly and dangerous foe Nathan has faced so far--a mirror image of himself in planning and execution.  This all builds to a suspense filled conclusion that fills the last 90 pages of the book as the Koreans, the Mexican Cartel, Nathan's team, and Tanner Mason's crew all descend on an abandoned quarry where each step and counter step is recorded and monitored in cat and mouse fashion until the somewhat surprising final violent confrontation.As mentioned earlier, there are appearances by a number of series regular characters but with the action so fast paced, there is not a lot of new characterization, although long time readers will recognize the philosophy and personal choices Nathan and Harvey make as they seek their own brand of justice.  There is also a sub plot involving Nathan and his girlfriend, Holly, who has been promoted to a major role in government inter agency planning that puts her at the ear of Nathan's father, Stone.  I strongly recommend this book and the entire series to interested readers.

Surely, someone somewhere thought of using baby wipes to clean and freshen their dogs' coats-but it wasn't me, doggonit.  The "Pogi's Grooming Wipes - 100 Unscented Wipes - All Natural, Extra Large, Earth-Friendly" are a clever and useful product to clean and condition your dog's coat.  They are all natural and earth friendly in that they contain no alcohol or irritating chemicals and instead, are based on the bamboo plant, along with Aloe Vera and Vitamin E.  They are considered earth friendly in that break down within weeks so as not to clog drains, landfills,  etc.  They are certainly generous in size (8" by 9") and sturdy enough to remain moist after using on two small short-haired dogs.The Pogi's Wipes appear very similar to baby wipes, only larger and neutral in odor.  They are packaged in hundred wipe bundles with a resealable opening.  They are also advertised as being hypoallergenic due to the absence of harsh chemicals and irritants.  After using the wipes on my two 25 pound schnauzers, I feel safe in saying that they seem to live up to the marketing hype.  They are basically odorless and as I said earlier, one wipe allows me to wipe down both of my dogs and still remain moist enough to use again.  Neither dog seemed irritated or agitated by the wipe or any potential residue (I have experienced no residue at all so far).  After wiping down each dog, I noticed a clean smell and a smooth looking coat; however, I have not yet been required to use them with a muddy or very dirty dog.  After using this product twice so far, I can recommend Pogi's Wipes based on my experience.

The "Health o meter nuyu Water Resistant Activity Tracker with Bluetooth 4.0 Technology and Long Lasting Battery" is an acceptable entry level activity monitor when one considers the price point against the efficacy of the device.  I had hoped this monitor would replace my stolen Fitbit but was disappointed in some ways and pleased in others.  To be effective, this activity monitor needs to be paired with the nuyu smartphone app in order to track and monitor your daily activities;  steps, caloric usage, distance traveled, and sleep patterns.It has a sporty enough appearance although the rubberized band does not give me hope for its long term durability.  It can be worn either on a wrist band or attached to a magnetized waist clip and is touted as waterproof.  It sports an OLED touchscreen display that while clear enough in display mode can be a bit difficult and troublesome to maneuver and it employs Bluetooth 4 for connectivity.  The monitor predicts a 4 month battery life although syncing often to the smart device app will definitely shorten that lifespan.I found the nuyu Activity Monitor to be less effective than I anticipated.  The touch screen is annoyingly inconsistent and the accuracy of steps and distance taken was also irritating as they were sometimes 25% off from known route distances assessed with other devices and pedometers.  BTW, this unit has no GPS on board so it is really a fancy pedometer and not a particularly accurate one at that.  I have not explored the sleep aspect of the monitor as yet.Also worthy of mention is the truly invasive privacy policy of nuyu that must be accepted before using.  It is so encompassing and intrusive as to be truly scary and off-putting.  By agreeing, the user allots permission to the company to access your photos and files, to use your real name, address, email address, and photos without any further permission or any compensation if ever used i publications etc.  Wow!When assessing the efficacy of electronic devices such as the nuyu Activity Monitor, I usually measure three things:  ease of use, quality, and accuracy.  While I have discussed quibbles above about each of these three elements, all in all, the nuyu would be an acceptable entry level  monitor for a first time user wishing to match price to effectiveness.

The "AmazonBasics Apple Certified Lightning to USB Cable - 6 Feet (1.8 Meters) - White" is recommended as an improvement over the standard supplied Apple cable.  I find it to be stronger and more durable than the standard cable; indeed, Amazon states that it is tested 4000 times with a 95 degree bend.  It feels more heavy duty with stronger, enhanced connectors that should protect the cable from coming apart at the connections.It is Apple MFi certified and charges and syncs all Apple devices that accept lightning connectors.  I especially appreciate the 6 foot length as there are multiple times when I need a little more length than the 3.5 to 4 foot cords.  The slightly larger lightning connector fit all my devices and Apple cases perfectly but if you have a very narrow connector space in your case, you might want to check the fit before buying (if possible).  I strongly recommend this cable for those seeking a replacement or a longer alternative to the standard Apple supplied cable.

For me, the "Philips Sonicare HealthyWhite Plus Rechargeable Toothbrush" is a definite winner.  Many years ago, I tried an electric toothbrush but quickly discontinued it due to its cumbersome size, noise, and inadequate cleaning.  I returned to using a manual toothbrush until I received this Philips Sonicare.  I truly love it so far.It is slim, lightweight, and easy to maneuver in one's mouth--all the facets that were a concern to me in my previous attempt to usse an electric toothbrush.  The vibrations of the unit, calculated at over 31,000 brush strokes per minute by the manufacturer, make my teeth and, more importantly, my gums feel cleaner and healthier.  Having once had gum surgery, that is a very important aspect of the Sonicare.The product claims that it removes up to 100% more stains and that it removes 7 times more plaque than a standard toothbrush.  It has a clean and a white mode ostensibly for different purposes.  The clean mode is for a normal brushing and cleaning for the recommended 2 minute use (timer included), and the white mode is designed for teeth whitening with product claims that of two shades whiter in one week.  Indeed, I have noticed my own teeth appear whiter and more polished since I began regular use of the Sonicare.  Similarly, the unit comes with a "DiamondClean Brush Head" that is designed to wipe away stains and plaque; however,even though I find it effective, it should not be used exclusively-especially if you have sensitive teeth.This model comes with a charger for the lithium ion battery and claims a 3 week usage on one charge.  A two color battery charge indicator visually cues users into recharging.  It also boasts of 3 intensity settings for the unit to meet cleaning and comfort demands of individual users but I have not tried them mush as I enjoy and am satisfied with the standard setting.  I periodically will employ a manual brush just as a change of pace and as a monitoring of the effectiveness of the electric unit--but I am totally committed to the "Philips Sonicare" for my cleaning and whitening needs at present.

The "Belkin MFi Certified 4-Foot Flat Lightning to USB Charge Sync Cable for iPhone 6 / 6 Plus, iPhone 5 / 5S /5c and iPod touch 5th Gen (Blue)" is a quality product that I recommend to anyone seeking a replacement for or an alternative to the standard Apple cord that accompanies each device.  It is, of course, a lightning to USB cable designed for charging or synching iPhones, iPads, and iPods.The cord certainly appears and handles as much sturdier and more heavy duty that the standard Apple cord.  At 4 feet long, it is longer than the standard cord but still not long enough to provide true flexibility to the user; however, the extra length does come in handy in autos and in certain space challenged areas.It is certified by Belkin to meet Apple standards and so far, I have had no problems with using the connectors at either end.  It is flat which contributes to its ability to resist tangling.  The light blue color is eye catching and easy to differentiate from other cords you may have in use.  In summary, this cord is longer and appears sturdier than the standard Apple cable and is certified to meet Apple standards.  Based on my usage to this point, I can recommend this product as an effective, even superior alternative to the standard Apple cable.

Ace Atkins offers "The Redeemers" as the fifth in his signature series featuring Quinn Colson.  Colson is a former Army Ranger who returned from the dangers of warfare on the international front to face warlike dangers as sheriff in his hometown of Jericho in Tibbeh County, Mississippi.  Johnny Stagg, Colson's nemesis and local power broker, has succeeded in getting Quinn voted out of office and, he hopes, neutralized as an opponent of his corrupt plans.  But loyal readers know that Quinn will not leave until he settles accounts with Stagg.A revenge seeker arranges for several opportunists to break into the home of Larry Cobb, a political and corrupt friend of Johnny Stagg, to steal over a million in cash and personal valuables.  Unfortunately, the safe also contains proof of Stagg's corruption within his illegal empire and, equally unfortunately, the thieves are neither very bright nor very loyal.  While Cobb and Stagg move furiously to regain the contents of the safe, Quinn, at the request of Lillie Virgil (his longtime loyal deputy) and the Cobb family, is busy working with an informant to shut down Stagg's evil empire once and for all.  Several lingering story lines and characters from past Colson novels head toward an electrifying confrontation that may or may not decide the fate of The Ranger and Jericho, Mississippi.As usual, readers are reminded of the quality touches that Atkins brings to his work.  "The Redeemers" is an  authentic, fast paced thriller with well- fleshed characters and believable dialogue all staged deep in the backwaters of rural Mississippi.  Atkins continues his subplots regarding Quinn's estranged father, addicted sister, and his on-again, off-again romances.  All in all, The Quinn Colson series is a compelling, well-written series that should appeal to fans of southern suspense/thrillers.

The abbreviated review of the "AeroFryer 9349 Cooklite Aero Fryer, 1000-watt 4.6-Liter/4.8-Quart (Extended Capacity 7.1-Liter/7.5-Quart), Black" is that it pretty much does what it claims but with annoying restrictions.  And an important consumer question would be to determine if you really need it considering what it does compared to your other kitchen appliances.  Because it does cook healthy crispy foods with little or no oil but everything else it does can already be done with other appliances and not necessarily with a great deal more time.Other reviewers have tabbed this "fryer" as more appropriately a broiler or a convection oven using a combination halogen and infra red heating; clearly, it is not a deep fryer as such.  It is simple and easy to use.  it comes with an instruction manual and small cookbook along with an oil spritzer and an ineffective pair of tongs.  It is easy to clean and is dishwasher safe, excluding the top with the heating element and the plastic bottom.  And it does not build up a lot of extra kitchen heat.Unfortunately, its ability to cook crispy food items like fries, onion rings, or chicken is compromised and limited by a very small cooking area in the basket that requires a single layer of fires etc. so that the hot air can reach all sides. I was able to cook only a small batch of fries or two chicken breasts at a time.  This limitation makes the appliance useful for a single person or two people at the most; otherwise, using it for larger families requires several cooking batches to acquire enough results to feed everyone (and keep the already cooked food warming somewhere).  Furthermore, you do need to flip the food to get overall consistency and crispness.While the fries, chicken,  fish will be cooked to crispy consistency and will be tasty enough to eat, it will not taste the same as deep fried food--but the trade off is healthier eating.  And except for the crispy food preparation, all the other recipes provided can be done in a crock pot, skillet, or oven/broiler.  I also found that my cooking times were surprisingly longer than the cooking times suggested in the cookbook.  lastly, it does require a large "footprint" when left on the counter and does need significant storage space in cabinets.I can recommend this appliance to those who cook for one or two people who desire crispier, more healthy food items.  It does perform several functions but is limited by its small cooking surface and does not do much (besides cooking crispy items without much oil) that your other everyday appliances can already do.  Three and a half to four stars.

I generally opt for cell phone cases that provide quality protection and come with a belt pouch or holster to avoid pocket stretching or sliding out of pockets while sitting.  But I decided to try a more "classy" looking case for use on more formal or dressy occasions.  The "OtterBox Strada for Apple iPhone 6" was an excellent choice as it met all my expectations without adding a lot of clunky size to the finished product.It is  part of the Strada series and features a minimalist yet elegant look  in a deep maroon leather.  The case surrounding the phone appears to have the well constructed protection that OtterBox products are noted for and  the attached leather flap snaps closed over the phone case by use of a strong magnet presenting a sleek smooth look.  The iPhone 6 easily fits snugly into the case with all ports and buttons aligned properly and there is a slot on the inside flap cover that can hold a credit card or a couple of bills.  Opening and closing the flap may be a pain for some users but I found I unconsciously adjusted to it immediately.  The flap may be somewhat problematical to some in that it must be kept open and extended when using the camera to prevent obstruction of the lens.I have quickly come to appreciate this eye catching carrying case.  It is stylish, highly functional, and offers OtterBox type protection for your valuable cell phone.  It is the type of case that imparts a touch of class to the owner when seen and used in a public place.

Before purchasing the "George Foreman GFO3320GM Indoor/Outdoor Grill", be clear on what you want or expect it to do.  It is designed to be an electric grill, similar to electric skillets, and not a more traditional barbeque or gas grill which cooks entirely differently; obviously, from reading some of these reviews, some users were apparently confused.  The ceramic grill plates will give the user traditional grill marks on meat and food items but it, of course, will not provide true open heat grilled flavor.The unit is light, easy to set up, and contains the classic George Foreman grease draining ability.  It is designed for indoor/outdoor use either as a tabletop grill or as a stand alone grill when connected to its pole like stand (think of an oversized  traditional George Foreman grill on a stand).  I found it a bit shaky and unstable on the stand but it does take a large footprint of space if used on a counter top.  Additionally, it may be difficult for some to store due to its size coupled with its dome lid.There is a temperature gauge in the lid but the lid does get a lot of condensation from grilling if closed often.  Unfortunately, the cook top of the grill does not separate from the whole unit making it impossible to use in a dishwater and problematic to clean in a sink.  It may be optimal for use in smaller apartments, condos, on balconies, travel trailers, etc.  It may be most useful on the patio or backyard either on the stand or on a table top as I currently use it.  If users are expecting clean electric grilling, and are concerned about space restraints, the "George Foreman GFO3320GM Indoor/Outdoor Grill" could be a valued addition.

Du Brul brings back Philip Mercer, geologist and adventurer extraordinaire,  in "The Lightning Stones".  As this was my first experience with Mercer, I found characterization to be a bit thin for a book full of ongoing characters, although it is certainly readable as a stand alone novel.  Billed as a thriller, I found it more of a mystery built around a pacing-challenged thriller.Mercer is riding an elevator deep into the bowels of a mine in Minnesota to visit an old friend and mentor, Abe Jacobs,  who is conducting a scientific experiment far from the surface.  Unfortunately, Mercer is too late as he hears gunshots and chaos, arriving to find Abe and his staff all slaughtered and their ore samples taken.  Vowing revenge, Mercer jumps into action only to see the gunmen escape leaving his next move uncertain.Thus begins "The Lightning Stones" which ambitiously combines the historical Amelia Earhart mystery with stolen ore samples of vast power (Lightning Stones), a wicked eco-billionaire, climate change science, and various sub plots designed to keep Philip Mercer globe trotting in his pursuit of the truth behind Abe's death.  Along the way, he is joined by an enticing young female, Jordan Weismann, who claims also to be a disciple of Abe Jacobs;  a sympathetic FBI agent, Kelly Hepburn; and an old mercenary ally in Booker Sykes, who adds a touch of humor and violence to the tale.Although confused by how his enemies seem to be a step ahead of him, Mercer and his allies close in on the forces behind the killing of Abe Jacobs and, with limited governmental resources, Mercer is forced to implement a plan of action that is several layers deep to identify finally those  behind a plot that could threaten the physical destruction of life on earth.  While an effective man of action, it is his instincts and planning that lead Mercer to a cataclysmic high seas conclusion and subsequent denouement.  Recommended for fans of Du Brul and of his Philip Mercer character, especially those familiar with his back story.

This  "Leather Lovers Sample Kit" from chemical guys includes  4 ounce bottles of (1) Leather Scented Air Freshner, (2) Leather Conditioner, (3) Sprayable Leather Cleaner/Conditioner, and (4) Leather Cleaner.  No instructional manual is included but each bottle does contain directions on the label for using the product.I initially experimented with the products on a well worn and heavily used leather sofa/loveseat set that had been relegated to the den.  Each of the cleaners and conditioners did a noticeably effective job of cleaning and moisturizing my leather furniture.  As for the Leather Scent, save that for your car if you crave the odor of leather interiors.I also tried the products on a pair of leather boots and an old, well-used leather bomber jacket.  In all cases, the products met my expectations and did not leave too fine a sheen.  The products contain both vitamin E and Aloe to help in the moisturizing, cleaning, and softening of the leather being cleaned.  So far, I haven't detected any "bleeding" of the color but it will definitely remove old caked-on grime.  I would recommend that users try test patches somewhere inconspicuous on jackets, purses, or furniture before jumping in feet first.  At this point, I am pleased with the products (although I have little use for the Leather Scented spray).

The "Zeetron LED Light up Charge Sync Cable For iPhone 6, 6 Plus, 5S, 5C, 5, iPad Air 2, iPad Air, iPad Mini 2, Mini, iPod 5th Gen Retail Packaging (Lightning)" delivers on its claims.  It is a three foot USB to lightning cable with an indicator light to monitor charging.  It is well constructed and I do not get the sense it will fray at the end like a couple of my Apple cords.  The connectors fit snugly and there is no wiggle room if the cord is moved while charging or synching.When plugged into a charger or computer, the lightning connector will light up with a blue LED that will turn red while charging until finally returning to blue when the device is fully charged.  It is a convenience to glance at your iPhone or iPad and see that it is either fully charged or still in the charging mode.The one caveat for some buyers is that the rubberized casing around the lightning connector is fairly wide (apparently to house the LED's) and will not fit every case made for iPhones.  Fortunately, it does fit my case making a snug, comforting connection; however, if you have a narrow charging port opening on your case, you may want to look for something else.  I recommend this product as I am now using it full time with my iPhone charger.

My first experience with the "Old Factory Scented, Natural Soy Wax Candles" was both positive and enjoyable.  These candle sets are made in the USA  with "natural soy wax and self trimming cotton candle wicks" and advertised to burn cleanly for 20 hours.  Surprisingly, they arrive with a 100% money back guarantee if the purchaser is unhappy with the fragrance or performance of the candle set.Each of the variously themed sets come in a three pack of 2 ounce candles.  I selected the "Happy Holidays" theme which included one gingerbread scented candle, one Christmas tree scented candle, and one candy cane scented candle.  The scents were authentic renderings whether experienced new in the jar or while burning.The fragrances are neither overpowering nor cloying--they will not linger for days after burning.  But if burned in a large room or a high ceilinged room, they struggle to fill up the space.  It is recommended by the manufacturers that two candles be utilized if burning in larger rooms to get the full effect and I discovered mixing two different fragrances from a themed set actually enhanced the overall efect--at least in the "Happy Holidays" set.  While a bit pricey for their size, I would not hesitate to use other themed sets and I enthusiastically recommend this product.I received free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review.

With "The Wolf In Winter", John Connolly continues to deliver as one of our finest writers in today's world of suspense thrillers--particularly in the subgenre of supernatural noir, to coin a phrase. Connolly is a master wordsmith who can create a sense of forboding or a palpable feel of evil with only a few well chosen words. He is a master at creating forbidding locations and evil incarnate. His dialogue is usually spot-on and often times humorous, especially when Charlie Parker, Angel, and Louis are interacting and one-upping. Connolly's plots within the Charlie Parker series are tightly woven and filled with enough characters and red herrings to keep most diehard readers guessing until the end.  Fans of Connolly and his signature character, Charlie Parker, can breathe easily because  "The Wolf In Winter" continues the author's history of rising to meet the increased expectations of his reading audience.Can a town be an evil entity?  Is something dangerously evil living among or in Prosperous, Maine?  What secrets are the town leaders hiding that keep the community more "prosperous" than those nearby?  Charlie Parker is forced to confront these questions when a homeless acquaintance mysteriously dies in an apparent suicide while trying to collect enough money to hire Parker to help him find his daughter who went missing in Prosperous, Maine.  Charlie feels compelled to look into the missing daughter and Prosperous after questioning his friend's  suicide.As Parker stirs the pot a bit in his exploration of Prosperous, he senses an underlying evilness that seems to drive the closely knit community.  His reputation precedes him and soon he is targeted for assassination to protect the town's secrets and well-being.  An attempt on Charlie's life sets a number of inexorable forces in motion that include vengeance seeking Louis and Angel, the Collector, hte Believers, and the Backers.  As internal conflicts begin to split the Prosperous leadership, Louis and Angel forge a tenuous truce with old enemies to get the information necessary to avenge Parker leading to a violent and satisfying conclusion.  It is to Connolly's credit that the Charlie Parker tales, while often tinged with touchs of the supernatural, are still enjoyable for the character development, suspense and thrills, and ultimately, for the ongoing struggle of good versus evil.

The "APLWL USB 2.0 A to Micro B Cable 3FT-PVC jacket-Green" is an A male to micro B cable in stunningly bright colors (mine is lime green) to easily distinguish among your cable clusters; indeed, no more looking for the "right" white cable that goes with a certain charger, etc.  It has a standard type- A USB connector on one end and a micro type-B connector on the opposite end of its 3 foot length.It purports to support 480-MBS transmission speed and is obviously designed for connecting PC peripherals such as printers, external drives, and digital cameras.  I found it to be well constructed with clean, tight connectors and a sturdy wire covering that felt much more substantive than many of the lighter, easily frayed cords that come with many devices.  At this point, I recommend this product and intend to buy other cords in contrasting colors for my other devices.

I have a wine accessory drawer that contains a plethora of wine corkscrews of every type, model, and size.  Additionally, I have several counter top corkscrews, lever operated, etc.  However, it is time to donate all those to someone and focus on my new "Metrokane Rabbit Automatic Electric Corkscrew".  It has been a pleasant surprise to me and my guests often are fascinated with watching it work.It arrives nicely packaged in a cardboard cylinder with directions and pictures of how to use it.  it is designed to be an all-in-one wine bottle opener in that it includes a foil cutter on top of the corkscrew (covering the USB micro charger).  It is lightweight (less than a pound), 9.5 by 2" by 2", and is eyecatching in design.  One charge supposedly will remove 30 corks with a recommended 4 hour charging time.  And, fortunately, it removes both regular corks and newer plastic corks.It is presented as an automatic cork remover with no buttons to push; instead, it has a built in sensor that reacts to the pressure on the cork.  The most difficult part seems to be centering the unit directly over the center of the cork so the downward angle remains relatively straight.  Place slight pressure on the corkscrew and it begins to whine as it "does its job" of removing the cork.  Once the cork has been removed and pressure relieved, the unit reverses itself and expels the cork.The "Metrokane Rabbit Automatic Electric Corkscrew" has a manual overridein case the cork removal process fails or the unit jams.  I am definitely pleased at this point (6 bottles of wine opened) and am comfortable recommending it for personal use or for a nice gift.  Certainly, someone with weak or arthritic hands should find this to be an incredibly helpful wine opener.

I am not a sophisticated audiophile but I do know what I like and appreciate in audio gear.  The "Logitech USB H570e Corded Double-Ear Headset" is a value-priced entry level stereo headset with Digital Signal Processing (DSP) and a noise cancelling boom mic for static free listening with no background noise interference.  It has "plug and Play" capability and is easy to install right out of the package.  It is compatible with most popular platforms including Apple Mac, PC, etc.  The ear cups (which do not cover the entire ear) are connected by a padded metal reinforced headband which appears to  be durable as well as functional although mine were a bit tight for total comfort.  The unit has in-line call controls and indicator lights for personal convenience and I appreciate the generous cord length making these controls easily reachable.  After two weeks of usage, I am comfortable recommending the "Logitech USB H570e Corded Double-Ear Headset" to anyone seeking a quality entry-level stereo headset and boom mic for business or gaming use.

The "URBAN ARMOR GEAR Case for iPhone 6 (4.7 Display) Clear" is my first experience with UAG cases.  Overall, I find it stylish and efficacious with a few shortcomings--still a very serviceable and protective case for most users.  Due to Apple's paranoia regarding the secrecy of its new releases, it is exceedingly difficult for after market vendors to produce "perfect" cases for simultaneous release with the new phones, which is why we often have to wait weeks for well designed cases and why second generation cases are always superior..  This UAG model comes close to hitting a bull's eye on its first iteration.It is impact resistant and very light due to a composite construction.  It claims to meet military drop test standards.  It features a HD screen protector (that doesn't totally cover the screen), affords easy access to all buttons and connector ports, and sports reinforced "skid pads" on all four corners for added impact protection.  The rubberized lip surrounding the front screen seems a bit thin to me and may be the one risky or vulnerable area to an accidental drop.Overall, the case has a simple tactical yet stylish appearance.  The translucent "honeycomb-like" rear cover with transparent plastic inserts gives it a personalized, almost military look.
