The connector ports on the bottom of the case and the vibrator/sound toggle switch on the upper left are all uncovered which may influence those who worry about dust entering their case.  It does feature an innovative glare free flash protector that has worked flawlessly for me.  All in all, an effective "early release" of an iPhone case that will provide sturdy protection from scratches and impacts along with easy access in a thin profile innovative design  that should provide users with some peace of mind until something better arrives.

The "Surpahs M1 Magic-Mirror Brite LED Tempered Glass Digital Bathroom Scale" is quite simply an elegant and highly efficient bathroom weight scale that you will quickly treasure.  It is a low profile luxury digital bathroom scale in a high gloss black finish with silver plating on the bottom and wrapped around the screen giving it a luxurious look in your bathroom.  It has a generously large and bright red LED readout display that is easy to read in the dark or subdued lighting.Besides its stylish and elegant appearance, the "Surpahs M1 Magic-Mirror Brite LED Tempered Glass Digital Bathroom Scale" is very accurate, never varying if I step on and off 10 times.  It is 12.6" by 12.6' by 1" and weighs just a bit over 4 pounds.  It is powered by 4 (AAA) batteries and is a "sense on" scale in that all you need do is step on it--no buttons to push etc.  It has a button on the bottom to switch from pounds to kiligrams to stones depending on one's desire.  It is certainly value priced and comes with a satisfaction guarantee.  A highly recommended product.

The "LifeCHARGE InAir Battery Case with Wireless Charging Technology for Apple iPhone 5/5s - Retail Packaging - White (Wireless Phone Accessory)" is my first experience with a charging case and with a wireless charger and I am very pleased with the results.  The product is intended to extend (perhaps double) your iPhone's battery life without needing a charger or outlet while at work or on the road.  If the case is fully charged, it can almost double the expected battery charge of the iPhone AND the phone itself can be recharged without any connections or wires by placing it flat on the charging pad which is, itself, connected to an outlet or computer.The case itself is stylish with a faux leather look backing with four small pinholes that light up to monitor charge capacity.  It purports to double battery life allowing 8-10 extra hours of talk time.  According to the developer, the unit was developed and is certified to meet Apple performance standards and it does align properly with all the iPhone 5 features such as connectors, switches, and microphone cut-outs.  It is powered by one Lithium Metal battery.  The product seems a bit pricey but that may depend upon how each user values convenience.One clarifying point that may influence some potential users.  The " LifeCHARGE InAir Battery Case with Wireless Charging Technology for Apple iPhone 5/5s" utilizes a Micro USB cable and a USB Micro Port/interface which allows users to charge the phone, the case, or both from the USB Micro Port.  Unfortunately, a lightening cable interface will not work on the unit which can be cumbersome for those who choose to link their phones directly to a computer for synching purposes etc.  The Micro USB cable is included and can be connected to any standard wall adaptor (not included).

"Invasive Species" by Joseph Wallace is a mixed bag that can be read as a fun page-turner with a little suspension of disbelief by the reader.  It is basically an apocalyptic "what if" look at a futuristic scenario that unfolds when a newly evolved insect predator begins to spread its deadly presence across the world linked by an all seeing/all feeling "hive mind".  The wasp like predator uses humans and other mammals as nurturing "hosts" for their unborn, ultimately leading to madness and death of the host.  Each predator is linked to the hive mind so that each sees and feels all,  leading to their calculated efforts to seek vengeance against those who harm or threaten their existence.Wallace does a good job of making this whole notion as plausible as possible with scientific references and decent characterizations of the leading characters.  His pacing is mostly effective at building suspense and maintaining a sense of "how can this end in a good way"; indeed, his climax and denouement make satisfying sense within his posited parameters but suffer a bit from alternatives not considered because of the reader's need for suspension of disbelief.  For example, except for one flawed major governmental attempt to "attack" the predators, no other alternative methods of eradication are even considered.This is part of the "mixed bag" I mentioned earlier.  The need for sustained suspension of disbelief and even turning one's head from the questions of .."why didn't they try X or Y or Z"?  Also, readers are subjected to the obligatory lecture on the consequences of man's destruction of nature and the obligatory corrupt governmental officials trying to hide the truth from the people.But heck, I enjoyed "Invasive Species" as a fun summer read for its chills and thrills with some attention paid to the science relating to insects; indeed, when read purely as fun escapist literature, this novel can be a page turner leading some to check their doors and windows for possible insect access.  Just keep the pages turning so you don't think too critically or deeply.

Note:  I received a sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.My experience with "Mental Clarity Recovery Formula" by Clarex was inconclusive at best and disappointing at worst.  I am in my "golden years", work out at the gym three times a week, and jog 3 miles three times a week so I hoped for the promised results.  After two weeks of the regimen, I noticed no discernible results physically or mentally--not even a "placebo effect".  I tried the tablets before a heavy workout or jog and after a workout but with no recognizable effects in either case.  I do not drink coffee at all and drink alcohol moderately, so I was unable to test the promised effects of clearing up the caffeine/coffee "crashes" nor the dreaded "hangover".So my high expectations were not met but that could be due to my individual metabolism and/or the effects of multi-vitamins I already take.  I personally have not had much success with "B" vitamin mega doses in the past.  It is a foul smelling and tasting  tablet that must be quickly swallowed to avoid the odorous effects and it will leave a brief unpleasant after taste.  I am rating the product with three stars because it does offer mega doses of many valuable vitamins and minerals and may work for others better than it did for me.

The "Apple Mfi Certified] ZeroLemon Lightning to USB Cable" by ZeroLemon is one of those products that makes you wonder why Apple or someone else hadn't done it this way before.  It is definately heavy duty in its look and feel and instills the confidence that the outer wire coating will not crack and separate from the internal wiring as has happened on many of the iPhone 5 cords, including mine.The cord is an amazing ten feet long and 3.5 mm in thickness which allows user flexibility in connection options (and can be controlled using twist ties) while seeming to be slightly less manipulatable than the more narrow standard cords.  The connecting points at both ends of the lightning cable appear well made and fit snugly in both my computer and my Apple devices (iPhone 5, 6 and iPad Air).The ultimate question to be answered over time is whether the cable meets or exceeds one's expectation for durability and utility.  After using the cord for two weeks, I have gained confidence that this product will continue to be effective over time and certainly exceed the efficacy of Apple's packaged cord. ZeroLemon does offer a nice two year warranty and barring some unforseen problem, I rate this product as a great functional value.

"Payoff" is Douglas Corleone's second Simon Fisk novel and my first experience with the character (and, hopefully, not my last).  Fisk is a former U.S. Marshall who is now a private investigator specializing in child abduction cases--predominately inter-family kidnappings.  Simon's own daughter was abducted eleven years ago and he has never received the comfort he tries to provide other parents who lose a child in this manner.Hollywood movie mogul, Edgar Trenton, calls in an old "favor" from Fisk asking him to search for his missing fifteen-year-old daughter, Olivia,  who was forcefully abducted from his home while his wife, Emma, was roughed up and drugged.  There are glaring bits of circumstantial evidence pointing at an inside job and Trenton is soon arrested while Simon goes on an exhausting pursuit of the perpetrators that takes him to Grand Cayman, then to the underbelly of Costa Rica, subsequently to a confrontation with a cartel leader in Colombia, and finally, to Caracas during Carnival, before returning to California.  Whew!Who is behind Olivia's kidnapping and was it an inside job?  What happened to the 8.5 million dollar ransom Trenton paid and why wasn't Olivia subsequently returned?  To get the answers to these questions, Fisk must deal with sleazy children of privileged and powerful officials, a deadly drug cartel, a sex slavery ring, and crooked government and church officials aided, in part, by Mariana, a clever young lady who desires to repay Fisk for having helped free her from sex dealers."Payoff" is a fast-paced read that ratchets up the suspense with each new stop by the intrepid Simon Fisk.  There are areas where the reader must suspend his/her disbelief, but nothing that ruins the pacing or the unfolding plot.  Fisk is an intriguing character, haunted by his own demons yet finding a way to combat those demons by helping other suffering families.  Character development was solid for those who became important to the story.  Corleone employs a tightly plotted, fast paced approach to the action in "Payoff" that will keep most readers engaged until the somewhat satisfying climax.

"Windigo Island" is the fourteenth installment in William Kent Krueger's well written and well crafted Cork O'Connor series set in the far North, usually in Minnesotan environs. Cork is a former sheriff turned private investigator in desolated Northern Minnesota where he raises his family, solves crimes, and proudly celebrates his Ojibwe Indian background.  Among the many attractions to this mystery/thriller series is the ongoing relationships Cork maintains with his children and his Ojibwe medicine man mentor, Henry Meloux, a wise old fox who may be over a hundred years old.In "Windigo Island", Cork is persuaded by the Arceneaux family to search for their missing fifteen year old daughter, Mariah, who seemingly ran away a year earlier with her friend Carrie Verga.  Alarmingly, Carrie's beaten body has washed ashore on the small desolated Windigo Island in Lake Superior.  How did she die and why?  Where is Mariah or is she already dead?Seeking answers to these and other questions, Cork, his stubborn and conflicted daughter, Jenny, Henry Meloux and others launch an investigation that leads to the shipping port of Duluth and a sex-trafficking cartel that preys on young vulnerable Indian girls.  With the indian population and the local police being mostly uncooperative, Cork and Jenny must follow their instincts as clues point to a fictional monster known the Windigo or an evil spirit known as Mishi Peshu.  Henry's knowledge of tribal lore is invaluable as an anchor for Cork in his search.A recurring theme in this series has been the entanglement of different members of Cork's immediate family into the storylines, sometimes with tragic consequences--a reliance on placing family members in peril that I hope has run its course with "Windigo Island".  Jenny O'Connor serves as both a determined motivator as well as a "conscience" for her father.  She will not let this missing person case go yet she is increasingly fearful of Cork's determination and the vengeful spirit she thinks she sees growing in him.  She is quickly confused and conflicted by the two sides of her father--the loving man who raised her and the vengeance-seeking force seemingly ready to kill, if necessary, to achieve his goals and to defeat the "Windigo".Krueger continues to weave amazingly well fleshed characters with pin point descriptions of life and places in the blizzard filled desolate woods and lakes of Northern Minnesota to propel his plot while maintaining edge-of-the-seat suspense for the reader. Though this effort drags in places during the first half, the white knuckle pacing of the second half  steam rolls the reader to an edge-of-the-seat confrontation between good and evil in the climax.  If you have never experienced this wonderfully satisfying series, grab "Windigo Island" and then go back and read the entire series. This is a highly recommended author and series.

I have been using the "Belkin Apple MFi Certified Car Charger with Lightning Connector for iPhone 5 / 5S / 5c (2.1 Amp / 10 Watt)" for about a week and find it adequately meets its stated claims and objectives.  It works for both my iPhone 5 and my iPad Air.  It apparently is okayed by Apple as to meeting its standards.  It seems sturdily manufactured and maintains a low profile in my console connector and boasts a 4 foot cord (not coiled) which I find more than adequate for my needs.It only works in my car when the engine is running which produces a green LED light on the unit to indicate it is connected properly.  I notice a lot of mixed reviews for this product online, but this latest iteration (code # F8JO75btBLK) seems to be getting much more positive reviews so I assume it is an improved and upgraded version of an earlier flawed product.I keep my iPhone and iPad on chargers when not in use so I seldom need a travel charger but keeping this product in your console or trunk compartment seems a wise way to ensure your emergency needs are met when on a long trip or when others are draining the battery while on a long in-car trip.  So far, I can recommend this product as a serviceable basic car charger for iPhone 5s, iPad minis and iPad Airs.

As a child, my parents would take me to a barber shop that utilized this line of product and often, after my haircut and a "pretend" shave, the barber would splash some Virgin Island Bay Rum on me, creating an olfactory memory I never forgot.  I encountered the product again on a recent visit to a golf club in the Caribbean sparking old memories and leading me to order a bottle online.It is a scent I easily remember with a splash on "burn" that is refreshing after a close shave.  The odor is a little more cloying than I remember and seems to hang on far longer than most after shave lotions.  It is cool and bracing when splashed on and is somewhat "old-school" in the simplicity of its spicy island odor as opposed to the emergence of modern laboratory inspired floral concoctions.  I doubt this will become my "go-to" after shave, but it is more than adequate and, for me, possesses a huge nostalgic attraction.

Long ago, Lee Child developed a winning formula for his Jack Reacher series that has served him well over the course of nineteen installments.  Regular readers know Reacher's personality, instincts, and capabilities so well that they can settle in comfortably with each new novel and forget that time is slipping away as they engrossingly turn page after page.  Readers know that each Reacher adventure will be action-packed as a suspense/thriller with often an enigmatic mystery thrown in.  Things and people are not always what they seem in a Jack Reacher novel.In "Personal", The CIA and the military reach out to our taciturn loner to help locate an American trained sniper who may be the shooter behind an attempt on the President of France and perhaps planning other assassinations of world leaders at the upcoming G8 conference.  The suspected sniper is John Kott, recently released from prison after a 15 year term, who was initially captured by Reacher when he was still a military MP.  Reacher is prevailed upon by governmental leaders to go to Europe and find and deal with this suspected terrorist.  But who is behind the sniper?  Who might be the "real" target?  Is Reacher really expected to succeed?  Child uses tight plotting and increasing suspense to bring all these questions to a satisfying conclusion and an unexpected denouement.Child employs a new character, CIA rookie analyst in her first field assignment, Casey Nice, as a real time "conscience" whose questions and ethical barriers help readers understand Reacher's underlying belief system.  As always, Reacher's intuitive skills, coupled with his attention to detail, allow him to stay one or two steps ahead of the bad guys and the readers as well.  He always picks up several clues to the "real" mastermind or "real" motivating force that he ponders until late in the story when all is revealed.  For this reader, this was an enjoyable return to form for Jack Reader and I recommend this effort and the entire series very highly.

"The Black Ace" was my first encounter with G.B. Joyce and his character, Brad Shade, a former hockey player and current hockey scout who also does some sleuthing.  Shade and his pal "Chief" travel to the small town of Swift Current, Saskatchewan to pay respects to the widow of their old playing buddy Martin Mars who apparently committed suicide.  But Mars' widow soon hijacks them into ascertaining if it was indeed a suicide or something else.Almost immediately, Shade finds himself unwelcome in town and is the center of fights and threats--all which reinforce his supposition that something is not right in the sleazy town of Swift Current which apparently harbors many secrets as did his buddy, Mars.  The rest of the book is the unraveling of the mystery surrounding Mars' death and the pressure exerted by Shade to find the truth and exact "justice" whatever that may be in his mind.  It seems Brad Shade is a philosopher of life who, while struggling with his own demons, tries to steer a path that is compatible with his own personal philosophy and the expectations of the law and society.I liked the prose and stylings of Mr. Joyce but this effort is certainly not a thriller; indeed. it is more of a character driven mystery.  There are long periods with little or no action and a lot of philosophizing and self introspection while driving long distances back and forth across Canada--there is a sense that a hundred pages could have been edited out and the story would not have been overly impacted.  And for this first time reader, the character of Brad Shade needs further refining as to who he is, what his core values are, and where he wants to go.  I will read the next effort by Joyce to see if his character and his plotting progresses with the promise I see in his writing.  Three and a half stars rounded up to four.

The "Pro Edition Wrist Wraps" are an excellent alternative for anyone seeking extra wrist support for weight training, heavy lifting at home or work, sports enthusiasts etc.  They are well made of high quality materials and come at a reasonable price making them a real value in my opinion.  They are a "one-size-fits-all" product measuring about 3" wide by 16" long (including velcro strip).  They are black with sporty red highlights and contrasts which attract interested looks from other gym-goers.  They are labeled Right and Left although each can easily be used on either wrist.  My remaining question about the enduring quality of the stretch material and velcro was answered by their no questions asked lifetime warranty.I have been a gym rat and weight trainer for over 40 years and as creeping age and wear and tear usage have weakened my wrists over time, I was eager to try these wrist wraps as an alternative to occasionally taping a sore wrist.  What a great decision.  They have a thumb loop on each unit that helps hold the product in place as you wrap it around your wrist (in my case almost two times around) adjusting it as you wrap to allow for the proper tightness and support desired.  If the user feels it to be too tight after a set of exercises, a release of the velcro strap allows for a slight adjustment in tautness followed by resnugging the velcro.I have worn this product through three total weight workouts and judge them to be excellent at support and ease of use.  I felt no pain during any repetitious exercise nor in any heavy lift; indeed, I felt secure, supported, and comfortable at all times.  I was surprised and amused at several gym acquaintances who came up to ask me about the wraps, often mentioning how sporty they looked.  I highly recommend this product to any athlete, weekend warrior, or individual in need of wrist support.

Among my many lifetimes "quests" has been the search for the perfect pillow--one not too hard and stiff,  nor one too soft and pliant.  Most of us seek a pillow that contours to our needs, is comfortable, and well made.  The  "Advanced Foam Core and Fiber Pillow" comes pretty close to meeting all my expectations.Its specifications state that it is 60% polyester fiber and 40% polyester foam, and its foam core is rated as hypoallergenic.  Construction specifics detail an egg crate foam core (which allows for air circulation to avoid heat builld-up) surrounded by a "down-like" fiberfill to help soften and contour to the head and neck areas.  It is enclosed by a 200 thread count cotton pillow cover and comes in three sizes, std., queen, and king (20" by 36").I have slept with this pillow for several months and am highly pleased with its utility and performance.  Is it perfect--no, but darned close.  It is every bit as comfortable for me as the highly advertised brands sold on TV informercials.  After over three months of usage, it still retains its original shape and feel with only a very slight compression area in the middle--something easy to anticipate with constant usage.  It gives me support contoured to my head and neck shape without being too firm or unyielding.  I never wake up in the middle of the night with that need to change pillows due to heat buildup or perspiration.I currently have over a dozen pillows of all sizes and types including foam filled, down filled, polyester filled, etc. with designs ranging from standard department store pillows to "revolutionary" egg crate to gel filled etc.  This pillow has become one of my preferred "go-to" pillows for a good night's sleep.  Until I find something better, I highly recommend it to those still seeking the perfect pillow.

I read all the Jonathan Quinn novels by Brett Battles except this prequel to "The Cleaner" until it arrived recently in paperback.  It is a true prequel in that it chronicles the metamorphous of Quinn from a rookie cop to a fledgling "cleaner", someone who cleans the site of an assassination by removing the body and any accompanying clues as to what might have really happened.In "Becoming Quinn", Jake Oliver is a young ambitious rookie cop with the Phoenix PD who is one of the first-on-scene of a burning barn with a dead body inside.  Blessed (or cursed) with an intense curiosity and eye for detail, coupled with amazing instincts, Jake quickly violates protocol and begins his own investigation following up several leads he thinks the detectives missed at the crime scene.  Soon, he is risking his job, his life, and the lives of others as consequences for his unauthorized investigation as he becomes watched and hunted by Larson, an unstable assassin, and Durrie, a cleaner extraordinaire.  Ultimately Durrie must decide whether to terminate Jake or recruit him.  Thus, the wheels are set in motion that will determine Jake's future--it is no spoiler to assume that Jake is the before and Quinn is the after--the fun is reading how he gets there.Battles continues to be one of those writers who seem to grow with each new effort--his prose is stylish and easy to read.  His character development is thorough along with credible dialogue and descriptions of places and people.  I enjoyed the young Jake Oliver fighting internally to follow police protocol while his instincts cry out for him to follow up on leads that mean something to him but apparently nothing to his superiors.  In the most fortunate of circumstances, Durrie sees the nascent talents of Jake and decides to recruit him against the wishes of "The Office".  However, Jake does not want to be recruited and has no idea of whom to trust.I am only assigning four stars as I have minor quibbles over the sloppiness of the hit team and with his determination to violate law enforcement protocol which ultimately has tragic consequences.  But these two points, while appearing somewhat contrived, are essential to Jake's story of "Becoming Quinn".

I have never been a balm man, preferring, instead, liquid aftershaves.  However, "Burberry Brit Rhythm Aftershave Balm" was a convincing eye-opener for me.  It is a soothing and refreshing after shave balm with the creamy consistency of a balm but leaves no oily feeling or residue.  It claims to be infused with the scent of Burberry Brit Rhythm Eau De Toilette, which is a product I have not used; however, I found the scent to be clean, refreshing, and woodsy smelling.  The scent is strong right out of the squeeze bottle but it quickly mellows and does not seem to linger nor to be cloying.My one concern regards packaging, in that, while the manufacturers created a plastic squeeze bottle with a textured surface to combat slippery hands and fingers, it has a square screw type bottle cap that is difficult to handle with slippery fingers after spreading the balm--might have been wiser to employ an alternate type of lid.  All in all, a soothing refreshing scent infused in a moisturizing balm that I am currently enjoying in place of my usual liquid after shaves.

Reading the reviews on this book reminds me of the dichotomy that now exists among Koontz'  loyal readers.  I have come to the conclusion, as have many others, that  sometime about a decade ago, perhaps around the time that his beloved golden, Trixie, died that a new Dean Koontz arrived.  This Neo-Koontz  relies much less on the supernatural  and with far fewer of the chills and thrills that used to grab the reader in a "can't-turn-the-pages-fast-enough" choke hold.  His novels have evolved heavily into faith based efforts that would be comfortable sitting on Christian literature shelves.In "The City", a young black youth, Jonah Kirk, is soon to discover his God given talents as a musical prodigy despite the absence of his wayward feckless father.  His near poverty driven life is counterbalanced by his wonderful loving mother, grandparents, and an inscrutable Japanese tailor named Mr. Yoshioka.  Jonah's life seems to change when he meets a mysterious woman who claims to be "The City" itself, personified in her person.  Almost simultaneously, Jonah meets and is soon terrorized by a woman who lives on the floor above his apartment; all of which leads to his discovery of a dangerous cabal of anarchists who threaten his very existence.The rest of the book centers around his efforts along with Mr. Yoshioka, to ascertain what this evil group is up to and how to hopefully stop them.  The problem is that not much really happens for huge chunks of the book (it could have been shortened by 100 pages with no loss of coherence).  Koontz' skill as a wordsmith coupled with his tremendous ability to describe people, places, and emotions are still very much in evidence, perhaps too much so, as his multi-paragraph descriptions can get tedious.But it is with his faith-based confrontations between good and evil have devolved from the thrill ride suspenseful page turners like "Watchers', " Phantoms", and "Strangers" into an era where faith, religion, commitment to goodness will always win out, usually with the aid of a helping spirit invested in a loyal dog, a precocious child, or in this case, a woman who claims to be The City.  According to the Neo-Koontz,  believe hard enough and live a good enough life and good people with be drawn to you and you will survive the darkness.I have no judgment for this change of styling by a wonderful author I grew up reading voraciously.  I merely attempt to explain my perception of his changed writing style in context of so many formerly loyal readers who are confused, angry, or disappointed by these changes--fans who continue buying his books expecting a rebirth of the Koontz of old.  I now read his novels with modified expectations and with less of a mindless urge to purchase each new book regardless of plot lines.  Koontz is still a fine author--just a different one from the one I grew up with.

"Ready To Kill" is Andrew Peterson's fourth offering in his Nathan McBride series and it the most disappointing of the series for this reader. McBride is a former CIA operative and highly trained marine sniper who now teams with life-long buddy and fellow operative, Harvey Fontana, to run a security agency which helps provide them cover for off-the-books government work.  As regular readers know, McBride still suffers from physical as well as psychological and emotional scars from a near fatal torturous questioning over a decade ago by a fiendishly devoted Nicaraguan interrogator specializing in torture and humiliation.  Nathan is a hard, tough fighting man who also has the proverbial heart of gold which helps explain his inner turmoil and conflicts over what he is required to do in the performance of his job while, at the same time, abhorring that same violence.A cryptic message containing information regarding a former CIA top secret operation in Nicaragua that involved Nathan and Harv is delivered to the American embassy in Nicaragua.  Nathan and Harv agree to return to the Nicaraguan jungles in a reconnaissance mission to ascertain if one of their sniper trainees, code name "Raven", has gone rogue.  They link up with another former team member, Viper, who is sure it is Raven who is operating as an enforcement arm for gold mine owners and drug cartels.  Once the 3 former team members link up in Nicaragua, the action slows down noticeably as the whole second half of the book is a long detailed depiction of their pursuit and ultimate confrontation with the villains.Compared to the other three Nathan McBride novels, "Ready To Kill" has a dearth of action and thrills and the pacing gets bogged down in minutiae.  Even the dialogue seems comparably less crisp and credible.  The imagined fear of Nathan returning to the jungle where he was almost tortured to death decades before did not develop into any meaningful plot line except for a brief revelation post climax.Peterson's McBride series features a conflicted smart, tough ex-government operative in fast paced suspense thrillers often featuring dark deadly villains involved in horrifying crimes against humanity. They are usually quick reads that often involve some cringe-inducing scenes  mellowed by satisfying final confrontations and finales.  While still a very acceptable read, "Ready To Kill" is the weakest  of this highly recommended series for all thriller/suspense fans.  Be sure to read the other three to get a full flavor of Peterson's work.

David Housewright's McKenzie series remains on my "must read" list and I have yet to be truly disappointed in any of the novels.  "The Devil May Care" is the eleventh McKenzie novel and it is a fun entertaining read featuring a mystery that ultimately entwines McKenzie once again with the hated Muehlenhaus family.  Rushmore McKenzie is a former St. Paul detective who retired to accept a huge reward and has since languished in retirement except when he does favors for friends as an unlicensed PI.Riley Brodin, granddaughter of Minnesota billionaire Walter Muehlenhaus, beseeches McKenzie to find her missing boyfriend, Juan Carlos Navarre.  Wary of becoming involved with Muehlenhaus  (a man who hates McKenzie) again, but drawn to Riley's plight, McKenzie launches an investigation that soon surprises even him.  Navarre is somewhat of a "ghost" in that everything he supposedly owns turns out to be rented or borrowed.  Who is he really?  Is he really a multi millionaire as he claims or is he a fraud?  Who else is looking for Navarre with deadly intent and why?  McKenzie must answer these questions while avoiding the wrath of Muehlenhaus as the bodies begin to pile up and as local police agencies scrutinize McKenzie's involvement.  Without tipping his hand too soon, Housewright entertains the reader with fully fleshed characters, locales, and dialogue that seem incredibly real.  Indeed, he has a knack for painting "word pictures" for his engrossed readers that allow them to almost "see" and "feel" the characters and places of the twin cities of Minnesota.As usual, McKenzie must rely upon his people skills, his instincts, and his training to try to accomplish the formidable task ahead of him. And as usual, his "inner voice" is there to help guide him and keep him out of trouble. The novel is tightly plotted with thoroughly fleshed characters and places. "The Devil May Care" is a fun and a quick read that is a rewarding experience for fans of the McKenzie series.  I highly recommend this book as well as the entire McKenzie series.

"Mr. Mercedes" is Stephen King's latest and, expectedly, some will lament the absence of supernatural forces and others will enjoy his tale of good vs. evil without paranormal goings-on.  "Mr. Mercedes" is, at its core, a battle of wits between a retired detective still haunted by a senseless killing of innocent people waiting in line by a madman in a Mercedes and the killer himself with the temerity to challenge the detective.Bill Hodges is unhappily retired and finding his life suddenly meaningless when he receives a letter from the "perk" who ran down 23 people waiting in an employment line.  The letter, meant to spur him into committing suicide, instead revitalizes him to revisit the crime and find the demented killer who is promising to kill again.  Soon, with the aid of an unlikely neighbor and a mentally unstable relative of a victim of Mr. Mercedes, Hodges engages the killer in a cat and mouse game of wits that he must win or face the lasting knowledge that his failure resulted in a great loss of innocent lives.King has gravitated toward the crime/thriller genre recently and, for this reader, he hits the mark.  Yes, some of the storyline and characters are a bit hackneyed but his great skill at word smithing and painting mental pictures brings the pursuit of a serial killer into a suspenseful "chess game" between representatives of good and evil.  Every King story does not have to include a Barlow the vampire, a deadly Pennywise the clown, or a Tommyknocker to be a well conceived and well plotted crime story capable of engaging a reader in a, at times, white knuckler thriller.As is often the case, King's main characters become fleshed through their interactions and he soon brings the reader along with him in a story not entirely predictable, especially considering his penchant for surprising the reader with the unexpected.  I continue to be a avid King fan regardless of genre, quite capable of enjoying an "11/22/63", a "Joyland", as well as a "Doctor Sleep".  Certainly, in "Mr. Mercedes", there is joy in watching King employ the talents of three unlikely allies to pursue a crazed killer armed with modern technology,and hell bent on another mass killing.  For me, the growth of these characters through the course of the novel was worth the price of admission.

"The Forsaken" is the fourth in Ace Atkins's hero-driven "Ranger" series starring Quinn Colson, a former ranger and army hero who returned to his hometown of Jericho, Mississippi to continue a struggle against corruption and injustice.  It is an engrossing series reflecting accurate depictions of the deep South along with deeply believable human interest studies.  Although I am getting a bit fatigued with some of the recurring story lines, particularly that of Johnny Stagg, the local master manipulator, there is much to enjoy in the Ranger series.In "The Forsaken", Quinn and his chief deputy, Lillie, are confronted with a cold case from 36 years earlier that ended with a rape and killing followed by a lynching of a homeless black man two days later.  A survivor of the attack assures Quinn the lynch mob hung an innocent man because she saw the real perpetrator on the street days after the lynching.  But no one else seems to want to help the law nor do they want this dead case reopened.  Who was involved and who did the actual killing, and, most of all, why?While embroiled in this investigation and fighting against trumped up charges stemming from the events in "The Broken Places", Colson and Lillie are forced to deal with Chains LeDoux, a former leader of the local Born Losers motorcycle gang who returns to Jericho with his gang looking for vengeance after spending twenty years in jail.  Who is on his death list and why?  Why is Johnny Stagg and his new protector, Ringold, pulling every string he has to set Colson against LeDoux?  These questions are answered as the novel ratchets up the suspense and danger with each new revelation that ultimately leads to a final confrontation that leaves several unanswered questions for the next installment.Quinn utilizes his instincts and his moral compass to ferret out the background of these deadly events from Jericho's past and is surprised when his Uncle Hamp, the sheriff at the time, and Quinn's own father, Jason, were possible participants.  For fans of this series, Quinn's father finally makes an appearance and some of the unanswered questions from Quinn's past are finally addressed.  As usual, the dialogue is spot on and highly credible and the characters are deeply fleshed out.  Atkins's portrayal of the people and the places of small town Jericho are so believable that the reader can almost 'feel" and see them.  A highly recommended series.

Just as there are fans who believe Elvis is still alive, there are Old West enthusiasts who insist that Billy The Kid was not killed by Pat Garrett and that Butch and Sundance did not die in Bolivia.  David Fuller's "Sundance" is a fun speculative "what if" novel that is built on the idea that Sundance was in a Wyoming prison serving time under an assumed name and never died in Bolivia.  Released in 1913, Harry Longbaugh (Sundance's real name) goes in search of his true love, Etta Place, who dropped off the face of the earth about two years before his release when her weekly letters suddenly stopped.Harry follows his instincts and a questionable trail to New York City in his search for his beloved--while he, himself, is being followed by lawman Charlie Siringo, a former ally, who does not believe the legends that Sundance is dead.  Harry's arrival in NYC presents a great but largely unfilled opportunity to explore the man-out-of-time paradox as he encounters electric lights, horseless carriages, subways, and telephones.  Harry quickly goes from wide eyed wonderment at the contrast of the big city from his stark cloistered prison to total acceptance of this new world as he pursues his search for Etta.In short order, Harry is involved not only in finding Etta, but avoiding the agents of the Black Hand who also seek her for personal vengeance and Charlie Siringo who is closing in.  Harry must employ all his outlaw instincts and experiences to find his lost love and save them both from the clutches of New York's most feared gangsters.  Harry does employ some Old West survival instincts when wielding his six-gun and when using a horse off a delivery wagon in a desperate race to save Etta.  Unfortunately, there are not enough of these moments.Fuller does an admirable job of constructing an alternative history for Sundance and Etta surrounded by extraordinary scenes of an emerging behemoth NYC amid the gathering clouds of WWI.  The prose is excellent and the dialog credible and believable.  His characters are generally fully fleshed and reflective of the time period.  Of course, there are times when a leap-of-faith by the reader is necessary but that flows with the theme of the novel.My quibbles are minor considering the efficacy of the whole.  I felt that outside of solving the mystery of where Etta is hiding, Harry was not given enough to do that was reflective of his Old west character.  There is little physical violence in the book and Harry is strangely reticent when threatened at times.  Concomitantly, Harry seems to adjust and "fit in" to his new world much more quickly than we might have expected; indeed, we quickly lose sight of how "new" all these sights are to a fish-out-of-water from the old west.  But read simply as a love story wrapped around a mystery, "Sundance" delivers in a big way.

What teenager hasn't imagined a team up of Batman and Robin or Spiderman And the Hulk? In the world of thrillers, many have wondered what might happen if their favorite signature character teamed up with someone else's signature character to solve a crime.  Who would be the lead, would there be intellectual competition, could two alphas get along?In "FaceOff", edited by David Baldacci, some of these imagined pairings are actually made real in a series of short stories.  Twenty-three top thriller writers were paired together to create 11 short stories featuring the signature character of each author. Think Jack Reacher and Nick Heller; Patrick Kenzie and Harry Bosch working together; Lincoln Rhyme and Lucas Davenport solving the same crime, etc.  Each story has a brief introduction describing the authors, the characters, and how they collaborated on the story.  A brief biography of each contributor is included at the end of the book to help new readers get a better handle on their work."FaceOff" contains some very interesting pairings that will bring many readers joy while reading of their favorite character and allow other readers to experience particular characters for the first time. I found that aspect to be useful since it gave me an opportunity to experience some characters from well-known authors who I had not yet explored.  Unfortunately the short story format forces a quick resolution of the plot line which can be contrived at times.The nature of short stories necessarily limits the amount of characterization and background in each of these stories; yet, our familiarity with many of the characters provides the needed character and background without having to have it explained to us.  Equally, the crimes are relatively quickly resolved again due to the nature of a 20 to 30 page short story.  Some of the pairings are handled more seriously than others which have more of a flavor of humor. But knowing that two well-regarded thriller writers collaborated to create something that encompassed both their hero characters, lends gravitas and fun to each short story.I personally enjoyed Dennis Lehane's Patrick Kenzie teaming with Michael Connelly's Harry Bosch and I found R.. L. Stine's  Slappy the Ventriloquist Dummy versus Preston and Child's Aloysius  Pendergast to be fun reading.  Lee Child's Jack Reacher and Joseph Finder's Nick Keller was a fun bonus highlighting their characters.All in all, a fun and somewhat innovative collection of team up stories. A fast read that is very appropriate for the beach or the pool.  Personally, I now have several new characters to catch up on. Recommended but limit your expectations.

"Third Rail" is the debut novel of Rory Flynn, featuring detective (usually) Eddie Harkness.  Flynn does a better job with characterization and locales than with action and suspense.  He writes in a stream of consciousness style that reminded me vaguely of Charlie Huston's Hank Thompson series.  While this flow of consciousness can foster gritty dialogue, it can also get the reader confused as to who is speaking.Harkness was a highly regarded leader of a Narco-Intel squad in Boston until a shooting creates enough of a furor to get him banned to the small town outside Boston where he grew up.  One night as he is fighting his demons with liquor, his police issue gun disappears and he is desperate to find it in order to preserve his future career.  Simultaneously, he begins investigating a new designer drug in the area called "Third Rail" which has a devastating effect on users.Not sure who he can trust, Harkness soon finds himself waist deep in dirty cops, slimy street characters, and corrupt politicians.  He is not sure he can even trust his new girlfriend who keeps him looking over his shoulder.  There are some minor surprises along the way and a somewhat satisfying conclusion but overall, I did not feel drawn to Eddie as a leading character;  certainly he is more of an everyman than a hero.  In fact, looking back, I sense that I never was invested in any of the characters or their back stories.  This is certainly something that first time author, Flynn, can rectify as he gets more comfortable.  The lack of action coupled with the shady characters drawn right out of casting 101 left me wanting more than there was to get.

I really enjoy this product.  The "Smart Weigh" kitchen scale and timer is far superior to the kitchen scale my family previously used.  It is a sleek and ergonometrically stainless steel design that is attractive and useful.  The backlit LCD readout is clear and big enough to read easily.  It has an 11.4 lb capacity (large for most small kitchen scales) and is listed at 9.5" by 5.75" with a low- to- the- counter profile.It is powered by 3 AAA batteries and includes an Auto Off  timer to save battery life.  It easily shifts into differing modes for oz., g., ml., and fl.oz.  An extra most will appreciate is the built in timer that is imminently useful in most kitchens.  For those who are math challenged, there is a "tare" feature which allows for the accurate measurment of quantities within containers by the push of a button.  All in all, a functional and useful kitchen addition that I have quickly come to value.

"Joe Ledger: Special Ops" is a fun addition to the action/thriller series produced by Jonathan Maberry.  Ledger is a former cop and Army Ranger who heads Echo Team for the Department Of Military Sciences (DMS) headed by the mysterious Deacon Church.  The DMS is tasked with being the last line of defense against terrorists who possess the latest in bioweapons, genetic enhancements, and even the supernatural.In "Joe Ledger: Special Ops", Maberry presents a compilation of Ledger short stories, some old and some new that supplement and enhance the ongoing series.  Each of the nine short stories is described as fitting into a timeline, such as occurring after the events of "Patient Zero" or between the novel's "Assassin's Code" and "Extinction Machine" to assist readers in referencing the context.Indeed, there is a later chapter that outlines an annotated chronological listing of each novel and short story in the Joe Ledger universe.  Another "extra" is a chapter on "Inside The DMS" which includes biographies of all the "good guys" and "bad guys" along with a glimpse inside the DMS--sporadic readers or new readers of the Joe Ledger series should find this to be excellent reference material.  While most of the stories have appeared somewhere before (I had never read any of them before), there are two brand new stand alones and each is incorporated into the Ledger series' timeline.The stories are typical Maberry/Ledger tales  of Joe and Echo Team continuing their battles against seemingly insurmountable evil with the action being short and to the point as is necessary with short stories.  There is still plenty of action, violence, gore, and heartache.  There is still much to learn about one of literature's true warrior heroes and we get time lapsed stories which amplify his growing legacy.  All the usual characters are represented including Top, Bunny, Church, Violin, Aunt Sallie, et.al.  I found this a quick fun read that at best added to the Joe Ledger growing profile.  Although designed for long time fans of the series, it can still stand alone for astute readers newly introduced to the character.

"The Discarded" is Brett Battles latest offering in his Jonathan Quinn series and it diverges from the usual formula a bit.  Quinn, Nate, Orlando, and  Daeng are all present and accounted for but this time, the team jumps into a deep and dangerous mystery involving an old case of Abraham Delger's, Orlando's mentor.  The action heats up as Quinn's team comes to Abe's support as he becomes threatened by an unknown force much like Quinn's former employer, the Office.Abraham reluctantly delivered a frightened  4 year old child to a contact as an assignment seven years ago.  He has regretted it ever since and periodically makes a cursory attempt to find out what happened to her through a CIA contact, Eli Becker.  Becker finally calls him with information but is killed before they can connect.  But Abe has discovered that others are seeking the missing girl with deadly intentions.Enter Quinn and his team as they rally to support Orlando's trainer and mentor.  Now two separate groups are hunting the girl and each other.  Who was the girl and why was she whisked away after her mother was killed?  Who is paying the shadowy  organization to find and terminate her?  Has Abe uncovered a hornet's nest better left untouched?  Battles answers all these questions as he moves the action along at breakneck speed while ratcheting up the tension and the stakes.I particularly liked that this was a free lance effort by Quinn and Orlando to aid a friend who has opened a Pandora's Box.  They operate mainly by the seat-of-their pants employing their usual resources to find and hopefully protect the girl.  There is a lot of behind-the-scenes skullduggery common to secret organizations each pursuing differing objectives.  "The Discarded" is highly recommended both to long time Quinn fans as well as curious newcomers.

Garcinia Cambogia has become a hot product in the past year or two.  Purportedly derived from the tamarind fruit with calcium and potassium added, it is marketed as the newest weight loss miracle pill in that it is supposed to block fat, burn fat, and suppress the appetite.  Scientific research is highly skeptical while anecdotal testimonies of many users are positive.  Instructions dictate that one 750 mg capsule should be taken with water twice a day thirty minutes prior to a meal.  Packaging and presentation of the product (a dark green capsule) is professional and attractive.My experience with this product has been inconclusive at best and disappointing at worst.  I tried to diligently follow instructions for 60 days and was disappointed in the results.  I must add that I suffered through a long nasty cold in the middle of the cycle that may have affected my sense of efficacy.  Since I run three times a week and work out three times a week, I had hoped for quick noticeable results; however, I never truly lost any significant weight and only occasionally felt less hungry.  Was the occasional lessening of hunger an effect of the product or simply my body reacting to less stimuli?  It is difficult for me to pinpoint the efficacy of an appetite suppressant when I ate the same amounts as normally which may be because of the exercise and running mentioned above; in other words, maybe I just build up a physical need for periodic food.  Therefore, I am hesitant to reject the claims of this product and choose, instead, to indicate that my results were inconclusive.  It seems that this product works for some and not for others which may be a function of body chemistry or of a psychological influence.

"Code Zero" is Jonathan Maberry's latest offering in his explosively violent Joe Ledger series-although chronologically the story unfolds immediately following  "Patient Zero", the series' debut.  It is rife with all the elements that legions of Joe Ledger fans have come to expect; extreme violence, lots of gore, mastermind villains, strange or aberrational creatures and killers, and high tech weapons.  Deacon Church, Aunt Sallie, and the rest of the Department of Military Sciences (DMS) are included as well as Top, Bunny, and other new and old members of Joe's Echo Team.  And one must not forget Joe's warrior dog, Ghost, who may be the most endearing killer dog in literature."Code Zero"  focuses on an  apparently anarchical cell creating murder and destruction randomly across the US led by a woman known as Mother Night with expressed desires to create anarchy and destruction but which is ultimately aimed at destroying Church, Ledger, the DMS, and the USA as we know it.  As Echo Team scrambles to find and stop Mother Night, her minions attack the DMS "Locker" where all the deadly bio weapons from previous encounters have been stored.  Soon, Ledger's task is magnified with the random appearance of zombies, "berserkers" and deadly viruses that are sudden additions to Mother Night's arsenal.Can Joe and his wounded team emerge victorious over an enemy fortified with myriad deadly bio weapons --a foe who even seems able to neutralize MindReader, the uber computer of the DMS?  And just who really is Mother Night, the diabolically evil leader who seems to know way too much about Joe, Church, and MindReader?  "Code Zero"  embarks on a suspense filled thrill-a-minute ride to answer these questions.  My only quibble is that the series is beginning to get overly formulaic in recent efforts by recycling villains and monsters at the expense of freshness.  This series is highly recommended for fans of action thrillers and supernatural antagonists.

"Showtime" is an engrossingly entertaining retrospective look at the Showtime Lakers of the 1980s.  It is an astonishingly compelling book relating everything you thought you knew and much that you never knew about one of the most exciting professional basketball teams of all time.  This is a book not to be missed by anyone who was a basketball fan during the 80's and, in particular, a Lakers fan of that fabulous era.  Kareem, Magic, Wilkes, Michael Cooper, Spencer Haywood, Bob McAdoo, Mitch Kupchak, Norm Nixon, and so many others who transform a lethargic Laker franchise into perhaps the most entertaining, fast breaking, and dysfunctional professional team of all time.Jeff Pearlman has clearly done his homework.  There are references to interviews over a three year period with all the major characters who were part of the Laker magic and interviews with many who were involved in the league but watching from afar.  We learn that Showtime was the brainchild of Jack McKinney, an innovative yet doomed head coach, who saw his fling at fame destroyed by a terrible bicycle accident.  The lamentable Paul Westhead era that followed was controversial and certainly ugly at times,  including the feeling that Magic Johnson was the real force who got him fired.  The Pat Riley era began somewhat inauspiciously and ultimately blossomed into one of the most exciting and entertaining basketball teams in the history of the NBA.Showtime really began when Dr. Jerry Buss purchased the Lakers from Jack Kent Cooke, an owner content to be the overlord of a professional team that really didn't know its own identity or its potential.  Buss changed that with his own personal desire to see a faster more entertaining game and his devotion to acquiring the young Earvin "Magic" Johnson to run his team and transform it into what quickly became known as Showtime."Showtime" chronicles the entire history of this era including flashbacks and behind the scenes looks at the interpersonal dynamics of the team, the coaches,  and the owner.  Having lived through this era and being a Laker and Celtic fan, a lot of what is represented in the book was known or at least assumed by the media but "Showtime" details the animosities, the friendships, the drug use, the wild sex, and the jealousies and pettiness of individual competitors.  Norm Nixon versus Magic Johnson, the recalcitrant Kareem Abdul Jabbar, the drug addled Spencer Haywood, the front office mistakes of drafting the wrong individual, or making trades that alienated players.  So much of what we saw (and didn't see) is revealed in  "Showtime"  to have been destructive beneath the surface.Pearlman's book can be deeply satisfying at times, depressing and sad at times, and sometimes simply infuriating when reading of the people and the times of the Showtime Lakers. But, it all happened, and it is exhaustively chronicled in this can't-put-down look at the team that changed the face of modern-day professional basketball.  If you were a fan of professional basketball and/or of the Lakers during this astonishing era of the ascendant Laker dynasty and you think you know its history, you need to read "Showtime".  Pearlman's book examines this transcendent team not only on its entertaining surface, but with all the dysfunction that occurred behind closed doors revealed warts and all. I cannot recommend this book highly enough for sports fans in general and Laker fans in particular.

In Randy Wayne White's latest Doc Ford adventure, "Bone Deep", readers receive an education in the ancient history of Florida including Spanish explorers and even Mastodons and mammoths in even earlier times.  Equally, readers receive education in phosphate mining and its tenuous relationship to maintaining the environment and in relic/fossil hunting, both legal and illegal.  Wrapped within all this information is an intriguing yet convoluted plot that ultimately involves black marketeers, relic and fossil thieves, beautiful but conniving women, a psycho Harley-riding killer, and an old money Florida family filled with historical "baggage".Doc Ford is enlisted to help Tomlinson's friend, Duncan Fallsdown, track down stolen artifacts from his tribe in Montana which ultimately leads Doc into a twisted tale of greed, double crosses, weird characters, and elephants...yes, live elephants.  Wayne does a decent job of weaving the plotline through his attempts to educate the reader on the tenuous and dangerous balance in Central Florida between phosphate mining, fossil thieves in Bone Valley ( a part of Central Florida containing a treasure trove of ancient bones and ivory) and a vulnerable and fragile environment.There is not a lot of in-depth characterization among a bevy of new and minor characters although readers are very familiar by this time with Doc, Tomlinson, and Hannah.  Doc employs his instincts and knowledge of his beloved Florida to zero-in on a complex relationship between the Leland Albright family, its phosphate mining operation, and greedy relic hunters who are willing to kill for what they want.  While the plot drags a bit at times, it does inevitably lead to a violent and sometimes surprising climax seasoned with a bit of historical mysticism.While this novel is an improvement over the last several, my concerns about the Doc Ford series remain somewhat validated.  I maintain that the Doc Ford series has subtly shifted from action/suspense thrillers to unique mysteries-of-the-week focused around Doc and Tomlinson's bickering and dime store psychology.  Each new outing features Doc's constant need to rein in Tomlinson's misplaced exuberance or entanglement in a plot he cannot foresee.  Truth be told, Tomlinson has become a tedious Gabby Hayes type sidekick to Doc to the extent that I would enjoy a Doc Ford novel in which Tomlinson is off somewhere far, far away.  Doc himself has morphed from a former NSA " black op" assassin who struggled with repressing his alpha dog violent side into a detective who makes stupid mistakes such as forgetting to bring his weapon or misjudging people or situations that now make him vulnerable and at-risk to common bad guys.  Doc will always be a formidable force for good...but I long for a return to the dangerous undercover assassin who must constantly fight his need for violence while making "gray-area" decisions that test his morals and his personal code.

"Dead Eye" is Mark Greany's latest Gray Man novel and it is a dandy.  Court Gentry (the Gray Man), perhaps the world's greatest assassin, is still on the run from powerful forces in his own country who is out to terminate him using all the resources of the CIA and even independent operators. Having been recently betrayed by his handler, Gentry exacts his revenge but in the process tips the hunters as to his location.Soon Gentry is in a life-and-death cat and mouse chase across Europe in an effort to prevent the assassination of the Israeli Prime Minister, while at the same time, struggling to escape the clutches of the CIA, and another assassin, code named Dead Eye,  who may be Gentry's mirror image.  How does one escape someone who is equally trained and seemingly equally adept at manipulating people and circumstances, blending into the background, and able to read your every next move?"Dead Eye"  is tightly plotted and immensely suspenseful,  filled with thrills, double crosses, and a body count that climbs quickly.  Who can Gentry trust and who is his real enemy?  How does one survive when he is being followed and targeted by the CIA, independent contractors, the Mossad, local police, and  just about anyone including high flying spy drones?  These questions are masterfully handled by Greany in his excellent suspense thriller, "Dead Eye". The confluence of the Gray Man's attempt to avert an assassination while protecting himself from assassination provides thrills and suspense that keep the reader on the edge of the seat.Some readers may find discomfort and/or frustration with a 400+ page novel that pretty much addresses one assassin targeting another assassin by assuming his identity and framing him for a world class crime. Plots like this can become tedious but Greany does a good job of keeping the action and suspense at a high-level while investing the reader  in the Gray Man and another character, Ruth Ettinger, a master spy for the Mossad.  If you are a fan of action and suspense thrillers with deadly and resourceful signature characters, the Gray Man is a series you should not miss . Highly recommended.

Going Dark" is the latest novel featuring James Hall's signature character Thorn. Despite his efforts to remain isolated in the wilds of Florida,  maverick loner Thorn finds himself inextricably drawn into a plot with eco-terrorists to disable Florida's largest nuclear power plant at Turkey Point. After a confrontation with a shady character named Cameron Prince, Thorn investigates Prince,  a member of a powerful Florida family located on their own island called Prince Key.  Thorn accidentally discovers that Flynn Moss, a son he only recently discovered, is somehow tied in with Prince and a group of eco-terrorists.Thorn seeks  the group out in an effort to find out what his son is involved in and finds himself forced to participate in a plot to disable Southern Florida's nuclear power plant at Turkey Point to protect Flynn. Members of the Earth Liberation Front, ELF, have decided to make a public statement against nuclear power by disabling the plant.Meanwhile, Frank Sheffield, a special agent in the FBI and a former acquaintance of Thorn's, is closing in on the suspected plot at Turkey Point. It appears that Sheffield has been getting information from Flynn but he has no idea that Thorn is now a part of the conspiracy. For his part, Thorn is trying to protect his son, prevent nuclear catastrophe, and keep as many people alive as possible."Going Dark" presents a considerable number of characters, some who are more fully fleshed than others, and many whose loyalties are questionable and/or change throughout the course of the novel. Just who can be trusted and whose side are many of them on?  There are double crosses, triple crosses, and a few other surprises that ratchet up the suspense and thrills in this latest thriller by Hall,  especially when one considers the consequences of a nuclear catastrophe in South Florida which would incapacitate the entire southern end of the state including Miami.All the loose threads and first and second level conspiracies come to a head in a violent confrontation at Turkey Point.  Can Thorne foil the plot against the nuclear plant while somehow shielding Flynn from harm or from a criminal conspiracy?  Can Thorne himself escape unscathed?  What happens when Thorn, the FBI,  the eco-terrorists, the inside plotters, and the back stabbers, all meet in one place at one time?  " Going Dark"  is certainly an entertaining thriller that could be pulled from today's headlines. It's a little heavy on the eco-terroism message and saving the planet philosophy, but it keeps the reader engaged. Reading some other reviews, it's clear that if you have not read any of the Thorn series in the past, you may feel a little lost as to the background of Thorn, Sugarman, and Flynn Moss. There isn't a lot of new character development in Hall's happy little family that many of us have become so fond of.I recommend this especially for Thorn fans even though I feel in this and the last several books, that our protagonist has been losing his edginess. Maybe we are supposed to accept that Thorn is now slowing down in middle-age but it certainly isn't the same Thorn who would be close to violence  anytime a friend or family member was threatened and a man of action who was always on the top of his game.  Lately he has seemed to fade into the background for long periods of time.  Admittedly, in the last two novels, he mentions being out of shape and rusty.  Let's hope that Thorn's next adventure finds him back as he edgy fly-by-the-seat of his pants avenger ready to take action on a moment's notice and certainly in shape enough to deal with weightlifting muscle bound posers.

"Discretion"  is David Balzarini's first novel. It's not a bad novel but does seem to be a novel in search of an identity. I was given a copy to read and provide an honest review without any prior knowledge except a brief plot outline.  "Discretion" aspires to be a suspense thriller, with a touch of the supernatural,  but it's basically a novel belonging in the Christian literature section.The first 70 pages read like a promising thriller.  Colin Wyle is boating with his girlfriend Natalie and his father when she disappears while he and his father nap in the boat on the lake. Where is she? How did she leave without waking them and why? Was she kidnapped? Has she drowned?  Colin and the authorities search diligently for days with no trace of Natalie. And yet suddenly it seems Colin has a new ally. He begins hearing a voice talking to him in his mind which he names Christel. The voice seems to know things about Colin's life that no one should know. Eventually the voice leads Colin and a friend to a large boat still on the lake where a gunbattle ensues, a stranger is killed, and Natalie is found down below deck. To this point, "Discretion" has kept the readers interest piqued and the suspense has been palpable."Discretion" then fast-forwards 15 years and Colin is now a highly successful  financier and is engaged to Marisa, a beautiful woman.  Colin and Natalie  inevitably went in separate directions after her kidnapping and rescue but they remain friends and in occasional contact. But from this point on, the novel focuses on the philosophical inner battle between good and evil, right versus wrong, free choice and will versus doing the right thing or the convenient thing.  Christel has made Colin into a highly successful stock trader with inside knowledge and future predictability that seems impossible for anyone to know. Who or what is Christel? Is she good or evil? Should Colin pay exclusive attention to her commands and desires? When Christel orders him to do some very questionable things, Colin is faced with exercising free will. In other words, between the philosophical musings of Balzarini and the biblical interventions of Colin's friend Jamal, the reader is hit over the head with the religious symbolism of doing the right thing versus doing something that makes us successful and happy.Indeed, the Colin in the beginning of the book is much more interesting than the Colin of 15 years later. This older Colin  is colder, more distant, and certainly more selfish and focused upon himself. Apparently, that is part of the intended lesson for the reader. Success in life without God means the person is soulless and aimless. Find God and you become a person of good and wonder again. But none of this is particularly new, but it is heavily ladled onto the reader in "Discretion"."Discretion" plays out as a private investigator hired by Colin's father to help search for Natalie when she was initially missing has continued to search for who kidnapped Natalie 15 years ago. Now he has found evidence of a criminal ring that seems to have kidnapped women to force him into sexual slavery. The FBI is also into this conspiracy at this point. However, the novel ends in a very forced and unsatisfying conclusion regarding the conspiracy and the kidnappers. The message of finding religion and finding one's own relationship with God becomes the overriding focus of the last three quarters of the book. All in all, "Discretion" is a somewhat muddled novel that does show potential for David Balzarini. As he sharpens his focus in future efforts, and ties together stronger characterizations wrapped in believable plot lines, he may have a great deal to offer.  Equally, this reader would prefer to make his own choices about the type of literature to be read with books like "Discretion" clearly labeled as Christian literature.

Most users of portable electronic devices know the quality, durability, and toughness of Otterbox protective cases.  The new "OtterBox Defender Series Case for iPad Air" is no exception.  It is impressive in its attention to detail (with the exception of missing "sleep" magnets), its sturdy polycarbonate and rubber construction, and its ability to absorb minor bumps, drops, and handling.  It comes with a protective screen shield and must be assembled which is not an inconsequential task for some.  It has a utilitarian device stand with four different working positions that are accessed by swinging out the shield stand hinge.But be advised that this is not the case for everyone.  If you enjoy the sleek looks and lightweight elements of the iPad Air, you will lose those assets once this case is installed.  It is heavy and bulky which counter the very features used to market the iPad Air.  However, if you are someone who is tough on your tablets e.g. on-the-go/ out-in-the-field workers, carrying it in and out of vehicles, young children or teens who may be rougher on devices than one desires, this is the protective case you need.  It certainly will take a lot of rough handling not possible with the unprotected iPad Air.  Be reminded, this unit does not include the magnets that put your tablet to sleep or wakes it up with closing and opening--you'll have to manually switch it off to avoid battery drainage.

"Send In The Clowns" by J. Gregory Smith is the third installment in his Detective Chang series but the first that I have read.  It is not truly an effective stand alone but a discerning reader can piece a lot of the past together from extraneous comments from the characters.  The novel is well written and edited except for the fact that it is a little long winded and the plot is sometimes labyrinthine.Paul Chang and Nelson Rogers are ex-NYPD officers now operating a PI office in Delaware who are hired by TV anchorwoman, Laura Stark, to deal with her ex-husband, Max, a former circus clown who has begun harassing her.  Max steals the book as an innovative over-the-top villain who always seems one step ahead of law enforcement and our heroes.  Chang and Nelson are promising characters and I enjoyed the interplay between their complementary skills and talents.  They are supplemented by Det. Ron Sieger, a figure out of their past adventures.While on the trail of Max, Chang and Nelson soon see their case expand as other elements including the Russian government, the Russian mob, Chechen Rebels, corrupt local governmental figures, dirty billionaires who are not what they seem, etc.  Whew!  Therein lies the novel's weakness--too much is happening at too many levels to follow logically and most of these characters are ordered right out of casting 101.  Who is the mysterious tipster that has promoted Laura's career with accurate inside information on mobsters and corrupt government?  Why is the mayor of NY brokering a truce between Russia and Chechen rebels to be memorialized in  treaty signing in the heart of NY?  What role does the local Russian mob leader Markov play in all this?  And why oh why is Max stalking Laura and tormenting Chang and Nelson?  Smith effectives ties all these threads in an out-of-control locomotive conclusion that seems both satisfying and strangely unfulfilling at the same time."Send In The Clowns" reads more like an overly wordy mystery suspense novel than an action thriller; indeed, our protagonist, Paul Chang is always reflecting on his violence seeking inner dragon who never appears until some 300 pages into the story.  All in all, I found Chang and Nelson to be intriguing enough to want to try them again and I would like more of their backstory and a bit deeper characterization.

Having read most of what Koontz has published over the years, I have remained a faithful reader throughout the changes in his stylings and novels as his work entered what I refer to as the Neo-Koontz era.  About a decade ago, Koontz' work began moving more toward spirituality, Catholic theory and moralizing about the philosophical nature of man and the world.  This era can be characterized as morality tales where goodness will always overcome malevolent evil, usually with a little help from a righteous spirit inhabiting the family dog or an innocent child. As the Neo-Koontz material develops, longtime devoted fans are usually forced to make choices between.sappy spiritually laden material often slamming you between the eyes to families in constant peril or,  very occasionally, brief glimpses of the former "master".  Certainly reading the many mixed reviews on his recent novels attest to the dichotomous split among his ardent readers as his work becomes less and less "edgy" and, often, more predictable.In "Innocence", Addison Goodheart (even the name is a signal) is a loner hiding in the underworld of subway tunnels and long forgotten underground hidey holes who must hide his appearance from everyone lest he be brutally attacked and/or killed by those repulsed by his facial features and his eyes.  He may be the sweetest character in literature to have bravely lived through parental abandonment, repulsion from mankind, and a miserable lonely existence.  During a middle of the night excursion into the city library, he meets Gwyneth, a girl who cannot stand to be touched and seemingly with as much baggage as Addison possesses.  Gwyneth seems to harbor answers but refuses to share them at critical junctures.  Thrown together amidst a worldwide breakout of the Plague (which is truly underplayed), this oddest of  couples  must bond to fight a common foe while sensing they are meant to be special to one another.  "Innocence" is at its root, a story of love in its many manifestations and the enduring character of the human spirit.For this reader, Koontz' stylings have lost the thrilling suspense and edge of your seat tension that his earlier works seemed always to generate. Now we know how the tale will end almost from the first chapter, we just have to stay on the ride to see how it gets there. For me, there was no compelling force driving me to read chapter after chapter in one sitting; indeed, one of the major weaknesses of "Innocence" is very poor pacing and the author's reluctance to get to the action at hand.  The entire book is ponderously slow to read with almost no action to move the plot.  Indeed, outside of their afflictions, Addison and Gwyneth are two dimensional characters plodding through a pedestrian plot until a somewhat hurried "surprise" ending which may or may not be its sole redeeming feature--again, it seems based on which side of Neo-Koontz one is on.

I am enjoying my "Workshop Wet/Dry Vac" immensely.  Every aspect of it seems bigger, better, or more powerful than my older model shop vac.  It has a very large drum capacity at 12 gallons and a powerful 5 HP motor.  The connecting cord is a generous 15 feet and the 2 and a half inch dual flex suction hose is 7 feet long and offers great flexibility while "locked" to the vac.  It even has onboard storage slots for the cleaning accessories (and hose) which I found very useful.The unit weighs about 19 pounds and is made of a strong plastic polymer that seems durable and dent resistant (so far).  The unit is supposedly rust proof and has a large drain for easy liquid elimination.  The "Workshop Wet/Dry Vac" is very easy to set up right out of the box (connecting casters) and includes a dry filter and waste bag which eliminates the filthy accumulation of dust and dirt that occurred in my older model vac.  I used it immediately after assembling to clean out my automobile and my garage and found it highly utilitarian.  It is loud but that should be expected with a unit this large and powerful.In summary, the extra large drum, generously long connecting cord, notable powerful suction, onboard storage slots, and a top carrying handle all combine to make this a highly recommended workshop wet/dry vacuum for many of your home cleaning needs.

"The Execution" is prolific television writer and producer Dick Wolf's second novel, both featuring NYPD detective, Jeremy Fisk.  Fisk is recovering from wounds resulting from intercepting Swedish Muslim terrorists who were sneaking into the US across the Canadian border--yes, I know it sounds screwy.  He is assigned light duty including protecting diplomats during United Nations Week in New York which will include the presidents of both Mexico and the US signing a narcoterrorism treaty.But something evil is afoot.  Twenty-three headless bodies were discovered along the US/Mexico border and just as UN Week begins, more beheaded bodies are found on Rockaway Beach in Queens.  A Hummingbird is found carved into these bodies, a symbol representing a depraved violent Mexican killer known only as Chuparosa.  Commandante Cecelia Garza, an officer in Mexico's intelligence agency, arrives in NY to protect  Mexican President Vargas while secretly hoping to find Chuparosa for personal reasons.After some initial sparring, Fisk and Garza reluctantly team up to stop an anticipated assassination which no one else deems credible.  Distrust and suspicion slowly dies between the two as potential romantic sparks begin to build; yet, there remain unspoken secrets between them that prevent romantic action.  Garza has other agendas that Fisk can only speculate upon as they close in on the mysterious Chuparosa, all the while wondering who pulls his strings.  The climax and its aftermath finally raised the thrill level for this reader as more than one secret and more than one killer is revealed.I respect and enjoy Wolf's work immensely on television and I thoroughly enjoyed "The Intercept", his first novel.  However, I felt this effort suffered from pacing problems and from a lack of in depth characterization.
