I have not been impressed with most Bluetooth headphones. The sound quality is inferior to a good wired headphone. So I wasn't expecting all that much when I received the review sample of the Air Fi Touch. I tried them on, and was immediately impressed with how comfortable they were. I held down the power button for a few seconds until the blue light came on. Holding the button down, I paired it with my portable device. I discovered quickly that sweeping my finger upward on the left ear cup increases the volume. Sweeping my finger with the down stroke on the left earcup lowers the volume. A swipe to the left starts the song over. A swipe to the right skips to the next song.I also own the $50 MEElectronics Atlas on ear headphones, and that headphone has a dynamic sound with deep bass and crisp treble, with a slightly withdrawn midrange. It's a terrific headphone for the price.This headphone is not as crisp and punchy and clear as the Atlas, and it doesn't play as loud as the Atlas, but it is more balanced. I would characterize the sound as balanced and warm and a bit veiled and gentle. The bass, the midrange, and the treble are well-behaved. The Air Fi Touch sounds more dynamic and clear when you raise the volume, it doesn't get harsh or break up like with cheaper sounding headphones.The Air Fi Touch delivers the goods when listening to Michael Jackson's Billie Jean or Robin Thicke's Blurred Lines.Country music and classical sounds good also, though those who like big bass or crisper treble might prefer the Atlas.The Bluetooth headphone impressed me with how well it sounded for the price and for being a Bluetooth headphone, so I tried plugging in the 3/5 cable that comes with it to see if it sounded better. I honestly could not tell the difference. The Air Fi Touch sounded just as well wireless as it did wired.The headphone is comfortable, but I am not sure I would recommend it if you are a janitor because as you bend over to sweep and mop and pick things up, the headphones can slide off your head.It is a much better choice for wearing while you are sitting on the train or the bus or taking a walk.The Air Fi Touch headphone will stay paired to your portable device. But you're farther ahead to keep your portable device in your pocket. If you leave your phone on the counter and wander away with the headphones on, the signal starts to cut out after about 15 or 20 feet.In my honest opinion, this Bluetooth headphone is close or equal in sound quality to the much more expensive Bose on ear wireless headphone, but not as good sounding as the Atlas or the Sennheiser Urbanite.I did get the opinion of someone else who also has the Atlas, and they felt that the Air Fi Touch headphone sounded equally good, they couldn't decide which one they liked better. So your mileage may vary.If you absolutely need a Bluetooth on ear headphone, this or the Meelectronics Air Fi Matrix 2 are your best options under $100.

Noontec has been making quality on ear headphones for several years, all of which bear a striking resemblance to the Beats Solo headphone line. The Noontec  Zoro came out first, and for around $50, it is a very good sounding, balanced headphone with good bass and a natural sounding midrange, but a cloudy sounding treble, which made the overall sound seem a tad blurry. Nevertheless, they sounded superior to the Beats Solo and Beats Solo HD in every way, which were plagued with a loose muddy, accentuated bass and a caved in sounding midrange.Next came the Noontec  Zoro HD, which had the same balanced sound profile as the Zoro (and looks identical), but the Zoro HD had better clarity and refinement. Like the difference between watching a standard definition TV and a high definition TV, the Zoro HD was just clearer and sharper. The treble was still a bit cloudy and veiled, but it was definitely better, and it punched above its price in the sound department. I preferred the Zoro HD to all the other portable on ear headphones I had, including the MEElectronics Atlas and Koss Portapro.If I could improve the Zoro HD, I would make it smoother sounding, more refined, and I would construct bigger, plusher ear cups.Enter the Noontec Zoro II HD! The build quality is better than before, it still folds up into a compact design so it can be carried in the Noontec pouch. The cable is removable. I tried using other 3/5 millimeter cables, including the VModa XS cable, and there was no difference in sound quality. The Zoro cable does great. It is flat with a push button to pause and play.It is a plastic headphone with plenty of soft leather-like material on the headband so it feels soft and comfortable on my bald head. The ear cups are bigger and plusher (!), so it not only feels more comfortable for longer listening sessions, it makes the sound richer and fuller (to my ears).The sound quality is clear, balanced, neutral, and punchy! The bass is plump and tight and extends down deep. The midrange is clear and natural, and the treble is more articulate and clear than previous Zoros. Those who want an added bit of sparkle might want to use the treble boost on their ipod or iphone or Spotify equalizer.Acoustic music with spare instrumentation makes it sound like you are there at the show! I appreciated that while listening to Neil Diamond's Hot August Night (256 mp3) on my Sansa Clip+ and while listening to George Philipp Telemann's Two Violins and a Guitar classical album.But I also rocked out to the Beatles and Led Zeppelin and Michael Jackson, and the Zoro II HD handled everything I threw at it. It is more refined than other Zoros, so you can turn it louder without the sound breaking up.I also used the Zoro II HDs with my Sony MHC G55 receiver (sounds great!!!!) and with my ipod classic and iPod touch 5th generation. It also sounds really nice with my Galaxy S4, my Sansa Clip+ and my iPad Air 2.How do these compare with the new Beats Solo 2? The Solo 2 is the best headphone I have heard from Beats, and it sounds similar to these! The Solo 2 has a more refined treble. But the Zoro II HD has better bass and mids, the Solo 2 still sounds a little loose and leaky in the bass, which adds a muffledness to the midrange. Keep in mind that the Solo 2 is $200, but the Zoro II HD is under a hundred dollars! Me personally I prefer these because of its clearer, more balanced profile.I would be quite pleased having these as my main on ear on the go phone. I think they are more balanced and stylish than any on ear phone I've heard in the $100 price range, and I even prefer them to more expensive on ears like the Sennheiser Momentum On Ear and the Sol Republic Master Tracks.To get a better on ear headphone, you would have to spend double the money or more. These are a great bang for the buck and is a very noticeable upgrade from the previous Zoro headphones. If you have the Zoro or Zoro HD, I would still definitely recommend upgrading to these.
Evans contends that Christ and his followers primarily clashed with Annas the high priest's family until 70ad, and there was a gradual parting of the ways with Judaism

A Midwest girl marries young, moves to California, becomes a famous actress, and spends most of her years trying to handle the tragedies and triumphs of life.There are heart stopping really sad moments and relief filled soaring moments.But each step of the way, you see Laura Lamonts life in pictures, both movie pictures and pictures of her life offstage and offscreen.Somehow, I was led to believe that more of the book would take place in Door County then was actually the case, but the story was still excellent. Very well done.

The 101 objects were well chosen, for they poignantly and passionately tell the story of America and its people. Fun to read. Moving and informative.The sheer bulk and size of the book may make it a better Kindle Electronic book purchase for some, but it would also make a great coffee table book. Five stars.

Assistant PI Cate Kincaid is on location at an auto warehouse where a double shooting takes place. The gunman dies and the the co-owner shoots the gunman in self-defense, but the case ends up invariably more complicated than meets the eye. Cate quickly finds herself in a complex situation requiring deeper investigation.I also like that Cate and her boyfriend are evangelical Christians who trust in God and look to Him.An absorbing read that you will want to zip through in a couple of days.

Brainwavz is known for their lauded budget audiophile over ear headphones (Brainwavz HM5) as well as their balanced and neutral in-ear headphones (the Brainwavz R3) which rival similar earphones from HiFiman. These do a great job of reproducing what is in the recording, but can sound flat to some.This particular in ear monitor is a more fun sounding earphone, with big, deep bass and detailed treble. Pop music fans will appreciate the beat and the pulse and the shimmer of Locked Out of Heaven by Bruno Mars, Party Rock by LMFAO, Jive Talkin' by the Bee Gees, and Lights by Ellie Goulding. The bass is tight and deep and propulsive without bleeding into the mids, and the highs are detailed without being shrill. The midrange is a bit recessed, and as a result, songs with acoustic guitar and breathy female vocals sound more distant and rough. The sound signature is sharp and clear, but lacks the warmth and the smoothness of the Brain Wavz R3 (but those cost more) and the Shure SE 425 (those cost MUCH more).The soundstage is fairly wide for an in ear headphone, and they isolate well, the world will not hear your music, and you will not hear the world! The cable is a thick, flat, tangle resistant, plastic material, which I prefer.If you like oldies or 70's soft rock, or something neutral where no frequency is accentuated, get the R3. If you like big bass, modern pop music, top 40, R&B or Rap, or you just want something that sounds good on the fly and is durable, get these!I should also mention the awesome, sturdy black and red carrying case and the assorted tips to fit all ear shapes and sizes. This is a great buy at the current price point.

Cate Kincaid is an evangelical Christian assistant private investigator who is just getting into her uncle's line of work and liking it. But she also has a knack for getting herself into troublesome situations, and she is blessed to have a conscientious, gentlemanly boyfriend (Mitch) to come to her rescue.Cate has learned from her semi-retired uncle Joe that everyone is a suspect, and we get to read her thoughts as she questions and queries clients and suspects alike.This case is particular troublesome because it involves more than one murder, and our young PI soon finds herself in her fair share of peril. The novel was absorbing, at times humorous, and a good followup to the first Cate Kincaid novel. Recommended.

I didn't realize how awesome this book was going to be. I bought it when it was on sale because the title seems like something that would speak to my life. It sure did. Mark talks about serving others. Using the blessings God has given you to be a blessing to the people he brings into your life.The stories are inspiring. The illustrations illustrate well. I'm going to buy multiple copies of this book and pass it around the congregation.

Plantinga makes a great argument that we not only read for preaching illustrations, but to get us in touch with the human predicament, the human experience, and parts of life we don't normally reflect about.Even if we never retell the stories we read about, they will inspire us to craft analogous analogies in our sermons. Plantinga also suggests that wide reading gives us greater wisdom and expands our vocabulary. I for one found the book to be poignant and poetic and powerful.
Get.this book. It is the Wimpy Kid of History books. Funny comics and comments about historical events. The writer occasionally tips his hand to show a slight conservative bent, but no harm no foul.

Update: The SAME DAY I posted this review, the review unit died. It just turned off and stopped working.I received a 16800 mah version of this at no cost in exchange for writing a review. Here are my comments.This is a bulky, but terrific power bank. It has enough juice to charge an iPhone 8 or 9 times and a Samsung Galaxy S4 six times. It charges my phones as fast as a 2.1 wall charger. It takes about 2 hours and 20 minutes to charge my phones from 0-100%. You can even charge two phones at the same time! Very handy!I rubberband my phone and my power bank together and I use four inch micro usb and lightning cables to charge my phones.It takes about 20 hours to recharge the power bank from empty to full. That's the only downside. You can charge a phone while the device itself is recharging, but it slows things down alot and heats the device up.I highly recommend this device.

Dr Beale does a nice job expounding and applying 1 and 2 Thessalonians. This is a good commentary to be used in conjunction with a more significant and academic exegetical work like Gene Green's commentary or the soon to be released tome by Jeffrey Weima in the BECNT.There is not much information about Thessalonica and Macedonia in the introduction, and on occasion, the amount of application oriented material outweighs the exegetical and expositional.But generally speaking, Beale's applications are more on target and accurate than many other application oriented commentaries. That was very impressive to me.Not everyone will subscribe to all of Beale's views, some of which are novel (The temple in 2 Thessalonians 2:4 is a spiritual image for the church, the restrainer in verses 6-7 is an angel, the rapture is posstrib).But these points aside, I found the commentary to be very helpful for preaching preparation.

I had Dr. Hamby as a professor almost 30 years ago. He was a very interesting lecturer, able to speak off-the-cuff with no notes. This command of American history can be seen in this book.The only reason why I didn't give it five stars is because it needs an editor badly. Run-on sentences conclude many sections, cut lines appear without pictures, and the quality of the text font varies from page to page.But I still found the book enjoyable, and I actually have recall of some of the notes I wrote in class that were reemphasized in this book. A trip down memory lane for me.

James Macdonald challenges churches to pray and prepare for God's glory to fill their houses. We don't want people to be impressed by our winsome ways, but to be floored and transformed by the glory of God.
We're all aliens in this messed up world, and we find community and home by helping each other out. That's what the Bean Trees means to me. It's a great story.

Bruce's book provides fantastic coverage of the Apostle's Paul's life and thought. He discusses Paul's Jewish background in Tarsus, his zealous Pharasaism, his conversion from unbelief to Christ, and his missionary journeys and theology. Bruce is a reliable guide as he takes you through the narratives in Acts and the supplementary material in the epistles. He is open to all of the Pauline corpus being authentic writings of Paul, and even if someone else had a hand with Ephesians, (Bruce is not convinced), then that someone else did a great job representing Pauline thought.I especially enjoyed the discussions of the Corinthian correspondence (Paul's teaching about marriage in 1 Corinthians 7 in particular, I found it to be very pastoral and sensible) and the proposition that the Onesimus in Philemon went on to become bishop of Ephesus years later.Bruce believes that the heart of Pauline teaching is that true religion is not a matter of rules and regulations, that Christ makes us all one in Him, that people matter more than things, principles, and causes (not sure about this one, I would want to qualify it), and that unfair discrimination against others is an offense to God. I think the first two points are the strongest.One of the most INTERESTING books on Paul I have ever read. Bruce is like an investigative reporter, digging into the New Testament documents and historical sources to present the clearest picture of Paul. Highly recommended.
This book inspired and equipped me to do a better and more intentional job of sharing my faith. I will be referring back to it for months and maybe years.

Explains what's wrong with the world, how it got this way, and how faith in Christ can transform people and inspire them to transform culture. Loved the chapters showing how design and the intricacies of DNA point to an intelligent and intentional origin to life rather than naturalistic chance.

Thiselton does a great job of sketching Paul's life and surveying his thought. He rightfully sees the heart of Paul's Christopogy within an apocalyptic framework. Not everyone will agree or subscribe to his view that Israel in Romans nine through eleven refers to the church rather than ethnic Israel, but there are many solid insights here. Borrowing from J.A.T Robinson, he sees the career of Christ in Paul's writings as the exact reverse of Adam's career, a point I had not considered before.He also observes that James 2 is not a contradiction ofPaul's teaching about justification by faith, it is a correction of the abuse of that teaching.A quick read and strongly recommended.

Roger Olson is a reliable guide as he navigates us through 2000 years of Christian thought. He discusses the frontline important people as well as those who are in the shadows of Christian history. Surprisingly, Olson does not talk about charismatic Pentecostal theology or the theology of the third wave of the Spirit, nor is there any discussion about the burgeoning open theism perspective.But what is here is enjoyable, readable, and essential. Highly recommended.

Grief and pain do not have to be the end of the story. Your life is still unwritten, there is more to say. God still has stuff for you to do. That's what the main characters learn in Charles Martin's latest novel. As usual, his writing is rich and evocative and his characters are complex. The narrative doesn't always move as fast as I would prefer, but there is no denying the power of the story. Another winner from Martin.

This is the cheapest portable cell phone charger I have ever received, so I was dubious about its performance. But in a little less than two hours it will charge your phone from 20%, and in three hours from 0%. It is portable. It is reliable. It is efficient.I am not exactly sure how long it takes to charge it up at home, but I usually leave it on for the nighttime hours and it is good to go in the morning.My wife took this from me so I will have to buy another one :-) highly recommended.

Dr. Plummer gives clear (and sometimes humorous) answers about how to read and interpret the Scriptures. He covers the different types of literature in the Bible, the importance of reading the surrounding context, and the blessing of getting good Bible study tools.But his ultimate goal is to get the reader of his book to read the text and discover how awesome it is.

This is a general overview of clergy roles and practices in American life. It discusses clergy attitudes toward their jobs, their diverse responsibilities, and their perception by others in America through the centuries.The book begins at the time of the Pilgrims and concludes in the year 2005. I wish more attention would have been given to the towering figures in clergy history, as well as more attention to the preaching styles of prominent clergy, but this is a minor quibble. It can be read in conjunction with books on the history of preaching, like David Larsen's outstanding tome.

Kruger contends that the New Testament books are self authenticating. Their origins with the apostolic community, their wide acceptance, divine beauty, eye witness testimony and prophetic accuracy bear witness to their divine authority.the collecting of these books into codices are evidence as to the books which found favor with the churches.A great book.

The world is ruled by a warring totalitarian regime that outlaws reading and the spreading of knowledge, but the sad thing is that people stopped growing and learning on their own long before.Guy Montag is a firefighter who is hired to burn books, but one day, after seeing how the government deals with free thinking people, he just can't do it anymore.Many of the professorial drifters in the Fahrenheit 451 world are like the folks of today who cherish free thought and expression and reading, they are alone.

This was a great book. Billy Graham is 93 years old and getting ready to go to be with the Lord, and he shows us how we can prepare for our own post-retirement years in heaven. He says we should stay active for the Lord wherever we are, whether it's our retirement home or in a nursing home. We can devote our time to praying for others, to volunteering at a rehabilitation center, or writing letters of encouragement.He also says we need to come to grips with the reality that we can't do the things we could do years earlier, and to concentrate on what we can do. He says that even though exercise has some value and we should take care of the bodies God has given us, we're still going to get old, and we need to accept certain limitations.He stresses the importance of continuing to grow in the grace and knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ, reading Scripture and sharing His love with others.He also says we should have a clearly outlined will so that there will be no family feuding after our departure. Be looking to God in prayer and blessing others around us, we forget about our problems and model for others how to age with grace.This is a book you can read in a few hours, but it will stay with you for the rest of your life. Great book!

I expected more discussion of the books themselves, but what we get from this book is a heartwarming tale of a father and a daughter who make a reading promise. The dad reads to his daughter at least one chapter a night, no matter what, for 100 days. Then when they hit 100, they decided to try for a thousand. The reading streak continues until the daughter goes to college. The narrative of the last night of the streak where the dad reads to Alice on the stairwell of her dormitory is very touching.Alice loves the Frank L Baum Wizard of Oz books, and the Lewis Carroll Alice in Wonderland books especially, but she becomes a lover of books in general. Her father is a library, and he takes it hard when the school library where he works gets rid of all the books in favor of making room for more computers.Both father and daughter struggle to fill the gap in their lives following the end of the Streak, but they continue to maintain their love for reading. Recommended for lovers of reading.

Room is about a nineteen-year-old college student who has been kept as a prisoner in a barred-up garden shed for seven years.  The room has a hot plate and a sink, a toilet and a television.  Her captor brings her enough food to survive (mostly canned food and junk food), disciplines her by cutting off electricity and heat, and rapes her several times a week.  She conceives and gives birth to a son she calls Jack, and Room is told from his perspective, which takes a bit of getting used to, because Jack is only five years old, and he doesn't understand figures of speech, or that he is a prisoner, or that there is a whole world outside of the room he's lived in his whole life.His mother does everything she can to bury her anguish and to make life as normal as she can for Jack.  They watch Dora the Explorer on television, they play ball together (the ball is a bag stuffed with paper), and "Ma" even reads the stories of Jesus to him.Slowly as the weeks go by, Ma tells Jack about the outside world and that this is where she wants to return.  Together, they attempt to escape from the dreary shed.  The suspense is tremendous, and the book is hard to put down.The broad theme of the book is about coping and learning to survive with extremely trying circumstances.  Jack's mother is an extraordinary person who copes with life as a captive while trying to make her son's life as stress free as she can, while Jack must later learn to cope with life in a world he knows next to nothing about.  This theme should resonate with the Christian community, for we too must cope with trying circumstances (even if they are less harsh than the ones Jack and his mother face).  Like Jack and his mother, we too have the stories of Jesus to inspire us and give us strength.  This book definitely touches on issues that matter to parishioners and can be a preacher's source for illustrative material.

The first volume dealt with the individual theologizing and ethicizing of Paul, Peter, Matthew, Mark, Luke, John, and others (Witherington 2009).  Witherington's goal for the second volume is to allow the New Testament writers to articulate their own synthesis of material from Jesus and the Hebrew Scriptures (Witherington 2010, 29).  He presents the theology of Jesus and then announces, "I will consider how the various New Testament writers add to, or reinforce, or delete from such a discussion.  I will follow the same procedure with the issue of the ethic of Jesus and then of the New Testament writers" (Witherington 2010, 29-30).After some preliminary considerations, Witherington discusses the symbolic universe of Jesus and the New Testament writers in chapter two, a storied universe that speaks of God, Jesus, the cross, substitutionary sacrifice, sin, the risen Lord, new/true people of God, the Spirit, and spiritual gifts (Witherington 2010, 60-82).  He contends that the New Testament contributors shared this symbolic worldview because they each drew from and relied on the Hebrew Scriptures (Witherington 2010, 82).  As an example, Witherington lists ninety-one examples where New Testament writers and personalities drew from the Psalms for authority (Witherington 2010, 82-89).Chapter three discusses the narrative thought world of Jesus and the New Testament writers.  Jesus presents Himself as the Danielic Son of Man who tells stories of His own making, but refers to the stories of Adam, Solomon, Noah, and other Old Testament luminaries.  His stories have a dark edge, noting the lost condition of His own people (Luke 15) and their danger of experiencing judgment (Matthew 11).Paul's storied world is also rooted in the Old Testament, and his Christological hymns recall wisdom psalms such as Psalm 1 and Psalm 119, as well as the non-canonical Wisdom of Solomon (Witherington 2010, 118).  After discussing the thought worlds of the other New Testament contributors, Witherington concludes, "Monotheistic, messianic, eschatological thinking characterized the thought world of all these early Jews.  They believed they lived in the age of the fulfillment of prophecy, the climax of history, the arrival of final redemption, and judgment that would begin with the household of God" (Witherington 2010, 201).The next few chapters examine what can be said about a shared set of beliefs when it comes to New Testament theology.  Christ Himself is the basis of New Testament thought, so Witherington begins with what the writers say about Him.  Paul sees Christ as "Lord," the true emperor of the world, the anointed one who died for the sins of the world and rose again, the true Israel who comes to save a world gone wrong (Witherington 2010, 213-18).  There is also a discussion of Christ as "God" in the Pauline letters.  He discusses Phil 2:6-7 and Rom 9:5 and Titus 2;13, concluding that Paul does attribute divine status to Christ (Witherington 2010, 218-23).  Witherington shows that Paul taught the essential humanity of Christ in passages such as Rom 5:15 and 1 Tim 2:5 (Witherington 2010,223-28).Witherington also shows that Hebrews shares with Paul a high view of Christ and a belief in the penal substitutionary death of Jesus in passages such as Rom 3:25 and Hebrews 9:14 (Witherington 2010, 233-45).  We see the same theme in 1 Peter, Mark and in Revelation.  His conclusion is that we do not need to talk about dueling Christologies in early Christianity, but rather a kaleidoscope of images and storylines that could be applied to Him (Witherington, 2010, 245).The remaining chapters demonstrate that the New Testament writers were not only on the same page with regard to seeing Jesus as Christ, risen Lord, God, and atoning sacrifice, but they also agreed that believing and behaving go together.  Divine action demands a human response (Witherington 2010, 735).  This sums up the 1700 pages of both Indelible Image volumes (Witherington 2010, 735).In a way, this book answers some of the questions raised by Carson's Collected Writings on Scripture (Carson 2010).  The researcher felt that much of Carson's argumentation was convoluted and circular in reasoning, while Witherington shows clearly from Scripture that there can be a collective theology of the New Testament.This book gives the researcher a fortified theological base to draw from when preaching through the New Testament.  It will provide food for thought when preaching about the substitutionary death of Christ, the deity of Christ, and the Christological hymns of Paul.  The biggest preaching point is that believing and behaving go hand in hand; you can't have one without the other.  There are a number of people in the parish who think that because they walked down an aisle or raised their hand or took communion that they are automatically saved regardless of how they live their lives.  But Witherington reminds us that faith without works is dead (Jas 2:17).

Foner's purpose is to trace the evolution of Lincoln's ideas in the context of the broad antislavery movement (Foner 2010, xii-xvii).  He states from the outset that Lincoln was antislavery, but he was not an abolitionist and never claimed to be one (Foner 2010, xii-xvii).  His personal wish was that men everywhere could be free, but he was also a legislator and later a President who recognized the South's right to own slaves (Foner 2010, xii-xvii).Lincoln's own antislavery views evolved through the years.  In 1849, Lincoln (anxious for a job in the Zachary Taylor administration) proposed a plan for all slave children born in the District of Columbia after January 1, 1850, to labor as "apprentices" for their owners "until they reached adulthood, when they would become free" (Foner 2010, 57).  Later as President, he proposed a number of plans for "gradual, compensated emancipation" (Foner 2010, 57).It wasn't until January 1, 1863, when he issued the Emancipation Proclamation, that Lincoln would take a different tack.  As late as the summer of 1862, he was worried that if he issued a general emancipation "half the army would lay down their arms and three other states would join the rebellion" (Foner 2010, 210).  He was quoted in the press as saying, "I would save the union.  I would save it in the shortest way under the Constitution .... My paramount object in this struggle is to save the Union, and it is not either to save or to destroy slavery.  If I could save the Union without freeing any slave I would do it, and if I could save it by freeing all the slaves I would do that" (Foner 2010, 227).In the end, he chose to take the path of general emancipation.  On January 1, 1863, late in the afternoon, he went to his office to sign the Proclamation, which said that all the slaves in the areas to which it applied--over three million men, women, and children "are and henceforth shall be free" (Foner 2010, 240).  The proclamation only had bearing on the slaves in the Confederate states.  There was no way at the time to enforce the Proclamation in the South, but then again, the Emancipation Proclamation was a political document more than anything else, and it signaled Lincoln's determination to end slavery without compensating slave owners (Foner 2010, 240-43).  More significantly, it altered the nature of the Civil War, the relationship of the government to slavery, and the course of American history (Foner 2010, 244).  Foner concludes, "Lincoln did not enter the White House expecting to preside over the destruction of slavery.  A powerful combination of events, as we have seen, propelled him down the road to emancipation and then to a reconsideration of the place blacks would occupy in a post-slavery America" (Foner 2010, 335).Signing the Emancipation took a lot of guts.  Lincoln's hand was shaking from exhaustion when he picked up his pen, so he laid it down.  He took a moment and said, "I do not want to appear as if I hesitated."  Then he picked up his pen again and signed the proclamation (Foner 2010, 239).Having the courage to do what is right is an issue that matters to people in the pew.  Having the guts to stand by your convictions in a tumultuous world is something we applaud and admire.  The signing of the Emancipation Proclamation will make a great sermon illustration, as will a number of other stories from the life of Lincoln.But we also at times see Lincoln's weakness, his willingness to say what is politically expedient in order to save political face.  We see his humanity, his desire to please his base. We see Lincoln as a conflicted man. I appreciated the author's mostly nonbiased portrait of the 16th President.

This book is written for anyone wanting to know more about the Bible, Christianity and "the God who is there."  Carson runs through the Bible in fourteen chapters, and each one focuses on one or more passages from the Scriptures, unpacks it, and "tries to build connections with the context, drawing the lines together to show how they converge in Jesus" (Carson 2010b, 5).  Each chapter tells the reader something special about the God who is there.The first chapter is an exposition of Genesis 1-3.  Carson says that even if you believe that the universe was created by a big bang fifteen million years ago, "sooner or later you are forced to ask the question, "Where did that highly condensed material come from" (Carson 2010b, 11)?  These chapters in Genesis tell us that God exists, He made everything, there is only one of Him, and He is a talking God (Carson 2010b, 14-15).  These chapters also tell us that we are made in His image, we were made male and female, and we were made well (Carson 2010b, 21-22).Chapter two is called "The God Who Does Not Wipe Out Rebels."  It is a discussion of Genesis 3.  Carson's careful exposition shows that people willfully rebelled against God, and that we need to be saved and reconciled to Him more than anything else (Carson 2010b, 37-38).Chapter three is called "The God Who Writes His Own Agreements," and here is where Carson examines Genesis 12, 15, 17, and 22 and shows that even though Abraham sinned and Isaac was a wimp and Jacob a trickster, the God who is there makes and keeps His promises (Carson 2010b, 47-49).Carson's discussion in chapter four is about "The God Who Legislates."  He looks at the Ten Commandments in Exodus 20, and also at Exodus 32-34 and concludes that the giving of the law was an act of compassion and grace and with the sacrificial system, it points the way to Jesus (Carson 2010b, 64-65).The next chapter is called "The God Who Reigns," which is a discussion of the line of Davidic kings which lead the way to Jesus, the greatest King of all (Carson 2010b, 67-79).Chapter six is called "The God Who is Unfathomably Wise."  Carson takes the reader through the Psalms, where the God who is there makes His people sing in thanksgiving, contrition, lament, and reflection (Carson 2010b, 92), and he also zips through Proverbs, Job, and Ecclesiastes, where more lessons are shared with God's people.In chapter seven, Carson discusses "The God Who Became a Human Being."  He looks at some of the great messianic prophecies of the Old Testament (including Isaiah 53), and also at Matthew 1 and John 1.  He became a human being to show us the Father and to be the meeting place between sinners and the Father (Carson 2010b, 114-15).Chapter eight is called "The God Who Grants New Birth," which naturally leads to an exposition of John 3:1-15.  We receive new life, or new birth, by believing in Christ (Carson 2010b, 130).Chapter nine is a discussion about "The God Who Loves."  Carson looks at John 3:16-21.  He says that the measure of God's love is Jesus, and the purpose of His love is that we might have life (Carson 2010b, 135-42), and the way to experience this life is through faith in Him.Carson goes on in chapter ten to discuss "The God Who Dies--and Lives Again."  There is an exposition of pertinent passages in Matthew's Gospel, noting that the man who is mocked as king is King" (Carson 2010b, 149).  He also observes that the One who is utterly powerless is transcendently powerful (Carson 2010b, 151), and that the One who can't save Himself saves others (Carson 2010b, 153), and that the One who was dead lives again, inspiring us to say to Him "My Lord and my God" (Carson 2010b, 162).Chapter eleven discloses "The God Who Declares the Guilty Just," and goes into an exposition of Romans 3-4.  This encourages a response of faith (Carson 2010b, 180).  Chapter twelve introduces a discussion of "The God Who Gathers and Transforms His People."  There are expositions of Eph 2:1-22 and Ephesians 4-5 which demonstrate that God is at work making His people more like Jesus (Carson 2010b, 181-96).Carson converses in chapter thirteen about "The God Who is Very Angry."  He focuses on Rev 14:6-20 and shows that there is a place called Hell where the wicked are tormented forever and ever.  They do not want to be there, but neither do they want to bend the knee to Jesus (Carson 2010b, 206).  We must warn the people we love that there is such a place for those who refuse the love of Christ (Carson 2010b, 206).The closing chapter is called "The God Who Triumphs."  Carson expounds Revelation 21-22 and shows that God's glory will be manifested "in the church, in the new Jerusalem" (Carson 2010b, 215).This is one of Carson's best and most accessible books, even more helpful than his collected writings on Scripture discussed earlier.  Each chapter contains tasty chunks of expositional meat ready to be passed on to the people, and so this book will be consulted again for sermonic insights. o

The silk side of the pillow is very comfortable. I never use the cotton side, its just not as nice. The cotton side is likely just to keep the cost down since their pillowcases that are silk on both sides are more expensive. i love the zipper, I toss and turn and my other pillowcases tend to fall halfway off. This pillow case completely wraps your pillow and the zipper secures it. The silk is very quality and you can easily tell the difference between this and he sateen knock-offs you can find at the big box stores.The downside is... its just one pillowcase. So you have to buy a few to cover all of your pillows, that makes these a bit more expensive.[I received this product for he purposes of an honest review]

As you can guess this product is a giant block of salt. I got one of these to try some creative things with cooking and there are several things I wish I understood beforehand. Cooking on a salt block requires much more prep time and clean up. There are 3 uses for salt blocks: presentation, cooking, and chilling.Presentation block: Salt blocks look cool. its pink and marbled and when you serve your guests on a salt block people will be impressed. Its a conversation piece. and food you serve on it will pick up a very small amount of the salt from sitting on it. If you plan to use the block as a presentation block, don't cook on it. once you heat the block up you lose much of the pink color, you'll get cracks, and by cooking food on it it will darken he surface. Best just to have a separate presentation/serving block.Chilling block: Pop this block in the fridge for a few hours to let it get nice and cold and you can use it for deserts! Pour chocolate on it and when the chocolate hardens you can break off nicely salted chocolate pieces. Or it works great on fruits and cheeses. It takes about an hour or longer in fridge to get it sufficiently cold.Cooking block: This is what most use the block for. WORD OF CAUTION.... Do not heat these up too fast or they can explode! You want to heat gradually, increasing temperature every 15 minutes until its hot enough. These can withstand temps of over 500 degrees. You can cook on a grill, stove or oven (I wouldn't use in gas oven though, salt absorbing moisture in oven can be a problem). You can cook food on the block or under the block (i.e. chicken on a grill with block on top of chicken. weight of the block presses on the meat infusing salt and flavor).Cleaning: After you cook on these you want to wait until its back to room temperature before cleaning the block. This can take a few hours to get cool again. You don't want to rush this since rapid temperature fluctuations can cause it to crack. Use water and a brush to scrape off food bits. Don't use soap for obvious reasons. Also when your cooking on these, you might make a huge mess! if you cook juicy items or too close to the edge that grease or juices will just run right off the block!I would recommend getting a salt block guide or cookbook to learn all the ways to use these blocks. Mark Bitterman makes a good one, that helped me learn proper way to use the block. Have fun cooking with these!

This took me a few tries to figure it out, not exactly the most intuitive device. Out of the box you get the main DVR unit, some USB cables, a mount bracket (suction cup), a car charger and an instruction booklet. The device is smaller than it seems in the pictures which is great since it doesn't take up a large amount of your windshield (don't want it obstructing your vision). The device easily fits into the windshield mount and you stick it on the windshield (suction cup style) and then you twist a small knob to lock it and it won't fall off. The battery life isn't good so you need this plugged in pretty much the whole time your using it. The USB cable plus in at the top which leaves you with an unsightly wire hanging down to your car charger.A micro SD card is required for recording. As soon as you turn this on it starts recording if a card is in. The unit asked me if I wanted to format the card and I opted not to and it worked fine. The recordings continuously make small video files and when the card fills up it deletes the older files with new ones. Video and audio quality is better than I expected. The unit can play back video or you can plug an HDMI cable in (or take SD card out and watch on a computer). You can also take still pictures with the device as well (button on top right).This would come in handy if you're ever in a car accident.[I received this product for the purposes of an honest review]

Step up your beer game! Honestly these really aren't going to make your beer taste that much better, that's mostly the brewmasters job. However, these are nice glasses and they do add to your beer experience. The stem keeps your hand from warming up your beer, and the bell shape can help release aroma, while the lip of the glass gives a nice amount of head (foam).The glasses are fairly thin so you want to be careful with them. They can be washed in dishwasher but I would handwash them. They are fragile and residue from dishwasher can affect taste of beer.I'm too old to drink beer out of a red solo cup. I have a set of these as well as more traditional pint glasses. I drink IPAs and more "hoppy" beers out of these TeKu glasses, and less hoppy beers out of pint glasses.

I got this bottle opener a few months ago and it works great. The resealing option is perfect since my girlfriend often doesn't finishes beers. Also sometimes craft brewers only sell certain beers in bombers (the large 22oz) and you can't always finish off those high ABV%. Resealing keeps your beer fresh and carbonated for another day, maybe two, but I wouldn't keep it any longer than that.The 3 in 1 refers to: Bottle Opener, twist/screw cap opener, and re-sealer

I got this bottle opener a few months ago and it works great. The resealing option is perfect since my girlfriend often doesn't finishes beers. Also sometimes craft brewers only sell certain beers in bombers (the large 22oz) and you can't always finish off those high ABV%. Resealing keeps your beer fresh and carbonated for another day, maybe two, but I wouldn't keep it any longer than that.The 3 in 1 refers to: Bottle Opener, twist/screw cap opener, and re-sealer

So I'm not a professional photographer or anything like that. But like most people I take a bunch of pictures with my cell phone. This set of lenses are great for taking pictures when I go out of town and am likely to take more pictures.Out of the box you get 2 phone clips, the lenses, and a small bag to carry them in. Having 2 clips allows you to snap them on and off pretty quickly. I tried them on both my front camera and back camera on two different phones (Samsung Galaxy S4 and LG G3). This should fit just about any smartphone since you can slide the lens along the clip to get the fit right. One thing that did bother me with the clip is that after a few uses the small cushion on the inside of he clip started to come off and that left adhesive gunk on my phone (easily wiped off but still an annoyance). If you use a thick phone case this will not fit (i.e. otterbox cases are too big). In fact most cases are probably too big. you would need a fairly slim case to allow this to fit, or just go without the case.On to the lenses! So most important thing about this review should be what kind of pics can you can take.FISH EYE LENS: Tried out this lens first, because well fish eye stuff is fun. The fish eye lens is a wide angle lens so you can get more in the pic than without it. The lens also sortof creates a curved shape to the pics (center bulges out). You can see from my attached pics of the football game that the fish eye captures more of the stadium while the pic without the lens looks closer (both pics taken at same spot seconds apart). The closer you are to your subject the greater he fish eye effect.WIDE ANGLE LENS / MACRO LENS: The wide angle lens and the macro lens are connected together. You can unscrew them to get the different lens effects. The Macro Lens is for super close-ups, and I mean really close up. You need to be right up on your subject or else the lens will make things blurry. Its great to get fine details in your pic.Overall these aren't professional quality but your also not paying professional prices or using a professional camera. Excellent value for the price. you can get alot of usefulness out of these.[I received this product for the purposes of an honest review]

So..... these are not dishwasher safe. I washed in a dishwasher 1 time (other washes were hand washed) and the words "Winter is Coming" were completed gone and the direwolf sigil is very faded.When brand new this was a great pint glass. I bought it at Comicon and I would drink my favorite beer from it every Sunday when watching GoT. Also goes great with Ommegang Brewery's Iron Throne beer if you can get that in your area!This is a good item, I just wish it were more durable. If you get these just make sure to hand wash it or else the print and sigil will fade away like the rest of our favorite Starks :(UPDATE: I added pics so you can see how the letters are completely gone and the wolf has faded quite a bit.

This set comes with 48 chalkboard styles labels and 1 "liquid chalk" pen. I used these to label plastic containers in my kitchen and they work great and look nice. I have a little difficulty peeling the labels off the sheet sometimes, but that's a minor issue. The pen looks like a felt tip pen, and it looks like chalk when you write on the labels. The product descriptions says 8 colors, but all you get is one white pen. Any other color must be sold separately.[I received this product for the purposes of an honest review]

For starters most USB cables are pretty much standardized in terms of fit and performance (the "U" in USB does stand for Universal after-all). So these perform exactly the same as any other USB 2.0 cable. They will fit just about any device that uses micro USB ports (just about any android tablet or smartphone, most cameras etc). So I just typed a bunch of words describing this as the same as any other cable, why did I give it 5 stars?DURABILITY: These are far more durable than the standard cheap USB cables the come with smartphones and tablets (and other devices). Typically the cables used to charge your smartphones and tablets are after-thoughts by the manufacturers and they usually use a cheap plastic or rubber to coat their cables to save costs. These cables are braided nylon and you can feel the difference in quality. My Samsung and Motorola cables usually get twisted near the connectors and over time the rubber separates and tears exposing the wires beneath, I do not have that problem with these.LENGTH: These are more than 6 feet long! That is big for me since my bedroom outlet is behind the headboard of my bed and I need a sufficiently long cable to reach my nightstand. Also most people tend to have outlets behind furniture, so it is a big plus to have a cord 6 feet or longer.COLOR: you get 4 fun colors. I don't really care about this as much but others might.[I received this product for the purposes of an honest review. I only post reviews after I have personally used and tested the product]

First thing I noticed with this is the solid build. Materials are sleek and sturdy, looks like it can withstand drops and scratches. The device is small, but fits well in my hand, good size for one hand use and it fits in pocket. Rec button is big red button on front, the other buttons are smaller and on the sides. There is a little red light at the top that lets you know its recording. It wasn't exactly intuitive to use at first. I needed to quick read instructions before I got it down. There is a 2 second delay before recording starts or before recording stops (saves).  Sound quality is pretty good. Out of the box this comes with the device itself, instructions, a mini USB charging cable, and a set of earbuds.This works well when I am recording at office meetings. Files can easily be transferred to computer using the provided mini USB cable (works on both mac and pc). So far I've had no problems with it. Other than the delay when you press or hold buttons, its pretty easy to use.[I received this product for the purposes of an honest review]

Not sure what else I can add that the other 10,000 reviews haven't mentioned already. I loved this book. I usually don't like science fiction because in my mind I'm always thinking "that wouldn't happen!". I have a hard time suspending my disbelief. However this book puts the science back into science fiction (I know thats cliche). The author has science back up every way that the protagonist survives. Whenever a concept or tool seemed made-up, I would do a quick google search and realize its a real thing (oxygenator, hydrazine, etc). And the book doesnt get bogged down in the math and science either.Beyond the science stuff its a good story of how the protagonist survives against all odds after being stranded on Mars. The characters wit and humor mixed in with so many set backs and problems keep you engaged as you wonder how he is going to get out of this mess. This was a really fun read. I give it 4.5 stars but since I can't do half stars I'll round it up to 5

This is a pretty nice backpack that can fold into a small pouch for easy storage and travel. The backpack has two mesh side pockets for water bottles, and a small zip pocket in the front for smaller items. The backpack can hold the same amount of materials a traditional backpack would hold, however the material is noticeably thinner than the canvas you find in most backpacks and there isn't a reinforced bottom, so if your carrying around lead weights or something i'm not sure the thin material will hold up.Folding the bag up is a breeze. I thought there might be a structured way to do it, but all you reall have to do is stuff the bag into the attached pouch from the inside out. Very simple. Once in the pouch its much easier to carry around. If your like me and come back from vacation with more stuff than you left with, this bag can be easily packed into luggage then filled with souvenirs on your return trip.No complaints this far.[I received this product for the purposes of an honest review]

What your getting here is 2 double walled glasses, 9 whiskey stones, and a small velvet bag to hold the stones. The glasses are larger than normal (probably a result of the double lining). The double wall prevents condensation from forming on the outside of the glass and keeps the drink colder longer. The whiskey stones allow you to chill your drink without watering it down with ice. Just put the stones in the freezer and place in your drink when ready. I actually do not use the velvet bag since the fuzz comes off on the stones. I jsut wash the stones and put them in a plastic bag in the freezer.Only downsides are the size, bigger in both width and height than your average tumbler but its not a big issue.[I received this product for the purposes of an honest review]

This is a great bar starter kit. It has everything you need to make cocktails (except alcohol and ingredients of course!). It all comes in a neat little package that makes this perfect for gifts. In the box you get 1 stainless steel shaker, a mixing glass, 25ml Measure, 50ml Measure, 25ml/50 ml jigger (measures out the alcohol), a Hawthorn Strainer (filters out the ice when you pour into serving glass), muddler (used to mash fruits and herbs to release their flavor) and bar spoon with masher.Only downside is that I wish it came with some cocktail recipes. The box did include a card with a URL to some recipes on the internet. And a quick google search can find tons of recipes easily, so its not a big problem.[I received this product for the purposes of an honest review]

This is a pretty nice ipad keyboard case for the ipad2/3/4. Installation was pretty easy. My Ipad 2 clicked right in and fit perfectly. From there you just turn the keyboard on (may need to charge it first), press the connect button and then find the keyboard case under the bluetooth settings on the Ipad. The thing I like most about this case is that they keys are hard keys like on a laptop. My previous keyboard case had soft rubber keys. The hard plastic case provides good protection as well. The case can swivel to use landscape view or portrait view of ipad. The case also comes with a USB cable to use when charging the device. Only drawback is that the case is a little larger/bulkier than my previous caseI have had no problems with this case. I recommend for anyone who is looking for a bluetooth keyboard for their ipad.[I received this product for the purposes of an honest review]

My PS4 gets pretty hot since it is on nearly all the time (games, Hulu, Netflix, etc). This product is perfect for me. The stand fits the PS4 perfectly and plugs into the USB port on the front of the PS4. The stand can charge 2 controllers simultaneously. There are also additional USB ports on the front of the stand. This comes in handy for me because I use a USB keyboard when I play an MMORPG on the PS4, which means previously I could only plug in one controller. The box it comes in is pretty plain and there are no instructions. But its pretty easy to figure out.Now my PS4 isn't in danger of overheating and I have extra USB slots and charging capability. This is not a need for everyone and casual users probably won't need this at all. But if you use your PS4 5 or more hours per day, I would recommend this product.Update: It seems there is a limit to how many things can be plugged into the PS4 at one time. I had 2 controllers charging, a usb keyboard, and a mouse plugged in and my PS4 displayed a message telling me to unplug some of the devices.

My PS4 gets pretty hot since it is on nearly all the time (games, Hulu, Netflix, etc). This product is perfect for me. The stand fits the PS4 perfectly and plugs into the USB port on the front of the PS4. The stand can charge 2 controllers simultaneously. There are also 3 additional USB ports on the front of the stand. This comes in handy for me because I use a USB keyboard when I play an MMORPG on the PS4, which means previously I could only plug in one controller. The fans aren't too loud and I usually can't hear them over the sound of my gameplay/movies. There is an on/o switch on the front, but if you plug it into the PS4 it turns off when you turn the PS4 off. The one downside to that is that if you keep your PS4 in "rest mode" like I do then you actually have to press the button to turn it off otherwise the fan just keeps going. The angular design matches the look and feel of the PS4. The box it comes in is pretty plain and there are no instructions. But its pretty easy to figure out.Now my PS4 isn't in danger of overheating and I have extra USB slots and charging capability. This is not a need for everyone and casual users probably won't need this at all. But if you use your PS4 5 or more hours per day, I would recommend this product.Update: It seems there is a limit to how many things can be plugged into the PS4 at one time. I had 2 controllers charging, a usb keyboard, and a mouse plugged in and my PS4 displayed a message telling me to unplug some of the devices.[I received this product for the purposes of an honest review]

This is a set of 2 16oz copper mugs, perfect for Moscow Mules or any drink really. These are made of stainless steel coated with copper. There is no nickel lining unlike several other copper mugs (stay away from nickel lined mugs since the lining wears off over time and gets into your drink). These are really nice to look at and even display. The copper is a good conductor of heat so your cold drinks stay colder longer. The handle does conduct temperature as well so be careful with hot drinks. These are inexpensive and make great gifts. The box even has the recipe for making Moscow Mules (vodka, ginger beer and lime, over ice)Everyone knows that you do Moscow Mules without a copper mug! Honestly all these really do is keep drink colder, and traditionally the drink is served in copper mug, so you'd be following tradition. There is no difference in taste whether your vodka and ginger beer is in a copper mug or in a styrophone cup (if you could taste the copper that would probably be a bad thing). Don't be that person who drinks Moscow Mules from a plastic cup, get some copper mugs!

In the debate of books vs movies I am firmly in the "books are better" camp. However I was a bit disappointed with this one. I saw and loved the movie Argo and naturally upon finding out that it was based on 1) a true story and 2) a chapter from this book, I had to go read the book myself! The book is significantly less exciting, and there are very few thrills.What the book does do well is it takes you through the role Antonio Mendez played in the CIA. He is more of an artist than James Bond. He learns how to create disguises, open and reseal envelopes without leaving a trace, forge documents etc. All very interesting stuff and not your usual spy story.

First thing i noticed about these is the quality build / durability of them. The head is made of wood and metal while the cord is nylon braid. The cord feels better than the cheap rubber feel of most ear buds. These come with the earbuds themselves, 3 sets of rubber tips, and a little burlap bag to carry it all in. I did not choose the color, but if I did I would've gone with something other than turquoise.The sound quality is pretty good. Its not top of the line but it will easily sound better than the default apple earbuds most people use. Like most earbuds these do not really fit well in my ear, but i suspect thats just the shape/size of my ears since no "in ear" headphones feel good to me. Still I will be using these often since I cannot (or won't) use over the ear headphones when I workout or go for a run.I received this product for the purposes of an honest review

This is a nice inexpensive gaming mouse. It is plug and play (thankfully since the box and instructions are all in chinese). The look and feel of the mouse are great. It fits perfectly in my hand and all the buttons are placed well. It has a nice edgy look to it however the red light doesn't glow the whole time and its not as bright as the picture on Amazon makes it seem. Imagine everything "red" in the picture as white plastic and thats more like what it looks like. The 6 buttons are the left and right click, the forward and back buttons on the side, the scroll wheel, and the DPI button. The DPI button is a nice touch and allows you to adjust the sensitivity on the fly (think of a first person shooter game going from a hip fire sub machine gun to a sniper rifle). I believe the DPI button has 4 levels of sensitivity.The USB receiver does not fit in all of my computers USB ports (a problem I have found with other wireless mice on other computers as well). The batteries barely fit in the battery compartment, and the compartment cover is a bit awkward. There is a place near he batteries where you can store the USB receiver. It takes 2 AAA batteries and the can drain fairly quickly. Overall not a bad gaming mouse for the price.I received this product for the purposes of an honest review

The Gear Beast Gearclip is a smartphone holder for your car. Its really simple to use. The device slides right into the airvent in your car. To place you cell phone in the Gearclip you simply pull the circular end of the gearclip and slid your phone between the two ends. the spring action securely holds your phone in place!. This is great for using your phones GPS since you wont have to look down for your phone to see directions. I highly recommend this product.I received this product for the purposes of an honest review

I often travel 2-3 days a week and wanted a way to play without lugging my PS4 around (which I actually did a few times). So I bought a PS Vita. I don't do much gaming on Vita specific games. 95% of my Vita usage is remote playing my PS4 gamesThe device:The device itself is a good size and rests nicely in your hands. The screen size is good and the picture is crisp and clear. The button arrangement is a bit uncomfortable for me. The right joystick doesn't seem to be in a very natural position and there is a lack of L1/R1 and L3/R3 buttons. I play Final Fantasy XIV: ARR and those buttons are pretty essential. To use those buttons you have to make use of the touchpad on the back of the device which takes a bit of getting used to. if you touch the upper right side of the back touchpad its like pressing R1, the bottom left is like L3 and so on.Remote play:This is why I bought the Vita. If your PS4 is in standby mode (rest mode not off) then the Vita can turn it on and operate it remotely. There are 2 different ways you can do this, at home via direct connect and away from home via the internet. If your home you can connect directly to the PS4 via a bluetooth connection. If your family needs the TV or you want to multitask and watch and play at the same time, you can play the PS4 using the Vita as controller and screen leaving your TV screen available to watch TV. If your away from home you can connect via the internet. I have used the Vita to play my PS4 remotely from several states away from home. The only thing you need to watch for is bad internet connections. Using hotel wifi can be hit or miss, and I've used stronger wifi connections that had trouble when someone else was using Netlix it hurt my Vita's connection. If connection is lost for Vita, the PS4 is still on, so when the vita regains connection a few seconds later your right back to where you were (or dead depending on the game!). Depending on the connection there can be slight lag using remote play.If a game bundle is available you want to buy that version. The Borderlands 2 edition comes with a game and an 8GB memory card for the exact same price
