with the exception of BigFish, the top ho/point-click adventure game makers seems to be lapsing off in releasing new games recently. my hope is that with the others the next game will be a giant winner for us all. in the meantime BigFish is giving us some enjoyable games to play and making all the money. like other more recent games from BigFish this one doesn't necessarily give you an overly challenging game, but you are given enough of a challenge to have a fun way to pass the time with. if you want a small challenge, but need to relax at the same time then definitely give this one a try. you aren't given any ho scenes per say, but with each scene will find objects you need to complete a goal/task. but before you can pick an item up you need to find 5-8 additional items found in the scene first. the puzzles aren't exceptionally hard, but challenging enough. if needed you can use the "skip" button after a certain amount of time has elapsed. the storyline is a fun one that deals with you wandering a small town and adjacent castle, while trying to avoid guards and robot sentries. as with most games of this genre, you are given a strategy guide if the hint button isn't helping you to precede if you get stuck. the graphics are great and playing on a kindle fire hd I didn't have any glitches while playing the game.

I wanted to start out by stating, while other reviewers have said this game seems to be aimed at the younger crowd (given the storyline), this is an enjoyable game for everyone from pre-teen* and up.  if you have played the Empress of the Deep games (also from BigFish) you will see it is like those, in that it provides a challenging game for them, but it's not so overly easy for adults and still makes for an enjoyable (if not overly challenging) game. The storyline is more of a mix of fairy tales with a fairy and/or dragon helping you along the way (you start with the fairy who leaves when the dragon is hatched and returns a couple of chapters later). the game has a good mix of ho and puzzle scenes and you pick up needed objects either individually upon entering a new scene, or from a ho scene (which are not hard or annoying). the puzzles are fun and some of the more enjoyable ones are coloring tattoo designs: you are given 3-5 colors and the goal is to color the design while not letting any of the same colors touch. There is a strategy guide included, but be aware it is not the normal kind of guide you come to expect with this genre. If you do need help you can click on the guide (not having to leave the game) and you are given a list of past/current goals, with the incomplete goals highlighted. you can click on the goal you need help with and you are given a hint as to what you need to do to accomplish that goal. you can keep clicking and get progressively more helpful hints.  there is some going back and forth between the scenes which is normal for this game and I'm happy to say this is not overly done as it is with some games. The game is an excellent length for the price and a bonus chapter is included after you finish the game.In all I would recommend this game for everyone. If you are new to the genre (or want a game for your pre-teens) then this is a perfect game to start with. for adults, while you might not get any super challenges with this game, you are given enough of a challenge to make this an enjoyable and relaxing game to play. and, as for me, this also gives you a game if you want some quality time with the 8-10 yr old crowd. meaning it is a good game to play together with, letting them being able to play the ho scenes on their own, while playing the rest of the game letting them "help" you in decided what/how to do next.*please note when I say pre-teen, I mean the ages of 11-13, but with the aforementioned Empress of the Deep games my 9 1/2 niece enjoys playing those games with my help throughout most of the gameplay.

*EDITED REVIEW:At first I wasn't sure of buying a game with no reviews and it not being from one of the top three ho game makers. **But when I saw this was an original game from bigfish I didn't hesitate. Freeze Tag seems to have bought this to adapt for the android market and did an excellent job. (please see an update re this below)** The story line and playability are great. The graphics during gameplay are good as well, but the cut away scenes get blurry/pixelated making it hard to see what is going on. One downside is there isn't a strategy guide included. Just about every game in this genre has one. If you are like me you don't necessarily need one while playing, but it is helpful for the one or two times I might get stuck when the hint/help button isn't clear enough as to what to do next. Another thing that is normal for this genre, but wasn't included with this game, is the option to play in different difficulty modes. There is only one mode to play, but you are asked at the beginning whether you want interactive help while playing. I didn't have any kind of problems playing on the kindle hd (although on replay the voices on some scenes were muted). I would definitely consider buying more games from this company if they made more android versions of more adventure games.UPDATE: After replaying this I am reminded that I wanted to put this at 4 instead of 5 stars for the following reason: at least once in every 5-10 rooms you get the annoying pop-up asking for a positive review. while I don't mind being asked for a review maybe ONCE in the middle and/or at the end of a game, this was extremely excessive. plus, asking for a review is fine, but you should never be asked as to the rating to give in the review (I think asking for a "positive" review is just unethical). For one I prefer to wait till completing the game to give my review, and second, they should let the game speak for itself as to what type of rating to give. if they have done a good job and made an enjoyable game it will get a high rating. but when you ask me to give a high rating with my review you will always loose a star.UPDATE #2: since, depending on the device you use, not everyone can see comments attached to reviews I wanted to share part of a comment I received from the devs: "...Victorian Mysteries: The Woman in White is a Freeze Tag original game. We created it, developed, and we own the copyright and trademark on the Victorian Mysteries series of games. Big Fish is one of our distribution partners, and we did sell this game through their web site at one point..." I thank them for the great feedback I received. not a lot of devs will take their own personal time to address reviews and I always like to make of note when they do.*edited to give additional information and add the update on the review requests.

This is ok for a time wasting game if you get it for the FAOTD. But I wouldn't waste any money on this one. I was questioning whether to download it at all with the app description being broken English that didn't make a lot of sense in some spots. But decided to let the game speak for itself. As other reviewers have said, there are no instructions. Basically you are given a checkered board with a few colored pegs. You need to move the pegs around to line up 5 of the same colored pegs. There are different bonus type pegs to help. Some examples of those are: multi-colored (to use as a universal peg), arrowed pegs (to clear a column/row from the arrow on), bomb pegs (to clear all adjacent squares), some that are combos of bonus pegs (multi-colored with another bonus). With each move you make more pegs are added to the board. So the goal is to make as many match-5 combos as you can before the board fills up. There are three difficulty levels. That's the game. Most of it is all up to luck since you can't make a lot of strategic choices with not knowing where the next set of random pegs are going to pop up.

Basically what this game is that you are given a cube with different "color swatches" of varying shapes on the bottom of the screen. By maneuvering the cube around and placing the swatches on the cube you have to match the colors to each side of the sample cube on the top of the screen. It gets progressively harder as you advance as each swatch can fit on one or more squares. There are 4 squares per side with each square sometimes being devided in half. There are 4 main levels, named after the seasons, with each level having 12 sub-levels.About the first half of the spring level serves as a tutorial. Played on a kindle fire HD with no obvious glitches so far. There doesn't seem to be any excessive permissions to this app. While it's nothing overly exciting,it does provide a good challenge for when you're bored.

because of how this "drawing" app works, I would describe it more of a doodling app. the way each brush works, even drawing a simple line expands it out beyond what you draw with your finger/stylus. there are two modes of drawing included with this app: 1)touch-where the line you draw will stop from beginning to end, but still expands slightly on the sides, and 2) continuous-where what you draw will continue to flow out from all sides. you have the option to change the percentage of how far the expansion is depending on the type of line you are drawing (zig-zag, straight, or rainbow shape).  there are several different "brushes" you can choose from, but since they are all basically the same with the exception of color it doesn't make sense to call it a change of the "brush". the another option you are left with is the background color. there is an undo (seems to be unlimited as to the number of strokes you can undo), and an option to save or delete the entire picture (not found in the same spots). there is an option to upload photos, with the option to upload from a computer, facebook, or a phone. I do have photo's in my kindle fire hd device, but they show up as an option to use for this app (unless I missed something, if I did I'm sorry). I didn't try to upload anything as you have to enter e-mail/facebookID/phone number, so I'm not sure how well this option works or not.  the app description lists IAP's but I didn't see any of those, so this seems to be the full app (instead of a trial version that a previous reviewer stated). this isn't even close to "the best drawing app available" as one reviewer states (my choice is sketchmobile), but this would be a nice and simple doodle app for yourself or anyone with younger children who can't draw yet and enjoy making lines and swirls (or any age in between for that matter)

UPDATE: since this review was published it seems because of an e-mail sent to the devs by another reviewer the IAP's are ow listed in the product description and the permission for current and recently running apps have been removed. Thus I will add a star to my rating. Wish more devs would listen to customers. Thank youAs far as a weather app this looks like it would work great.Once you enter your location you get the temperature, conditions, the feels like temperature, humidity, wind, when it was last updated, and the date and time. In the bottom left corner you also get t high/low prediction and moon phase. In the top right corner there are icons: 1)change the bunny's wardrobe 2)piggy bank to buy more clothes (with earned coins or real money 3)give bunny an umbrella 4)camera to send bunny photo via Twitter/facebook 5)options. The bunny part of this app is described as a virtual pet, but all you can do with it is change it's clothes and add an umbrella. Some reviews have said the app does not save your location, but I didn't experience that problem when I exited and returned.I think this company is showing questionable practices though. Two reasons are 1)the piggy bank has an option for IAP which is not disclosed in the product description 2)there is NO reason this or any app needs to know anything about current or recently running apps on my device. I know some devs have noted in the past this is to check for game cheating apps/software, but this is not a game,much less one that would need any kind of cheating. Thus, one could conclude it is for data mining.

This game isn't one of the best, but it's still a keeper. There are two modes to play: easy with hints, or expert without hints. I played on the first mode for my first way through, and while it's not as helpful at first, after the game unlock the game seems to become more helpful and intuitive. Sometimes it wasn't as clear as to what to do, but once you realize that when you leave some scenes there are new objects that pop up when you return. As for the storyline, if you are tired of all the ghost stories lately you might want to give this one a try. It does deal with the supernatural (evil creatures living underground) but no hauntings. There didn't seem to be any glitches that I found while playing on a kindle fire hd.

I had another of these skins for my 1rst gen kindle fire and when I upgraded to an hd model I didn't hesitate to make this one of my first accessory purchases for it. they not only have a wide selection as far as the design, they fit perfect, have open holes for all the correct spots (camera, speakers, etc), and they are easy to apply with none of the bubble issues that can happen with the screen protectors. some might think it's just putting a sticker on the device for decoration, but with it being a "vinyl skin" it has a rubbery feel which protects the kindle from any scratches or spills.

the midnight mystery series are all among my favorite games for the ho/point-click genre. they all have fun and interesting storylines on famous characters throughout history. while some reviewers have said this game is hard, if you are familiar with the genre that isn't so. if not it comes with a step by step strategy guide to help you along.the follow is cut/pasted from a review for another midnight mystery game, but still applies for this game: I would normally rate this a 5 star as it is among one of my favorites. but it loses a star for mumbojumbo's unethical tactics with this game. I bough this a year ago for my kindle fire 1rst gen when it was at the high price of $4.99. however I have since traded in my 1rst gen for an hd model. well the first game I bought was incompatible with the hd model so in order to play I had to buy this version for another $0.99. yeah, it's just a dollar, but since I already paid $4.99 for the exact same game it's double-dipping in my mind. also, while there are "ravens" to collect for clues/hints, if you can't find them all they have iap to buy additional hint packages. but, with the free strategy guide I don't see why anyone would even need to do that.

This is a really fun ho/point-click game. great graphics, storyline, etc. some reviews have said it is hard to follow and know what to do, but if you play a lot of these types of games it's not really hard at all. plus there is a strategy guide included so if you get lost you can just follow that.I would normally rate this a 5 star as it is among one of my favorites. but it loses a star for mumbojumbo's unethical tactics with this game. I bough this a year ago for my kindle fire 1rst gen when it was at the high price of $4.99. however I have since traded in my 1rst gen for an hd model. well the first game I bought was incompatible with the hd model so in order to play I had to buy this version for another $0.99. yeah, it's just a dollar, but since I already paid $4.99 for the exact same game it's double-dipping in my mind. also, while there are "ravens" to collect for clues/hints, if you can't find them all they have iap to buy additional hint packages. but, with the free strategy guide I don't see why anyone would even need to do that.

This is another physic based game. With this one you have to get the rolling ball head into the bubble. You need to press the two arrows on each side to tilt the maze of boards. While this seems to be aimed at some of the younger crowds it takes coordination to use both hands at the same time. Easy enough for the preteen+ audience. Other than the ability to turn off the sound there are no other setting options so what you see is what you get.

A good strategy game that's like checkers with a twist. The goal is to knock a certain amount of your opponents pieces off the board. The default is 6 (with the beginning tutor level being 1), but  in the settings this amount can be changed (1-6). Unlike checkers, where you move one piece at a time, with this game you can move your pieces in groups of three and in every direction. There are three modes of play: 1)by levels where there are several different levels with around 10 different stages to each, 2)free play where, like the first mode you play against the computer with three different board set-ups to choose from, 3)duel player, which is the same as the previous choice only you can play against a friend on the same device.I was questioning myself as to rate this 3 or 4 stars for the following reasons: went from a 3 star for what a simple game of checkers would be to a 4 star for the twist and added challenge of the game. I could (or some would say should in this case) change it back to 3 for the invasive type of permissions for this type of game. As others have said there is no reason why this game nets network and gps information.

I like to play enough of a game to give fellow customers an honest enough review. While some games I will play to completion first, after playing this one for about 10 levels I think I have enough.  This game starts out pretty cute in a robot factory with robot heads being crated up. The 3rd one (roby) fakes a defect to avoid the crate and finds that the crate is the only way out. That is where you take over. Each level has several crates and you need to figure out the correct one(s) to break in order to coolect each levels three gears (same as the "stars" that all physic based game has for scoring purposes) then fall into the crate. Of course each level increases in difficulty with some adding more elements along the way (like finding and helping friends). This game is fun and (so far) is easy enough for the much younger crowd to enjoy.

To start off please be aware that although this is a kindle edition it is for the hd model's only. That being said alawar is one of my favorite game developers but I find it hard to believe they would put out such a shoddy game. The plability and length was way less the the first alabama game (which is a tp game in it's own right). There was by far way too much going back and forth. While this is the norm for this genre it was excessive and became very tedious. You would be in one room to find you need water for something then had to go to another room, switch the time piece to go into the past, get a cup, switch back to the present, find the water in another room, then find your back to where you started only to discover that this is when the game tells you it requires a rag to complete the task so you have to do all that again.  This happens with just about every task. You are told the objects you need one at a time. Even on replay or if you know ahead of time the additional items needed the game won't let you get them till the game itself tells you they are needed. On top off all that the game was unresponsive many times, taking it 3+ more times to recognize an action. Also on most of the hidden object scenes what you are looking for is a ghostly silhouette, meaning the are see-through and blended into the color of whatever it is sitting on making them near impossible to clearly see what you are looking for.In all I was very disappointed in this game and would tell anyone to pass and save your money. If this was any other company I would even steer clear from them in general. But alawar is truly one of the best developers for the ho/point-click adventure games. This is just the exception to the rule when it comes to the standard of games they are known for.

this game is the FAOTD today, and, as much as I love watching The Walking Dead, I'm not the type to play zombie or any kind of rpg's. So I definitely did not get this for me, but instead for my teenage nephew. if you are familiar with the choose-your-own-adventure books from your youth, then you can easily imagine how this game works. to make it more a game rather than a book, the devs made this so when you arrive at some of the choices dependent on a dice roll. but on the dice roll choices they aren't exactly choices. the best example of this is when you come face to face with zombies. you have the choice to "fight the zombies" or if you have saved any pages with a bookmark you can go back to any of those. I got real bored with the "game" about 10 minutes into it. it's pretty much read, read, read, make a choice, read, read, read, make a choice, ect. with about 1 in 10 choices finally involving a dice roll. there are 3 difficulty levels, so maybe it could be more interesting for people who enjoy this genre, but I am not one. If when my nephew plays this and he likes it I will edit my review to reflect his game experience. so until then, unless this is your kind of thing or any other reviews change your mind I would pass on this one.

while so far in my experience I haven't found any particular brand of capacitive stylus that is in any way better or worse that others I tend to pick the bluecell brand for some conveniences (which are not exclusive at all to this brand). they come in a wide variety of colors and/or combo packs for a lower price than some of the other brands out there. while being cheap, they do last and the 4 pack that I bought over 2 years ago I am still using today. I only bought a new set to receive new colors to go with the different skins and cover/cases for my upgraded kindle. they not only have the side pen clip but have a bottom tip with a hole for a phone jack attachment (although you need to buy those separately). while the capacitive tip glides smoothly over most of the different brands of screen protectors/anti-glare screens I think that has more to do with the screens themselves rather that the stylus (although it could be a combo of the two I find it is generally the brand of screen that makes the difference (you can see my reviews for my favorite as far as screens go). any an all of these features can more or less be found on just about any stylus you look at so the main reason I tend to go with the bluecell is because each purchase comes with a free cable tie. with all the cords/cables that comes with anyones everyday use (be it tablets, cell phones, laptops, etc.) the more cables ties you have the better, and if it's free you can't argue with that.if you don't want to wade through my reviews to find the aforementioned screen protector/anti-glare screen here is a link:  http://www.amazon.com/rooCASE-Anti-Glare-Invisible-Protector-Compatible/dp/B00A407R5W/ref=sr_1_cc_2?s=aps&ie=UTF8&qid=1371460514&sr=1-2-catcorr&keywords=rooCASE+screen+protector+anti-glare+screen

we all know there are countless brands of either/or anti-glare screens and screen protectors on the market. when I got my first kindle a few years ago I got a case cover for it made by rooCASE  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00B2POVWA/ref=oh_details_o01_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1  (you can see my review for this item which is HIGHLY recommended) and after purchasing it clicked on amazons "those who purchases xxxx also bought xxxx" for the anti-glare and screen protector combo pack made my the same company. I was not disappointed and while a couple of times I bought other brands at different stores for sheer convenience I recommend the rooCASE brand over all the others. just to start with it comes not only with soft dust cloth to clean your screen before application, you also get a perfect size "installation card" to remove any bubbles when applying the film (other brands I've bought either have cards too small to be of any use or just tell you to press hard with your fingers or use a credit card). this one seems to be the easiest one to install not only with being able to align it in the right spots, but I get less bubbles (with being able to do it with no bubbles now with practice). while my newest hd kindle came with a screen protector after only 3 days I already notice underling circles showing up on the film and unlike the rooCASE the fingerprints/smears build up much faster. with the rooCASE films I not only get less buildup of both the fingerprints and smears, but on the anti-glare screen you get the best anti-glare effect with the lease amount of the annoying darkening blurriness that comes any/all anti-glare screens (it is unavoidable in all brands in how they are made). another difference that is very noticeable is the fact that I use a stylus more often than just my finger and with the rooCASE brand the stylus glides smoothly over the film (unlike right now again with the screen that came with the kindle the stylus skips here and there and does not keep a constant contact with the screen). I just received my screens this afternoon and am planning on replacing them with the current one first thing on the morning.  I certainly understand going with the convenience of buying these items in the store versus ordering on the internet and waiting for delivery. but in this case I feel it is worth the difference.

I bought one of these for my original 1rst gen kindle fire and when updating to kindle fire hd 7" my first and most immediate accessory was another rooCASE. I thoroughly enjoy this for everything it offers. it comes in several colors. you have the option of sitting your kindle up in either portrait or landscape mode. it comes with a safety enclosure that separates/attaches from the case with velcrow on the back to keep it from falling out of the case when carrying it. the separate safety enclosure is one of my favorite features because I can read/play with my kindle without the case and not worry if it is dropped or anything else that might damage it. I have actually dropped my device from about a 4 foot height with it landing face down on a hard tiled (hospital) floor with absolutely no after effects. that should sell you on this item alone.  happily with this hd 7" case it comes with some additional options I didn't have with my 1rst gen model. first off it has a slot for your stylus so if you don't have the option to attach your stylus to the phone jack you can still keep it close. closing the case will not only automatically put your device in sleep mode but it is kept closed with a very small magnet in the bottom/right hand corner (between the case and safety enclosure).  as with each model the rooCASE is made for, all the places you need open slots/spaces for you will find them. I have seen several other cases, covers for the kindle and I will turn to the rooCASE every time (and it has nothing to do that "roo" is a nickname of mine since childhood-but it certainly helps to identify my kindle as MINE)

first off this third Snark Buster game  is for the KINDLE HD only, so if you only have a 1rst or 2nd gen kindle you need to wait till you can get an updated model. that being said, although I enjoyed this game, it wasn't quite up to par with the first two. there were only five levels compared to the others with about 10 levels each. the levels seemed to be shorter as well. as far as the puzzles go they seemed to be the same on a challenge level (not too hard and not too easy). the graphics were great and the storyline an enjoyable one (although there was only one small not at the beginning that mentioned anything about the normal snark hunt with nothing else to follow). this was a fun game that I would recommend, just don't expect the higher caliber of game that alawar is known for. it's because of that and for ignoring have their kindle customers in the KINDLE TABLET EDITION that I am rating this 4 instead of 5 stars.

ho games are my favorite genre to play. while I generally buy the ho/point-click adventures I like to get the plain ho games when they are offered as the FAOTD (like this one was for fathers day). starting off one thing I don't like is the option settings don't save. so if you prefer to play with the sound off you have to go through all the different pages to get through all the setting to turn it off each time you enter the game. I know it's just as easy to turn the devices sound off, but most games save option settings. there are 23 levels with three difficulty settings: 1) NORMAL limited time, limited hints, bonus, 2) NICE AND CASUAL unlimited time, unlimited hints, 3) CHALLENGE MODE items are rotated, words have missing letters. after choosing your difficulty you choose how you want to look for items: 1) by picture, 2) by silhouette (spelled sillhouee), or 3) by word. I played each of the three lists for a more thorough review and here were the problems I found. when playing by picture the color shading didn't match between the list and the main picture. when playing both the picture and silhouette the sizing of the list didn't match with the main picture. for example on one level there was a fairly large flower followed by a very small arrow on the list. however when I found them on the main picture the arrow turned out to be the largest item to find. finally when playing with the word list it wasn't always clear what you are looking for. one example being a soda can on the list but on the picture it ended up being a very small grey circle with a barely visible line of the soda pop click opening thing (so only the top was visible and hardly recognizable). in all three occasionally I had items that weren't even on the screen and when I clicked the hint for those there was only one or two stars visible of the normal 10 stars in a circular shape. this was played on a kindle hd 7" with the brightness turned all the way up, so none of that should have impacted any of the problems I faced. in all I was very disappointed from a company that usually turns out much better games than this.

this game only came out a few months ago and I have been wanting to get it but have always talked myself out of it wondering if it was really fun enough or not for the cost. needless to say I was happy to see that this was the second FAOTD after the first one for today was a total failure for amazon customers. there was a version of this game on the science channels new show Brain Games (re-aired on fox I think). some reviewers have rated this 1 star because it's too easy when taking your time. however, from watching that show to get the true challenge of this game it's supposed to be played with a short time limit. I can see without having to race through the choices this game could get boring.  you are given two columns of blocks with the name of a color in each one. sometimes the color that the word is written in matches the word and sometimes not. the goal is to match a block from each column by matching the names of the colors, matching the colors themselves, matching a color with the word itself, etc. even though you might be able to find a certain solution that gets everything matched, but the game seems to only accept the programed solution for that level for you to score and move on. some reviewers have also said when playing on the fire that the colors weren't clear. I'm playing on a 1rst gen and when the brightness is turned down it is hard to differentiate some colors. so play this with the brightness turned up.

this is a trivia game with several categories to choose from: history, sports, science, art, music, tv/films, language, cuisine, games, geography, or all of the above. because there are so many categories with who knows how many questions for each it takes 3-5 minutes to load the questions so sit back and be prepared to wait (it only took a minute to download the app itself). there are three modes to play in: 1)single in which you play on your own to gain points and potions, 2)versus where you can play against a friend who also has the app on their android device, and 3)live where you play with a random (worldwide) player found in their database. I'm guessing it is for the latter two that they need either an e-mail or facebook account. however IMHO there should be the option to play without the e-mail/facebook if you just want to play in single mode. that's where the shadiness begins. I choose the option of using my facebook account to play so as for playing by signing in with an e-mail I can't say what is/isn't shady about that. but the first time I tried playing when I signed in with facebook you have the option for the game to post on facebook for your behalf (usually this is to post scores for anyone unfamiliar with facebook), or you have the option to skip that step. at first I clicked on the skip option. however when re-entering the game from the facebook sign-in I was given an error message that the game could not be played at this time (and this was in single mode). then I had to un-reinstall the game and surprise when I clicked to allow the game to post for me the game worked just fine (I changed the option that only I and not the public or my friends could see these posts). I think I will be uninstalling this game for good unless there is an update with the ability to play without an e-mail or facebook. BTW this was played on 1rst gen kindle.

I want to start my review by copying/pasting a post I wrote in the amazon discussion boards in response to all the complaints about there not being an e-book for this novel available at this time. This also goes out to everyone posting a 1 star review for the same reason. Also I use the words TRUE FANS in my review title because real and true fans of Stephen King could care less about the publication form and collect his works because there are few authors who can write the amazing novels/short-story collections that are so imaginative and descriptive and in so many genres as SK does.  I understand that there are some readers who need e-books for reasons of eyesight, arthritis, etc. I have enough faith in SK that he will eventually put this novel in other forms besides paperback like he has in other publications that were released in only one form to start with.SK has a long history of publishing his stories/novels only in certain formats for the express purposes of creating an atmosphere. The ones that come to mind are The Mist, The Storm of the Century, the joint publications of The Diary of Ellen Rimbauer and Rose Red, and finally UR. The Mist was originally published as a "3-d sound" audiobook. In the hopes of enhancing his readers imagination this short story was made into an audiobook with a unique 3-d sound stereo effect. With the background noise, excellent voice actors, 3-d stereo effect, etc. the fear and panic the characters feel was geniusly portrayed (if you can find it I highly recommend this to all). This was eventually published in a short story collection, adapted into movie format and can also be purchased individually. The Storm of the Century was published as a "novel for television." SK did this not only because the larger cast of characters would make this almost impossible to publish it in just one book in written form, but in order to portray the immensity of the storm. Once again this was eventually released in written form (the script was published in paperback). I have both the script and the movie and I love to read the script while watching the movie to see the differences. Another concept SK tried in order to enhance the atmosphere intended was the joint publication of the book The Diary of Ellen Rimbauer and the movie Rose Red. Under the pseudonym Joyce Reardon SK published in paperback form The Diary of Ellen Rimbauer in order to provide a more detailed background into not only the characters, but also the house (a character in its own rights) Rose Red. The cover of the book has a note for readers to watch Stephen King's Rose Red. Publishing the book before the movie once again helped to enhance the readers (or in this case the watchers) imagination and create the intended atmosphere. Last on my list is the more recent UR. Because of the theme this was originally published in e-book format. You definitely would have not shared the characters feelings if this was first read in paperback form. Hence SK decision, once again, to publish this in only one form at first (this can now be purchased in audiobook form.on to my actual review. this novel was as much of a great read as all his others are. I don't want to go into any detail of the story and ruin it for other readers with spoilers, so here is a small description. the basis of the novel is about a college student who gets a summer job at an amusement park, makes friends with others that are both living in the same boarding house, but also on the same "work team" at the park. at the park learns about the local legend regarding the funhouse's history and the resultant haunting. from there it just gets better and better as only Stephen King can do. the story's main character, Devin, is now much older and is narrating the story through flashbacks. at times while trying to tell about a certain part that happened during that summer the character seemed to get sidetracked with other side stories. at first I found that annoying. but, I started to think that that is what people do in real life so why is that not portrayed as much in novels. So I actually found that feature to increase the realism of the story for me. yes, I know this is fiction, but we all read books with our imaginations flowing as if the story is happening for real.in conclusion I encourage anyone who is a fan of mystery books to give this a try. Even if you aren't a fan of SK I think you would enjoy this novel as his descriptions aren't as "hard core" as some of his longer books. some have stated they dislike his work if he gets too descriptive with violence and/or sex for their taste to handle. that is not the case here so I think you could take a chance with this one.

When I tell my niece she can use the "game-pad" for books only this is usually the first book she picks. Yes there are a couple of mini games in this interactive book she has to "read" (actually be read to) the book to get to them.

I enjoy the hidden object (ho), point-and-click adventure games and rarely get the one that are purely ho. I made an exception in this case for two reasons: 1) this was made by the same company that gave  me one of my favorite games on my kindle (100floors) and 2) it's  free.  For a free game I wasn't expecting more than 3 or 4 levels. I was happily wrong. Can't remember exactly  how many levels there are I think it was about 10 or so with about 5 scenes per level.
The kids love to sit and "read" the books on the "game-pad" whether it be an e-book or an interective app book. This is a sesame street interactive book. Can't go wrong with that combo.

You are given a board filled with colored marbles. The goal is to move the marbles and make a line of three or more to clear different squares on the board. The difficulty increases as the game progresses. What I really like is that even though you technically only have three lives (with the possibility to earn more) when you run out of lives the game will restart at the current level. So you really have unlimited lives. In the latter levels you may have to replay them several times to finish the level, but I like that I don't have to continually restart the entire game. There are about five boards per level.

This was the only recording I could find that had Pippins song that he sings for the kings steward (john nobles character) when he sends his son on the suicide run to retake the lower town. Beautiful. One of my favorite parts of the trilogy
I found out about this product after reading some posts on an amazon discussion board.  This is a great app to use when you need to clear up some memory (for both game and internal storage space).

Fun game app where you move pudding globs around until they are connected together. The main goal is to cover all the squares on the board with a blob. Each level increases in difficulty while you are also given different types of pudding globs and powers to accomplish your goal. All ages will enjoy this game since just getting all the blobs to connect is enough to finish a level regardless if any of the squares are covered or not.

only done a few levels so far but wanted to get the word out about it working for first gen kfire. you basically go around the board collecting the various types of tiles. before you begin you might want to increase the nav speed since the default setting is one were you very slowly move one tile at a time. taking one star off for control because sometimes (depending on the speed you have set) you can scroll through the board without lifting a finger and other times you have to constantly lift your finger up and down on each individual tile.

first off, to the reviewers bashing the 1 star reviews complaining about the price: the point of a review is to leave an opinion of the app. yes, some people think the reviews should only be about the quality of the app. but, the price a person pays is part of the whole experience for an app. when bashing the 1 stars reviews one reviewer even said to let people make their own opinion regarding the price. using that logic there would be no reason whatsoever for reviews to begin with, right? if a person should be able to form their own opinion regarding the price they should also form their own opinion regarding the quality, functionality, etc.ok, sorry about the rant. on to the app review. pretty much everything the other 1 star reviews say is true. yed it flips a coin. the product description says there are more coins to download for free but when I try all I get is a message saying they are unavailable. so if I hadn't gotten the app as the FAOTD I would definitely feel cheated shelling out $2.99 for an app that just flips a coin and only one coin despite the fact there should more. I have bought several (actually all) apps/games that can be played for hours and hours of entertainment for a lot less pocket change. oh look I have pocket change so what do I need the app for anyways.

some people might look at the game icon (with the elevator) and thin this is just another dumb clone of the popular 100floors. not so. this is a real room escape game. you have a whole room to explore(compared to the one scene). you also have a few puzzles to solve while collecting items and clues to eventually find the key to open the elevator door. this game has the perfect amount of challenge I like. NOT too easy but also NOT too challenging as to making it impossible tp play without finding a walkthrough. the game is short but hey it's free and more levels are promised to come. hope it doesn't take too long.

if you liked either/both the previous quell games this will not disappoint. this one still has four games per level with each level having it's own theme (turing on lights,  breaking ice, etc. this one also contains a couple of new twists on the game. each puzzle has hidden jewels to find (by breaking solid squares) and at least one game per level has a hidden game inside (look for a bronze ring in the same place you see the "game complete" and "found jewel" icon on each levels main screen). it is physically impossible to find the hidden objects and get a perfect score which makes it even more fun playing each game  at least twice to accomplish both goals. and btw the hidden games have hidden objects (clocks) to find as well.so far I am on level 5 and have found all hidden objects/games and have perfect scores except for two. one I can't seems to find any place for the bronze ring and another where I find no way to get the perfect score (only one off). on the other hand somehow I managed to get a better than perfect score (13/14) on a hidden game but can't exactly figure how I did that one since on replays I am finding it hard enough to get that perfect score (even though my score was better than perfect it did not count as a perfect score for the game stats hence the replay on that one. in all this is a game I highly recommend. I know my 9 yr old niece will be excited to see I have another of one of her favorite games.

update: changing my rating from 3 to 4 stars. I did the whole un-re-install thing and replayed the game. upon trying to get to the lighthouse the game seemed to freeze on the loading screen. I attempted going in and out of the game as I had before only I kept being taken back to just before leaving for the lighthouse and the game kept seeming to freeze on the same loading screen. without leaving the game I put my kindle down to try to send a message to big fish about the glitch. about five minutes into that my game suddenly started playing again. there were no problems continuing the game after that. no freezes or black screens. at least till the final cut scene again. I was able to grab the ankh and the cut scene started then kept freezing 3-5 seconds at a time and skipping ahead into the cut scene till it got to the credits. hence the 4 instead of 5 stars: I still did not see how the game actually ended.original review: everything was fine for most of the game. good graphics,  storyline,  ho and puzzle scenes all with a decent length. that is till the end of chapter six. from the time I tried to go to the lighthouse on everytime time the loading screen would pop up it would either freeze on that screen or I would loose all pictures for the game (I could hear the game continue to play seeing nothing but a black screen). in both cases I would have to click on the kindle fires (1rst gen) home screen and click back on the games icon. when returning I would be placed back were I should be in the game (although it skipped the the whole bigfish main page and the games home page). then after completing what was (as far as I can tell) the last task of the game (grabbing the ankh shown on the games icon) I didn't get to see how the game ended. game went black again and when I try to return to the game and click continue it all goes black again (having to force close the game).  I'm going to try playing with a different profile and/or try the whole un-re-install trick to see if I get a different outcome. if so I will update my review. otherwise it is a fun game but BUYER BEWARE.

I highly recommend this as this truly is a faster charger. In the past when I got that dreadful "only 15% power left" I would plug my charger in and if I was doing anything on the Kindle it would either keep it from draining further or just barely charge the battery. this is not the case with this charger. now if I get that message while playing/reading or whatever I can plug this charger in and within a couple of hours my battery is back to 100% (and remember that is while the kindle is in use and even if the brightness is at 100%). you can also use this with any USB cord to charge any device. worth the price so buy it.

When buying the DVD for Fringe season 4 I had the choice of getting it with or without the comic. I chose to buy the one with the comic. However, that one came with just the first story "Peter and the Machine" and the writing was extremely small. While I was able to read it I knew when some others of my family took their turn at borrowing the season would not be able to read the comic. That explains my reason for buying this comic for my kindle (not to mention the fact that I could not wait to read the "what if..." stories). Even though I thoroughly enjoyed the extra tales, while larger, the writing was still small making it hard for at least one family member to read (she said with reading glasses she might be able to read it). That is also with using the zoom: double tapping the panel to enlarge it. other that, this is definitely a must have for any and all Fringe fans

I was under the impression that these were the tales as they were originally told in the show Once Upon A Time, but that is not the case. which is why this gets 4 instead of 5 stars. This is a collection of the original tales, written by the original authors, of the characters from the show. all the characters whose tale from the enchanted land was told in season 1 of the show have their original stories in this book. so definitely buy this book because there aren't a lot of places you can get so many wonderful, classic stories in one  place for such a great price. but, if you want to read a book to be reminded that Belle, from Beauty and the Beast, went to live and fall in love with Rumpelstilzkin then this is the wrong book for you.

nice collection of tales. I am rating this only four stars because I was under the impression this was based on the show. This is not the case. while the story for each of the characters of these tales were told in season two of Once Upon a Time these are not the same stories. These are all the original tales/stories by the original authors, not the stories as they were played out in the series. so if you want to read all of these wonderful original stories for a great price then buy this book. if you want to be reminded how Frankenstein animated his monster by getting a heart from the evil queen you won't find that here.

this isn't one of those match-three games you get bored with after playing only one or two times. the goal is to help the forest sprites rebuild the Tree of Life. you do this by completing different match-three scenes to build up the needed supplies. in each scene you need to match a certain amount of three different items (although there are about five or six different items mixed on each board. you also need to match as many coins as possible to build up enough to buy a bonus when they are needed (like a hammer to knock out an item in one cell or lightning for a whole column). although there are some cells in some puzzles you can only get rid of by using a bonus (in every puzzle each cell must be cleared at least once) there was never a puzzle that could not be finished. the puzzles progressively get harder but like I just said none are so hard that you cannot complete it. in all this is a very fun and relaxing game.

got this as the FAOTD I do not regret it. it's a bunch of interactive scenes where characters/items pop in for the player to place anywhere in the scene. sometime they will react if placed in certain spots (for example: place something on the slide and it will slide down). the grocery store scene is a game where after you place the children in the aisle a picture will pop-up and while the children walk down the aisle the player has to find that item and place it in the cart. I have several nieces and nephews under the age of 9 and this is a favorite of them all (especially the one that turns three next month). they all enjoy sitting with their aunt so we can play with the "game-pad" together.

if you enjoy zuma (another name is marble saga) you will more than enjoy this game. basically this is zuma with a fun twist: the first and main goal is to get rid of the ball that are outside of the ball path (there will be one or two groups of balls the path of the other balls go around. while other zuma type games made for the android devices are harder to control without the arrow buttons that the older phones had that is not the case here. zuma plays with the controller in the center and you use the arrows to turn and shoot. with this game the controller is on the bottom and you slide it back and forth to get into the needed position. I do highly recommend this game.

if you enjoy zuma then definitely get this game. while, without actual arrow buttons that a phone has, it's harder to control with practice you will eventually get the hang of it. one little warning though, this is the EXACT same thing as Marble Saga developed by popcag game. each puzzle/maze is an exact copy so if you have one of these games don't waste your money on the other. neither one is better or worse than the other so I'm not endorsing one over the other, just making you aware so you don't waste money buying a game you already have.

if you enjoy zuma then definitely get this game. while, without actual arrow buttons that a phone has, it's harder to control with practice you will eventually get the hang of it. one little warning though, this is the EXACT same thing as Marble Saga 2 developed by wagnan. each puzzle/maze is an exact copy so if you have one of these games don't waste your money on the other. neither one is better or worse than the other so I'm not endorsing one over the other, just making you aware so you don't waste money buying a game you already have.

this app is just as much fun as any of the other alchemy games. I like the feature that your mix section and list of items available to mix are on the same screen. no going back and forth over and over again to pick what you want to mix. the big thing that knocks down the rating is although the game saves your mixes when you leave the game and come back the part of the screen that you do the mixing is blank. you shouldn't have to keep a list or make a mental note of what exactly you were doing when last you left the game.

I enjoy playing the different alchemy games (alchemy, and all the doodle ones). there are a few aspects that set this one apart from the rest. one of the best being that one the page where you choose what animals you want to attempt to mix on the main page has two sort options: alphabetical or in order of when they were made. this second option makes it soooo much easier to figure out what you have attempted to mix with other animals. at first it was hard to figure out why certain mixes made other animals, but when you look at the info for an animal it lists the attributes of that animal that can be used to mix with others. to make the animal on the games icon (mouse with wings) you would think mix a mouse and any bird. but no-mix a mouse only with a bird with wings listed on it's mixable traits. hope that helps with those having trouble mixing animals or trying to make sense of why some mixes work and others don't. while some alchemy games aren't necessarily appropriate for kids (even some games with a kids rating option in the game have some mixes that shouldn't be there) since this is strictly animals I have no problem letting the younger playing this one. in all I highly recommend this game. definitely fun for all ages.

I love playing with all the pathpix games so I didn't think twice when I purchased this app on the first day with no reviews showing yet (yep, sorry, I am late posting my review). I have finished with all the pictures in this particular one and I can say this game does not disappoint. as with previous pathpix games the puzzles start out easy and progressively get more challenging. there have been one or two puzzles in some of the earlier pathpix games where it took me a few days (or several hours of actual play time) of refiguring different lines over and over again until the solution was found. While, by the end there were some very challenging puzzles I did not have any that took me longer than an hour of playtime. please keep these games coming. they are very enjoyable even when replaying

a long and challenging game that we have all been waiting for.  I was surprised to see a second release in one week. this game does not disappoint. long game (with bonus chapter included), great graphics,  new wnd interesting (somewhat twisted) storyline, great new puzzles that get increasingly difficult as the game progresses (with a skip button if needed), strategy guide included,  and I could go on and on.  this is by far a 5 star game but I took one off because I couldn't get a couple of puzzles to respond to touch and/or it wasn't always clear enough about how you were supposed to accomplish the goal of the puzzles. other than that no glitches playing on the kindle fire.

An unconventional pastiche, 'A Study In Terror' is a novelization of the somewhat overlooked 1965 film of the same name; although whilst several prominent plot points remained, it does very much deviate from the movie it was based on. Additionally, in the tradition of those "editorial" notes which find themselves preluding many Watsonian manuscripts, explaining where this lost adventure you are about to read was uncovered, this book takes that trope a step further, weaving its origin into the story itself. Ellery Queen, knee deep into a writer's block, finds himself the unwilling recipient of what is purported to be Dr Watson's journal, but who sent it to his acquaintance, and, more importantly, why?Thus, the reader has two mysteries to unravel, and while neither are overly complex, they both provoke the mental gears into turning, or else one risks losing the threads entirely. We follow Ellery as he reads the journal piecemeal, every chapter or two interspersed with his ruminations on what he has just read, and his acquaintance's investigation into how the manuscript came to be in his hands.The case itself, as I mentioned, was not very difficult to solve, but there was still much fun to be had in unraveling this mystery. Aside from that, the exceptional characterizations helped me to overlook some of the more easily guessed at aspects. This was, if nothing else, a convincing pastiche that admirably met the task of conjuring Holmes & Watson as penned by Doyle.What I did not expect from this was the twist, of sorts, at the denouement. Instead of Holmes cleanly solving the riddle, and Watson writing it down for posterity, we learn that the doctor has leapt to the wrong conclusions in penning it, with the actual solution (that we learn Holmes was aware of) being well concealed somewhere in the journal's pages. In that regard, it excelled as not only pitch-perfect pastiche, but traditionally structured mystery, where all the clues are hidden in plain sight and the solution is logically explained at the denouement. Overall, I found it to be an excellent read worthy of Holmesian attention.

While I have felt something intangible has been lacking in the past few albums, overall, I found this new release a refreshing collection, with several truly solid tracks more reminiscent of the Trans-Siberian Orchestra of yore, where the sounds of rock and classical blended into the perfect marriage. Albeit, though I enjoy both genres tremendously, personally found the only "misses" for me were those inclusive of vocals more suited to outdated '80s "metal", as in my humble estimation, it degraded what could have been a harmonic masterpiece into unforgivable cheesiness.'Not Dead Yet' was probably the worst offender and weakest of the lot - not bad, but a few stylistic tweaks and less coarse vocals would have salvaged it quite nicely. 'The Night Conceives' also suffers from this problem, though to a lesser degree; still I found it grating and something that did this album little credit. Classical vocals, I believe, have always worked best for this band.Despite this, a preponderance of material from Letters From The Labyrinth are not only excellent, they have the potential to become classics and hopefully mark a turning point for a tremendously talented band.

I am an avid reader of short stories, and find they often make the best introductions to excellent new series/authors. It is also no exaggeration to say that in my opinion, the best thing about the Kindle is how it brought back this format of writing by creating a new market for them, yet it is ones such as this that remind me why they fell out of favor in the first place.A quick, occasionally amusing read, Summer Rain may have been slightly on the predictable side, but its plot was, at least, going somewhere - that is, until the author abruptly cuts it off with the most trite and ineffective conclusion. A good short story is an art form, a bad one, nothing more than a diverting waste of time. Or in this case, an advertising ploy, since the story ended at the 50% mark to make room for an excerpt of the latest book in this series. Along with characters who were names devoid of personality, there to move things along, in all probability, this will be an author whose work I will not be revisiting.

In what I found to be an airy and insubstantial read entirely lacking in anything resembling Christmas spirit - despite its being specifically marketed as a holiday tale, this was one novella that suffered for its length and inevitably left me cold. Although the writing is lush and evocative of the era, it proves that a story should be more than its prose, and after a time, the dialogue becomes so overwritten that one character blends into another.Even so, Lady Emily manages to come off as vaguely pretentious, and, for a woman who certainly believes in egalitarianism, can be a bit too dismissive of her husband, even going so far as to mention "his opinion does not concern me in the least". Never mind Colin is portrayed as a limp rag - imagine if that statement were turned around.The plot itself is bland in the extreme, revolving around something of a personal mystery surrounding one of Lady Emily's new neighbors, a peculiar lady who at first glance appears to be on the verge of madness. It is obvious her condition connects with a ghostly apparition both she and lady Emily have both seen, and while it did have some involving aspects, before Lady Emily even does some digging on who this apparition might be, the solution is obvious, the mystery too easily, and anticlimactically, solved. It did have potential, but aside from my never warming to the characters, ultimately seemed too rushed and scraped together. I love a good Christmas short story, even when they stray from the usual trappings, but this was just not one of them. Actual rating would be 2.5 stars.

I went into this book almost hesitantly, supposing it would be a light, fluffy, cozy-type mystery with yet another modern author utilizing an established classic character; this time to reel in those vulnerable to the promise of Dickensian charms. Well, it proved neither of those things, and while historical accuracy was sometimes called into question, it did turn out to be intricately plotted, fast paced, and an unexpectedly pleasurable escapist read.Opening several days before Christmas, 1833, we are introduced to a young Ebenezer Scrooge, who has the makings of, but is not quite that embittered, stingy curmudgeon we see in A Christmas Carol. In fact, he is, if slightly pessimistic, fairly quick-witted, sympathetic for all his flaws, and endowed with almost Holmesian like deductive abilities that I wish the authors would have taken more advantage of throughout the course of the story.We meet Mr Scrooge in his counting house, where two visitors that will change the course of his life are about to enter stage left. One of them is Miss Adelaide Owen, a young woman applying for employment as a clerk, and the other... is the ghost of Fezziwig, who has apparently  been murdered that morning. It is Fezziwig who enlists the duo to bring his murderer to justice, with the added warning that not only will more die, Scrooge will be the last amongst that number. Reluctantly, they take up the investigation, aided by Charles Dickens himself, no less, and are rapidly thrown into the seediest corners of London's underworld, where they will encounter a murderer whose motives are deeper and darker than anything Dickens could have written of in his day. And might possibly even be of the supernatural realm...Of a much darker tone than would be expected in a Christmas story, The Humbug Murders was an expertly crafted mystery that truly had me doubting my own conclusions at every turn, with its well hidden clues strewn about and lively characters (many lifted from from the pages of other Dickens' novels) who each have their own motives for murder.While I felt it did nicely convey the atmosphere of an early Victorian London, the plethora of modern terms and anachronistic details peppering its pages could not be overlooked. For instance, while Robert Peel and his "bobbies" were officially formed in 1829, it would be decades before it functioned as it did in later years - that is to say, detective work was unheard of and Inspectors did not even exist. That detail, where constables took on the roles of investigating crimes, was more than a bit jarring, as was hearing an often crude modern expression when generally the dialogue and writing style came off as sufficiently antiquated. The anachronisms are my sole complaint, but those aside, I thoroughly enjoyed this book and would recommend it without reservation.

This book, or at least, its premise, seemed so promising, but as an avid mystery reader I did not find that it delivered on any of those promises. While not actually bad or anything that defied credulity, the plot still manages to become simplistic because the author relies more on coincidence than brain work on her detective's behalf.On that note, Lavender and Woods have the faint whiff of cardboard about them, though perhaps they were fleshed out more fully in the first book - which I have not read. But they were very much generic detectives, or rather, generic Holmes & Watson knockoffs, and there was nothing even vaguely unique about him or what I hesitate to call his methods.I found myself growing increasingly annoyed as it played out, not only because of the irritating nature of many side characters plucked straight from the Book Of Cliches (don't get me started on how gratingly banal her "mobs" are), but because unbeknownst to this reader, a romance was also part and parcel with the book. I found myself skipping over the scenes with Magdalena, who is herself a caricature, because I simply do not care to have my mysteries with a side order of romantic angst. It's an annoying trend in historical mysteries lately, that just when the plot picks up, out of the blue will come a chapter devoted to the detective's love interest, and the story veers off into soap opera territory from thenceforth.Inevitably, that is what forced me to give up on this, even though I hate leaving books unfinished.

This program is the gold standard for how history documentaries ought to be produced. Engaging entertainment that never sacrifices the quality of its content. From the lingering traces of Roman conquest to the devastation caused by the plague, to the science of modern crime scene analysis that was pioneered by Scotland Yard, and the technological and architectural innovations of the Victorian era, it is comprehensive and paints a unique perspective on some very old subject matter. Each episode covers a single topic, yet they are dealt with in such a broad manner the series in its entirety covers every imaginable aspect of London's rich, and often bloody, history. Anglophiles and history buffs alike should take delight at this first rate production.

For several months, I had 'Art In The Blood' on pre-order, which is something I almost never do, and was greatly looking forward to a book that gave every appearance of being a traditionally penned Sherlock Holmes story. Alas, it disappoints me to admit not only was this nothing of the sort, it has also gone a fair way in causing me to reconsider the wisdom in continuing to read pastiches by modern writers. It has been apparent for a while now that certain television and movie characterizations have leaked into published Holmes novels, yet here, the author maintains a pathetic knowledge of Canon and, as she admits herself, makes no attempt whatsoever in imitating the characterization or writing style (the latter, I admit, is far less of an issue) of Doyle's creations.Therefore, before the story itself began to fall apart, my main gripe was that these men referred to as Sherlock Holmes and Dr Watson were anything but; though her Watson is not so lamentable, and even fairly good at times, Holmes was entirely unrecognizable to this stodgy old Canon purist. On that note, however, it must be said that the greatest flaw of this book was not actually the intentionally skewered characterizations, but what passed for its plot.After Watson is married and his wife is away visiting her mother (apparently, Mary Morstan is not an orphan in this author's world), he is summoned to Baker Street, where Holmes is languishing in a black mood after a stint in prison. Nothing the doctor can do rouses him, until an interesting missive requesting his assistance in the possible kidnapping of the woman's young boy comes along. Holmes then journeys to Paris, where it appears, aside from some utter twaddle regarding the man becoming besotted with a client, there lies a nice, juicy mystery ahead.Except, this is where the plot begins to unravel and the nonsense begins. Along with this investigation of the disappeared child, Mycroft has enlisted Holmes to look into the whereabouts of a stolen statue which it turns out connects to the kidnapping case. Instead of the two plots intersecting gradually, after interviewing the Parisian woman, Holmes and Watson magically end up at a nightclub where the most utterly ridiculous and extraneous "action" scene transpires. There, he meets Vidocq (can we say derivative?), who has also been enlisted by the child's mother/his paramour. Of course, being the glorified fanfiction this is, we get to see a jealous!Holmes whose emotions cloud his judgement.Not, in all honesty, that it would matter, because this kidnapping "investigation" goes absolutely nowhere, not even in a circle as it chases its own tail, and after a second, pointless interview with the child's mother, Holmes arrives in London and gets the solution to the case handed to him on a silver platter by Mycroft. You read this correctly. At around page 110, Mycroft basically just tells him where the boy is, and as a favor for this piece of information, has his brother go undercover at the house of the boy's adopted parents, who, we just magically are told out of thin air, is the art thief who stole the statue. To be fair, Holmes does find this out himself whilst disguised at the docks, but there is not even a sentence of explanation as to how he made the connection betwixt the shipping yards and the thief. Loose threads such as this littered the story, and really made it impossible to continue holding my attention when we know everything from motive to perpetrator 1/3 of the way through the story.In short, though I am loath to leave books unfinished, it took me five or six days just to slog through to somewhere over page 230, where I finally had to admit defeat. An airy, insubstantial, incredibly dumbed down version of Doyle's creation, the Holmes we were presented with here was but a pale intimation of that great intellect, the "introspective and pallid dreamer of Baker Street", and replaced with an action figure more suited for modern audiences who prefer to check their little grey cells at the front door in regards to their reading material. Quite frankly, this was BBC fanfiction with a thinly veiled Sherlock & John in something vaguely resembling the Victorian era, and although saying as much will no doubt get me burned in effigy, it is indeed a sad day if this is what the future of pastiche is destined to become.In conclusion, this is not a recommended read for Holmesians, those of that dying breed who prefer the intellectualism of the originals over sensationalism. I also noticed this book was not endorsed by the ACD estate, and whilst that has never been a factor which weighed at all with me, if this is what does /not/ get approved or vetted by the estate, then I might just have to reconsider that stance.

It is incredible how, at the tenth book in this series, I not only find each new installment brings something new, fresh and original to the table, this dynamic duo of authors has made me fall in love with Agent Pendergast all over again. Or even harder than before, if that is even possible. Through a hypothyroid haze, which usually makes reading or concentrating on anything for more than two point five seconds an impossibility, this book could not be pried out of my hands for any enticement - it is such artfully crafted suspense of action and character developments I was hard pressed to put it down. I particularly enjoyed the healthy doses of D'Agosta (thank you very much for that, o authors) who was back in form here after I felt his characterization wavered a bit in Cemetery Dance. An excellent addition to the series and most entertaining diversion.

The eighth installment of the Agent Pendergast series proved a thrilling change of pace after completing the Diogenes trilogy, and despite a seeming barrage of lukewarm or hostile reviews, which made me half expect this to be a disappointment, it was an excellent, thrilling adventure that ties up some loose ends left over from The Book of the Dead. And very satisfactorily, at that.True, this one diverged from the other books, sometimes dramatically so, yet Pendergast was more his old self here, and proves his worth as a sleuth as he tracks through Europe an ancient artifact which has been stolen from a Tibetan monastery. I did not find the setting detracting in the least, and in fact was a favorable welcome, with some very nail-biting scenes on the high seas.Personally, I did not view this as a weak link in a phenomenal series, only a book that starts off a bit weakly then takes off full speed ahead. A very, very enjoyable, exciting, and a lavishly written read.

While this film has undoubtedly garnered some mixed feelings from this particular viewer, if one is patient and is able to suspend disbelief during the more over the top elements, The Physician can be appreciated as a commendably acted, (mostly) cerebral view into an 11th century medical profession that was lamentably bereft of adequate knowledge. With absolutely stunning cinematography that brings to life the medieval Middle east, a twisting plot line and characters that invoke emotion, there is too much here to overlook it because of its glaring - and oft intentional - historical inaccuracies.Opening in medieval London, we are introduced to Rob Cole, who is only a boy when his mother dies, but seems to have a perception or instinct that warns him someone is nearing death. Taken in by a sympathetic "barber" who performs medical procedures from his travelling caravan, it is this skill, along with a love of learning, that assists him throughout his apprenticeship, of sorts, to the barber. In all honesty, I nearly gave up on it entirely for the first twenty minutes or so, because it just gets so... odd during Cole's apprenticeship in London.Apparently, medicine has not just stagnated and become a dubious practice, but there are no such things as doctors or hospitals, and no one even knows what the terms mean, which is, of course, entirely the fault of the Church in England, whom it is clearly stated equates the art of medicine with "necromancy". They were also the sole reason the old knowledge of Hippocrates was lost (fall of the Roman Empire, anyone?) - but when monks start throwing punches in the street, I must have gazed at my computer screen in abject stupefaction. That... was more than a little heavy handed.Nonetheless, I persisted, and it did indeed improve vastly once Rob begins his trek to the middle eastern lands to find the noted physician, Ibn Sina (portrayed gloriously by Ben Kingsley), where medicine was far more advanced. Islamic and Judaic history also suffer to a milder degree from warpage by either the author of the book this was based on or whoever dramatized the script. It's not quite so over the top, however, and takes a backseat to the story, as not long after Cole arrives, a plague infection breaks out, and while the methods by which the doctors at Ibn Sina's medical university control and effectually cure the disease would not be hit upon until the early 20th century (though some plague experts do believe it was a contagion related to Ebola and not bubonic plague), it made for excellent fodder in watching Cole blossom into one of the best students at the university.With a smattering of romance, intrigue and the political uphevals of the day, The Physician made for a movie I became very involved in, and would certainly recommend it to anyone interested in the ancient Near East and/or the history of medical practices. I enjoyed it on both accounts, and found it to be an excellent movie if one was willing to sift through the flaws and inaccuracies. When all was said and done, I was even interested enough by this production to look into the novel it was based on.

For the past few installments of the Pitt series, in particular, the quality of Ms Perry's work has varied considerably - some I have greatly enjoyed for what they were, whilst others were consigned to a pile in the farthest recesses of my bookshelf, never to be looked upon again. Unfortunately, this latest effort not only falls into the latter category, it is quite possibly the only book to this author's credit that I have ever deemed truly terrible, despite having read a few "misses" penned by her over the years.Our humdrum case begins with Thomas Pitt being called upon by Sir Walter to keep guard over a Spanish nun and her "acolytes" who have been the recipients of threats, and whose safety Special Branch is taking seriously as it might cause friction with Spain if she were to be harmed on British soil. From thence, the storyline rolls into one excuse after another to degrade Christians, Catholics in particular, and throughout all this soap-boxing against religion and Victorian morality, the investigation goes /absolutely nowhere/, reads more like a gritty police procedural, while that magical feel of the era Perry is always able to convey in her novels regardless of their overall quality, is entirely lacking. Even when her plots go downhill, her books never fail to provide an engrossing read that allows one to travel back into time.I have ever admired the way Anne Perry portrays the underbelly of Victorian London along with the highest echelons of society, and rather than moralizing (which she really is in no position to do), paints a beautiful, if shocking picture of that world. The Angel Court Affair does nothing but paint the ugliness, with characters who are cynical, bitter and nothing like the Thomas and Charlotte Pitt I have come to know.In all honesty, I do find myself wondering if Ms Perry has acquired a ghost writer or two whilst she takes a creative holiday. This book was just so poorly constructed, lifeless, its overall theme so bleakly derisive, the writing style (dare I say almost hard boiled, at times) veering so significantly from her past works, I can come up with no other conclusions. As for myself, I derived no enjoyment from this, and as a long-time admirer of Ms Perry's works, have nonetheless decided it is time to put the Pitt series, at least, on temporary hold.

A definite improvement over the last installment, 'Shadow of the Raven' was an elegantly written novel that I was glad to see did periodically return to the series roots as an intelligent glimpse of detection at the dawn of the scientific age. The research concerning the Enclosure Act brought it to life, the descriptions (which never felt like random info dumps) of how its enactment affected the daily lives of commoners who literally depended on the land for survival, was so educational as to be almost historical non-fiction. I honestly found it fascinating.As usual, the mystery was original, and Dr Silkstone skillfully applies his expertise at pathology in the solving of it. Whenever we get to see him in action, the story takes off.
