Sir Montagu Malthus, the recurring villain, has recruited a surveyor to chart the common lands, and when Turgoose is murdered, Silkstone is called in to perform a post mortem and set the matter to rest. Suspicion, of course, lies with the peasants who derive their livelihood from Ravens's Wood Forest, but the clues may not lead to them, after all. Meanwhile, the drama surrounding Lady Lydia's confinement to a mental institution continues, smothering the life out of the story with practically every scene devoted to her.Unfortunately the only true complaint I have about this book is the reliance it placed on a sordid romance angle, which was not only applied with too heavy a hand throughout, it verged on frustrating for how slowly that facet is developing. It was maddening, like a drawn out soap opera.That excessive amount of emphasis placed on melodrama and extraneous details caused me to frequently struggle with this. I do enjoy a tinge of romance, but it had the tendency to overwhelm an otherwise excellent mystery. Lady Lydia is becoming an annoyingly overdone damsel in distress, and not even a very interesting one, at that. While my technical rating would be 3.5 stars, I still found the good to outweigh the lifeless parts. That being said, I would love to see Dr Silkstone return his focus on crime...

Short stories are my favorites when well penned, and this one was decidedly so. Not being familiar with the novels, I found it richly drawn, steeped in the atmosphere of the time period it was quite simple to guess it took place within, and for such a quick read, the mystery was exceptionally clever, solved entirely by Flavia's considerable knowledge of science.Alan Bradley undoubtedly has a natural talent for contriving a believable, engaging mystery, yet I found Flavia herself defied credulity. The precocious child sleuth seemed just a plot contrivance to make her different from other detectives, when in my estimation the eleven year old girl aspect lowered an otherwise serious book into the pre-teen or young adult category. Disappointing, because Mr Bradley would really have had something here if not for the device of utilizing a child as his main protagonist. An enjoyable read, nonetheless, which I would not hesitate to recommended for lovers of traditionally spun mysteries.

An outstanding example of early cinema that should appeal to any aficionado of the silent era, this 1922 film also proves its merit as a serious Holmesian adaptation. While there is no question liberties have been taken with characterization, a testament to the fact it was heavily based on William Gilette's infamous stage play, remarkably enough, those changes flow well with both the character and plot, so that this version of the Great Detective's exploits is actually not so Canonically dubious as this purist had originally imagined it might be.Featuring one of the most mesmerizing actors to fill the exalted role of Sherlock Holmes, John Barrymore's portrayal cannot be overlooked. True, the acting was above par, the plot strikingly complex, but he slips into the character so thoroughly, sans all those extraneous trappings not found in the stories, which would later become synonymous with Holmes due to the innumerable other actors who left their mark, even the love aspect becomes tolerable - if not believable. It is obvious Barrymore is deriving a monumental portion of his inspiration from Canon, because while there /is/ a love interest for him in the form of Alice Faulkner, his Holmes remains a thinker, his deductions and solutions deeply motivated in intellectualism. And make no mistake, while it does involve a romance, it is more of a background sub-plot, and this film is decidedly not a love-story.On that account, though, being such an early example, Barrymore has mainly the books to gain insight from, and that is apparent in the way in which he plays a Sherlock Holmes under the spell of Cupid's arrow. His Holmes is obviously head over heels, but still manages to come off as tentatively innocent, quietly reserved about what must be an overwhelming emotion for one so accustomed to repressing them. He is blessedly free of theatricality, truly the "quiet thinker of Baker Street".As a general rule, I normally find romance to be off-putting character assassination, but developing it as he did with the confines of how Holmes might react without losing his formidable acumen, Barrymore not only convinced me it could have happened in such a way, but also made it quite endearing. From a personal standpoint, he epitomized Sherlock Holmes for me that well. As did the film itself, its plot strikingly complex, with the entirety of it reminiscent of several Canon stories. I even lost count of how many deductions and snippets of dialogue it paid homage to. And cleverly, too, with a Moriarty that was given a prominent presence and was possibly one of the most ominously creepy Napoleon of Crimes to grace the silver screen until Eric Porter later epitomized the role.Roland Young, unlike others who would follow shortly thereafter, portrays a capable, multifaceted Watson who is a schoolmate of Holmes' at Cambridge, as is Prince Alexis, who has been wrongly accused of theft and petitions the doctor for help. Watson, of course, petitions Holmes to look into the matter, where he sees Moriarty's hand, but is at the present unable to thwart the Professor. After the initial case is resolved - or rather, covered up by Moriarty - Holmes loses sympathy for the Prince regarding his ill treatment of his fiance, who also happens to be the sister of Alice Faulkner. There both his interest in her and that case will lie to rest until many years later, when he learns Moriarty is out to harm Miss Faulkner, who intends to use letters of her sister to blackmail the Prince (a la SCAN), letters he wants for his own nefarious purposes...In summation; intricate plotting, a (apologies, but I must admit it) satisfying romance, competent Dr Watson, Barrymore's eccentric, cerebral Holmes who epitomizes the character, intelligent "dialogue" that did not require the complete cessation of neuronal activity, and one pretty impressive Moriarty, made for an extremely enjoyable silent film which is, from a  personal standpoint, deserving of being ranked alongside other Holmesian classics. My only complaint is that Watson, while faithful to the man described in the original stories, his relationship with Holmes ringing true, was shamefully underused here. If that were not the case, I would be hard pressed to say this were not the greatest underrated film adaption. As it stands, its definitely one of the better ones, and really should be viewed by those who love the silents and serious Holmesians alike.

For newcomers to the Ian Rutledge series, 'A Fine Summer's Day' is the perfect introductory. An intricately crafted plot of seemingly disconnected threads, which are linked at its denouement, serves as a conduit for the fleshing out of those characters and situations appearing throughout the previously written books, making this latest installment work well as a standalone or prequel to readers familiar with the other novels. Atmosphere plays as important a role as the story itself; the writers managed to meticulously bring across into its pages the somber pall hanging over England during that ominous summer of 1914.There was much in the way of personal drama for the cast of characters, and the political intrigue that would eventually lead to the Great War was seamlessly threaded into this aspect, and that of the mystery Rutledge is called upon to solve. It was as much well researched historical that truly drew me into the era.Beautifully written, with a complex mystery that should prove difficult for the most seasoned mystery readers to solve, Charles Todd's latest is at its heart the story of how Inspector Rutledge came to be who he is, presented here as the vibrantly youthful man he was before heeding the call of duty and enlisting in the war. I found it to be a believable contrast from his older, more haunted self in "later" books, and unlike many prequel/character study oriented novels, I appreciated the focus remained on Rutledge's investigation.Overall, it tilted a bit on the side of slowly paced, but proved an exemplary read that I felt made for a strong inclusion to the series.

Having read one of the Sydney Chamber's novels a few years back, I must confess to being somewhat disappointed in the televised series, which, with each ensuing episode, is rapidly spiraling into a more uninspired - and uninspiring - mystery featuring an Anglican priest who is fairly adept at solving crime, as was the character from the novel, yet unlike his fictionalized counterpart, the series leaves much to be desired in the portrayal of this drinking, smoking, spiritually apathetic priest.Changes have also been effectuated to the script that irreparably distorted the original mysteries, making them dull and contrived, while also adding elements of crassness here and there which are nonexistent in the book.Based on its own merits, Granchester does have potential. While the storyline lacked originality, and plodded along too predictably, the characters of Chambers and Inspector Keating are the only noteworthy aspects to emerge from the hash that was made of it. This is one instance where the adaptation did not simply lose the flavor of the books - it simply lost all flavor whatsoever, however, James Norton and Robson Green do their absolute finest with the rather prosaic material. I am willing to continue watching in the hope for improvements, but those changes will need to be profound if Granchester is to be salvaged.

Dare I say it of a mere pilot of an Amazon original series? Yes, I shall - 'Point Of Honor' is unequivocally the finest period dramatization of the Civil War era since the illustrious Gone With The Wind. I exaggerate not; this was a lavishly produced, gripping, emotive glimpse into the lives of Southerners who both supported and renounced the institution of slavery, but who chose to fight for their home, ideals, and literally everything they knew and were born into, crumbling around their ears though it was with the Union invasion. Herein is portrayed admirably what it meant for brother to be pitted against brother, father against son, and that ultimate, very human cost of this familial betrayal for North and South alike.Truly, it evoked the conflicting emotions of these men forced to choose their country versus personal honor, this sentiment never captured more wonderfully than in the scene at West Point, when John Rhodes excuses himself to fight for the Confederacy, reading a letter written to his sister renouncing slavery but adamant to defend his home and state's right to secession.Furthermore, 'Point Of Honor', to my great relief, strayed from the trend of films that villainize all European Americans over a lamentable period in history, while portraying what every Southerner in that time stood to lose, the human toll it took on real families and communities, offering a glimpse of precisely why the Civil War's reverberations are to this day felt so deeply in the lands this awful war was fought upon. By not casting all whites as evil monsters, while also rejecting an outdated institution, this program is an incredible step in the right direction.Aside from that positive light, I genuinely found this to be quite an absorbing drama, its characters lively and bold, despairing that it ended with only one episode to its credit. If this theme is continued, I would gladly watch more, and think it would be a shame if a program of this caliber were discontinued.

As a novel I had been looking forward to for quite some time, never mind that I understood it was set to take liberties with the usual confines of a pastiche, 'Moriarity' ultimately turned out to be an unsatisfying foray into the world of Sherlock Holmes for reasons other than its lack of a Watsonian narration.It begins at the Reichenbach Falls, after the fatal struggle between the great detective and his adversary, where Inspector Athelney Jones of Scotland Yard (who only ever appeared in SIGN), along with a Pinkerton detective by name of Frederick Chase have both been summoned to inspect the recently recovered body of one Professor Moriarty. Chase, we soon learn, finds himself in Switzerland on the heels of an American criminal mastermind to rival the erstwhile Napoleon of Crime, who is effectually spreading his tentacles around London, and will soon be a worse menace than Moriarty ever was. Chase and Jones subsequently join forces in something meant to resemble a Holmes and Watson type association, to track this unknown mastermind back to London, led there by a note discovered in the pocket of the dead man.Athelney Jones has become so far removed from the ineffectual blunderer he was written as in Canon, where he literally pulls asinine assumptions out of his proverbial hat, that I originally wondered if he was indeed not Sherlock Holmes in disguise. Since his last case with Holmes, as described in Horowitz's absolutely brilliant short story 'The Three Monarchs' - which any Holmesians out there really ought to read, even if this particular book does not strike one's fancy - Jones has battled illness, and in his dejection over being showed up by an "amateur theorist" a second time around, has taken to studying, replicating to perfection, even, Holmes' methods during his downtime from the Yard. Jones certainly does come off as an overdone caricature of Sherlock Holmes, presented in too similar a fashion to the detective and so unlike even the most perceptive Yarders, it's difficult to believe this Athelney Jones and the one Watson tells us of are not entirely separate entities. And yet, once more of his background is divulged, and the investigation with Chase plays on, he does become a sympathetic, likable character in his own rights.The book had a tendency toward rambling, drawing out a case with what appeared to be unnecessary lulls in the action or depictions of violence - and make no mistake, this rival, or so we are led to believe, indulges in outrageous acts of violence/torture, while giving the impression he is far more brawn than brains. Without elaborating, this aspect was one of many flaws in the story, particularly with the ending, or rather, how Horowitz ties up the loose threads. Which takes me to my absolute main gripe, which I perceive to be an unpardonable authorial sin.For all its uniqueness, shall we say, 'Moriarity' was otherwise an enjoyable, artfully written book, a weak form of pastiche, yet truly a solid novel in its own rights. The blow, however, falls somewhere around the next to last chapter, and does it ever hit hard! The problem entails the very ending, just before the loose ends are explained, and was not so much a plot twist as it was the revelation of a dirty trick that has been played on the reader from the opening chapter. It actually made me angry, a good thing, I suppose, as it indicates I was invested in these characters, but aside from my reaction to this "twist", the book fizzled out dramatically in the remaining 30 or so pages. I felt if it /had/ to be done that way, a brief few sentences, several  paragraphs at most, could have concluded it neatly without the endless exposition that only further annoyed. To say this could have been a Holmesian classic that ended poorly is a gross understatement. I found the ending to be a disastrous mess that ruined the entire book, like a domino effect in reverse.My final rating, for whatever it is worth would be that 'Moriarity' held up far better as a classically plotted mystery, especially as any Victorian atmosphere was a bit lacking, then it did if being read as an unorthodox pastiche. This may not be for many Holmesians, especially us stuffy old hats for whom nothing can ever rival the original Canon. That being said, I found the majority of it to be immensely enjoyable, and have settled for a three star rating to balance out the horrible conclusion which might otherwise have earned this offering two stars at most if the rest had been any less engaging. All that having been said, Horowitz remains an author I respect, enjoy reading, and certainly wish to see more pastiches from in the future.

With the overwhelming majority of Christmas compilations disappointing in terms of their neutral winter "holiday" content or predilection for taking questionable artistic liberties with well-loved carols, I nearly refrained from purchasing this album - that, and I hadn't much interest in what I assumed might be a promotional item for the series. It was, then, a pleasant little revelation to hear the strains of such beautifully sung traditional late Victorian/Edwardian era hymns, the entirety of which are deeply rooted in British culture.Aside from two inclusions of instrumental themes for the series, and, as I understand it, a few of the actors lending their voices on a number of tracks, the finished product was a refreshing return to traditionalist music that avoided relying too heavily on the television series to carry it off. The most exquisite rendition of 'Panis Angelicus' was of of particular noteworthiness, along with several inclusions by Julian Ovenden that conveyed the wonder of this magical season. And of course, the King's College choir contributed some of the most ethereal and transportive devotionals.This may be an album connected to the Downton Abbey franchise, yet there was nothing that reeked of commercialism here. Only heavenly carols that hearkened back to a bygone era, and emphasized the birth of Christ as being the true reason for the season of Peace on earth and goodwill towards our fellow men.

Rarely have I read anything that opened so superbly as 'The Revolutions'. It was impressive with its fantastic, yet simultaneously authentic depictions of the Victorian fascination with all things occult, the peculiar events Arthur is thrust into, and the romance between him and Josephine which very much showcased what a strong grasp on characterization the author started off with. This book begins as serious historical fiction - with a steampunk twist - reminiscent of Dickens in many veins. The circumstances of the story itself may be off the beaten track, but the descriptions, events and players were so well drawn as to exceed my wildest expectations.After the incident with Josephine, however, it devolved so rapidly, I had to convince myself I was not dreaming, and that the book had actually switched to a Martian setting, where we follow one of the characters who has become stranded on the Red Planet and sift through pages of exposition regarding her experiences therein. All the same, I would gladly have allotted this five stars - and then some - even after it began falling to pieces, as there were still plenty of scenes that made the read worthwhile, that gave glimpses of how outstanding a story it began as.Alas, this was a truly excellent novel irrevocably ruined as it derailed further and further off of what it had been and devolved into something that had no place in this book, not after nearly two hundred pages of setting up the events taking place in London. It not only destroyed the atmosphere so grandiosely achieved, but made the character of Arthur seem inconsistent. The writing was captivating, the characters were fantastic; I had been completely drawn into this world only for the author himself to pluck me out of this wondrous version of London.It strays from the lively atmosphere of Victorian seances into something utterly nonsensical that overshadowed the entire story. The Martian angle would have been great in another book entirely. Despite my complaints regarding the ending, I believe that if a good hundred or so pages were eliminated, and less time elapsed between the start of Josephine's predicament and the point at which she is rescued, even then the last several chapters might have been salvaged, and would have given the book as a whole a Jules Verne feel.Instead, it began to shift from the scenes on Mars to an often overdone element of magical realism - I felt the magician's war unraveled it not only in terms of plot, but with too many erratic changes in the characters. To an extent this extends to the author as well, as his views on the occult and God seem to swing like a pendulum. Then to be bounced back and forth into the heavy science fiction aspect of the Martian world was just too much for me. Somewhere around Chapter Twenty-Seven I became disgusted with what 'The Revolutions' had turned into. From previously adoring this work and being completely invested in Arthur and Josephine, I felt how the story played out was a severe disappointment due to its sheer absurdity. Although I enjoyed a good deal of this book, I had to push it away in frustration after completing it. This could have been one of my favorite stories... as it stands, I hope to entirely forget it and the promise it held at the outset.

This could have been an interesting new spin on alternate history had it not been so predictable from a very early stage, which any reader who has even a passing knowledge of the events surrounding and unfolding after WWI could easily see through. I knew precisely where Mr Cook was headed with this story when he very obviously refers to the war of 1914 as the Great War, when it is set in 1960s America.Herr Altman, upon concluding a speech to commemorate the 50th Anniversary of Armistice Day, meets a frail, tired looking old man who attended the same school as him before the war, and who clutches a "mysterious" manuscript to his chest. The entire story becomes one prolonged conversation between the two men, with some admittedly nice emphatic realizations on behalf of Altman, but even the sparse crumbs of interest that get dropped here and there are left suspended in the air.Having previously read several stories in the Bibliomysteries series, I definitely expect them to be short and concise, but this is the only one where I can say that its brevity was to its own detriment. Over 25 pages of dialogue between Altman and this nameless ex-soldier were not nearly absorbing enough to warrant being the entire focal point - nor did the intended weight of learning the man's identity have its desired effect, since it was so obvious from an early point who he was.As I mentioned, if the author had taken a less predictable route, this could have been decent, but as it was executed, I felt the story was flat and, sadly, rather pointless.

One does not have to be a vintage aeroplane enthusiast to appreciate this delightfully absurd movie revolving around the historic 1910 London-to-Paris air race, although I doubt the actual event was quite so entertaining. The humor sparkles with classic British wit, much physical comedy, while never veering off into the realm of slapstick.Produced in a time long before the advent of CGI or sophisticated wardrobes, the period costumes were excellent, even the dubiously constructed planes go a fair way in recreating the atmosphere of Edwardian England. This is a movie that is not meant to be taken seriously; all the same, it does do a far better job than any 1960s production I am aware of in keeping true to the era.Anyone who appreciates solid acting, the variety of which simply does not exist in any form in modern movies, I dare say this will be a treat to watch. For such a silly comedy, there were some nice moments, and more subtleties than I would have expected. The cast made a superb effort so that the physical scenes are cute without being stupidly so.I have seen a similar films from the time period which I found to be unwatchable for all the overly saccharine silliness. Thar be only clever dialogue here. I am also a little surprised this is not more popular with the Neo-Victoriana crowds, since the cinematography allows for such a realistic peek into the mechanical ingenuity that marked the early twentieth century.

In typical Anne Perry fashion, her latest Thomas & Charlotte Pitt novel begins on a high note, the action never wavering from the opening to its denouement. While this series has ever been rife with rich historical details, Death On Blackheath combines her usual lush descriptions that so completely transport the reader into the time period with pacing so remarkably quick, I believe this may be one of Perry's best literary efforts to date.Instead of sputtering out, both Pitts are in excellent form here. I will ever marvel at the unique plots of these books, and this one in particular is more intricate than I have come to expect. There was much going on in terms of plotting, with twists and turns around ever corner, but Perry never loses the thread. I would go so far as saying this may be one of the most intricate storylines she has yet to contrive.Moreover, more attention is paid on Pitt's partner, Stoker, who has appeared in other works in this series though has previously been flat. I was glad to see him elaborated on, and am beginning to admire him (and many other of the side characters) just as much as the regulars. Perhaps we shall see more of Stoker in one of her Christmas novellas? Either way, a wonderful read from an author who I would swear only becomes stronger as time goes on.

*** THIS REVIEW CONTAINS MINOR SPOILERS ***When Mycroft Holmes dies suddenly, a now twice-widowed Dr Watson comes to be accidentally reunited with his old friend at the funeral, where Holmes confides in him that his brother's death was in fact a murder he intends to investigate. As Sherlock Holmes has sold his cottage in the Sussex Downs and moved back into Baker Street, he of course asks Watson to do the same. The first few opening chapters were a nicely done getting together of the detective and doctor in their golden years - the meat and potatoes, as it were, of a solid story, were in place. There was an attempt made at recreating those intellectual puzzles of the originals, the idea behind the ciphers was exceptionally clever, and the first few chapters came off as very polished for a first novel. It appeared then, as though we were in for a nice "retirement era" story that attempts to recreate, with a few obvious exceptions, the spirit of the duo's old days solving crimes in Victorian England.Except, that is the last thing it actually does.The case revolves around a series of murders where all the victims are "musical" and being killed in a very gruesome way. It made for a promising start, but the plot collapses quickly. The historical accuracy was nil - too much of the antagonist's motivation seemed rooted in 21st century sensibilities. It is one thing to take a topic that Watson would have had, for proprieties sake, to leave unpublished, yet another to insert modern situations and reactions to them into a Victorian setting. This contributed to straining an already thin plot. Aside from that, the killer's identity and reasoning behind his murder spree were veneer. There was, essentially, no mystery to solve.The characterizations were not exactly up to par, either. Lily Hudson - who is no substitute for her aunt, the estimable Mrs Hudson - was grating from the very page on which she was introduced, with her overdone cockney accent. Mycroft Holmes was apparently a Bohemian socialite. Holmes, I have to admit, was mostly himself, which is why I stuck with it all the way through. Watson starts off fairly well, however, does not get away so unscathed. Somewhere mid-way through, he becomes an absolute farcical bumbler, who contributed nothing whatsoever to the story and apparently had no other purpose than sleeping and eating. If this was an attempt  portraying the aging process, it was not a successful one.The way Holmes arrives at (or rather, jumps to) conclusions and solves each cipher are often pulled out of thin air. There is no solid reasoning behind why he should arrive at a certain answer or why one particular type of cipher was being used as opposed to another in any given instance, while the solutions seemed just a bit too contrived. At one point, Watson suggests bringing Lily Hudson into their confidences, his reasoning being he believes they might "need her intuition to supplement Holmes' logic"... and what Watson then goes on to refer to as his own "shambling efforts". In this case, my dear doctor, I would have to agree. This poor Watson had the whiff of Nigel Bruce about him.Which brings me to the antagonist, who was ultimately the reason I downgraded this book from the 4 stars I originally planned on rating it, to the 2.5-3 stars I settled for. Holmesians may have our differences, yet I think we can all agree it is indeed a sad day when a villain in a supposed Sherlock Holmes pastiche "giggles maniacally". Something, I realized, was gravely amiss when we discover the note left beside Mycroft Holmes' body is signed "love and bubbles". This quite literal lunatic asylum escapee who refers to himself as the "Goatslayer" is nothing more than a thinly veiled, less coherent BBC Jim Moriarity, a sad comic book character that ultimately ruined the entire book for me.On that note, the final problem here (no pun intended, I swear) was what I suspect the author intended to be the climax. Thinking it could not possibly get any worse after the obligatory Evil Villain Soliloquy we are subjected to, it literally skips from a high tension scene wherein Watson has been kidnapped and bound at the end of one chapter, to the next chapter opening with Holmes and Watson in front of a fire at Baker Street, with Holmes expounding on how he cracked the final code and discovered the doctor's whereabouts. This is not even anti-climactic. There was NO climax whatsoever. It literally went from dramatic scene to explanatory conclusion! I actually had to go back and re-read to make certain I had not missed anything.If anyone has made it this far, my sincerest apologies for the length of this review. Because of its few enjoyable aspects, I am sorry to rate it this low, would even consider other works by the same author, but cannot reconcile many of the major issues this book was plagued by. What did begin as a decent enough story was irreparably ruined by an unbelievable, comic book antagonist and the mess that was its last few chapters.

This may have been an artist I was unfamiliar with previously, but I pre-orderd it all the same (because, steampunk), and could not be more delighted with this imaginative book! It turned out to be exactly what I was hoping for. Featuring top quality designs that are primarily geared at adult colorists but suitable for all ages, the artwork is moderately complex while the pictures themselves exude Neo-Victoriana to perfection. Consisting of oddly wonderful gadgets, mechanized devices, automatons, and a few scattered ones of appropriately moustachioed gentlemen, this particular book should be appreciated by those who enjoy the more sci-fi side of steampunk - I've some new metallic colored pencils that have thus far gone well with the artwork. It is vastly different from the two other steampunk coloring books in my collection, and comes very highly recommended by this finicky lover of all things Victoriana.

The Raffles stories, written by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's brother-in-law as a lighthearted homage to Holmes and his Watson, require no introduction for anyone looking to enjoy them all over again in this definitive e-book edition. To those just discovering them, A.J. Raffles and "Bunny" Manders are certainly based on the their more famous crime fighting counterparts, yet they are not at all imitations. If you go into this expecting another Holmes knock-off, you will be sorely disappointed, because characterizations and writing style veers dramatically despite the nods and gentle pokes to the Sherlock Holmes Canon. Enjoy them for what they are, and not what they were based on.As a side note, the formatting is excellent; the editors have even gone so far as to chronologically order both the short and novel length stories. This is a complete and unabridged edition, made even better for the inclusion of several classic pastiches, most of which I have not previously been able to find elsewhere.

For most of us stuffy Holmesians, this movie will never amount to much more than an "alternate universe" reworking of the first meeting between the doctor and detective, and yet, there is not a single adaptation that can claim it is anything other than another writer's revitalization of our much beloved characters. When one considers the liberties taken with Holmes & Watson of late, any deviations here are tame by comparison. This was written with the utmost respect for the source material, and not by someone attempting to outdo Doyle, so in that regard, I view it as a deserving film pastiche.The main divergence from the cold, occasionally misogynistic reasoner of Canon was the insertion of a love interest. I am not particularly enthusiastic about adding romantic elements, though if it had to be done, this was the way to go about it. Elisabeth, the niece of an eccentric inventor, Professor Waxflatter (portrayed, incidentally, by Nigel Stock, who may be remembered as Dr Watson beside both Douglas Wilmer/Peter Cushing in the 1960s BBC series), exudes such a radiance, and is an immensely likeable, competent female lead with absolutely nothing of the dreaded Mary-Sue about her.In fact, Elisabeth becomes less of a distraction to a good Holmes/Watson adventure, and more of a vital addition. What little we do see of the romance, however, quickly takes a back seat to the plot. And an enjoyable one it is, with secret Egyptian societies, a killer who strikes using a dart gun whose poison drives the victim to madness - very reminiscent of the era in general, with elements straight out of SIGN and DEVI.Overall,I was not bothered much by the alterations. Holmes retains his cleverness - as evidenced by some fairly good deductions - and Watson, his heart. In no way whatsoever did it seek to "reinvent" Holmes, so much of his character was recognizable enough. The sets and costumes were absolutely glorious, being richly evocative of the mid-Victorian era, making this movie an extremely underrated serious, if slightly darker, period piece. Young Sherlock Holmes may not rank up there with the best of them, but it at least deserves a spot as an above average attempt, and was actually quite good by its own rights. I was prepared not to care for it, but ended up falling for it by the end.As a side note, continue watching until the end credits have finished rolling for the bonus scene...

Before Mariah Mundi's parents go missing, his mother tasks him with keeping his brother safe, and entrusts both sons with the piece of an ancient Egyptian amulet. But he soon finds himself entangled in a quest for the fabled Midas Box when Felix, his younger brother, is kidnapped by the same organization that his parents have fallen afoul of. Help comes to him in the form of a man named Charity, who sets him up as a porter in the hotel where the villainous Otto Luger is keeping Felix, and where he learns the amulet may have a darker secret than he ever expected.The story unfolds quickly, and for a low(ish) budget, independently produced film, I was left impressed with how high the standard was set from the scripting to wardrobe. The Victorian costumes are lovely, the paltry use of CGI not one bit detrimental to the visuals. The plot was original, where unexpected developments abounded, and while technically a young adult movie, it was more than mature enough for any age to enjoy. It may not be the absolute best in the genre when compared to other period sci-fi/adventure films, yet this still held its own nicely.As a bonus, there was no standard Hollywood glorification of filth or depravity here - just a solid movie that provided me with a much needed steampunk fix.

While this book is set around two intriguing mysteries that did keep me reading when all the other elements either failed to snag my interest or made my blood pressure rise, I have not had the displeasure of reading such a dreadful piece of tripe in quite some time. I normally enjoy books that revolve around Holmes/Watson inspired characters, yet this one made me grateful the author scraped up enough decency to at least change the names.Colin Pendragon and his partner, Ethan Pruitt are called upon by Lady Arnifour to prove that the man Scotland Yard suspects of her husband's murder is innocent of the crime. Sensing more to the story than at first meets the eye, Colin agrees to take the case. In my estimation, the one redeeming factor of the entire book comes into play during the ensuing investigation, as Colin never strikes me as a Detective X sort, asking all the usual suspects the usual questions. Instead, there is a good mystery buried beneath all the detritus that comprised The Arnifour Affair, and many of his inferences, especially at the stable when he reads the tracks, are actually quite inspired. A second plotline also comes into play when a street urchin comes to Colin for help in finding his lost sister, although while not bad, I felt this was the weakest part of the story and did at times bog the plot down.My main issue here was the unrelenting coarseness of every single character which left me unable to sympathize or even like any of the players, including Pendragon and Pruitt. There was not simply a hostility between every person who interacted with one another, but an unaccountable brashness, crudeness and downright nastiness. Related to that was the author's blatant lack of respect - even dislike for - women that shines through with every female character he writes in. Without exception, Harris portrays ALL women as liars, backstabbers, whores, adulterers, general villains or braindead squealing airheads only interested in one thing.Certain scenes and dialogue, instead of coming off as edgy, as I suspect the author was aiming for, became nearly unreadable due to his wretchedly cynical presentation of humanity. His main characters are not exempt from this habit, as at one point, Pruitt wants to "backhand" a woman for no other crime than being overly flirtatious with Pendragon. I will leave it there, and let that speak for itself.Less grating on the nerves but no more acceptable were the historical inaccuracies and modern Americanisms which ran rampant through its pages. The text was littered with anachronisms, and a point which one investigation hinged on was based completely on a detail the author, during his no doubt extensive historical researches, failed to discover collapsed the entire plot - that is, there was no "illegal drug trade" in late 19th century England. Opiates and other narcotics were frowned upon around the turn of the century, but were still perfectly legal and available at any chemist. And a friendly note to Mr Harris: When writing British fiction, please DO look up modern slang terms as they pertain to the Other Side Of The Pond, because "tossed off" does NOT mean what you believe it does. I am also reasonably certain "ya must be starkers" was not in use during the reign of Queen Victoria.I will not even get started on the practically criminal overuse of what I suppose were meant to be character quirks. Suffice it to say, if I took a shot every time Colin flipped a coin between his fingers or shot someone a glance, I would need a liver transplant by the last chapter. Overall, I had the feeling this author wrote in the time period not for any great love of it, but to disparage it, and the social mores the Victorians lived by. So while there were some good and interesting parts, it failed miserably on all other accounts, and even the small potential it did show was overshadowed by its problems.

For as long as memory serves, this has been a controversial book in Holmesian circles, one which I was warned off reading many years ago, and since being informed of the blasphemies within, have avoided like the plague. I do not appreciate new "interpretations" of the Canon that play with the characters to such an extent as to make them consistently unrecognizable, but herein lies the crux of it. Dibdin is one of a scant few authors with the uncanny ability to summon the very essence of the Great Detective and his doctor - yet while I normally delight in such talent for penning an authentic Watsonian narrative, there was no such elation to be had in these pages. The tone throughout is bleak and somber, though knowing what was to come made it an emotionally difficult, oft times disturbing book to get through.The most unnerving part of it all is the way in which the Ripper clues are made to run parallel to what we know about Holmes, even several of his cases. Such was never more apparent as in the first 'Dear Boss' letter, which actually gave me chills when read in the context of the book. And it is not necessarily the nature of the explosive plot reveal that was so upsetting, but that the solid facts of both worlds were so eloquently intertwined. In short, this was in character and at least in the book's setting, was remotely plausible. That, I think, is what unsettled me so badly.Even at this juncture, I am unsure how to rate it. It was exceptionally well written. It was suspenseful, evoked the mood of the Ripper's Whitechapel district, and for the first half of the book, with the investigation still underway, was unquestionably the best Holmes vs. Ripper novel I have read to date. However, if you love Holmes, this is bound to be a profoundly affecting, disturbing book that tosses your emotions into the proverbial wringer. Admittedly, the ending had me in tears. I loved it, while utterly despising it at the same time, especially the way in which it ended. Even then, there is one last act by Holmes that makes you want to love it all over again... while still seething in boiling hot hatred.Needless to say, after coming to the end, I felt like I had been hit by a truck. It is not the sort of book one can really recommend, only advise other readers what it was and was not. For my own part, I only continued reading because the plot hinged on the final few pages of SIGN, where I can remember being very angry with Watson for so blithely overlooking that statement revealing the extent of Holmes' pain over his impending marriage. It is a point I have only ever seen touched on superficially, while the "what if's" are thoroughly rummaged through here. What I will state is that it is not a sensationalistic or trashy book intended to profit off Holmes, but be aware if you do decide to give it a chance, it *is* as profoundly disturbing as most Holmesians claim it to be.Dibdin is a genuine (if heretical) devotee of Sherlock Holmes, who is also very well versed in his 'Ripperology', though I think it is fair to say he has written something that has to be the product of the most pernicious plot idea to ever haunt an author. Certainly, it will haunt me for a long time to come.

At its heart, this was an imaginative novel, one that delved into a truly unique world woven into the very texture of the book, where villanous Steam Barons terrorize not only the citizens, but each other. I loved the creativity behind the world building, the color coded lights that identified each Barons territory, and found myself enjoying that aspect even though I am not normally a fan of magical realism. In my estimation, however, it was one of the best aspects therein, as I could not help but feel this fell short of its promise as a Holmes inspired mystery. Evelina is headstrong and fairly capable at investigative work, though in all honesty she did not inherit the lion's share of acumen from the Holmes side of her family. Then again, this is far more of a Victorian era urban fantasy than anything resembling a traditional mystery. I liked the character and found her to be sharp enough at times, in that she did make some capable deductions as to the meaning behind small clues left on the murder victim.That being said, what could truly have been an incredibly enjoyable journey through this vividly created alternate universe London was so fatally crippled by pacing problems that it did, at times, become a very frustrating read. The author has a tendency to describe at great length every thought and motion in excruciating detail, instead of condensing these to a brief summation. The reader does not need to have described for them every step a character makes, or know every thought and insecurity that flutter's through a character's head. Which brings me to another of my issues. The overuse of introspection and painfully overwriting every single scene was one problem, yet the self-doubt and constant stream of questions was quite another. It was amateurish, and unfortunately marred a book I otherwise liked.Because when the reader begins to strike through with imaginary red lines entire blocks (or pages, in some cases) of text, that is never a good sign.Literally, seventy-eight pages covered the events of one night, giving us in painstaking (and altogether unnecessary) detail the actions of every single main character. That translates to SIX entire chapters going through the motions and introspections of what Evelina, Tobias and Nick did during the time preceding and following the murder. And it was not just the tedium of reading through this that aggravated me, when the author uses all these extraneous scenes to do nothing but reveal little tidbits that could have come out over time with, you know, an actual investigation on the part of this supposed amateur detective. And instead of letting the suspense build, events just unfold over the course of the narrative, where Evelina is apparently in absentia for several chapters on end. Random, frequent POV changes are also not my favorite thing.A Study In Silks was, despite my quibbles, a promising start to this series and did contain enough enjoyable parts that I will not rule out taking a peek at the second novel. It did need a good editing and would have only benefited from the trimming of at least a good 100 pages. I think the main problem was that the author excelled more at the steampunk and magical realism elements, but had issues when she attempted to fit in the mystery elements. All in all, not a bad book by any stretch of the imagination, though one I would only recommend to die-hard fans of the genre.

I started out using Herptivite as an occasional treat for my extremely finicky land snails, just to ensure they were getting all the nutrients they needed after bouts of hibernation or when they decide to turn up their noses at a variety of foods. Even when eating well, I noticed an increase in activity on this supplement, but for my GALS, who require protein in their diet but are infamous for not cooperating when it comes to accepting anything beyond their favorite fruits and veggies, the results I have had with this are amazing.It contains a complete profile of amino acids, and is far superior to the ethoxyquin laced fish flakes most GALS owners recommend to meet protein requirements. Fed 2-3x weekly, Herptivite produces robust health in adults and hatchlings - who often outgrow their parents, and whose colour is strikingly richer than previous generations. There is undeniably a remarkable difference in health, size, weight and life span in those snails who are raised on this supplement.I have also found this to be an efficient way of getting nourishment into convalescing snails, and it has saved or prolonged the lives of many an ill mollusc or one who otherwise would have wasted away after laying eggs. Unlike the cheaper knock-off products sold in pet stores, Herptivite is completely natural, with no artificial coloring agents, flavors or preservatives, and is scientifically formulated to avoid both vitamin imbalance and overdose. I use this in conjunction with Rep-Cal in the pink bottle, and would not recommend any other supplement for herps - or snails.

A disremembered rarity that deserves more recognition if only for its bold divergence from early era horror films, 'The Drums of Jeopardy' holds up as a suspenseful thriller that seems to have creepiness down to a fine art. Dark and stormy nights, mad scientists, darkened mansions where phone lines have been cut by the villains, and long intervals of silence in the background soundtrack - all contribute to the atmosphere of gloom. The latter has been utilized to great effect, heightening the suspense as did the deliberate lack of sound in Hitchcock's earlier works, such as in the climax scene of 'Saboteur'.The quick-witted dialogue accentuates this swiftly moving thriller, where the ever menacing threat of Dr Boris Karlov (!), a Bolshevik (the communist party that caused such havoc in Russia) and something of a mad scientist who is spurned into murdering off an entire royal family when one "ruins" his daughter, who subsequently takes her own life in disgrace. Her lover, it appears, has gifted her a family heirloom necklace, referred to as the Drums of Jeopardy, which of course has the standard obligatory curse attached to it. Karlov vows vengeance against the Petrovs, returning a single piece of the necklace after each inventive murder.What follows is a political espionage meets your typical old dark house trope, with Karlov picking off each victim in his own dramatic fashion. Even the sinister characters are delightful (despite the glaring American accents) the twists and turns of plot deft and entertaining. An unusual film, but a cinematic treasure nonetheless.

If you can overlook the pithiness of this tale, you will not be disappointed in the substance of the actual story, wherein Wellington and Eliza are summoned to investigate a particularly peculiar haunting. What follows next was a charming bit of seasonal cheer, a nice little character study, and an ingenious twist on Dicken's much beloved classic. This was just an appetizer to hold one over until the next Ministry of Peculiar Occurrences installment, but a very satisfying one indeed, and was just what I needed to get into the holiday spirit... if three months early.

Having been unimpressed with the mostly lukewarm amalgamations of Sherlock Holmes pastiches set amidst a steampunk backdrop, I was initially skeptical going into this book. There have been no shortages of newly discovered Watsonian manuscripts unearthed from the vaults of Cox & Co. of late, though I have had the sneaking suspicion that most are merely clever forgeries. It is very seldom I can believe the doctor is responsible for the narration or that it is the convincing recounting of a lost case, but if for nothing else, I would rate this book highly for the sole reason that so far as pastiches go, this is definitely the genuine article. There are no paper thin caricatures here, Holmes' deductive process and methods while on a case feature prominently, the narration voice is suitably Victorian, and the science fiction elements were an integral part of the plot - not some weak addition in an attempt to widen the audience appeal.The story takes off quickly, with a bomb detonating in Waterloo Station as Watson is returning from visiting his convalescing wife in the country. Holmes, we soon learn, has been engaged by Mycroft to investigate what is the third in a series of such "terrorist" bombings, and here the story takes off, as he follows the trail of Baron Cauchemar, who is something of an urban legend in the East End. Holmes, however, is convinced The Black Baron is not a figment of the collective criminal imagination, and the ensuing investigation leads to wild chases through the London sewer (in which the doctor is not even the slightest bit amused), booby trapped rooms a'la Indiana Jones, technological gadgetry galore, an airship ride over London, and a race to save the monarchy from an overzealous villain. There was more action than one could shake a stick at, all while never slipping on the pacing or characterizations. In that regard, 'The Stuff of Nightmares' was well done, indeed. One of the best "rediscovered" Holmes stories I have read in a while, in fact.While the plot begins very well - and the concept behind it also had potential - it is riddled with holes. For instance, we never do learn how (or why) Holmes makes any association with the spate of bombings and Baron Cauchemar. I can believe that Holmes would reject the popular theory, but not that he would pluck some mythological figure of sorts out of the air with no solid reasoning behind it. As it turns out, the Baron is not the bomber, and Holmes knew this, but again, why Holmes even suspected a link between him and the bomber was never clearly stated.The plot also stumbles a bit towards the latter half. Parts of it were conceivable in the context of the story, others not so much. There were also an inordinate number of anachronisms, which was odd being that the author's writing style was so inherently Victorian. They did become infrequent somewhere around the halfway mark, much to my relief. Aside from that, in my opinion, this does outclass most recently published pastiches. The author was well suited to both genres, and this made for an exciting, pleasurable read - one I would have no qualms recommending to any Sherlockian.

When Gideon Smith's fisherman father is mysteriously killed at sea, his son vows to avenge the death, which he is convinced was not accidental. Intent on enlisting the assistance of his penny dreadful hero, Captain Lucian Trigger, he crosses paths with an aspiring author researching for his new novel - one Bram Stoker - who at first is more interested in the local reports of a large black dog that appears to be the only survivor of a shipwreck than Gideon's claims that monsters were responsible for the death of his father. It seems at first their interests are at cross purposes, but Gideon's monsters and Stoker's vampires turn out to be one in the same - though neither are what they appear to be. Several different story lines then come to the forefront, only to converge in the most unexpected ways, so what seemed like a hodgepodge of unrelated scenes and characters eventually blend seamlessly (and ingeniously) into one.We are thus introduced to an amusing array of fictional, historical and original characters alike - sky pirates, archaeologists, vampires, assorted adventurers, clockwork automatons, Jack the Ripper - and follow along almost rapturously as we are led through this richly described steampunk world. As each layer of the story is peeled back, Gideon uncovers government conspiracies, ancient Egyptian curses and mummies straight out of the pages of his favorite magazine, World Marvels and Wonders. And learns some disappointing truths about his hero, Captain Trigger, in the process.Blending elements of Victoriana, pulp fiction, sci-fi and mystery, Gideon Smith was a fantastically enjoyable and intricately plotted adventure set in an alternate universe London powered by gears and gadgetry. This elaborately contrived world, in fact, practically takes center stage, contributing as much to the story as do the actual characters, and was possibly one of the most imaginative renderings of a steampunk setting I've read to date. This would make for an excellent movie, one that I would actually spend the price of a ticket to see.I did have a few quibbles regarding the overuse of foul language - this may be an instance of the pot calling the kettle black, but I feel strongly that it should be kept out of literature with the exception that it might contribute to the story. Show, don't tell us with one expletive after the next, that the character is a boor. Also, frequent instances of modern turns of phrase did tend to jerk me out of the story.Minor nitpicks aside, I have not enjoyed a story this much in quite a while, and my technical rating would be 4.5 stars for the aforementioned nitpicks and some character development issues in the first few chapters. Overall, though, it reminded me of a Victorian Indiana Jones (with vampires... who do not sparkle) and if this is to be continued into a series, I would read the next one without reservation.

For anyone who is fond of classic high fantasy, 'Swept Up By The Sea' is a charming, character oriented (and extremely tongue-in-cheek) homage to the genre, and I think would best be enjoyed by those who either prefer or are willing to stray from the average YA fantasy novel. I certainly appreciated the deviation, and in spite of a few slow chapters here and there, found myself utterly enchanted by this book.Equal parts adventure, romance and a comedy of errors, the story follows Percival Taylor, who has been given some dubious advice by a gypsy fortune teller, as he seeks to become a pirate... an undertaking which is not so simple as it first appeared. He quite literally stumbles into the seafaring town of Blackshore, where he is unintentionally thrust into one adventure after the next - whether he likes it or not. Tuppence Magrathia-Paddock, who has indulged in a few too many romance novels and subsequently arranges for him to abduct her, while his betrothed, Vestia, has plans of her own to win him back.Awkward situations ensue, much to the reader's advantage. The wit sparkled, the characters are quirky, likable, memorable, and their stories all merge in a very unexpected but satisfying conclusion. I found myself setting it aside at intervals just to savour the story, and this is one of very few books I would unreservedly recommend for all ages. Though it is meant to be a light read, especially for the younger reader, there is much depth to be found within its pages.

*** THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SLIGHT SPOILERS ***Maybe I went into this with expectations set too high, but after an atmospheric and spine tingling opening that promised an exciting ride, it was clear by the end of the second chapter that the story was already beginning to deteriorate. It may have started out strongly, but 'Sherlock's Demon' lost a fair bit of its momentum along the way.After Joseph Hepworth's initial "attack" of what his wife refers to as possession by the "Sherlock Holmes Demon", we meet the team of Ghost Hunters, who are, every last one of them, as flat - and just about as compelling - as cardboard. One character blends right into the next; there was nothing to set them apart or make them interesting. In the one instance where a strong personality was required for the plot, Joseph's sister was deliberately made unlikeable, though even this came off as laughable. Her motives were thin as chiffon and the tweaks to the plot made when she enters the scene were eye-roll inducing. A great suspension of disbelief was required for me to continue reading once she entered onto the stage.The bare outline of this book was actually quite good, though most of the promising aspects were deflated as events progressed. We learn that Sherlock Holmes is a fictional character in this world, and that his spirit does not, in fact, possess the body of Joseph Hepworth. The actual explanation was one of those exasperating moments of the plot. Certain scenes were unnecessarily repetitive while others (primarily the climax, which actually had a clever idea behind it, but was infuriatingly anti-climactic) seemed rushed. The side plot surrounding Kit and Ashara was obviously and annoyingly contrived, their supposedly budding "relationship" so one-sided as to be a bit creepy.That aside, for a late night read, this was better than average, containing just enough original elements with a slight twist on the old 'haunted house built on unhallowed ground' trope to make me interested in a ghost story... which I usually hesitate to read. This was also mostly a page turner and Mr Clark's stories are always impressively atmospheric. He can give you the chills with a description. So definitely not his best work, yet a decent read all the same.

Despite numerous attempts to settle into this book, I had a difficult time appreciating what appeared to be an interesting story due to fundamental problems with flow, continuity and structure. The writing was actually quite fluent and beautiful, however there were issues, mainly with the pacing, that I simply could not overlook. From the opening scene, we are quite literally thrown into a choppy, confusing action sequence that should have started things on a high point, but instead, due to the utter lack of explanation as to precisely what was going on, I found the story difficult to follow. There were a few bits mentioning who Clare was fighting off, but only crumbs were dropped for the reader so that there was a perpetual question as to what was occurring in many of the fast moving scenes.This became a trend. Half the time I had trouble picturing what was going on when things picked up, and the other half was spent on entirely too much inward exposition - so that the general pace of `The Red Plague Affair' swung back and forth between choppy action scene to chapters of introspection. There was also a distinct lack of dialogue throughout, which made for tedious reading after a time.Unlike some other serialized novels, there was practically no real introduction here to this world, so if reading this without being familiar with the first book, you might find yourself out at sea in regards to back story. Unfortunate, because the bare bones of the premise intrigued me greatly, though I felt the main issue here was the execution of that idea was sorely lacking, and made this a largely dull novel that took a painfully long time to complete. In fact, back in June, I received this as an ARC from the publisher in exchange for an honest review, and am only just completing it now.

Great game made bigger! GIANT in fact. With 1" x 2" x 6" solid wood blocks--54 of them--in 18 levels to start, this game is the highlight of a party! But please don't have little children or pets around it, because when the tower falls it's like a tree falling, and it makes A LOT of noise. I'm thinking of setting up a classic (smaller) Jenga on top of this one :)

Worked to first and without ANY hassle, using Amazon Kindle Fire HD. This is a full-sized keyboard: i.e. easy to type on. It's LED lighted without waking up the person next to you, And be it a tablet or a phone it stands beautifully on the ridge above the keys. You can even program a single keyboard for up to 3 separate devices at once.

0:08 Mins Great toy to make a moving bug. What's even more interesting is the gear system it comes with. Connecting a gear to the motor and then connecting Push/Pull Spring Scales - 250g (2.5 N) - Blue about a centimeter from the center of the gear gave me a chance to demonstrate my seventh grade kid a way to measure the ability of the motor to rotate: torque. When we turned on the motor, the scale stopped the motor at 0.5 N. So the torque is 0.5 N-cm. Very small scale compared to, say Bugatti Veyron, which has an engine that has about 1,100 lb-ft torque. About 300,000 time more capable than our little electric motor, and just as much more expensive :)

There are two plastic stoppers for the zipper handle to shut off when when closing the bag on either end. I filled a bag with water and no drips, unless I squeeze the bag really hard--even then they are tiny drops. The seams where the rail is really well sealed. This is a beautifully designed butter holder, and helps keep it fresh and soft. One improvement I would suggest is to have clear lines scaled to Table spoons for the standard grocery butter stick.

Awesome hopscotch rug for ANY age! You may think it's too small for adults, but not really. The challenge is getting bean bags in the right square and even if your feet might be a little bigger than the squares you still have to hop around to finish all the squares. The player covering all the squares first wins. Needless to say my daughter is much better at this game, but I get my exercise, too!
Plot(s) are all over the place. Lacks coherence. I'd rather have Amazon spend its money on "Highston".
Very promising.It's about a young man, whose idols appear to him in his imagination. They are his friends and supporters. Perhaps one day he'll find the most important celebrity in his life--himself.

Update: Even though I received a message that the fax was sent successfully, I checked with the recipient and they had not received any fax. I re-sent fax using a Xerox fax copier and they did receive the fax.Seems to be working, and Microsoft fax software is pretty outdated. One thing I noticed is that if you enter the fax # in the canonical format: +1 (123)-456-7890 the fax seems to go through. All other number formats ended up in "error".

It's damn fast...BUT it comes formatted in Fat32!? Why? I would recommend you reformat it at as exFat for large files--large as in 4 GB and up. 32 bit is too small to handle sizes larger than 4 GB. So I'm taking a star off for that silly default format. Otherwise this is a great product.

The labels for pieces between the components and the manual don't match. For example, #207 (L/.R) are not there. Disengagement of rails is different from what the manual says. Good luck disconnecting them yourself--that's component #451.There are 150 pieces to put this thing together.No, I do not recommend this product.
Highly versatile magnifying glass with lights. This is an excellent design. I think I will buy another soon.

2.4 GHz wireless don't make corners too well and the signal weakens considerably depending on where you are in the house and where the router is. TRENDnet AC750 comes to the rescue to strengthen that weak signal. It comes with its own website once you plug it in and connect it to your home wi-fi. Then most of my devices directly connect to the TRENDnet and full-strength Internet connection. On top of that, I can take it anywhere in the world that doesn't use 110 volts. I occasionally go to Europe, where they use 240 volts.

From the dusty remnants of the Hejaz Railway in Syria, where Lawrence of Arabia turned a licorice storehouse into his digs, to the ashen bottom of the Ganges river, to the rags to riches stories of Sayyid in Cairo by collecting Egyptian trash, to the graffitied tunnels of New York Citys Pennsylvania Station, this book is a whirlwind of travel BETTER than actually traveling.

This product fulfills the #1 need for a good power-strip: You must be able to close the unused sockets. And this does with easy to use sliding safety covers. It can support devices up to 1800 Watts with 15 Amps. That's a lot of juice, I mean Joules.If you're not happy with the distance between the sockets, I'd recommend Etekcity 10-Pack Upgraded Power Extension Cord Cable Strip Outlet Saver, Lifetime Warranty, UL Listed, 16AWG/13A, 3-Prong, 1-Foot (Black) to fix that issue.

Probably made of titanium alloy, this outdoor-elements-proof cable runs 8 feet long and it is little over a quarter inch thick. I attached user instructions to give a good idea of how this cable can be used. I used it to comfortably lock up my bike including the frame and both wheels. The cable is little over a pound. Because it's so light I can easily carry it on the bike like a cowboy carries lasso on his horse. The key and the locking mechanism can be matched by a unique word labeled on both. Not only can you what the key is for, but if you have several of these you can easily match the key to the lock. One last thing, it has an exquisitely designed cover where the key goes, to prevent water to go into the lock.This is a great product and of great quality, which made me curious about the company that makes it. The company is Wordlock. It is a private company. They normally make combination locks using letters instead of numbers. They haven't done that with this particular lock because it is primarily designed for the outdoors. The word Wordlock was commercialized in 2004, 8 centuries after the Chinese had first invented it.I'll probably buy more of Wordlock locks in the future. If the company ever goes public, I'll buy some shares, too.

WOW...Haitham Alsarraf's new book starts off describing all of Middle East with just two words: Inshallah and Habibi. The first two paragraphs sets off the first peel of an onion that will reduce you to tears of laughter and thinking:--------------------"lnshallah, habibi."This is the reply I get in Arabic from my floor manager. I request a three-day vacation and all I get back is inshallah, habibi. Not just any inshallah, either. It is the third and most ridiculous one. One being the true religious term, God-willing, which is said with the most seriousness. The second means a careless and ambiguous maybe. This third one, though, is the most potent.It is the least sincere, given without direct eye contact, combed onto a nonchalant smirk and hand-gestured with dramatic, semi-pleading palms. It means there is no way in hell you will get what you request. It is just wishful thinking. Take your pathetic pleading somewhere else. Leave my sight.--------------------

What an amazing design! Not only can you open the valve with a spring-loaded button with one hand, but it also vacuum shuts the stainless steel container when releasing the button. Holds 2 cups of coffee or water or whatever.It's also dishwasher safe. One simply cannot ask for a better mug. Period.

This is a far more realistic "American Psycho". It is a phenomenal script and Oscar-worthy acting by Jake Gyllenhaal. Finally he settles on news sensationalism and owns the night in Los Angeles.

This pen write smoothly and clearly, but what makes it special isn't in its ink and delivery. It's also well balanced and feels good in the hand. Its rubber coating prevents slippage, and pocket clip is sprint-loaded--I've never seen this before. It doesn't depend on a plastic to bend, and this means it won't break any time soon.

These are gorgeous hand made glasses with sturdy thickness and smooth brim. It can hold about 12 US fl oz of liquid--so  4 of these each day. And the set comes conveniently with four. Drinking must have motivated writing a bill :)Great product!

Other than that this product is of the highest quality.I also found out I can buy more ClosetMaid accessories at the local Home Depot. I'll be buying another shelf.

This heavy beast of a computer weighs in 5.8 pounds. It feels heavy and bulky, but it is a powerhouse of a computer that boasts i5-5200U two-core processor, 8 GB memory, Intel HD graphics 5500. It's not a gaming machine, as I tried to test it with a few Steam games and noticed intermittent freezes. This could be due to the Intel graphics card. For gaming, a beefy desktop computer with a muscular Nvidia card still seems to rock. For everything else it's a pretty decent computer with responsive Windows 8.1, productivity tools, such as Microsoft Office, and even software development work. It also comes with a free offer of switching to Windows 10 when it becomes available.Security seems to be at the top of the list of this computer. You can't boot this computer with a USB stick, unless you specifically enable this feature through its setup by pressing F2 during boot up to disable the Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) and then pressing F12 to boot from a USB stick. After you're done with your USB stick to boot the computer with, I recommend you switch the UEFI back and boot from the main Operating System normally. Otherwise the computer misbehaves.Like I noticed the touchscreen may stop working. Anyway, this is not normal use and not really recommended. I was just testing.Its SD card reader is rather slow. It clocks at about 200 Megabits per seconds, which is an average USB 2.0 speed. But the USB ports, with the same SD card and a reader adapter, clocked reading speeds around 600 Megabits per seconds, which is more in line with the USB 3.0 spec. The USB ports are black in color, as opposed to blue you might see with USB 3.0. In any case, the USB ports are 3.0.External speaker of this machine...forget about it. It's horrible. That's the one reason I'm taking a star off from this product. Otherwise it's a good machine.

This is better than the corded version of the same concept: bone conduction. These support two criticial Bluetooth technologies: Advanced Audio Distribution Profile (A2DP) and Hands-Free Profile (HFP), which works on most Bluetooth 2.0 technologies found with newer, as well as older phones.Its microphone is superb, someone who calls you will hear you with crystal clarity. But hearing them is another matter. It's not impossibly bad, you can hear the other person, but in a muted sort of way unless you can put the end right over your ear, which would beat the purpose of this kind of technology. You'd also have to be in a very quiet place to really hear well; like a library. Any ambient noise, such as a relatively quiet fan will make it really difficult to hear.It does fit nicely as designed, and there's some amplification thanks to a re-chargeable AAA battery inserted in a well-designed compartment. It also comes with a fantastic USB charger for both AA and AAA batteries. You can charge two at a time, but you'll need only one for the headset.

If I were less hungry I might give this bag of chips less than five stars, but I had just walked over two miles to watch the fireworks in Rochester, New York. So they tasted great.Kale is a vegetable. There seems to be a continuing debate about nutritious effectiveness of food cooked or raw. Especially when it comes to vegetables. Kale Chips' is somewhere in between: they're air-crisped under low heat. This probably prevents the enzyme myrosinase getting damaged. Myrosinase helps break down compounds derived from glucose and amino acid. Breaking down glucose is a good thing.The fundamentals of Kale Chips are sound. 7g of non-trans fat per serving Zero cholesterol. 220mg of sodium. 13g of carbs, but only 3g of which is sugar. There are also 6g of protein. In other words a complete snack-meal  in a bag. It is nutritious and healthy. It packs 140 calories. To really appreciate it get yourself a little tired.

Just 10 turns with the handle provides half hour to power a flashlight and a radio. That's how efficient the dynamo in this beautifully designed device. It provides a USB and MicroUSB port to charge it or to charge other devices with it. Now here's the real doozie: leaving its solar panels under the sun for just 10 seconds is equivalent to the 10 turns I mentioned earlier.

I love it! Not only does one of these sheets cling on window, but also on a drywall. Two place I tried. It stays on at least two days--that's how long I tested. You can take it from one area to another and still clings on! I can write on it with erasable markers, take a digital picture of it, and erase and write again, and again.Multiple sheets allows for a complete brainstorming session with my team for hours. This is the single greatest invention since the whiteboard. Very highly recommended!
The smell itself is refreshing. I don't think it's different from any other soap--that I can notice.
I love the smell of orange in this lotion. It makes it refreshing even if there is nothing wrong with the skin.

What differentiates this lotion from daily moisture is the north Brazilian tapioca starch and olive oil, as opposed to eucalyptus. A few other ingredients such as panthenol and cetearyl promote the effectiveness of this lotion to reduce itching.
Loved it! I think this movie is actually better than even the 6th Sense, for which Haley Joel Osment is best known for.

Loved it. I also heard rumors that the contents of the book is still under litigation.In any case, it is a well written book about you girl born to one of the richest families in the world, the Duke family. The same family better known today for their namesake institution, the Duke University, then the American Tobacco company. The girl is Doris Duke, who grew up sheltered from most rituals of life in general, such as going to school or having a career. Her father, Buck Duke, ensured the wealth of her daughter by betting on the United States early 20th century, which is now known as the American Century. Buying treasury bonds, hedged with tons of gold in safes around the world, Miss Duke was forever banished into being too rich. What she witnesses with people around her and with herself are some of the ugliest extremes of the human nature. The lesson learned here is this: very rich people shouldn't give all their wealth to anyone who doesn't know how to earn it in the first place. The story makes the strongest possible point in the validity of foundations such as The Giving Pledge, founded by Bill Gates and Warren Buffett.

I have had the Paperwhite for a while now. It's beautifully lighted and easy to read with especially at night without waking up my wife.But what motivated me to write this review now is that I was on vacation recently and as I moved from sunny areas to shaded areas the clarity of the text did not change because of the outstanding lighting technology used. This is really a big plus.
There is a little loop inside the edge of this beautifully hand knit basket. I use it to hang it on the knob of my nightstand and that's where all the remote controllers go. Great product!

This is my favorite kind of lotion because it has one very special ingredient: cetyl alcohol. It gets its name from "cetus", which means whale in Latin. It was first discovered in whale oil back in the early 1800s. Cetyl helps thicken the lotion. It's also used to lubricate nuts and bolts.

It comes with a folded map of Paris, and calendar of what happens in Paris each month, which can be very useful depending on when you're going. The book is full of useful information.Here's how you can really use this book. Find a place that might strike your fancy--for example, Saint-Chapelle. Then open up Google Earth using Nvidia 3D Vision and go to the address given in this book: "8 bd du Palais" and check out the spectacular view of "Paris' most exquisite Gothic monument." This is so much fun, you may not even find the need to actually go to Paris! But you'll need a good guide, such as this book. Enjoy!
